webTitle: Brown to signal tax cuts for poor

fields.headline: Brown to signal tax cuts for poor
fields.standfirst: Labour's heartland to get help in pre-election budget as confident chancellor aims for second term
fields.trailText: Labour's heartland to get help in pre-election budget as confident chancellor aims for second term.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today hold out the prospect of a series of pre-election tax cuts targeted at Labour's heartland supporters as he lays the basis for a record second full term.

Abandoning the traditional pre-budget "purdah", the chancellor makes clear that he is determined to bring down taxes to help families struggling with children and to boost investment in Britain's inner cities.

In a speech to a Fabian Society conference in London, sponsored by the Guardian, Mr Brown will reassure grassroots supporters by saying that he is determined to spend more and never to embark on the sort of "indiscriminate" Tory tax cuts of the late 1980s which led to boom and bust.

"We need both targeted tax cuts and spending increases as engines of opportunity for families," the chancellor will say. "We need tax cuts or credits and public investment together as the engine of opportunity and prosperity."

The chancellor will then list the previous tax cuts he has aimed at the less well off. These include the working families tax credit and the new 10p tax rate.

The chancellor's speech, which was billed last night by his aides as an ambitious attempt to set out his vision for a second term, demonstrates Mr Brown's confidence after his success in restoring Labour's reputation for economic prudence. During the last election Labour was paranoid about talking of spending increases, insisting that the party would stick to Tory spending limits for its first two years in office.

With the economy in a buoyant state, Mr Brown indicates today that he has no qualms about talking of spending rises and an important role for what he calls the "enabling state".

Mr Brown will say: "For us, equality of opportunity cannot be achieved by markets alone, however dynamic; by individuals alone, however enterprising; or by voluntary organisations alone, however close to the community. But nor can it be achieved by government alone. It is the duty of the state to provide the framework and the finance to make opportunity possible. It is the role of the private and voluntary sector and not just government to deliver these opportunities."

Mr Brown's speech comes as his position has been strengthened as never before after the resignation of his foe, Peter Mandelson. However, both Mr Brown's aides and his detractors denied reports yesterday that the chancellor is using the departure of the arch pro-European Mr Mandelson to stiffen a series tests Britain will have to meet before the government holds a referendum on the euro.

At the same conference, education secretary David Blunkett will call on Labour to lift its vision beyond arguments over income inequality towards creating a "civil society" for all.

He will argue that parties in office had to review and refresh their thinking continually, and recognise that ideas matter profoundly.

Mr Blunkett will emphasise the importance of equipping people with skills and education to create thriving, moral communities. The party's "key challenges" were to "ensure that all have good skills and jobs, that opportunities through lifelong learning and quality of life are shared across the society, and that people are equipped and engaged as citizens shaping their future".

Mr Blunkett will argue: "Too often the centre left has focused on income distribution as the measure of its success or failure without looking behind the statistics as to the real cause of inequality - inequality of skills, education, jobs and assets that people hold.

"We need to look beyond income to determine how more just our society has and can become."

Rewriting the old clause 4 of Labour's constitution, which emphasised common ownership, had helped it to address quality of life issues. Labour had to help people build "reservoirs of social capital".

"In the past the centre left allowed its concern with physical and social conditions to obscure a commitment to social morality and the importance of civil virtues and civil society." But that was changing. The party was addressing people's concerns as individuals and citizens, whether in talking about crime, anti-social behaviour, welfare or education.

fields.headline: Fowler faces trial by firepower
fields.standfirst: The striker who had it all and threw most of it away has another shot at redemption today. By  Ian Ross :   The highs and lows of a player who had the world at his feet
fields.trailText: Salutary tales are 10 a penny in football but there is still a certain piquancy to the one which maps out the rise and fall of Robbie Fowler. The Liverpool striker is facing the most crucial period of a once brilliant career that has lurched recently from crisis to crisis.
fields.body:
Salutary tales are 10 a penny in football but there is still a certain piquancy to the one which maps out the rise and fall of Robbie Fowler. The Liverpool striker is facing the most crucial period of a once brilliant career that has lurched recently from crisis to crisis.

Brief respite from the rumours and intrigue was provided by Wednesday's Worthington Cup semi-final against Crystal Palace in which the Fowler of old fleetingly emerged, but Leeds United will hope to prove in today's FA Cup fourth-round tie at Elland Road that what was unquestionably his finest single performance in years was a one-off.

Two seasons ravaged by ankle and knee troubles have lessened his effectiveness to such an extent that it is still conceivable that his manager Gérard Houllier will sanction his departure come season's end, with Chelsea and Rangers possible destinations. In essence, one of English football's most gifted, most natural footballers will spend the next four months on trial. If he can become the main man on the pitch and the invisible man away from it, he may yet put his troubles behind him.

That his seemingly inevitable transformation from local hero to world star has been savagely interrupted by unfortunate injuries is not open to debate, but at least five summers ago a Merseyside public which had come to marvel at the young striker's prodigious talent was first warned that, where Fowler was concerned, though you could take the boy out of Toxteth you would never be able to take Toxteth out of the boy.

At the time it seemed little more than a neat, smart-arse quip. However, though the sage responsible has long been forgotten, his words are arguably more potent and more relevant today. It is hardly surprising that Fowler is struggling to score goals for, despite being only 25, he has spent so much time walking towards crossroads, watersheds, defining moments and points of no return that his feet must be blistered and sore.

The less sympathetic might also suggest that he has spent so long supping in the last-chance saloon that he is too often found to be tired and emotional - usually in the wee small hours. To suggest that he has developed the unfortunate habit of being in the wrong place at the wrong time would be to understate matters. Liverpool has become a city of bars and 24/7 revelry; its vibrancy is addictive and those supportive of Fowler argue that he is doing no more than falling prey to the temptations of youth and so deserves not wholesale condemnation and abuse but patience and understanding.

"I honestly believe he has been so unlucky in his personal life," says Fowler's most illustrious former strike partner Ian Rush. "It's not as though he's out roaming the streets with a gang of lads. On the last occasion he was attacked he was out with his wife - something we all do. I don't believe he is a marked man in Liverpool; he's growing up now, he's happily married and has two young children. Different people mature at different rates.

"On the playing front he has struggled for so long with injuries; now he's struggling to adapt to a squad rotation system, an alien system to players like him and Michael Owen. He'll make it back to what he was, I'm sure of that. Why? Well, because he's one of the finest forwards we have ever seen in this country."

Jan Molby, the former Anfield midfielder and now Kidderminster's man ager, strikes a more cautious note. "There always comes a point in life where we have to deliver on our promise. Robbie has done so much for Liverpool but he now finds himself in a situation where he must prove himself all over again.

"He doesn't necessarily have to prove himself to the fans but to the manager. I believe in him and so do the fans, but it is results which matter to a manager. The rumours about his future have been going around for more than a year now and the only thing he can do is to put Gérard Houllier in a position where he could not even consider selling him."

Those who really know Fowler invari ably speak in almost reverential tones about his love of Liverpool the city, Liverpool the club, his wife and his two young kids. Of course, the postscript is always that he is simply misunderstood and seeks nothing more than a shed-load of goals while working and the quiet life when off duty. In short, though friends, apologists, call them what you may, acknowledge he is hardly angel material, they see him as a non-malevolent free spirit.

Many players have chosen to walk on the wild side but they were invariably the game's mavericks - players such as George Best, Stan Bowles, Alan Hudson, Rodney Marsh and Eric Cantona. Fowler is more tenderfoot than maverick, the Peter Pan of Anfield who is reluctant to grow up and now faces the very real prospect of being classified as one of English football's most celebrated lost boys. There is genuine fear within his club that at 25 his best days may already be available on video cassettes in the Anfield souvenir shop.

As even the most dedicated of his tormentors would concede, Fowler is undemonstrative, polite and self-effacing when in company and one can only conclude it is the unsuppressible childish streak within him which tends to land him in bother. And there has been plenty of that these past couple of seasons: two late-night assaults on him in bars, sendings-off, suspensions, fines, dressing-downs, warnings, threats, ultimatums.

The footballing fraternity is still prone to throwing a comfort blanket around his shoulders when invited to discuss an apparent obsession with self-destruction. That, perhaps, is understandable, for amid all the tales of dark deeds it is easy to forget what a truly brilliant footballer he can be.

"He is one of the best strikers I have ever seen," says the former Liverpool manager and striker Kenny Dalglish. "He's certainly one of the most intelligent in footballing terms. He was only 15 or 16 when we were together at Liverpool but he used to come and train with the first team and you could see that he had something very special. You don't lose that sort of thing."

Dalglish is not usually wrong. Indeed, he prides himself on an ability to have the last, telling word. He may well be proved right again, but for now at least the doubts linger.

1993 Makes league debut in September. Later scores five goals for Liverpool against Fulham.

1994 Fined £1,000 for baring backside at Leicester City fans.

1995 Scores 31 goals and is voted the PFA's young player of the year.

1996 England debut In March and later voted PFA young player of the year again, after scoring 35 goals in 53 games.

1997 Praised for sportsmanship when he tries to persuade referee Gerald Ashby not to award a penalty against Arsenal's David Seaman.

1997 Fined £900 after lifting his shirt to display a vest in support of striking Liverpool dockers.

1998 Injures knee in February and misses rest of the season and World Cup.

1999 Charged with misconduct after making insulting gestures towards Graeme le Saux (left).

1999 Two months later fined £32,000 and banned for six matches after pretending to snort the white line of the six-yard box in a clear reference to drug-taking (below).

2000 Attacked in the toilets of a Liverpool hotel.

2000 Chelsea's bid of £12m is rejected after he insists he wishes to remain at Anfield.

2001 Assaulted in the early hours while out in Liverpool with his wife.

2001 Aston Villa become the second Premiership club to lodge a bid of £12m but he reiterates his desire to remain on Merseyside.

fields.headline: Best travel company winner
fields.standfirst: Laskarina
fields.trailText: Laskarina
fields.body:
Let's be honest, I knew the Derbyshire-based independent Laskarina had been voted best travel company in the Guardian/Observer travel awards for five consecutive years when I booked a one-week holiday for my friend and I on Leros. It wasn't even the first time that I had used the firm, my partner and I having booked a house on Alonissos through them the previous year.

So I felt more than a little guilty at taking all the credit when the trip turned out to be everything we had been hoping for: a no-hassle, restful break.

If you want to escape from the crowds, a trawl through the Laskarina brochure will take you to places you've probably never heard of, let alone considered going to. If you don't like organised activities and overbearing reps, you will be relieved to find that the Laskarina reps are on call but keep a low profile.

Some of the bigger travel companies go to the same places, but with Laskarina you can chat on the phone to the sales reps for ages, the brochure has a warts-and-all pitch, and the pricing is clear - there's no rooting around in the small print for surcharges.

Best of all is the accommodation. Having booked my holiday to Leros at the last minute, I had a certain trepidation, as my choice had been somewhat limited. But the apartment - set in a hillside, castle-like folly with beautiful gardens - was spacious and tastefully decorated in the traditional style. On Alonissos, it had been even better - a charmingly restored house in the old town, with a corner-style Greek fireplace and antique furniture.

Whether you plump for a classical villa, traditional house or one of the more quirky options, you're likely to have a fantastic view because Laskarina is big on balconies.

Transportation to your property is arranged, usually by taxi. You are warned in advance that you might have to carry your luggage to your door if your accommodation is not roadside. But it is likely to be a short distance. In fact, the only real difficulty with Laskarina is settling on which island to go to next time. See you on Symi?

A brochure from Laskarina Holidays can be ordered on 01629 822 203 (www.laskarina.co.uk).

fields.headline: The pursuit of leisure
fields.standfirst: There are enough Greek myths, monuments and islands to keep both historians and hedonists busy for a lifetime. Libby Brooks composes an ode to idleness on Kalymnos
fields.trailText: There are enough Greek myths, monuments and islands to keep both historians and hedonists busy for a lifetime. Libby Brooks composes an ode to idleness on Kalymnos
fields.body:
The Ancient Greeks had some fine ideas about leisure. It was Aristotle who insisted on the psychic importance of setting aside time to pursue arete and eudaimonia - cultivation and happiness. Unfortunately, this was contingent upon the existence of slaves to wrestle with the dreary details of daily existence, but nobody's perfect.

By the middle of last summer, my best friend Sophie and I had had our naturally glass-half-full dispositions sorely tested by a catalogue of unlucky and unsolicited happenings. August bowled in with neither the promise of a change in the weather nor in our fortunes, All Saints were in the charts with the single Pure Shores, and their insistent "Take me to the be-ee-each" resonated in our eardrums. And so, in need of leisure, in need of time, we found ourselves on a rickety bus, thighs sweat-sealed to the hot plastic seats, heading for Emborios, the northern-most village of the Greek island of Kalymnos.

Presented with two family-free twentysomethings, the airport rep furrowed her brow when we walked off the plane on the neighbouring island of Kos."There's not much to do there, girls," she said fretfully. But that, of course, was precisely the point.

As we scooted past the steak-and-chops cafés and cramped beaches of the tourist haven of Kos, we smiled benignly. On the open top deck of the ferry to Pothia, the Kalymnian port capital, the warm wind whipped around us like a cobweb cleaner. And when the bus finally deposited us on the dusty beachside track at Emborios, we knew the good life had arrived.

Too often these days, holidays become a competition - the wierdest, the furthest, the most dangerous, the most culturally enriching. As we work longer hours in increasingly insecure scenarios, "I don't have time" has become both a necessary mantra and a cultural identifier. Our contract terms may be unstable, but our lack of minutes provides us with the sense of importance we crave. And consequently, with leisure time, if we allow ourselves any at all, we are embarrassed by any form of relaxation that is not stifled by activity, that is not proving its and our, worth. As depression rates rise like steam, we become proportionately less versed in the simple pleasures of life. Yet we ache to stretch out on the sand in the sunshine.

But Sophie and I had no such qualms. We'd earned our rest. As we hauled our bags along the pebbly upper shore towards our apartment, it was obvious that we had found Our Beach and, thankfully, one without a populous of experience-rich backpackers to bore us senseless.

The George Apartments are named after their owner, a sharp-eyed barrel of a man who brings us peaches. The building contains six apartments in all, each with ample kitchen, wide balcony and cool tiling. Inside and out, they are painted that particular Mediterranean white that radiates sunshine during the day and, even in the pitch black of night, emits a blue glow that seems to hang in the air around the stone.

The building hunches to the right of the dark sand beach, bounded by tamarisk trees. Our balcony looks across Arginondas bay to the islets of Telendos and Kalavros, which acquire a variety of hues from pink to purplish depending on the hour of the day and the angle of the sun. A volcanic island made up of three ridges, split by two fertile valleys, Kalymnos' northern range begins to our left. The mountains dip their toes in the sea. One looks like a skull in the early morning light.

We make our way to the beach forthwith, but are waylaid by Bob from Portsmouth. He arrived a few days ago with his wife, the beatific Mrs Bob, to manage the apartments for George after selling up his newsagent's business back home. This is the beginning of their retirement plan.

Bob didn't like the climate in England. "I know," Sophie responds sympathetically, "it's been a terrible summer." No, he replies stoutly, the social climate. We nod knowingly and shake out our beach towels. Every morning, George and Bob can be found sitting on the terrace, bonding in their shorts. George's chest is brown and forested with glossy dark hair. Bob's similar expanse is turning a ripe red. Mrs Bob, who prefers to stay out of the sun, makes tea. She shares with us her discovery that one of the local loaves can be sliced lengthways "so it's just like toast".

And so the days develop a rhythm of their own: breakfast on the balcony, swimming and sunning through the day, an ouzo at sunset then a stroll in the musky evening air to one of the four or five tavernas dotted through the village.

We buy huge bright tomatoes and sweet peaches from the fruit and veg van that drives through the village once a day. The local shop sells slabs of tart feta and olive oil in dusty bottles. And for dinner, we pick a fresh fish from the rack to have grilled with garlic and herbs. We commit only one culinary faux pas after brazenly ordering octopus, which I have to hide beneath my chips. Try as I might to get along with seafood in all its forms, I am consistently confounded by octopus. It is the rubbery flesh, and those unapologetic suckers that flummox me.

But mostly, we talk. Our conversation ambles along tangents, up spiral staircases, and into cul-de-sacs in a way that would be impossible elsewhere. We explore thoughts to their logical, and sometimes illogical, conclusions: if it's possible to burn through the clouds, whether the large ants sting. Somehow, different subjects come to be discussed in different places: the balcony for politics, the beach for jokes, the dinner table for sexual and family matters, the sea for secrets. One time, during sea-talk, I tell Sophie a nugget that makes her shriek for the rest of the day. This place is heavenly.

Our rep is called Susan. She is kind to us once she realises that we are making our own fun, and are not desperate for directions to the nearest disco. Her company, Direct Greece, caters for genuine Greek-o-philes, she tells us. We feel suitably privileged.

K alymnos is one of the 18 islands, also including Kos and Rhodes, that make up the Dodecanese, the furthest Greek island group from the mainland. Beading the throat of the west coast of Turkey, these islands have had a turbulent history, enduring centuries of occupation by Crusaders, Ottomans and Italians, and were only finally included in the modern Greek state in 1948.

Most of the population of Kalymnos lives in or around Pothia. Built into the southern valley, the back streets wind and duck, offering a maze of brightly-coloured Italianate houses. The practicals

Direct Greece (0870 5168683) offers a wide range of packages to Kalymnos. Return day flights are available from London Gatwick, Manchester, Glasgow and Newcastle. A seven-day stay for two at the George Apartments between May and September costs £419pp.
fields.bodyText: The Ancient Greeks had some fine ideas about leisure. It was Aristotle who insisted on the psychic importance of setting aside time to pursue arete and eudaimonia - cultivation and happiness. Unfortunately, this was contingent upon the existence of slaves to wrestle with the dreary details of daily existence, but nobody's perfect. By the middle of last summer, my best friend Sophie and I had had our naturally glass-half-full dispositions sorely tested by a catalogue of unlucky and unsolicited happenings. August bowled in with neither the promise of a change in the weather nor in our fortunes, All Saints were in the charts with the single Pure Shores, and their insistent "Take me to the be-ee-each" resonated in our eardrums. And so, in need of leisure, in need of time, we found ourselves on a rickety bus, thighs sweat-sealed to the hot plastic seats, heading for Emborios, the northern-most village of the Greek island of Kalymnos. Presented with two family-free twentysomethings, the airport rep furrowed her brow when we walked off the plane on the neighbouring island of Kos."There's not much to do there, girls," she said fretfully. But that, of course, was precisely the point. As we scooted past the steak-and-chops cafés and cramped beaches of the tourist haven of Kos, we smiled benignly. On the open top deck of the ferry to Pothia, the Kalymnian port capital, the warm wind whipped around us like a cobweb cleaner. And when the bus finally deposited us on the dusty beachside track at Emborios, we knew the good life had arrived. Too often these days, holidays become a competition - the wierdest, the furthest, the most dangerous, the most culturally enriching. As we work longer hours in increasingly insecure scenarios, "I don't have time" has become both a necessary mantra and a cultural identifier. Our contract terms may be unstable, but our lack of minutes provides us with the sense of importance we crave. And consequently, with leisure time, if we allow ourselves any at all, we are embarrassed by any form of relaxation that is not stifled by activity, that is not proving its and our, worth. As depression rates rise like steam, we become proportionately less versed in the simple pleasures of life. Yet we ache to stretch out on the sand in the sunshine. But Sophie and I had no such qualms. We'd earned our rest. As we hauled our bags along the pebbly upper shore towards our apartment, it was obvious that we had found Our Beach and, thankfully, one without a populous of experience-rich backpackers to bore us senseless. The George Apartments are named after their owner, a sharp-eyed barrel of a man who brings us peaches. The building contains six apartments in all, each with ample kitchen, wide balcony and cool tiling. Inside and out, they are painted that particular Mediterranean white that radiates sunshine during the day and, even in the pitch black of night, emits a blue glow that seems to hang in the air around the stone. The building hunches to the right of the dark sand beach, bounded by tamarisk trees. Our balcony looks across Arginondas bay to the islets of Telendos and Kalavros, which acquire a variety of hues from pink to purplish depending on the hour of the day and the angle of the sun. A volcanic island made up of three ridges, split by two fertile valleys, Kalymnos' northern range begins to our left. The mountains dip their toes in the sea. One looks like a skull in the early morning light. We make our way to the beach forthwith, but are waylaid by Bob from Portsmouth. He arrived a few days ago with his wife, the beatific Mrs Bob, to manage the apartments for George after selling up his newsagent's business back home. This is the beginning of their retirement plan. Bob didn't like the climate in England. "I know," Sophie responds sympathetically, "it's been a terrible summer." No, he replies stoutly, the social climate. We nod knowingly and shake out our beach towels. Every morning, George and Bob can be found sitting on the terrace, bonding in their shorts. George's chest is brown and forested with glossy dark hair. Bob's similar expanse is turning a ripe red. Mrs Bob, who prefers to stay out of the sun, makes tea. She shares with us her discovery that one of the local loaves can be sliced lengthways "so it's just like toast". And so the days develop a rhythm of their own: breakfast on the balcony, swimming and sunning through the day, an ouzo at sunset then a stroll in the musky evening air to one of the four or five tavernas dotted through the village. We buy huge bright tomatoes and sweet peaches from the fruit and veg van that drives through the village once a day. The local shop sells slabs of tart feta and olive oil in dusty bottles. And for dinner, we pick a fresh fish from the rack to have grilled with garlic and herbs. We commit only one culinary faux pas after brazenly ordering octopus, which I have to hide beneath my chips. Try as I might to get along with seafood in all its forms, I am consistently confounded by octopus. It is the rubbery flesh, and those unapologetic suckers that flummox me. But mostly, we talk. Our conversation ambles along tangents, up spiral staircases, and into cul-de-sacs in a way that would be impossible elsewhere. fields.headline: Booby prize
fields.standfirst: The Galapagos Islands are under threat from an oil spill.  Neil Robinson visited last year and reports on the wildlife that draws 60,000 visitors a year
fields.trailText: The Galapagos Islands are under threat from an oil spill. Neil Robinson visited last year and reports on the wildlife that draws 60,000 visitors a year
fields.body:
Apart from the name, what really set me against twitching as a hobby was the thought of standing all day in a field with a bush on my head and only seeing a magpie for my troubles. All that effort and embarrassment for what exactly? Call me cynical, but it never seemed to offer the casual enthusiast proper guarantees of reward because you can never ensure that the birds will agree to the deal. No, what I needed to really share the passion was to find a place where the birds packed the skies with their presence, demanding to be noticed, and where I didn't need to wear a puff-sleeved anorak.

So it is with a degree of triumph and embarrassment that I can report that this unlikely synthesis was achieved while lounging in a hot tub, gin and tonic in hand, on the top deck of a cruise ship somewhere in the Pacific. We were still several miles off the Galapagos Islands and yet there they were, a dozen strange-winged creatures soaring and swooping in silhouette against the early-morning sky. As a taster of one of the most unsullied bird havens in the world, it was remarkable; and I began to understand what all the fuss is about. This was Luxury Twitching, and it has a charm all of its own.

To see this sight, it took Charles Darwin, with whom the archipelago will always be associated, four years on The Beagle, frequent bouts of sea-sickness and endless disputes with a quarrelsome captain. It took me a couple of days out of London, a form of evolution for which I am eternally grateful. The islands are now a fully-accessible tourist destination, offering a five-star entry ticket into Birdville.

A few more minutes and the skies were alive with crackling energy as blue-footed boobies dive-bombed for fish from 50 m, disappearing into the turquoise sea with pinpoint precision before emerging seconds later like underwater missiles bursting through the air. Once on land, an unofficial greeting party of mocking birds, curious and welcoming, hopped and skipped among us while multi-coloured finches hovered over the burnt-brown bushes.

Darwin, who identified 13 different types of finch on the islands, is never far away from the thoughts of modern visitors, who in a weird way recreate their own updated version of The Origin of Species. These are the most highly-developed tourists around, completely unafraid to set foot on their new surroundings and beautifully adapted to the rigours of luxury travel. Within minutes of stretching out on the bleached white sand of San Cristobal, we resembled the big barrels of blubbery sea lions who sprawl around the place like they own it.

Each year, around 60,000 people travel to the islands, drawn by their mix of isolation and abundant wildlife. Situated 600 miles west of Ecuador, they have become one of the most tightly controlled tourist zones in the world, and the talk is of cutting numbers rather than increasing them, an interesting reversal of every known travel trend.

For understandable conservation reasons, independent travel is frowned upon so tourists are bundled up on boats and carefully shepherded around the 13 islands which are strung out over 60,000 square miles of the Pacific. Although settlement has never been encouraged, the larger islands are now inhabited in a reasonably unobtrusive sort of way. The smaller ones, no more than strands of volcanic rock jutting out of the water, have been left to the wildlife. There is nothing else to see, but it is enough. Imagine going on safari by cruise ship and you'll get the general idea. Companies offer three-, four- or seven-day island-hopping trips which, if booked via British operators, are combined with further time spent on the mainland.

Almost everyone onboard is transformed into a wildlife enthusiast, thumbing through guidebooks as if they are pot-boiler novels. There is no escaping this process because almost every species on the islands demands attention. I found myself arriving with a headful of thoughts and leaving with a headful of knowledge, dumbstruck by the details of everyday bird life.

While the onboard regime tends towards the militaristic with early-morning wake-ups, group check-ins and lectures of variable quality, you are offered a reasonable degree of freedom to mooch around on shore. However, failure to stick to the routes, marked out with black-and-white posts, does not go down well with the guides, who regard it as an offence akin to seal-culling.

The age-span on our ship ranged from seven to 65, although this kind of holiday tends to attract more elderly tourists. Hikes on shore are gentle affairs, with little climbing and much meandering. Groups tend to be limited to 20-30 at a time, which felt about right, with three-hour trips on land morning and afternoon. They are interspersed with copious amounts of food - good rather than excellent - onboard, where downtime was spent relaxing rather than partying.

Each island has its own charm and distinctive wildlife variations. My favourite was Tower, a horseshoe-shaped outcrop to the north of the chain. It is a fantastically bleak place, built from jet-black boulders and covered with sparse vegetation. In summer, the many-tentacled incense trees perfume the air with the richest aroma. Here, red-footed boobies with bright-blue beaks cling to the trees like bolt-on extras and albatrosses circle overhead in a scene straight out of Hitchcock. These birds are not tame, but as they have no predators as adults they harbour no fear, inspecting intruders with regal disdain.

Equally lofty are the marine iguanas, which are unique to the islands. Originally land reptiles, they evolved over a couple of million years into creatures able to stay underwater for up to an hour. Scour the sea and you will spot them bobbing up and down like pieces of darkest driftwood waiting to be tossed on to the rocks for a breather. On land, they spit the salt from their nostrils while perching unnoticed on the rocks, moving their exquisitely webbed feet with tiny steady-as-you-go steps.

For history, Floreana has the edge, largely because of its reputation as a lost paradise. A group of Europeans, including a disciple of Nietzsche and a sex-mad baroness with three lovers, made this their home in the 1930s, becoming a cause célèbre when murder and shipwreck destroyed their tiny colony. The inhabited islands hold other bizarre tales of humanity's misguided attempts to settle, including a spectacularly unsuccessful foray by a group of 2,000 Norwegians who turned up thinking this was the new Tahiti. Floreana also boasted one of the most brutal penal colonies known to man. All in all, you get the sense that this really is a place best left to the boobies.

Just to the north is Santa Cruz, an inhabited island where the giant tortoises roam. You'd think it would be easy to spot such a ponderous mover, but they tend to lurk behind dense vegetation and are not easily spotted in the wild. We saw three in the Highlands above Puerto Ayora, a long drive for limited reward. An alternative is to view them on the island's Darwin Center, where they are bred in captivity and come in all shapes and sizes.

Tortoises hatch their eggs in April, but there is never a right or wrong time to visit the islands because the shifting seasons bring their own rewards. The busiest months are December and January, when you will also spot whales swimming alongside the ship. While the islands are lusher at the start of the year, temperatures can reach 40C and many prefer to travel, as I did, after the rainy season ends in June. One guidebook plumped for November as the ideal visiting time, neither too hot nor cold, with a minimum of tourists. Certainly one attraction of going later in the year is the number of baby sea lions and birds, all learning the rudiments of island life.

There is something truly astonishing about sea lions. One minute they are gliding through the water with complete aplomb and the next they are lumbering around on land looking like they've had some vital part lopped off. Most of the day is spent lolling, an art they have refined to perfection. They are the animal equivalent of the idle rich, but for me the undoubted stars of the islands.

Darwin required the best part of 15 years to fully evaluate what he had seen here, and it is hard to think of anywhere likely to leave a more indelible impression on the modern traveller. The islands are intoxicating, a natural high that leaves the senses giddy with excitement.

The practicals

Cox & Kings (020-7873 5000, www.coxandkings.co.uk) has a 10-day package for £2,395pp (based on two sharing) including return American Airlines flights via Miami, three nights in Quito at the Colon Hilton (B&B), with excursions in a private car with guide, the three-night Galapagos Explorer II cruise (full board), internal flights, one night at Hosteria San Luis hacienda (B&B), and the last night back at the Colon.

The famous five . . .

Boobies

Thousands of them. Blue-footed, red-footed or masked. The red-foots, which have blue beaks and brown feathers, spend much of the time perched on bushes, a skill the blue-foots have not yet mastered. Of course, that might change in a couple of million years.

Frigate birds

With their huge wingspans, they look like pterodactyls, a throwback to another age. They have been called the "bad boys" of the Galapagos, and make a living from stealing food from their country cousins. Their best trick is to attack a booby just as it has emerged from catching fish underwater. If all goes to plan, the booby will regurgitate the fish in mid-air, allowing the frigate bird to catch it before it hits the water. Amazing.

Giant tortoises

Only found in the Galapagos and the Seychelles. The Galapagos species can grow to up to 250kg and live for more than 100 years. Of course, their numbers have been much reduced over the years, largely due to the discovery by sailors that they could survive on board without food and water for six months, at which point they would be eaten.

Marine iguanas

Unique to the islands. Up to 300,000 are thought to hang out there, soaking up the sun and diving to prodigious depths. Although they look ferocious, often hanging out in groups, they are actually harmless vegetarians who like nothing more than a spot of coastal seaweed. Their numbers have been affected by the 1982/83 El Niño, which warmed the waters and killed algae, a prime food source.

Tacky souvenirs

Fancy a plastic tortoise or a bronzed booby? Well this is the place. Exhaustive research showed that there is absolutely nothing of value to bring back from the islands, but that doesn't mean the vendors won't try to sell you the usual rubbish.

Their numbers have been affected by the 1982/83 El Niño, which warmed the waters and killed algae, a prime food source. Tacky souvenirs Fancy a plastic tortoise or a bronzed booby? Well this is the place. Exhaustive research showed that there is absolutely nothing of value to bring back from the islands, but that doesn't mean the vendors won't try to sell you the usual rubbish.

fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: Latest news and conditions
fields.body:
It should be another quiet week before the February rush. Conditions have been excellent, particularly the Swiss and high-altitude French resorts. More snow is forecast across the Italian Dolomites.

Austria

Soll (* *) is in desperate need of new snow and the pistes are slushy and hard going by the end of the day. Obergurgl (* * *) has been lucky enough to receive a light dusting of new snow this week.

France

Argentière (* * *) has some excellent powder off piste and soft conditions on piste. The new snow in Méribel (* * *) has created some great conditions at altitude. Serre Chevalier (* * * *) has new snow and some fantastic both on- and off-piste conditions.

Switzerland

Fresh snow this week has refreshed the pistes and created a winter wonderland. Great powder on and off piste and extremely quiet slopes all add up to fantastic ski condi tions in Verbier (* * * *). Crans Montana (* * *) has benefited from the new snow. Zermatt (* * * *) still has excellent conditions.

Italy

Cervinia (* * * *) has some fresh snow although conditions can become heavy in places. La Thuile (* * *) has plenty of good snow at altitude.

Andorra

On-piste conditions in Pas de la Casa (* * *) are fair and the best snow can be found on the upper slopes.

North America

Aspen (* * *) has good on piste conditions but off piste is variable. A good fall of snow is needed for perfect off piste powder skiing. New snow is forecast for California including Squaw Valley (* * *) and Mammoth Mountain (* * *). In Canada, the Banff Ski Area (* * *) has good on-piste skiing but has not had any fresh snow for over a week.

Key to conditions: No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open. * = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open. * * = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition. * * * = plenty of good skiing. * * * * = good conditions. * * * * * = fantastic on and off piste. For the latest snow conditions in more than 250 resorts, check out www.skiclub.co.uk.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Katy
fields.trailText: Hope you are enjoying New Zealand. One thing you must do on your trip is a tandem skydive - it is the biggest adrenaline thrill you will ever have in your life! The best place to do it in NZ is probably Taupo - as well as being the cheapest, you also get amazing views of the lake.
fields.body:
Sam,

Hope you are enjoying New Zealand. One thing you must do on your trip is a tandem skydive - it is the biggest adrenaline thrill you will ever have in your life! The best place to do it in NZ is probably Taupo - as well as being the cheapest, you also get amazing views of the lake. Otherwise do it in Australia. I've been twice now and I have vertigo and hate flying - so you have no excuse!!

I share your feelings on the whole 'there must be more to life than work' debate. I only lasted about a year in my 'proper' job before taking off. I enjoyed my trip so much (NZ, south-east Asia) that I now feel that my aim for the next few years is to travel as much as possible. Now I'm back in London saving to do just that. Maybe your trip will give you the same idea. There is so much out there to see. I have decided that for the moment my job is just a means to an end - a way for me to fulfil this ambition.

All the best,

Katy

PS Make sure you go Scuba diving as well!

fields.headline: Flights of fancy
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor on tips for booking flights on the net
fields.trailText: Booking flights
fields.body:
Never believe anyone who tries to persuade you that booking flights is an uncomplicated process. If that were the case, why would travel agents take courses in flight ticketing? No: if you're after a reasonable fare, booking flights is immensely complex, which is why so many travellers like to speak directly to an agent, even if that means waiting on hold. Some sites are making it easier for us to get an answer to the question: "When's the cheapest time to fly?" Others aren't - here are a few tips.

Ryanair

www.ryanair.com
Avoiding Friday and Sunday travel on Ryanair helps to keep the price down. It also helps to know that the "View More Fares" button means "View Some More Expensive Fares". Stansted to Knock in April, for instance, varies from £20 single before tax (an H-fare), rising to £127 (an S-fare). So if the first fare you come up with is marked V or K, try again: there are probably cheaper (albeit less flexible) deals on offer. The sequence, from the least to the most expensive, runs HVKLBQMS.

Go

www.go-fly.com
The cheapest fares tend to be the Super Savers (£39 each way to Milan); Savers are the next cheapest, followed by Two Nighters, Flexible Discounts and Flexibles (£121.50).

Expedia

www.expedia.co.uk
Go to Flights, click on Fare Compare and type in where you want to go. (You can also try Lowest Fares, but it's a bit hit-and-miss and doesn't guarantee that the said fares are still available.) The results show the cheapest deals found by other Expedia customers. Click on the price to find out whether any seats are left and whether the price has gone up or down.

ebookers

www.ebookers.com/travelagent/farealert/
When is ebookers going to be able to search only for flights that still have seats available? The initial scattergun search, suggesting fares the site can rarely deliver, continues to annoy. Try the Fare Alert service instead, which alerts you by e-mail when a flight becomes available under your price to a given destination on a specified date. I offered £300 for a return to Windhoek last week; I'm still waiting.

Flynow

www.flynow.com/fares/specials.htm When I saw a £186 special fare on British Airways to New York advertised on this page - valid until the end of February - I didn't think that it would actually be available on the dates I specified. Happily, it was. Subsequent searches for Delhi weren't so successful, but the page is worth a visit if you're flying to a fairly common destination.

webTitle: Who lost their heart in The Burren, County Clare?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... The Burren, County Clare
fields.trailText: Why? I love it because it's a true wilderness. Maybe this is part of my Indian background. I love it in the wild, and suddenly, when I went to the Burren, it was all there: a place where you could really get lost - with caves and the most incredible wildlife and flowers. I just found it the most magical place.
fields.body:
Why? I love it because it's a true wilderness. Maybe this is part of my Indian background. I love it in the wild, and suddenly, when I went to the Burren, it was all there: a place where you could really get lost - with caves and the most incredible wildlife and flowers. I just found it the most magical place.

What's the best thing? Its wildness and the delicacy of the flowers and plants that grow there, because it's mainly this amazing limestone rock. They call the rock a pavement because of the great sheets that go in layers. But out of that come the most incredible flowers, quite unique to the Burren. But also you find yourself connecting with the birds and wild goats, and find yourself lost in the caves. In one of them, I found a fox bone that immediately inspired a book.

My perfect day: Just to walk in the Burren and watch the sky change and the contours of the landscape. I think the most perfect thing is to lie down in a low meadow field full of flowers. You really feel enchanted.

My advice: One is always proprietorial over these magic places; you become terrified that if too many people discover it, it won't be magical anymore. But I'd recommend people just to walk it and really experience it as it is now, because there is talk of making it into one of Ireland's national parks and a bit of a tourist attraction.

Getting there: Ryanair (0870 3331231 www.ryanair.com) flies to Shannon from around £60 return. By hire car, head for Ennis on the N18, then take the R476 for Corofin. The road journey will take about an hour. Irish Tourist Board 020-7518 0800.

Jamila Gavin's Coram Boy was this week named the winner of the Whitbread Children's Prize. It is published by Mammoth at £5.99.

fields.headline: Thomas Cook
fields.standfirst: www.thomascook.co.uk
fields.trailText: www.thomascook.co.uk
fields.body:
Yet another behemoth of a travel company?

It wasn't always so. Thomas Cook himself was a Baptist preacher who believed that his cheap railway excursions would help the Victorian working classes to drink less and become better educated.

Ah. So if he could see the TC-owned Club 18-30 site (www.club18-30.co.uk), supported by Bacardi Breezer, he would . . .

Turn in his grave, yes. But no doubt the current shareholders would argue that budget airline JMC opens up similar opportunities for today's impoverished travellers.

Get on with it.

Patience. I was just about to add that the major attraction here is some pleasingly cheap air travel - St Lucia for £219, Toronto at £203. That said, the main flight search can be unreliable, and the special offers can only be booked by phone.

The travel guides are a bit flaky. I typed in Namibia and the search engine couldn't find a thing.

You should have tried Ibiza. "You may see some outrageous things," warns the entry, "but you can be sure that whatever they are, the people who live here have seen it all before."

No need to worry about the locals when I've had a few at three in the morning, then? I don't think Thomas would have appreciated that.

Perhaps not. But just think how astonished he would have been to be able to order commission-free foreign currency online and receive it by registered post the next day. He could have booked insurance, too - the cover is reasonably comprehensive, but far from the best deal on the web.

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: Devon | Berlin | Florence | Mallorca | St Petersburg | Iceland | Zanzibar | Morocco | Bangkok | Montego Bay | Toronto
fields.body:
Europe

UK: Spend Valentine's Day in a converted music room in South Devon. The cost is £240 for the week from Helpful Holidays (01494 764932, www.helpfulholidays.com).

Germany: Save £94pp on a weekend break in Berlin departing February 2 or 9 with Travelscene (0870 7774445). Three nights' B&B at the three-star Hotel Berlin Mark costs £249pp including return British Airways flights from Heathrow.

Italy: A Valentine's week in an appartment overlooking the Duomo in Florence costs £526 including car hire (based on twin share) through Vacanze In Italia (0870 0772772). Flights extra.

Spain: Limited Edition by Virgin (0800 716 919) is offering a special four-night Valentine's break from February at La Residencia in Deia, Mallorca from £ 275-£445 plus VAT per couple. The package includes breakfast, gourmet dinner and surprise gifts. Flights extra.

Russia: The British Museum Traveller (020-7436 7575) is offering an Art and Palaces of the Romanovs tour of St Petersburg for £1,295pp (twin share), including flights and four nights' B&B accommodation.

Iceland: Three nights in the Lake Myvatn region, just south of the Arctic Circle, costs £495pp (based on twin share) from Arctic Experience (01737 214214, www.arctic-discover.co.uk). Return scheduled flights from either Heathrow or Glasgow departing every Thursday throughout February.

Africa

Zanzibar: Seven nights' at the Beach Breezes Club costs £1,085pp for departures between February 8-13, including return flights, private transfers and half board. Holiday Options (01444 239999).

Morocco: Singles aged 45 to 69 can enjoy seven nights in Agadir for £595pp, including half-board single-room accommodation, return flight from Heathrow and transfers. Departing February 23, the deal is available through Solo's (08700 746453).

Asia

Thailand: Quest Travel (0870 4430746) is offering five nights in Bangkok from £469pp (based on twin share). The price includes direct BA flights from Heathrow and three-star B&B hotel accommodation.

Caribbean

Jamaica: Seven nights' all-inclusive accommodation in Trelawney Beach, Montego Bay, costs £699pp through Travel Choice (0870 9005833). The flight departs from Manchester on February 8.

North America

Canada: Until March 31, the price of two nights at the five-star Le Royal Meridien King Edward in Toronto has been cut by £130 to £299pp, including return scheduled flights from Heathrow, UK taxes and room-only accommodation. British Airways Holidays (0870 2424243).

fields.headline: The Greek classics
fields.standfirst: From Alonissos to Olympia,  Sarah Barrell  offers an alpha to omega guide to the best breaks
fields.trailText: From Alonissos to Olympia, Sarah Barrell offers an alpha to omega guide to the best breaks
fields.body:
Most big tour operators include Greece in their programmes, and last-minute cheap packages are widely available to Rhodes, Kos, Crete, Skiathos, Zakinthos and Corfu, and often to Halkidiki and Tolon on the mainland. If you're after a basic beach holiday, the price of a package is often no more than the cost of a flight.

But if you are looking for something more remote, unspoilt or geared to a particular interest, it's best to book through the smaller, specialist agencies or go backpacking - island-hopping is one of the easiest, most pleasurable and cost-effective methods of exploring (see page 10). A good source of updated information is www.greekislandhopping.com , which has ferry schedules, passes and links to other Hellenic sites.

Greece has almost 1,500 islands, 160 of them inhabited, and only a handful have suffered from excessive tourist developments.

Starting in the north, Skopelos has a fertile green landscape and pretty flower-filled hill towns.

In the Dodecanese, Ikaria offers thick pine forest, tranquil lakes and empty beaches. Neighbouring Samos is more visited but has an impressive 160km of coastline plus a mountainous, rugged interior popular with walkers.

Over in the northern Aegean, one of the quietest islands with direct flights from the mainland is Limnos. This butterfly-shaped, agricultural island offers 250km of unspoilt coastline and hosts surprisingly few tourists due to its infrequent ferry services.

But for something truly tranquil, head further west to the Ionian for a painting holiday on the island of Corfu where, away from the obvious tourist areas, there are deep green valleys, olive groves and tall cypress trees making a perfect backdrop. Classes are hosted by Wendy Jelbert, a professional artist, teacher and member of both the Society of Acrylic Painters and The Society of Women Artists. The medium is watercolour and classes cater to all levels.

Travel à la Carte (01635 863030) has seven nights' self-catering at Liakada Cottage, Skopelos, from £409pp, including return flights and ferry transfers. Ikaria and Samos are new programme additions for Sunvil Holidays (020-8568 4499) with a week's holiday costing from £358pp, including flights, ferry transfers and self-catering accommodation. Sunvil Holidays (020-8568 4499) offers a seven-night stay at the self-catering Afrodite Apartments, Limnos, priced from £386pp, including flights and transfers. Greek Islands Club (020-8232 9780, www.greekislandsclub.com ) has a painting holidays on Corfu from £641pp (one week) and £898pp (two weeks) including return flights, transfers, half-board accommodation at the Villa de Loulia, excursions and painting tuition.

Pack an enormous reserve of energy and head straight for the Cyclades. A requirement of entry on to the tiny, pulsating lump of rock called Ios appears to be the desire to drink your bodyweight in island moonshine, and to lose your passport/tickets/dignity within 24 hours of hitting the ramshackle port. You can't fly direct, and the island's clientele are mostly young backpackers, with so many of them originating from Ireland that Ios is sometimes said to be an acronym for Ireland Over Seas. Visitors seem either to stay for an entire season or leave on the next boat.

The queen of the Cyclades however, is Mykonos. Although 800,000 tourists pass through the island each year (and if you've been in August you'll be convinced they're all there at the same time), it retains a sophisticated party atmosphere, rarely cheap though always cheerful. Ibiza and Sitges may have superseded it as gay Meccas of the Med, but Mykonos still has a thriving scene, and with its immaculate whitewashed houses and picture-perfect windmills, the main town is as beautiful as any in the Aegean.

Further south and shifting down a gear or two in pace (at least outside peak summer months) is Santorini. It was a sophisticated outpost of the Minoan civilisation until an enormous volcanic explosion in 1,550BC ripped the island apart. The sultry black-sand beaches and sulphur-clouded hot-springs are a constant reminder. Here hedonism comes in the shape of gold and silver: the jewellery shops in the main town, Thira, are enough to make you wish for 10 more fingers and multiple piercings.

easyJet (0870 6000 000, www. easyJet.com) flies Luton to Athens from £140 return. A direct bus from Athens airport goes to the port of Piraeus, from where you can board a daily ferry to Ios. Gay specialist Man Around (020-8902 7177, www.manaround.com) has B&B packages from £326pp for a seven-night break at the three-star Carrop Tree Hotel, Mykonos, including flights. First Choice (0870 7500001) offers a week's self-catering at the Marillia Village, Santorini, from £324pp, including return flights and transfers.

Ferry services to the far-flung islands are often infrequent, so it's easiest to travel in peak season. Tilos, halfway between Rhodes and Kos, at first appears barren - arid mountains and sheer cliffs swooping down to the sea - but becomes seductively fertile as you go inland. Valleys full of fruit trees and flowers make great terrain for walkers.

Leros is gentler and greener than its nearest neighbour, Kalymnos, with uncrowded beaches and coves and bustling, non-tourist-dependent towns.

Without an airport or an inter-island ferry connection, Samothraki attracts few visitors, but the dark, imposing mass of granite has some good beaches and classical remains.

In the Dodecanese, Patmos is 12 miles across and has a population of 2,500. With no airport (it's reached by one-hour hydrofoil crossing from Samos) and a host of pretty beaches, Patmos is also one of Greece's most upmarket islands, dominated by an imposing fortified monastery where St John the Divine wrote the Book of Revelations.

Over in the Ionian, Ithaca's proximity to Corfu and the increasingly popular Cephalonia (Captain Corelli's island) would suggest a similar degree of mainstream tourist development; this is not the case. Odysseus' legendary homeland, one hour by ferry from Kefalonia, still retains sparsely populated beaches (albeit pebbly coves rather than sand) and peaceful fishing villages .

Laskarina Holidays (01629 822 203 www.laskarina.co.uk) has two weeks' self-catering accommodation on Tilos or Leros, from £400pp, including return flights and transfers. Filoxenia (01422 371796, www.filoxenia.co.uk) has two weeks' B&B on Samothraki for £650pp, including return flights to Kavala, four hours away by ferry. Sunvil Holidays (020-8568 4499) has one-week holidays on Patmos and Ithaca from £450pp, including return flights, all land and boat transfers and B&B hotel accommodation.

Greece's spectacular Easter celebrations are equalled only by Spain's Semana Santa. On Good Friday, expect effigy-burning processions followed by the breaking of the fast at the stroke of midnight on Saturday with dazzling candle-lit mass, firecrackers and feasting. Veggies should note that this is a meat-focused festival; a lamb on a spit is at the rotating centre of any party.

The mainland has impressive celebrations in the pretty Peloponnese town of Nafplio, and the celebrations in Crete are most likely to be accompanied by good weather.

Filoxenia (01422 371796, www. filoxenia.co.uk) has two weeks' self-catering at the Villa Lilly just outside Nafplio, from £440pp, including return flights; and two weeks' half-board at the Hotel Istron Bay in eastern Crete from £440pp, including return flights.

Some of the best walking in Europe is to be found in the Pindos mountains, an area of semi-nomadic shepherds, stone hamlets and wild, rocky national parkland. Walking is mainly on old mule tracks passing richly-decorated churches, monasteries and some 6,000 species of flowers including 100 types of orchid.

And on the southern-most tip of the Peloponnese, the Mani peninsula is pretty much unchanged since Homer described it, an arid Mediterranean weather-beaten "gateway to the underworld".

Naturetrek (01962 733051, www. naturetrek.co.uk) has a 15-day tour of the Pindos mountains, departing June 4, for £995pp, including return flights, hotel accommodation with most meals (the walking is mostly moderate with some more strenuous optional excursions). Headwater (01606 813333, www.headwater .com) has an eight-day guided walking tour of the Mani from £827pp, including return flights and hotel accommodation with most meals (5-6 hours of moderate level walking each day).

Athens is the best place to start a tour of Greece's antiquities. Within half an hour of leaving the airport, you can be at the Parthenon overlooking the terracotta roofs of the 19th-century city (the rabbit-warren streets of Plaka).

Easily accessible from Athens are Epidaurus, with its spectacular restored theatre, the Bronze-Age fortress of Tiryns and the extensive ruins of Mycenae, Argos, the oracle at Delphi, and Olympia, birthplace of the Games.

British Museum Traveller (020-7436 7575, www.britishmuseumtraveller.co.uk) offers the Classical Greece Tour, departing May 5, taking in Athens and the Peloponnese, from £2,350pp, including the services of a lecturer, return flights, transfers, transport, accommodation with most meals, and all the site entrance fees.

Flotilla holidays, which involve a group of yachts loosely following the same route, are an excellent way to feel independent while retaining sociable and safe contact with other craft. Yachts come in all sizes and cater to all levels - unskippered or fully crewed. In the Ionian, you can take in popular islands such as Zakinthos and Cephalonia, along with deserted craggy coves along the mainland shore and less visited islands such as the charming and undeveloped Kythira off the southern tip of the Peloponnese.

An alternative to flotillas for the more tentative sailor are club-based holidays where a variety of water sports and craft can be tried out on a daily basis.

Neilson (0870 9099099, www. neilson.com) operates flotilla holidays, based around the Ionian and Peloponnese, from £705pp for two weeks including return flights, transfers, accommodation, instruction and insurance. Sunsail (02392 222222, www.sunsail.com) offers two weeks at the secluded Club Leda, on the Pelion peninsula (eastern mainland) from £695pp including half-board accommodation, return flights, transfers and free use of all equipment (catamarans, yachts, windsurfers, dinghies etc). Mark Warner (08708 480480) offers sailing at its clubs on Kos, Lemnos and in Paleros on the mainland. Prices per person for seven nights, including sailing, windsurfing,waterskiing, watersports tuition, tennis, aerobics, kids clubs (2-17yrs), full board with wine, and flights, start at £455 for Lakitira, £545 for Paleros and £584 for Lemnos.

Hallowed stomping ground for chic new-age types, the Skyros Centre on Skyros offers alternative R&R for those that want "sun, sea and a sense of community". Courses include creative writing, sailing, singing, dance, reiki, massage and yoga.

Further south, in Crete, you can take a holistic holiday at a renovated 17th-century olive mill. Based in the bay of Kissamos, the West Crete Holidays centre is run by an English couple who offer courses in everything from yoga and belly dancing, to bird watching and the Alexander technique.

The Skyros Centre (020-7267 4424) offers two-week holidays (including up to six courses) from £625pp with full-board accommodation but not flights. West Crete Holidays (0114 244 6273) has one-week holidays from £300pp, including full-board accommodation, transfers but not flights.

According to Rosemary Barron (author of Flavours of Greece), real Greek cuisine remains very much undiscovered. Her one- week cookery course in Santorini aims to teach guests about the wine, history and food lore of Greece, and to conjure up dishes from such seductive ingredients as the miniature tomatoes that take their concentrated flavour from Santorini's volcanic soil. Along with syrup-soaked deserts, you will learn to make local specialities such as bay-leaf-scented chicken with figs and the most famous Santorini dish fava , which takes its name from a yellow-gold lentil grown throughout the island. Classes generally take place in the morning with sightseeing excursions in the afternoon.

Further east on the quiet Dodecanese island of Symi, you can learn to make Greek treats with local chef Stavros Gogios. For one week this spring, Stavros will be turning his attentions to teaching British travellers, rather than serving them, with a new Greek cookery course. Spend four hours each morning learning to turn locally- grown produce (from the neighbouring organic farm) and freshly-harvested fish and mountain herbs into such specialities as seafood filo pastry parcels and lamb cooked with honey and rosemary. Long lunches at Stavros's Mythos restaurant, located on Symi's steep harbour, follow morning classes, which leaves the afternoons free for walking off the excess, climbing the island's endless, steep stone steps.

Tasting Places (020-7460 0077, www.tastingplaces.com) has one-week courses with Rosemary Barron from £1,070pp including full-board pension accommodation, tuition and excursions. Flights extra. Laskarina Holidays (01629 822203) offers a one-week cookery course, departing April 18, including, lunch, self-catering accommodation,and flights from £565pp.

webTitle: Contemplating the Navel of the World

fields.headline: Contemplating the Navel of the World
fields.standfirst: Douglas Morrison feels the weight of history at Delphi
fields.trailText: Douglas Morrison feels the weight of history at Delphi
fields.body:
The first singer was pretty good. A plump teenager, she stood self-consciously twisting one arm behind her back as she sang into the empty open-air theatre perched halfway up the mountain. She didn't have to force her voice; the acoustic here, in this classic auditorium designed and built by masters, is so good that a soft word carries easily to the top, a good 75m away and 30m up. It was only when her school pals on the hillside above started cheering that the temple warden bustled over and told her to stop.

This is, after all, Delphi, the Navel of the World, the site chosen for his temple by Apollo himself 3,000 years ago. It's a sacred place where pilgrims have been coming ever since to ask the god for help, given in the form of prophecies by his mouthpiece, the oracle or Sybil. With that weight of history and expectation you don't want barbarians, however inspired, interfering in the transaction - reverential or not - between modern visi tors and the place itself.

And there is definitely something in this place that draws them, in ever-increasing numbers (650,000 last year), even if they may not be aware that it's the same thing that drew Apollo all those years ago. They come to pay tribute to their classical European heritage, represented by the ruined temple and its treasuries, theatre, athletics stadium and Sybilline rock on this steep mountainside 120 miles northwest of Athens. But underlying all that, in the towering cliffs, streams, wildflowers and shady trees themselves is something inherently ancient, powerful and atavistic, that is at once awe-inspiring and ominous.

The temple lies in the cradle of the mountains below Mount Parnassus, traditional home of the muses - patron goddesses of the arts - and probably the most spectacularly beautiful ancient site in Greece. Behind it rises the precipice of the twin peaks Flemboukos and Rhodini. Below it, across the road to the village of Delphi, the mountainside falls steeply away to the river Pleistos, whose ravine winds westwards, opening out to a rich plain of olive groves that ends at the Gulf of Corinth and the town of Itea.

It is possible to ski down the slopes of Parnassus and then amble around the Delphi temple and museum, where there is a copy of the omphalos - the sacred stone assumed to mark the centre, or navel, of the world - and a magnificent bronze charioteer from 474BC. It is wonderful walking country, particularly in spring, before summer's heat burns off the crisp, pine-scented air, the wildflowers, dark poppies and thistles. There are trails from Delphi up to Mount Parnassus, which can be climbed in two to three hours.

At its most obvious, the ancient power of the place moves people at the theatre to get up and perform - Apollo is also associated with music, poetry and dance. After the young girl had gone, a succession of would-be stars strode on to the auditorium and threatened to strut their stuff.

Like all the similar sites, Delphi's very fabric is threatened by the rise in visitors. The 4m-wide stones of the sacred way - the path that winds through Delphi, which pilgrims have walked for millennia - are worn smooth by their feet. The equation remains constant: heritage site plus tourism equals good business plus damage to site.

Perhaps this ancient site will be helped by the most modern technology - it has been suggested that virtual sites could be created on the Internet to take some of the pressure off. Maybe they'll even offer an oracle to answer questions.

BA (0345 222111) and Olympic (0870 6060460) fly daily to Athens from Heathrow and Gatwick. Buses to Delphi run about every three hours from 7.30am until 8pm from 260 Liossion Street in central Athens. Around £5 single for the three-hour journey. Accommodation in Delphi ranges from guest houses, such as Samsons at £2-£5 per night single, to B-class hotels such as the Castalia (00 30 265 82205) or Fedriades (00 30 265 82919) at £35 single or £47 double, and A-class hotels such as the Amalia (00 30 265 82101), £55 single, £80 double; or the stunningly situated Xenia (00 30 265 82151) £47 single, £70 double.

A plump teenager, she stood self-consciously twisting one arm behind her back as she sang into the empty open-air theatre perched halfway up the mountain. She didn't have to force her voice; the acoustic here, in this classic auditorium designed and built by masters, is so good that a soft word carries easily to the top, a good 75m away and 30m up. It was only when her school pals on the hillside above started cheering that the temple warden bustled over and told her to stop. This is, after all, Delphi, the Navel of the World, the site chosen for his temple by Apollo himself 3,000 years ago. It's a sacred place where pilgrims have been coming ever since to ask the god for help, given in the form of prophecies by his mouthpiece, the oracle or Sybil. With that weight of history and expectation you don't want barbarians, however inspired, interfering in the transaction - reverential or not - between modern visi tors and the place itself. And there is definitely something in this place that draws them, in ever-increasing numbers (650,000 last year), even if they may not be aware that it's the same thing that drew Apollo all those years ago. They come to pay tribute to their classical European heritage, represented by the ruined temple and its treasuries, theatre, athletics stadium and Sybilline rock on this steep mountainside 120 miles northwest of Athens. But underlying all that, in the towering cliffs, streams, wildflowers and shady trees themselves is something inherently ancient, powerful and atavistic, that is at once awe-inspiring and ominous. The temple lies in the cradle of the mountains below Mount Parnassus, traditional home of the muses - patron goddesses of the arts - and probably the most spectacularly beautiful ancient site in Greece. Behind it rises the precipice of the twin peaks Flemboukos and Rhodini. Below it, across the road to the village of Delphi, the mountainside falls steeply away to the river Pleistos, whose ravine winds westwards, opening out to a rich plain of olive groves that ends at the Gulf of Corinth and the town of Itea. It is possible to ski down the slopes of Parnassus and then amble around the Delphi temple and museum, where there is a copy of the omphalos - the sacred stone assumed to mark the centre, or navel, of the world - and a magnificent bronze charioteer from 474BC. It is wonderful walking country, particularly in spring, before summer's heat burns off the crisp, pine-scented air, the wildflowers, dark poppies and thistles. There are trails from Delphi up to Mount Parnassus, which can be climbed in two to three hours. At its most obvious, the ancient power of the place moves people at the theatre to get up and perform - Apollo is also associated with music, poetry and dance. After the young girl had gone, a succession of would-be stars strode on to the auditorium and threatened to strut their stuff. Like all the similar sites, Delphi's very fabric is threatened by the rise in visitors. The 4m-wide stones of the sacred way - the path that winds through Delphi, which pilgrims have walked for millennia - are worn smooth by their feet. The equation remains constant: heritage site plus tourism equals good business plus damage to site. Perhaps this ancient site will be helped by the most modern technology - it has been suggested that virtual sites could be created on the Internet to take some of the pressure off. Maybe they'll even offer an oracle to answer questions. BA (0345 222111) and Olympic (0870 6060460) fly daily to Athens from Heathrow and Gatwick. fields.headline: Uri Geller
fields.trailText: Vitamins, good luck charms and a vibrating hairbrush
fields.body:
A necessity: My big box of vitamins. It's a box I bought in a mechanical store and it's designed for nuts and bolts.

A luxury: It sounds strange, but I have a hairbrush that vibrates. It's a great feeling, and I use it to massage my scalp and neck.

A memento: I carry many little good luck charms, crystals and talismans, but one particular item that's special is a tiny red wool horse. It was given to my mother about 60 years ago.

If only: A big staple in my diet are the Greek dips humous and tahini. I can't always get them, so it would be nice to take a big batch of those.

Uri Geller's book Nobody's Child is currently being published in installments on his website, www.uristory.com.

fields.headline: From side to slide
fields.standfirst: Martin Bell guides you through the basic manoeuvres
fields.trailText: Martin Bell guides you through the basic manoeuvres
fields.body:
No responsible ski instructor will allow any novice out on to the main slopes until they show that they can turn and stop under control. The quickest and easiest way to gain that control is the "snowplough" position. (In North America, this is referred to as the "wedge" position.)

In the snowplough , the ski tips should be kept close together (about an inch or two apart), whereas the tails should be much wider apart. The foot position should be fairly wide, which naturally puts both skis on to their inside edges. It is the friction of those inside edges against the snow that will control the skier's speed.

But this is not a static, stable position; it is a dynamic equilibrium. If the skier relaxes, the skis will naturally start to come together into parallel alignment. To maintain the snowplough position, you need to keep pushing your heels apart. Gradually, you can learn to control the width of your snowplough and hence your speed. The wider the angle of the skis, the slower you will go; the narrower, the quicker you will go.

The snowplough position is also the basis for the first turns that most novice skiers will learn to make: snowplough turns . The key principle is that the outside ski controls the turn. So, if you want to turn left, you need to apply pressure to the right ski, and vice versa. This tenet of putting most of your weight on to your outside ski is one that remains crucial, up through all levels of skiing ability.

There is a simple way for snowploughers to get their weight over the outside ski during the turn. They can learn how to bend their body sideways, so that their shoulders lean out over the outside foot. This sideways bending is called "angulation", and is an invaluable habit for all skiers to learn. Some ski schools, though, teach a more modern method, recommending that the shoulders are kept level.

A common problem for first-timers with the snowplough turn is getting the ski tips crossed. This can be remedied by pushing the inside ski forward during the turn, so that it remains slightly ahead of the outside ski.

After a couple of days, most beginners will be happily making snowplough turns all over the mountain, on the flatter runs, and many will be ready to take the next step: learning the traverse position. This is the first time that they will be skiing, at least for short periods, with their skis in a parallel alignment.

The traverse is a funda- mental stance, used by all skiers when skiing across a slope, in between turns. It is crucial that you learn a correct traverse position from day one, as faults will get much harder to rectify later on. The body angles used in traversing are so basic, that it could be said that all parallel skiing can be defined as a series of traverses.

When traversing, the uphill ski should be slightly ahead of the downhill ski. This will dictate the correct angle for the whole of the rest of the body: the uphill knee, hip, shoulder and hand should all be slightly ahead of their downhill counterparts. The shoulders should be leaning out, to keep the body weight over the downhill ski. The knees and hips should be pushed towards the uphill side. This helps tilt the skis on to their uphill edges, enabling them to hold an edge and preventing skidding. Viewed from directly ahead, the body should have a curved shape.

Sounds easy in theory, but when inexperienced skiers get on to steeper slopes, they get nervous. Their instincts tell them to shy away from the drop below them with their shoulders, and lean instead towards the uphill side. This eradicates that curved body shape, causing the skis to flatten, and skid out of control. This is probably the single most frequent mistake made by intermediate skiers. Becoming a better skier entails overcoming your instincts, and teaching your body to always apply a good traverse position, even on the steepest slopes.

Once you're able to consistently make snowplough turns, linking them with the traverse position, you'll be encouraged by your instructor to start "matching your skis earlier in the turn". In other words, you will continue to use a narrow snowplough to start each turn. But, during the turn, you will bring the inside ski around so that it is lined up parallel to the outside ski. The remainder of the turn is done with the skis parallel. This type of turn is known as a stem turn , and is achieved by the majority of people before the end of their first week on skis. The next step, which can prove tricky, is to eliminate the stem completely, and progress to parallel turns.

Next week: learning parallel turns. Martin Bell is running ski courses for intermediate skiers this season in Vail & Breckenridge, Colorado. For more information, call 0170 8224080 or e-mail: vailresorts@clara.co.uk
