fields.headline: Home to the heroes
fields.standfirst: Elkan Allan takes in the settings for the great dramas of Greek mythology
fields.trailText: Elkan Allan takes in the settings for the great dramas of Greek mythology
fields.body:
The little white plaque on our bedroom door proudly proclaimed: "Dr Schliemann's Room." On the wall downstairs were photocopied signatures of Debussy, Sartre and Henry Moore. We were in La Belle Helene (tel/fax: 0030 0751 76179), a modest pension in Mycenae, a mile or so from the ancient site where Agamemnon, Clytemnestra and Orestes are reputed to have lived and agonised, and which was unearthed by Dr Heinrich Schliemann in 1876.

Nothing much has changed at La Belle Helene since the good doctor lodged there - probably not his pretty art-nouveau but board-hard bed and certainly not the plumbing (communal loos and showers down the corridor). But, wonder of wonders, the great names from the past remain, in the shape of Achilles Dassis and his son, Agamemnon, the latest in the line of tavern-keepers from the same family who have run the little hotel for the past 150 years.

One cannot say it was the best hotel we stayed in during our fortnight's unguided tour of the Peloponnese, the "plane leaf" as it looks on the map, extending south from Athens. This is where all the great dramas of Greek mythology were played out, and it has retained its beauty and mystery, due in part to the travel industry's preoccupation with the islands.

The latter-day Achilles is quite a character and not keen on coach parties. He has been known to turn them away, preferring to lavish attention on individual travellers.

In July and August the buses descend on Mycenae, Mystra, Olympia and Epidaurus in their hundreds, their arrival anticipated by the taverna owners whose first job each morning is to lay out as many tables and chairs as possible outside their establishments. Thankfully, by the time we arrived in September there was no problem finding a place for lunch.

Ancient Mycenae, built on a steep mountainside, is a breathtaking sight. Those who want to reach the summit and the palace - where Clytemnestra must have stood and watched for the bonfires signalling Agamemnon's return - are advised to drive to the upper entrance to climb the citadel. Those who are hearty of lung and stout of leg should make it in about an hour from the main entrance. Clytemnestra's tomb, with its narrow walls and beehive shape, lies between the main entrance and the distinctive 13th-century Lion's Gate, but you will have to ask your way, as there is no signpost to it.

With a fast new road from Corinth, Mycenae makes a handy first stop on a tour of the Peloponnese. If you fly in to Athens, take the old road from the capital to Corinth, which is a welcome alternative to the E94 motorway that is choked with frantically-driven trucks. The old coast road winds picturesquely along the Megara gulf and, if the timing fits on the way out or back, there is a delightful, quiet, cheap hotel - the Hotel50 (0296 62250), so-called because it's exactly 50km from both Athens and Corinth - perched over the bay at Kineta, with balconies overlooking the sea.

You can descend by a staircase to the beach and take your first swim, too, but you will need something on your feet, as like most (but not all) Peloponnese beaches, it is stony and rocky.

From Mycenae, we headed for the Mani, via Sparti, a pleasant enough town with good accommodation in the shape of the Sparta Inn (0731 21021/3 fax: 24855). The hotel has two swimming pools - one on the roof - and was pleasingly cheap: Dr12,000(£21.80) for a double room, balcony and bath, including a good breakfast.

Sparti has a few relics of the brutal city state, but nearby Mystra, the most complete Byzantine town anywhere, is the real reason for going there. Beautifully restored, it offers a true step back into the past.

But the tour buses, ever pushing onwards to pack in as many famous sights as possible, miss an absolute jewel, a mile down the road. There, in Parori, nestled about a quarter-of-an-hour along an easy track, is Panagia Lagadiosita (Virgin of the Gorge), a tiny church hewn out of a cave, its icons and flowers testament to the fact that it is still used for worship. Spectacular in its location and construction, it is a haven of beauty in a wild landscape.

So to the Mani, the middle peninsula of the three pointing south from mainland Greece, which is reputed to have the brightest light and the widest variety of herbs in Europe. We stumbled on a wonderful central point to rest, a few miles north in Alevra's Tower (0733 59388 - when closed, call Athens (01) 6645023). Run as a summer hobby by the plump and beautiful Alevra, who lives in Athens the rest of the year, it looks down on Limeni Bay where half-a-dozen tavernas compete for diners. At £36 a night for a room with a large balcony, a kitchen, bathroom, shower, and the use of a lovely pool, it was a snip.

Nearby are the Dirou caves, best experienced via a boat-ride among millions of stalactites and stalagmites. As our room was already booked in the middle of our stay by weekending Athenians, we had to move out for one night. Luckily, the nearby seaside village of Gerolimenas has two hotels, and we chose the Akroyiali (Phone/fax: 0733 54204) in the centre of the bay.

Refreshed, we headed north to Olympia, but changed our plans about staying there when we discovered that even in October the adjoining town was over-run with tourist buses and shlock shops. We doubled back to a road we had passed on the west coast, with signs to a spa and a lake. Fortune favoured us again and we ended up at the Kaifa Lake hotel (0625 32954 fax: 33800), another modest, almost empty and welcoming family establishment (with mandatory swimming pool) from which we visited Ancient Olympia.

The ruins were, indeed, thronged with tourists eager to stand where the Olympic Games began, but the site turned out to be extensive and evocative enough to absorb the assembled throng, and we found ourselves unexpectedly touched by the presence of ghosts.

We cut back across the mountains, visiting the disappointing Lousios Gorge (you really have to spend three days walking down it) but finding the surprisingly elegant Mainalon Art Hotel (0795 22217 fax: 22200) in Vitína - a small town surrounded by stunning mountains and forest - for an overnight stop.

Our final mini-break was just outside the startlingly beautiful town of Nafplio, which, with its steeply-terraced streets and modest port, manages to retain the essential charm and hospitality of the region. Eschewing the highly-recommended Byron Hotel (0752 22351, fax: 26338), which offers spectacular views, we chose what our guide-book called the "budget-breaking" Amalia Hotel (0752 24401).

From Nafplio we made our last stop at the stunning theatre at nearby Epidaurus, surely the best-preserved ancient amphitheatre. Those forced by the school holidays to go to Greece in July or August have the considerable compensation of being able to see works by the three great tragic playwrights Sophocles, Euripides and Aeschelus performed there at the weekends. It is indeed an arena that puts into context the legacy of this ancient land.

The practicals

Elkan Allan flew to Athens on easyJet (0870 6000 000 www.easyjet.com) from Luton for £111.20 return and rented a car with the local Budget associate, Sixt Rentacar (0124 6220111), for £183 for 17 days. Information on Epidaurus from the Greek Tourist Board (020-7734 5997). A good site for Greek hotels is www.dilos.com.

fields.headline: Micromap
fields.trailText: A pocket-sized precision optical viewer.
fields.body:
This weather is testing my patience. Last weekend, I was hiking in the Lake District but the wind turned my map into a battering ram, and by the time I'd wrestled it to the section I needed the soggy thing was virtually unreadable. Get a MicroMap - it's light, smaller than a mobile phone, easy to use and pretty stylish.

Well, I hope it's not one of those plastic folders you wear around your neck. No, it's a pocket-sized precision optical viewer. You just slide in a mini map reduced to 1/40th of the normal size and view it through a fold-way magnifying lens.

Which maps does it have? When I'm walking, I use the OS Outdoor Leisure series. There's quite a choice, with 24 card sets including inner London and 20 UK regional cities with street indexes, Britain's Best Cycle Rides, European cities and several sets of the Ordinance Survey maps.

The Micromap viewer costs £19.99 (inc p+p) mail order from 020-8866 0400 (www.minimap.co.uk). It comes with a UK road map. Additional sets of cards cost £8.

fields.headline: Scotland creates a new north-south divide
fields.standfirst: Free care for pensioners and a 21% rise for teachers pose a big challenge to Westminster
fields.trailText: Free care for pensioners and a 21% rise for teachers pose a big challenge to Westminster.
fields.body:
Devolution is drawing an indelible line across the UK. On one side students pay tuition fees, the teaching profession is in crisis, and many of the frail and elderly must pay to help meet the costs of their care. On the other there are no tuition fees, teachers have won a 21.5% pay deal, and now it looks as though all pensioners will enjoy free long-term care.

Scottish executive proposals to fund long-term care for all pensioners has opened up the biggest policy divide yet between Holyrood and Westminster, and raised the spectre of a two-tier UK society split along the Scotland-England border.

Yesterday, as pressure grew on the UK government to follow Scotland's lead, there were warnings that Labour risked losing the grey vote over the issue, and predictions that Scotland could become a giant nursing home as pensioners rushed north to take advantage of any better deal.

Sir Stewart Sutherland, who chaired the royal commission which recommended free personal care for the elderly, said he believed its introduction in England and Wales was now inevitable. But the health minister, John Hutton, ruled out any policy reversal in England and Wales, where nursing care is free but personal care is means-tested.

"Devolution means that it is for the Scottish parliament to make decisions on its response to the royal commission on long-term care," he said. "Both the government and the Scottish executive are committed to improving health and social care services for older people, but we are doing this in different ways."

Analysts say the government and the public have to accept that Scotland can follow a different path, however awkward it might prove. "This is exactly what the Scottish parliament was designed to do," said Malcolm Dickson, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "It was designed to take decisions that reflected the broadest strand of public opinion.

"But it is an embarrassment for Labour in the run-up to a general election and following on from tuition fees and the teachers' deal. What the Scottish parliament has done is provide a stick with which to beat the party. People will say if it's good for Scotland why is it not good for the rest of the UK? But this is something the political parties need to get used to in a post-devolution situation."

Downing Street may have been spared some difficulty by the fact that the Scottish executive will not reveal the detail of its proposals or take a final decision until August.

Yesterday, the Scottish National party and the Conservatives demanded clarification of the executive's apparent commitment on free long-term care, but the first minister Henry McLeish would not comment further. However, the Liberal Democrats, whose rebellion forced Mr McLeish to rethink his earlier refusal to fund all long-term care, said the executive's position was unequivocal.

Enormous impact

Public policy experts say this will have an enormous social impact across the UK. "This is absolutely huge," said Allyson Pollock, chair of the school of public policy at University College London. "It is really a triumph for Scotland if they really do go down this road. Over the last 20 to 30 years a lot of care has been shifted to being a personal responsilbity and what the Scottish parliament is saying is that care is now a universal collective responsiblity."

Professor Pollok said the issue would shine a light on the "covert privatisation" of the health service in England and Wales. "You have to ask why in England we are shunting more and more care into the unregulated private sector," she said.

Teachers leaders have already warned that a recent 21.5% three-year pay deal for Scottish teachers will cause deep discontent south of the border.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, has said schools in England could find it even harder to attract teachers. "I think morale of teachers in England and Wales will be severely depressed if they do not get at least equal treatment." Pensioners' groups in England have also warned that there will be great anger and bitterness if Scotland's elderly get a substantially better deal, but warnings that Scotland wll be colonised by middle class English pensioners have been dismissed.

John Curtice, a political analyst at Strathlclyde University, whose elderly mother lives in Cornwall, said: "At the point which people need that kind of care the last thing they are going to be capable of doing is making a long-distance, long-term move."

Others say the biggest question raised by the care issue is how Scotland can afford to be so generous. The country has traditionally enjoyed a favourable slice of public funds in its £17bn budget, some 25% higher per head than the rest of the UK.

Some analysts say the care issue will increase pressure for a complete review of funding, but economist Arthur Midwinter says Scotland has an appropriate share for its level of need and can afford the £110m cost of universal free care.

"If it's a priority they can find the money," he said. "I don't see any difficulty in funding it. They might have to adjust some of their other programmes, but they won't need to put up the tartan tax to do this."

Mr Curtice, however, said much of the unease at this latest policy departure comes not from Scotland's ability to pay for it but the process that allowed it to happen.

"It illustrates the impact of PR and the different power balance from Westminster," he said. "What is shows is that, boy, oh boy, haven't we got a different parliament up here."

fields.headline: Netjetters
fields.trailText: The latest news from our interpid globe-trotters
fields.body:
There has been drama of different sorts for our three netjetters this week. Our trio set off at the beginning of December on their own routes around the world, organised by Bridge the World. Hundreds of people have e-mailed Milly, an 18-year-old gap student, Sam, a fed-up 28-year-old civil servant and Sue, a 51-year-old divorced mother of three, with advice and are keeping in touch with their whereabouts on www.theguardian.com/netjetters each week.

Milly has settled in Coogee for several weeks. She finally has a room of her own, and is looking for temporary work while enjoying the sun, sea and sand off the Australian coast after a scare. "One afternoon, I was having a short amount of sun and sea before my evening's employment (a trial shift as a waitress). I was in the water when I felt a hot pain across my legs, and looked down to see what looked like a blue string of seaweed with bobbles attached to my leg.

"I recognised this as one of the tentacles of a bluebottle jellyfish, one of the many Australian creatures that will happily cause you pain. Leaving the water, I rushed to the first-aid stand, set up specifically for those who get stung (and who are careless enough to have not kept a closer eye on the water), to rub ice into my bright red leg. The attendant happily informed me that a girl had once swallowed one, so my sting was nothing. He was right too. Though it hurt, by the evening it had totally subsided."

She has also been to hear Sydney Symphony Orchestra at an outdoor concert, attended a Learn to Meringue class, and she's experimenting with going teetotal for a week.

Sam, meanwhile, is travel ling round New Zealand with a tour company called Magic Bus. A three-day sea kayaking and hiking trip gives him time for reflection: "I also finally began to think about what I'm going to do when I get back to England. 'Why - you have four months yet?' I hear you say. Well for me this trip is as much about the travelling as finding the time and space to figure out where my life is heading. Like many people my age, all I'm left with is a feeling of 'is this it?'"

But Sam is doing more than reflecting and is taking advantage of New Zealand's position as tops for adrenalin holidays - he's just done a bungee jump.

Sue spent the night in the Malaysian rainforest and witnessed the extraordinary events at a Chinese trance festival: "The man entered the trance. He began shaking and then making elephant noises . . . He then slowly forced a large steel hook right through his cheek and out of his mouth, which he left there for about 20 minutes. When the spirit finally left, he collapsed and they had to try to revive him and find out which god had entered him. On finding out, they dressed him in the appropriate robes and he sat on a chair of sharp nails with his feet resting on blades.

"He now blessed amulets, and people ask him for help with problems. I really don't know what to make of it all. I saw the hook go in and come out without a mark."

webTitle: Top of the range in Val d'Isère

fields.headline: Top of the range
fields.standfirst: Paul Kelso enjoys first-class quarters and sport in Val d'Isère
fields.trailText: Paul Kelso enjoys first-class quarters and sport in Val d'Isère
fields.body:
Even the most practical traveller could get used to waking up in a luxury chalet in one of the world's great ski resorts. From the freshly-laundered confines of a double room in Chalet Sanville, a deluxe pad just a short slide from one of Val d'Isère's chairlifts, this feels like the real thing.

Your alarm call comes in the shape of a genetics graduate with a first-class hockey career on her CV, bearing a perfect cuppa. She retreats, allowing the pampered guest to shower in a marble-clad bathroom, slip into a monogrammed bath robe and slippers, and emerge from the en-suite bathroom to the kitchen/dining room, which, at this end of the market, comes with en-suite chef. All chalets operated by Ski Scott Dunn come with a staff of two.

Come the afternoon, the dining table sags under the weight of homemade lemon cake and chocolate biscuits, steaming pots of oolong and Java, fresh baguettes and several varieties of confitures. Appetite temporarily sated, there's just time to assume the horizontal on one of three enormous sofas and ferret around in the video library for something to fall asleep in front of before being woken for canapes.

Having polished them off, it's eyes down for four courses of the finest modern British grub, washed down with a bottle or three of wine, before you crawl from the table, waistband straining, feeling like a minor European royal. And nothing to look forward to in the morning except some of the finest skiing in Europe.

Such plush living is far from the norm in Val d'Isère. Not that the town is shabby. Tucked away at the head of the Tarentaise valley, a spectacular three-and-a-half-hour crawl from Geneva on precipitous mountain roads, Val d'Isère was subject to a substantial makeover in 1986. The concrete aberrations of the 60s were swept away and replaced with a timber- and stone-fronted town centre more befitting the ideal of an Alpine retreat. But the town is more famous for its sporting heritage. People come here to ski. The legendary Jean-Claude Killy, winner of three gold medals at the 1968 Winter Olympics, was raised here; and, to this day, children in the town are imbued with the sporting ethos, getting afternoons off school to hurl themselves down some of the most challenging and enjoyable slopes in the Alps.

To an impeccable history can be added the sheer scale and variety of the skiing. Combined with Tignes, which sits in the next valley, the éspace Killy , as it is known, stretches for some 300km, offering testing fare for intermediate skiers and some of the sport's more famous challenges to the more accomplished. These include the spectacular Face de Bellevarde, fashioned for the 1992 Winter Olympics men's downhill, which plummets around 1,100m to the village.

The après ski is, by reputation at least, no less formidable. Dick's Tea Bar was and is the original Alpine "nightpub", designed with the unique demands of the British winter tourist (late licence, well-stocked bar, dance floor on which to stagger until dawn) in mind. Other pubs, bars and restaurants abound, offering enough watering holes to slake the combined thirsts of the Grenadier Guards, the Irish Guards and the Oxford and Cambridge ski club, all of whom are regular early-season visitors. They take their partying seriously here.

Away from the luxury, lodgings on the whole fall into the functional class. Affordable, practical and at last properly regulated and inspected, the apartments and chalets cater for those who want to spend the bulk of their trip on the piste in every sense, as opposed to on the sofa.

The practicals

Ski Scott Dunn (020-8767 0202) operates chalets in Courcheval 1850, Méribel, Zermatt, Champary as well as Val d'Isère. Prices start at £475pp per week, rising to £1,470, and include return flights from London to Geneva or Lyon, transfers, and breakfast and dinner six days a week. Child care is available in all resorts on request. A personal nanny for a week costs £265, with an £85 supplement for each additional child, and cr che facilities cost between £140-£225 per child depending on age. Additional charges may be made for private transfers and some large bedrooms.

Getting the best out of Val d'Isère

Ski schools

Val d'Isère's ski area is vast. Combined with Tignes, the éspace Killy covers 300km of runs, and for this reason alone a guide is a good idea. As well as improving your skiing, they'll help you get the most out of the bewildering choice, speed you through lift queues and secure a decent table for lunch.

Top Ski (00 33 479 061 480) is run by the sage-like Pat Zimmer, a man with so many years on the slopes you fancy he can hear the mountain breathe. He specialises in off-piste trips.

Mountain Masters (00 33 479 060 514) is made up of largely British guides who go by the book. They'll push as hard as you want and have a knack of instilling confidence.

Snow Fun (00 33 479 06 19 79) is made up mostly of local boys, with some formerly very good young racers among them. Once again, local knowledge is invaluable and illuminating.

Restaurants

On the mountain, the restaurants, with the odd exception, are unspectacular and all of them charge Ffr2 (20p) to take a pee (taking the piss some call it, but it is free if you are eating) and the "picnique interdit" signs do detract a touch from the air of open-armed welcome you might desire. Self-service grub ranges from sandwiches to hot pots, with an omelette setting you back around Ffr55. Not cheap, but then they have to get the eggs up the hill.

Best by far was La Fruitière (00 33 479 060 717), a former dairy. Plat du jour - a warming rabbit hot pot or lamb stew was typical - costs Ffr99, and with staff dressed in blue overalls, there's a functional, fashionable feel. Booking is essential in season.

In the village, there was seldom reason to tear oneself away from the chalet, but Café Jacques is a charm ing, open-all-hours family restaurant. The Ffr150 menu included duck cassoulet, a delicate slice of terrine, cheese and coffee. Add a modest Cte du Rhne and an armagnac and Ffr200 a head is realistic.

Bars

Dick's Tea Bar heaves with Brits. Bar prices increase from Ffr16 for a beer before 9.30pm to a breathtaking Ffr32 after 11.30pm, when the door charge is Ffr70. Full of the sort of people you would try hard to avoid back home.

Bananas is a cute operation in a former 60s chalet. Low key, with comfortable seating and a dozen backgammon tables upstairs; plus a snugger room downstairs which gets better as the evening goes on.

Café du Sports in the centre of town is mercifully old-school in approach. No daft cocktails, drinking games or DJ, just a fabulous array of spirits and liqueurs, some glorious sepia photographs of skiing's greats and a barman with whom, given time, you could establish a meaningful relationship. One day, you imagine, he might reach for your usual as soon as you walked through the door.

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Pyranees | Devon | Sardinia | Nairobi | India | Thailand | St Lucia | Orlando
fields.body:
Europe

Britain : Until April 12, the Grade 1 listed Combe House, Gittisham, in Devon (01404 540400, www.thishotel.com) is offering three nights for the price of two, with midweek breaks from £364 for two guests including breakfast and dinner.

France: Pyrenees Adventures (01433 621 498, www.pyradv.demon.co.uk) is offering packages between April and October to discover the Pilgrims' Way in the Pays Basque region. The seven-night breaks staying in an 18th-century farmhouse cost from £595pp. Flights not included.

Italy: Voyages Ilena (020-7924 4440, www.voyagesilena.co.uk) has a seven-night break in a restored Galluran cottage on Sardinia departing June 14 for £575pp based on four sharing. The price includes return flight from Gatwick, car hire and insurance.

Africa

Zimbabwe: A five-week journey from Harare to the Kenyan capital of Nairobi, taking in Tanzania's Ngorongoro crater and the Mikumi national park along the way costs £651 plus £490 kitty per person through Dragoman (01728 861133, www.dragoman.co.uk). The price for the trip, departing March 5, includes hotel and camp accommodation and guides, but flights cost extra.

Asia

India: Discover cookery, ayurvedic health, or wildlife and culture of the southern state of Kerala on one of three themed packages from Gateway to India (0870 4423204 www.gateway-to-india.co.uk). Ten nights' full board costs from £240pp (flights extra).

Thailand : Depart May 1 for 10 nights' room only at the three-star Bay Inn Hotel in Phuket for £549pp (two sharing), including return flights, pre-paid taxes and transfers. Bridge the World (0870 4447474, www.bridgetheworld.com).

Caribbean

St Lucia: The 10th annual Jazz Festival runs from May 4-13, and this year's attractions will include soca, salsa, zouk and steel drums. A 10-night stay in the Windjammer Landing Villa beach resort, including British Airways return flights, transfers and accommodation in a one-bedroom villa with pool, costs from £1,279pp (based on two sharing) through Harlequin Worldwide Travel (01708 850300).

North America

webTitle: How to buy a VW camper van

fields.headline: How to buy a VW camper van
fields.standfirst:
I plan to go travelling for a year in a van. Is a VW Camper is the best choice? and where can I buy a good one cheap?
James Hood
fields.trailText:
I plan to go travelling for a year in a van. Is a VW Camper is the best choice? and where can I buy a good one cheap?
James Hood
fields.body:
The words good and cheap are not often synonymous with buying a VW Camper. You may be lucky enough to find a bargain in the for-sale columns in one of the VW specialist magazines (such as VW Motoring and Volks World), as we did. They also list a number of dealers, of both new and second-hand models. Buy one with a long MoT, check for rust and leaks, and get the engine checked by a qualified person.
Kate Carfrae

VW campers have the 60s hippie wanderer image, but the old aircooled rear-engined ones are slow, thirsty, not too reliable - compared with modern vehicles - and very difficult to repair.
Chris Wigzell

There's an unofficial street market for used VW Campers in London every Saturday or Sunday morning. It is in Market Road, Islington, beside the astroturf pitches. Visiting Aussies and Kiwis who are about to return home bring along their vans and flog them to the newly-arrived ones embarking on their grand tour of Europe.
Tim Cooper

On a tight budget, you would be better off buying a standard Mercedes-Benz 408 diesel and converting it. They are tougher machines, have enough headroom to stand up in and are wide enough to put a bed crossways in the back. You can install proper heat insulation - winter in a Camper would not be enjoyable - and they look like working vans rather than tourist carriers, so you will be less conspicuous parking overnight beside the road or in a town.
Jake

· You could not do much better than to pay a visit to Ian Campbell of the VW Camper Centre, Bell Weir Garage, Hythe End, Wraysbury Road, Wraysbury, Middlesex TW19 6HE. Call 01753 541 488 (mobile 07802 980 290), or you can mail him at campbells4ffc@aol.com, or check out his website on www.vwcampercentre.com. It is a family business which has been going for 30 plus years and they have at least 20 campers on display with prices ranging from £1,500 upwards. I bought my first camper there last November and have no regrets.
Rory Wyley

webTitle: Tests hold out the hope of cure for diabetics

fields.headline: Tests hold out the hope of cure for diabetics
fields.trailText: Britons are to test a treatment for diabetes described by campaigners as promising the biggest breakthrough in combating the disease since the discovery of insulin in the 1920s.
fields.body:
Britons are to test a treatment for diabetes described by campaigners as promising the biggest breakthrough in combating the disease since the discovery of insulin in the 1920s.

The pioneering technique, involving transplanting cells into the livers of patients under local anaesthetic, could pave the way for many sufferers to abandon daily insulin injections.

The operation, developed by a Canadian team led by British-born surgeon James Shapiro, has so far succeeded in 13 out of 15 patients, and trials should begin in Leicester this summer, and later at six other centres.

More than 300,000 Britons have type 1 diabetes, the form against which the technique is used, but hopes are already being expressed that it could also help others among the 1.4m diabetes patients. Another 1m diabetics are thought to be undiagnosed. Treating diabetes and its complications costs the NHS an estimated £4.9bn a year, 9% of the budget.

Paul Street, chief executive of the charity Diabetes UK, which is spearheading funding for the work, suggested "this could be the route to a cure" for those living in fear of coma, blindness, renal failure or other complications. The disease prevents glucose in the blood being converted into energy because the natural insulin is not working.

In type 1 diabetes, islet cells in the pancreas which produce insulin are destroyed by the body's immune system. Scientists have tried to transplant them from donors for more than 20 years but with little long-term success.

But Mr Shapiro's team in Edmonton, Alberta, appear to have cracked many of the problems by sharply increasing the number of cells transplanted, using non-steroid drugs to combat rejection, and other changes.

Thirteen of 15 patients have survived without insulin injections for up to two years, after having cells implanted from different donors in operations up to a month apart. Most were out of hospital within a day.

There are drawbacks which have meant the technique so far is aimed at those with the most unstable conditions, leaving them at most risk of complications and with low quality of life.

The patients have to stay on anti-rejection drugs for the rest of their lives and there is a severe shortage of pancreatic donors.

But scientists hope that the size of the drug cocktail can be reduced and that stem cell research, using adult cells to trick the pancreas into growing more of the vital islet cells, may also ease shortages in future.

Mr Shapiro said: "This is not a cure for every patient with diabetes today. It is one step forward, a major step forward."

Diabetes UK is to spend well over £250,000 on the initial stages of the work, while universities and hospital trusts will pour millions into training and equipment if the trials are a success.

Ten patients are expected to have the transplants by summer next year but it may be another year at least before it is clear whether the success of the Canadian pioneers has been matched.

Moira Murphy, director of research for Diabetes UK, said: "It is early days yet, but this may well lead to a cure for diabetes ... We are extremely excited by this opportunity and feel we have to grab it with both hands.

"If this research proves successful, it could revolutionise the lives of people who currently need to take daily insulin injections just to stay alive."

The partners in the charity's consortium are Oxford transplant centre and Nuffield department of surgery, Oxford University, King's College hospital and Royal Free hospital, London, University hospitals of Leicester, Southmead hospital, Bristol, Worcestershire acute hospitals NHS trust, and Addenbrooke's hospital, Cambridge.

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: Sound advice from readers in the know.
fields.body:
 While mosquitoes and midges are attracted to many kinds of cosmetic perfumes, most are positively repelled by citronella (essential oil) when a few drops is applied to a base of olive oil, and massaged into exposed areas.

Ronan Coburn

 Borrow inspect repellents and creams from someone who has just returned from the tropics. The ones on sale there are a lot more effective than anything available here. The Australian RID Tropical Strength and Paraderm Plus are brilliant.

Margaret Power

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Chinese new year | Up Helly Aa | River and Rowing Museum | The Jewish Museum | Wakehurst Place | National Centre for Popular Music
fields.body:
Snakes and . . .

The Year of the Snake has uncoiled and Chinese New Year events will be taking place worldwide this weekend. Expect dragon dances, music and entertainment in London's Gerrard Street and Leicester Square, all day Sunday.

Information: 07765 257618.

. . . dragons

Join the Edinburgh Chinese School in its annual new year visit to the Festival Theatre. Traditional Chinese music, Chinese dancing, an acrobatic display and a martial arts demo all welcome the new year.

Sun, 1pm. £3.50. Edinburgh Festival Theatre, 13-29 Nicolson St, Edinburgh (0131-529 6000).

Northern exposure

Take your woolly hats to the traditional Viking fire festival, Up Helly Aa, in Shetland, where a day of festivities and concerts culminates in a torchlit procession and the burning of a replica Viking longboat.

January 30. Evening procession 8.30pm. Lerwick, Shetland. Tourist Office: 01595 693434.

Current account

Fans of Steve Redgrave and Kenneth Grahame should be fascinated by the River and Rowing museum in Henley-on-Thames, which celebrates the past, present and future of the river and the sport of rowing.

Open daily 10am-5pm (10.30am weekends). £4.95/£3.75/family £13.95. Mill Meadows, Henley-on-Thames, Oxon (01491 415600).

East End memories

London's East End Jewish heritage is imaginatively illustrated by a collection of photographs from award-winning photographer Sam Tanner in What Remains, a new exhibition at The Jewish Museum.

Open Mon-Thurs 10.30am-5pm (Sun 4.30pm). Exhibition until April 22. £2/under 12s free. The Jewish Museum at the Sternberg Centre, 80 East End Road, London N3 (020-8349 1143).

Sown up

A brand new Millennium Seed Bank exhibition has sprouted at Wakehurst Place - the Royal Botanic Garden set around a striking Elizabethan mansion in Sussex. Its aim is to save wildflower species from extinction.

Open daily 10am-4pm. Wakehurst Place, Ardingly, West Sussex (01444 894067).

Hit parade

It may be a highly futuristic building, but the National Centre for Popular Music devotes itself to history, starting with the 1950s and working up today's hi-tech sounds. The Making Music Zone is the most interactive and should be a big hit with children.

Open daily 10am-6pm. £5.95/£4/ family £18. Paternoster Row, Sheffield, Yorks (0114 296 2626).

fields.headline: Club class
fields.standfirst: Jane Cunningham overcomes her guilt at leaving the care of the kids to others, and kicks back for some well-deserved R&R
fields.trailText: Jane Cunningham overcomes her guilt at leaving the care of the kids to others, and kicks back for some well-deserved R&R
fields.body:
Family holidays rarely manage to be the wholesome, bonding breaks that parents guiltily feel they ought to be. Throwing one's entire brood into an apartment abroad and expecting them to be sweetness and light is asking too much. Self-catering invariably ends up being harder work than staying at home.

So, having previously been sniffy about parents who dump their kids in the creche the second the plane touches down in paradise, all we wanted was five minutes' peace. Booking a Sunsail holiday in Greece, where the kid's clubs are more popular than the sailing - which is what it is supposed to be all about - was the first step to realising just how relaxing a family holiday can be.

Club Vounaki, set in front of the rugged Arkarnanika mountains beside the Ionian Sea, caters for all ages, from babies through to oldies, and is a place where something or nothing happens every day, depending upon your requirements.

After the short coach transfer from Preveza airport, bags are delivered to the three-storey accommodation blocks that overlook the bay. The children are introduced to their clubs and follow a hectic schedule from 9.30am to 5pm, when they are collected by parents for tea in the open-sided restaurant overlooking the bay. While adults enjoy their dinner, their offspring are taken upstairs to the video club until 9pm, by which time they, and the staff, are on their knees with exhaustion.

Even if your children are apprehensive at first, the trained activity staff are so friendly and adept they bring the best out of everyone. All children are issued with the Sunsail uniform - a white T-shirt bearing the club logo, navy blue swim bag and sunhats. No child is pressured into taking part - the joy of it is that they want to. They take ownership of their activities immediately. The group leader is theirs, the club is theirs, and they don't want to miss a moment.

For older children - eight to 12-year-olds - in the Junior Gyber's Club, a typical day begins with some gentle exercise such as rock-jumping, banana boating or canoeing. A brief pause for lunch and reapplication of sunscreen is followed by a treasure hunt, sailing or swimming, rounded off with a quiz or a competition. Babies are given first-class treatment by qualified nannies who face paint, play sandcastles, read stories or just cuddle.

So where does that leave mum and dad? Sneaking off to their rooms at any time of the day for "a rest", going on a day's sail to the island opposite for a picnic or propping up the bar and indulging in some sailing chat.

However, no one could say Vounaki is the Garden of Eden. There is something vaguely holiday-campish about the set-up. The spread-out facilities make maintaining a cohesive atmosphere difficult. And on the days when relaxation is so deep, and even making conversation at dinner seems like a trial, be warned: Sunsail's habit of putting a member of staff at each table means there is no peace for the wicked. With room for 160 guests, being alone is a challenge.

What to see
The pretty town of Paleros is a 15-minute coastal walk from Club Vounaki. A small line of beach-front restaurants offering seafood and stuffed vine leaves are cheap, laid back and child-friendly. The little town also has a couple of excellent shoe shops, a chemist and regular groceries. Behind the small village lies an even smaller village, Korpi, famous throught the country for its mineral water.

To visit the towns of Astakos, Mitkas and Levkas, car hire is essential. Levkas Town has a beautifully romantic central square overlooked by Italian architecture; perfect for sipping some strong Greek coffee and watching the world go by. Steeped in history, the bustling atmosphere makes it well worth the £25 car rental charge. Hiring a skipper or cribbing a ride with a competent sailor makes sailing to the islands of Meganissi and Kalamos easy. The kitchen staff will make you a picnic to take.

What to do

All Sunsail Clubs offer a variety of water sports. Vounaki's positioning is such that wind conditions are ideal for beginners and intermediate sailors, but advanced thrillseekers will find the gentle breeze prohibitive. Three-day dinghy sailing: RYA beginners level 1 £60; two-day catamaran course £75; three-day yacht sailing course £120. If boats aren't your passion, windsurfing and waterskiing are also on offer (three half-day windsurfing course £50, or one-to-one day course £50); waterskiing is £9.50 per session.

Eating

With one main meal a day not included in your package, Vounaki cleverly has its own taverna and bar at the bottom of the site with an outdoor terrace and views of the bay. The club operates a tab system, payable weekly. Making the trip into Paleros in the evenings is slightly hazardous as the path is not well lit. However, for the more adventurous, the most popular taverna on the waterfront is Mikey's. Welcoming, friendly, and an immaculate kitchen make it a safe bet for dining. On site, beer and wine is charged at roughly UK prices.

The practicals

Sunsail (023 9222 2222, www.sunsail.com) offers a week off-peak in Vounaki from £525 per adult, £425 per child, rising to £1,345 per adult and £1,000 per child. There are some twin rooms and double rooms with sitting area, plus mezzanine rooms, which should be booked early. Prices include flights from Gatwick plus use of all sailing and tennis equipment, Kids Clubs (other than Mini-Club, four months to two years, £150 per week), afternoon tea, informal sailing tuition, half-board meal plan, clean towels and linen.

fields.headline: Ferrying around
fields.standfirst: If there's one thing Greece has more of than islands, it's boats.  Phil Daoust  gets networking
fields.trailText: If there's one thing Greece has more of than islands, it's boats. Phil Daoust gets networking
fields.body:
The northern Sporades lie just east of the Greek mainland, offspring of the same tectonic humping that spawned Mount Pilion, where the centaurs once roamed and the gods had their holiday home. Skiathos in the west, Skopelos in the centre, Alonissos in the east, they stand shoulder to shoulder in the northern Aegean like a trio of wading giants. They might be holding hands in the steel-blue depths.

Around and between them flit lumpy roll-on roll-off ferries that would be at home in the English Channel; sleek hydrofoils that once plied the Volga; garishly-trimmed excursion ships; high-prowed fishing boats; streamlined yachts. Their wakes criss-cross the sea like turquoise ribbon. Greece has 1,425 islands, and what feels like 1,000 times as many boats.

The Sporades have seen it all. Their pine-clad slopes have been conquered by Persians, Athenians, Cretans, Macedonians, Romans, Franks, Venetians, Turks and Germans. Between wars, their shores have been lashed by wave after wave of pirates, forcing the natives into fortified towns high above the sea. And now every spring and summer their bars and beaches are overrun by tens of thousands of tourists, together with mainland Greeks fleeing the heat. Increasing numbers are opting to "island-hop", flying in to the airport on Skiathos and then visiting the other islands by the network of ferries and hydrofoils.

I was sitting in a bar in Skiathos Town, enjoying a cool Mythos beer after the flight in, when another Brit who knew the system came racing over. "Quick! The ferry's coming in. Finish your drinks and get your luggage." A few gulps and we rushed down to the harbour, where a white-suited policeman fussed around as passengers piled off the hydrofoil. We picked up the bags we'd left on the quayside (no thieves outside high season, the locals insist), and within minutes we were bouncing over the waves. The ride was fast but bumpy, and the hydrofoils stop running when the seas are rough. Then - or if you're happy to take your time - you hop on a ferry. You'll get a better view, as well.

First port of call was Skopelos, the largest of the three islands, though still under 100 sq km. Skopelos Town is an attractive overgrown village of whitewashed buildings with red roofs, with streets you climb as much as walk. Of course, you'll probably end up in one of the less picturesque apartment complexes on its borders.

The island has some fine beaches, though you might want to avoid the oily-looking water around Skopelos Town itself. They're mostly pebble rather than sand, which keeps some travellers away but does its bit for the sunlounger industry. My first dip came at Panormos, a short taxi ride away on the far west side of the island, with a sharply shelving beach of silver stones and fantastically clear water. If you're used to swimming in the brown soup around Britain, you may worry about the dark shape following you in the depths of the water. It's not a shark - it's your shadow. And once you get used to it, swimming is one of the great pleasures of island-hopping. Take some goggles or a mask and have fun chasing the fishes.

When you feel like a change, Panormos has a windsurfing school, as well as several large but friendly restaurants smack on the beach. The islands' staple diet is grilled squid or lamb chops and chips, with a side order of horiatiki , or "Greek salad". Simple food, cheap and well cooked. Within a few days you may find yourself craving pizza.

Skopelos is best known for its churches: 120 in Skopelos Town itself, 300 in the island as a whole, for less than 5,000 locals. On a good day, you can have one to yourself. One morning, I walked the dusty road to the Monastery of the Metamorphosis, high in the hills to the east of Skopelos Town, where whitewashed walls encircle a cool, dark chapel tended by a grey-bearded monk. Outside, a weatherbeaten bench overlooks a valley lined with pine woods and olive groves, where goat bells clank and yellow and green butterflies flutter by. The sun blazed down, but a fig tree offered a little shade. Birds sang while I watched a stream of ants carrying fragments of grass and leaf back to their nest. Is there any finer holiday activity than watching someone else work?

But the prettiest of the three islands is Alonissos, the least populated of the Sporades with a winter popula tion of just 1,500. It's also the least wooded, but the locals do their best to make up for that with potplants. Alonissos also boasts dozens of quiet sandy beaches, accessible only by boat or dirt track (the Sporades aren't big on roads). The main settlement is Patitiri, a rock-circled bay full of laid-back hotels and tavernas. When you get sick of stuffing your face among the bougainvillea, a bus or taxi will take you 2km up the hill to Old Alonissos. One fellow passenger pointed out: "Sun every day in Greece; no sun in London." How very true.

Old Alonissos is a 3D maze of steep, narrow alleys that suddenly open on to spectacular views. This was the island's capital until it was devastated by an earthquake in 1965. Greece's military rulers ordered its population rehoused in the port, but now the ruins have been bought up and renovated, mainly by foreigners who look down their noses at the "ugly" new town.

Every second building in Old Alonissos is a smart bar or restaurant, and there are too many stalls selling Camden Market-style trinkets, but the place stays just the right side of airy-fairy. Perhaps it's the cats. Everywhere in the islands, mangy specimens beg for scraps while you eat, occasionally spitting at each other. At one maritime-themed bar in Old Alonissos, I was treated to a full-on fight, as two moggies chased each other under and over the tables until the owner finally had to push them away with his broom.

Alonissos is the quietest of these islands, but the nightlife is there if you go looking for it. After dinner in Old Alonissos, I popped into one of Patitiri's disco-bars for a nightcap and somehow didn't get home till 6am. This put the mockers on a planned boat trip to the nearby monk seal colony, but a local confided that you're more likely to see a martian than one of these endangered animals.

After Alonissos, Skiathos comes as a shock, with its crowds and the constant whine of scooters. The best-known of the Sporades, Skiathos balloons from 5,000 souls in winter to more than 50,000 in high season. The main settlement, Skiathos Town, is just minutes away from the airport, a mass of waterside bars and restaurants whose owners wave their wares at you and beckon you in.

The island has just one metalled road, which runs along the south coast and serves countless sandy beaches separated by rocky headlands full of umbrella pines. At the western end of the island, Banana Beach is said to be the finest nudist stretch in the Mediterranean; further east, Kolios offers a gentle sweep of sand with a friendly watering hole, the Sand Bar Café.

Cars, bicycles and scooters can all be rented in Skiathos Town; you'll need one of these to reach the ruins of the island's former capital, Castro, at the northernmost point of the island five or six hilly and dusty kilometres down a dirt track consisting entirely of hairpin bends full of suicidal Swedes on scooters. This picturesque mess of houses and churches clings to a headland that offers terrifying drops and stunning views. A narrow track leads down to a sandy beach, where a no-frills taverna offers basic fare and a horse occasionally pops in to beg for food.

Also well worth a trip is the islet of Tsougria, 4km south of Skiathos Town, which has the usual golden beach, plus a taverna and a chance to rent a kayak. I sailed there on a private yacht, hired for the day - but if I told you the details of that trip, you'd only get jealous.

The practicals

First Choice (0870 750 0001) offers a 14-night island-hopping holiday to Skiathos, Skopelos and Alonissos from £425pp, including return flights, all ferry transfers and B&B accommodation, as well as seven-night twin-centre holidays in Skiathos and Skopelos or Skiathos and Alonissos. Cycle hire starts at about £2/day; 4x4s at £30; luxury yachts at £200. Mopeds and scooters are readily available but not recommended for safety reasons. Expect to pay £1 to £1.20 for most drinks and £10 to £15 for a good meal, including drinks.

fields.headline: Take a hike
fields.standfirst: Ed Douglas goes for a ramble in Halkidiki
fields.trailText: Ed Douglas goes for a ramble in Halkidiki
fields.body:
'You know," said Andreas a little sadly, "the Greeks have a saying: only donkeys and Germans walk." At the time, I assumed the proverb was modern, generated by the significant numbers of German tourists who are not content to sit on the beaches but prefer to examine the interior shod in stout boots. But, on reflection, the origin of the phrase might be 50 years older.

Whatever, the Greeks are the ones missing out. And their preference for long lunches over afternoon walks has had a curious consequence. Whereas England is seamed with paths, the Greeks have moved straight from the donkey to the motor car without feeling the need to have any footpaths at all.

So Andreas, a former mountain guide and German army officer, deserves some credit. Thanks to him and his team, Halkidiki, the three-pronged peninsula thrusting into the Aegean now has a network of paths.

Halkidiki, with its higher rainfall, is lusher than the islands, where visitors can be forgiven for just wanting to grill themselves, and in May and June this northern corner of Greece is perfect for the dissipated rambler who fancies a spell on the sunlounger and the opportunity to work up an appetite.

In the village of Parthenonas, 1,000ft up in the hills of Sithonia, Halkidiki's central prong, it was all I could do to stop the juice from my lamb chops from dribbling down my chin. "You've earned this," I told myself, reaching for the olives while simultaneously swinging back another glass of local red wine.

Paul Karapas, the taverna owner, stood at our table, happily rubbing his hands and threatening to do something expansive like sing or dance. Parthenonas is impossibly charming, all window boxes and fashionably rough plaster work. Once a refuge from pirates who put in at the harbour below, the village was more or less abandoned in the 1970s on the back of the tourist boom that transformed the local fishing ports.

Now the wheel has turned, and those who have done well from tourism are escaping the summer chaos to live quietly in the hills, renovating the dilapidated cottages.

After lunch, in a fit of puritan guilt, I left my companions to take the quick route down, and shouldered my rucksack to explore the surrounding hills. Just round the first bend out of the village I had one of those ghastly moments when you are suddenly surrounded by snarling, barking dogs whose job it is to frighten strangers, especially ones with white legs and clad in shorts. Quaking with fear, I tried to appear calm as I backed down the track facing my tormentors, bitterly regretting my decision to go it alone.

But once my heart had settled back down to its normal rhythm and I had negotiated my way around the dogs, I suddenly found myself without a care in the world. The olive groves were fully of poppies nodding their heads in the breeze, and the smell of resin wafted out of the pine forests. I lay down on a jumble of granite boulders overlooking a narrow thread of water trickling through a rock gorge. It was hot, but not unbearabe and I had outstanding views out to sea.

Halkidiki is famous for its third peninsula, Agionoros, literally holy mountain. Prince Charles was on retreat last May with the Orthodox monks who live there on the slopes of Mount Athos, which rises 6,000ft straight out of the sea. The Orthodox monks can often be seen in Ouranopolis, a largely unspoiled fishing village that acts as the gateway to the restricted part of the peninsular and whose name translates as the "Gateway to Heaven". They look rather displaced, hauling their suitcases off the bus in the village's main square, but I can't deny that the sight of the monks fixed in me a strong desire to beg, steal or borrow a permit to get access to their remote peninsula. Only 10 non-Greeks a day, and they must be male, are allowed to set foot there. As an incentive, apparently they make decent home-brew.

Denied the opportunity to imbibe with the monks, I had to content myself with the more sobering pursuit of watching a Michael Jackson lookalike from Las Vegas and The Temptations tribute band, one of whom had the deepest voice of any man I ever saw. They were on stage for an hour and a half at the Regency Casino in Thessaloniki, and afterwards we got to shake their hands before hitting the roulette tables. Michael didn't take off his yashmak and I didn't ask him how the chimp was. Some things are better left unsaid.

The practicals

Olympic Airways (0870 6060460) fllies Gatwick to Thessaloniki from £138 return. Halkidiki-based A La Carte Travel (00 30 373 25261, e-mail alacarte@mail.otenet.gr) organises walking tours and other specialist activities in Halkidiki from £160 including transfers and B&B accommodation but excluding flights. Thomson (08705 502 554) has two weeks self catering in Halkidiki for £603pp including flights and transfers. Ed Douglas stayed at the Hyatt Regency in Thessaloniki (www.hyatt.com).

webTitle: The plight of the phoenix - part 2

fields.headline: The plight of the phoenix - part 2
fields.trailText: The fiasco over the rebuilding project dates back to May 1997, when the Fiat-owned construction company, Impregilo, one of five applicants whose design projects were considered by a commission set up by the Prefecture, was awarded the contract. Work began that summer and proceeded smoothly for almost a year. Hopes that La Fenice might re-open by the millennium were dashed when the rival consortium, Holzmann-Romagnoli - which had challenged the adjudicating commission's decision on the basis that Impregilo's bid, though cheaper than its own, was incomplete - won its appeal. Rebuilding ground to a halt. Impregilo counter-appealed, insisting that the judges had been misled by a last-minute addition to Holzmann's design, created by the architect Aldo Rossi, which, according to Impregilo, was not part of the original specifications for the theatre's reconstruction.
fields.body:
The fiasco over the rebuilding project dates back to May 1997, when the Fiat-owned construction company, Impregilo, one of five applicants whose design projects were considered by a commission set up by the Prefecture, was awarded the contract. Work began that summer and proceeded smoothly for almost a year. Hopes that La Fenice might re-open by the millennium were dashed when the rival consortium, Holzmann-Romagnoli - which had challenged the adjudicating commission's decision on the basis that Impregilo's bid, though cheaper than its own, was incomplete - won its appeal. Rebuilding ground to a halt. Impregilo counter-appealed, insisting that the judges had been misled by a last-minute addition to Holzmann's design, created by the architect Aldo Rossi, which, according to Impregilo, was not part of the original specifications for the theatre's reconstruction.

The disputed area consisted of an extensive property belonging to Emilio Baldi, who had his home and a restaurant abutting La Fenice: this was to provide space for a small auditorium. Although the sale of the property eventually went ahead, a friend of Baldi's says that the restaurateur, on practical grounds, refused, despite threats, to sell a large basement used as a laundry for his restaurant linen, a facility that, in this city, is virtually irreplaceable.

For the next 18 months, lawyers for the various parties locked horns in and out of court. When finally the State Council in Rome - the highest court of administrative justice to which the appeal was presented - ruled in Holzmann's favour, a third disgruntled bidder, the Genoese company Carena, insisted that the entire process begin again. After more appeals and counter-appeals, Holzmann was awarded the 90 billion lire (£30m) contract in October 1999 and began work, by which time the re-opening date was rescheduled provisionally for late 2001. It has since been further extended, to spring 2003.

But, given the unique problems of any construction work in Venice and the little so far accomplished, even that date seems ludicrously unrealistic. However, not everything is bleak. Despite still being housed in a tent, the Fenice Opera Company, rising to what they unequivocally call "this positive challenge", has continued to present varied and ambitious seasons of opera, music and dance. There are, reportedly, ample existing funds for the project: more than 90% of the cost is being met by insurance, state and local funding, with back-up from generous private donations controlled by such strictly supervised charities as Venice In Peril. To the delight of local architects, such as Francesco Da Mosto, who worked on the new plan for La Fenice with its original creator Aldo Rossi, killed in a car crash in 1997, the original architectural plans and written instructions by the engineers Tommaso and Giambattista Meduna, who rebuilt La Fenice in 1837, have been discovered in a forgotten archive.

This means it is possible to recreate precisely both the theatre's celebrated perfect acoustics and its aesthetic grandeur. "The decorative details are an integral part of the acoustic principles," explains Da Mosto excitedly. "The Medunas established specific techniques for cutting wood, so waves of sound from the orchestra and stage travel along the longest, uniform lines within the grain and are carried evenly to every part of the auditorium. Even the smallest bit of decorative wood panelling was cut this way and angled in a special way. The curves of each balcony, every papier-mache decoration was specially placed to ensure perfect transmission of sound. All these decorative elements will be replaced as they were, according to those organic principles." By studying Graziano Arici's photographs of the interior and such films as Visconti's Senso, largely shot inside La Fenice, he insists a perfect replica of the auditorium will be recreated.

But when? Shortly after Holzmann took over the project, work was suspended for seven months when Roman and medieval artefacts were unearthed beneath the theatre's foundations. Although reconstruction work began in earnest last May, so far only the perimeter walls have been reinforced, the foundations prepared for the installation of underground storage and rehearsal rooms and electronic stage equipment; it is, however, just possible to distinguish which areas will eventually become the auditorium, the proscenium arch and the stage. Venice's new mayor, Paolo Costa, ex rector of Venice University and a former minister of public works, has created for himself the temporary role of "commissioner extraordinary" with personal responsibility for the rebuilding project. At a press conference on December 4, he publicly lambasted Holzmann for falling behind schedule and so far completing less than 10% of the total building work. Holzmann's response has been to demand another 30 billion lire, almost one-third of the total budget, to continue rebuilding, blaming the town hall for recently requesting modifications to Rossi's original plan, changes that, it argues, will cause delays and extra costs. Reconstruction is again at a standstill. A legal battle seems imminent, and the government has already approached the state legislature for guidance about the new costs of rebuilding.

Given that all my most recent requests, following the new year, to Costa, his press secretary and representatives of Holzmann- Romagnoli for information on this latest impasse have been ignored, it is impossible to determine the next twist in the plot. So far, no one in the whole bizarre saga comes out of this well. fields.headline: JFW Herschel, Julia Margaret Cameron (1867)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Julia Margaret Cameron (1815-79), born in Calcutta and famous in her youth as one of the seven Pattle sisters, glamorous stars of British colonial society. In 1838, she married the legal reformer Charles Hay Cameron. After his retirement, they moved to England where, in 1863, she was given the gift of a camera and took up photography. Using her high position in Victorian society to secure portrait-sitters, she championed photography as high art.

Subject: John Frederick William Herschel (1792- 1871), one of the eminent Victorian scientist, whose achievements in astronomy - building on those of his even more famous father Sir William Herschel - included discovering 1,202 pairs of close double stars and 1,708 nebulae and clusters, charting the southern skies and popularising the wave theory of light. He met Julia Margaret Cameron in South Africa in 1835, when he was doing research on the southern skies and she was there to convalesce; they became close friends.

Distinguishing features: "He was to me as a Teacher and High Priest," wrote Cameron of her adored mentor Herschel. In this photograph, he is a prophet, an Old Testament figure, or perhaps a magician, an alchemist, swathed in black, his face set alight by his flaming white hair, his eyes catching the light, his whole presence that of a mystical figure. There's almost a madness in Herschel's eyes, a romantic intensity. This is a picture of the scientist as artist, highly pertinent to Cameron's attitude to photography. She rejected the idea that the camera was a mere recording instrument, capable of documenting facts but not making art.

Her photographs are flamboyant works of art claiming the status of paintings and participating in the Pre-Raphaelite aesthetic. Her great niece poses near naked as St John the Baptist, her friends play Sir Lancelot and Queen Guinevere in a series of photographs illustrating Tennyson's Idylls of the King.

Cameron also had a tremendous grasp of the sensual, expressive power of the medium and a taste for the glamour of famous faces - all of it coming together to make her portraits some of the most arresting in the history of photography. Looking at John Frederick William Herschel, in a big, generous albumen print, you feel you are coming face to face with a natural magnificence; as his corona of hair explodes around him, it's as if he were a stellar phenomenon. Herschel himself was fascinated by photography as well as astronomy; light is what links the two.

Cameron catches the light on Herschel's face; light that bursts out of his eyes and fiery hair, light that makes him glow. It is as if we are scrutinising some exotic and remote star, savouring light from an object that died millions of years ago and has only now reached earth.

This is not so far from the case. The light caught in Herschel's eyes, that makes them so vividly present to us, was reflected into a camera lens in the middle of the 19th century. The face that we see before us is that of a man who was born in 1792, who was in his 20s at the time of the Battle of Waterloo. And here he is, and we can see every scrap of stubble. Cameron could not have created a more powerful argument for the magical, uncanny nature of the photograph.

Inspirations and influences: One of Cameron's friends was the Victorian painter George Frederick Watts (1917-1904), who attempted to document all the noblest faces of his time in his portrait series The Hall of Fame. She photographed him, he painted her, and they shared a commitment to the seriousness of portraiture and a capacity to see old Victorian men as glamorous.

Where is it? National Portrait Gallery (020-7306 0055), St Martin's Place, London WC2.

webTitle: Wales to bear brunt of steel job cuts as Corus regroups

fields.headline: Wales to bear brunt of steel job cuts as Corus regroups
fields.trailText: Welsh steel plants will take the brunt of up to 7,000 job losses to be announced by the Anglo-Dutch group Corus next week, under a drastic restructuring plan to stem hundreds of millions of losses and restore investor confidence.
fields.body:
Welsh steel plants will take the brunt of up to 7,000 job losses to be announced by the Anglo-Dutch group Corus next week, under a drastic restructuring plan to stem hundreds of millions of losses and restore investor confidence.

Rhodri Morgan, first minister of the Welsh National Assembly, said he had held talks with Corus and wanted to prepare Welsh public opinion for a "hammer blow". He said 85% of the job losses would be in Wales but the Llanwern plant near Newport, Gwent, could retain its strip mill and some 1,300 jobs out of the 2,800-strong workforce.

His "educated guess," after extensive talks with Corus executives and UK cabinet ministers, is that the steel group could take the axe to the strip mill on Teesside, close or partially shut down the tinplate operations in Ebbw Vale and close units at the Shotton coating business in North Wales.

Corus refused to comment on Mr Morgan's analysis, which came in the wake of a report that the group would declare between 5,000 and 7,000 job losses among its 30,000-strong UK workforce but spread the pain across its British operations rather than opt for full-scale closure, as feared, of two of its four main plants - Llanwern and Redcar.

Sir Brian Moffat, chairman and acting chief executive, is under pressure from the cabinet, led by Tony Blair, to mitigate closures and redundancies in the face of evidence that the problems of an over-valued pound - a main cause of Corus's UK losses - are easing with the resurgence of the euro.

On Wednesday, the prime minister and Stephen Byers, industry secretary, warned Sir Brian that he would be condemned for short-termism if he over-reacted to City pressure for savage cuts and ignored evidence of a recovery in UK demand for steel, notably in the car industry.

Since early December, the pound has fallen by the equivalent of 20 pfennings against the euro to DM3.06 - worth about £160m to Corus's bottom line, which last year showed a loss of about £400m in the UK. "It's no longer losing £1m a day," senior assembly economists said, while admitting that the recent strengthening of the euro was not enough to stay Sir Brian's hand.

Both assembly leaders urged Corus to take a longer-term view of its prospects but conceded: "They have run out of money and time."

Steel unions, which are staging a huge rally on Teesside today, expect substantial job losses, however, at Port Talbot - and at other UK plants such as Scunthorpe.

They warned that Llanwern could eventually lose its strip mill under pressure from Corus's Dutch executives and from investors.

webTitle: Review: Emerald Germs of Ireland by Patrick McCabe

fields.headline: Germs, madness and murder
fields.standfirst: Aisling Foster  navigates Patrick McCabe's maze of black humour and Irish myths in  Emerald Germs of Ireland
fields.trailText: Aisling Foster navigates Patrick McCabe's maze of black humour and Irish myths in Emerald Germs of Ireland
fields.body:
Emerald Germs of Ireland

Patrick McCabe

384pp, Picador, £14.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

His neighbours dismiss him as "a complete and utter oddity", but if you're a Patrick McCabe fan you'll recognise the main character of his latest novel. Pat has been around since The Butcher Boy as abused son, bullied schoolboy, village scarecrow or anarchist, the bright-enough child beaten into the darkness of his own bent imagination by the cruelty of dysfunctional parents and an uncaring community. You'll recognise versions of the brutish father, too, and a mother whose violent emotions swoop between sentimentality and hate.

If, like the author, you grew up in an Ireland struggling between De Valera's old, anti-materialist ideals and the bright promises of the modern world, you'll remember quaint publications like Emerald Gems of Ireland . Through the late 1950s and 1960s, their blurry newsprint lined up beside the shiny new titles of the day to recall the disappearing songs and stories of some kinder age.

Cleverly, McCabe has fitted his novel into that faded literary frame, so rendering his sudden passages of gore and mayhem all the more colourful when they appear. Pat McNab is an innocent, pulled back and forth between those extremes of old and new Ireland. Tales of his disillusionment, of sweet optimism dashed again and again by the selfishness of the real world, are strung together in unchronological order like the rough "gems" of those forgotten magazines.

Insights into Pat's horrible childhood, adolescence and middle age are set between the mawkish songs of heroism and love that have helped shape his dreams. The disjunction between reality and the cosy old images of small-town Irish life set the scene for Pat's descent into madness. Beginning on his father, our hero becomes avenger, dispatching his adversaries into eternity "like they were the shite of fleas... a sack of good for nothing germs!"

Language is shaped to serve the author's bitter wit. He uses a multiple narrator, who lurches between naturalism and pretension, like the writers of old Emerald Gems. At one stage, Pat's face becomes so taut with fury "it was as though he possessed a length of carpet for a mouth". As more and more dead bodies feed the laurel bushes, Pat's predicament is compared to Macbeth's: "I am in blood stepp'd in so far that, should I wade no more, returning were as tedious as go o'er." Elsewhere, knowing archaism is used, as when the killer steps out into a morning "spreading its gossamer cloak across the countryside".

Like Pat's darkening imagination, some horrific scenes are lightened by memories of film. Disinterring his mother's disintegrating body to sit with her "in the warmth" suggests another more famous mammy's boy. Did Psycho inspire Pat to kill? Or simply to dress up in his mother's wedding dress when dispatching some of his victims? Certainly, a peyote trip into border territory is delivered in the jerky style of spaghetti westerns; but a long sequence in which Pat captures a bagful of money from some gun-slinging gangsters travels beyond the dreamworld of Bonnie and Clyde to a chilling reminder of the real-life murderers who operate just a few miles from him in Northern Ireland.

Yet there is no chance to reflect. A relentless comic narrative sweeps tragedy aside. Often it is delivered as brilliant one-liners, but it can slip between irony and slapstick, as when a black American baddie tries to shake down the local drapery store. Having felled him with a baseball bat, the old Irish proprietor informs him that "this ass-mother... was shakin' shook in Brooklyn when you was knee high to a culpepper coolshank!"

Yet for all its quirkiness and ventriloquism, the novel's structure fails to satisfy. The changing narrator and Pat's unchronological history create a maze that even the most persistent reader might find difficult to follow. Also, by beginning in the middle of McCabe's (already familiar) psychosis, the build-up of tension as each new experience accumulates upon the last is never allowed to develop. Instead we must examine the varying texts as psychologists, picking out small germs of truths from so many falsehoods.

In that, the sharp-eyed reader will be rewarded. Evidence that seeps between funny digs and fantastic nastiness makes McCabe's continuing thesis about the deep-laid ambivalence of Irish life all too clear. The parody of voices that once peddled old fictions about Ireland's "difference" as a nation of saints, scholars and comic songsters may amuse those who can remember them. But the raw fury with which they are mocked is not funny at all: these fake gems are splattered with real blood.

fields.headline: Games companies play
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: While chip designer ARM Holdings and Imagination Technologies got caught up in the hi-tech gloom yesterday, the more astute market players were carefully weighing the long-term prospects for their recently announced joint venture.
fields.body:
While chip designer ARM Holdings and Imagination Technologies got caught up in the hi-tech gloom yesterday, the more astute market players were carefully weighing the long-term prospects for their recently announced joint venture.

All the musing followed the publication of a note by HSBC Securities, which poured cold water on the venture that is aiming to develop 3-D graphics capability for handheld devices.

HSBC believes it could be five years before any such units are on the market and does not think the deal will have any substantive financial impact for either of the parties.

What could be important for Imagination, HSBC says, is its close ties with Sega. But if, as seems likely, Sega withdraws from the games console market, HSBC warns that Imagination's operating profits could fall by 40% - a painful hit.
