fields.headline: Face to Faith
fields.trailText: Churches around the world have just marked the Week of Prayer for Christian Unity. In Britain, there have been special services at which congregations from Protestant and Catholic churches joined together for worship and prayer. Unfortunately, these events do not reflect reality.
fields.body:
Churches around the world have just marked the Week of Prayer for Christian Unity. In Britain, there have been special services at which congregations from Protestant and Catholic churches joined together for worship and prayer. Unfortunately, these events do not reflect reality. The Week of Prayer for Christian Unity has, in effect, become a sham.

In the 80s, as the BBC's Religious Affairs Correspondent, I covered a British Council of Churches (BCC) conference at Swanwick, in Derbyshire. At the time, most of Britain's mainstream churches belonged to the BCC, except for the Roman Catholic Church. The conference aimed to find a way to bring Orthodox, Protestant and Catholic churches closer together. Dr Robert Runcie, then Archbishop of Canterbury, and Cardinal Basil Hume, leader of the Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales, were present.

The discussion was getting nowhere. Then, late one afternoon, unexpectedly, Cardinal Hume announced that his church would adopt a position of greater ecumenical commitment. The Cardinal's speech electrified the conference and broke the logjam.

That radical shift by the Roman Catholic Church helped lead to the formation of the Council of Churches for Britain and Ireland (CCBI), with the Roman Catholic Church as a full member. The CCBI recently renamed itself Churches Together in Britain and Ireland, and the Catholics are still in it.

Last century, church leaders believed the search for Christian unity among divided churches in a divided world was an urgent task. In Amsterdam, in 1948, the World Council of Churches (WCC) was founded. Almost all of Britain's main churches belong to it. The Roman Catholic Church is not a member but, in many ways, works closely with the WCC.

As I grew up in the church, I was taught that Christian disunity was a scandal and an affront to the Christian gospel. I heard that Jesus prayed, "May they all be one." In Britain today, however, there is no longer any expressed urgency to work for unity. The CTBI presents itself and its purpose as one of utilitarian ecumenism. The churches "often need to work together", it says. This is feeble in the extreme, implying that the churches should come together when it suits them, work together for a bit and then retreat into their denominational isolationism.

In its list of priorities, the CTBI has relegated the search for "visible unity" from first to third place. It is as if it believes that Christian unity is something that will happen by a kind of osmosis as churches work together. It won't. Yet in many places religious disunity - often, Christian disunity - leads to pernicious evil. As a Christian leader from Northern Ireland once told a WCC meeting, "Where I live, Christian disunity costs lives."

It should be as unacceptable for one Christian to dismiss another as not a "proper" Christian, as it is to dismiss another human being on the basis of their skin colour. However, Christian dismissal goes on across the spectrum. Fundamentalists dismiss liberals, liberals dismiss conservatives, and Protestants dismiss Catholics.

Last year, the Roman Catholic Church, at almost the highest level, said that other Christians belong to ecclesial communities; their "churches" are not proper churches. Shortly before this declaration, the Council of Bishops of the Russian Orthodox Church came out with its own statement in which it repeated the Orthodox view of non-Orthodox Christians as somehow less than the true church.

This has not changed by this year's coming together of local congregations in the Week of Prayer for Christian Unity, no matter how hard they may have prayed. There needs to be legislation within the churches that makes it difficult to speak and act denominationally rather than ecumenically.

Britain is a closed, cosy and complacent community. Its churches display the same self-absorbed insularity. I do not believe that most church members want this. They would welcome a lead but are not getting it. Instead, they are served an insipid brew of denominational self-centredness that has little to do with Christianity. At the institutional level, the search for Christian unity in Britain is dead.

 John Newbury is a Methodist minister, and works as a communications consultant.

fields.headline: Making a scene
fields.standfirst: He sells his own wife in Michael Winterbottom's The Claim, but when Peter Mullan gets behind   the camera, his principles are a little higher
fields.trailText: He sells his own wife in Michael Winterbottom's The Claim, but when Peter Mullan gets behind the camera, his principles are a little higher
fields.body:
One-time political cabaret performer on the Glasgow comedy circuit, Peter Mullan has forgotten what he learnt from stand-up. For the 40-year-old, who won Best Actor in Cannes for his portrayal of an alcoholic in Ken Loach's My Name Is Joe, has this uncanny knack of rattling those in power. Namely distribution company FilmFour, who backed out of releasing Mullan's directorial debut, Orphans, resulting in a heated dispute. But considering the actor - who features in Michael Winterbottom's Gold Rush drama The Claim - battled on behalf of Mel Gibson in Braveheart, what did they expect?

Your character in The Claim sells his wife for a gold mine, and is ultimately punished for it...

Yes, it's a very Catholic story in the sense that up until his wife comes back, he's having a very good time. When she does return, with his daughter, the good times stop, and guilt, and the quest for redemption, come into play. He has a belated sense of humanity in him; he can't turn his back on them, in the end.

How was the weather?

Cold. We filmed at the height of winter. The average temperature was around minus 30. But it was a dry cold. You're constantly thirsty, and there was also an altitude problem so you got weak very quickly. Though it's not like Scotland! Scotland has this damp cold that'll make you weep.

Do you have any more projects as director?

Yes. I will be shooting Magdalene in the spring. I wrote it after I saw a Channel 4 documentary called Sex In A Cold Climate.

What's it about?

It's set in Ireland in the 60s, in these prisons. They were for young women who had committed no crime but were deemed promiscuous by the state or their families. So they were put into the care of these nuns, who put them to work, 365 days a year, in these laundries, for no pay. Between times they were raped, beaten, humiliated, tortured. And everyone knew this went on, but nothing was ever said.

After the problems you had releasing Orphans, what will you do differently this time?

I'm working backwards now. Instead of, "Will you please give us the money to make the film?", I'm asking, "When you do give us the money, and we make the film, how will you distribute it?" I want guaranteed distribution, the right kind of enthusiasm.

In retrospect, what caused Orphans' distribution difficulties?

The biggest problem I had with Orphans was that I was told, "You have a great film. We just don't think there's an audience for it." I've since learnt, they meant, "We don't know how to sell it." FilmFour's lack of imagination was mind-blowing. At the time, they couldn't see past the fact that it was a Scottish film, thus it should be another Trainspotting. They were much more comfortable trying to sell The Acid House than Orphans.

What have you learnt about directing from those you've worked with?

Since Orphans, I've worked with Ken Loach, Michael Winterbottom and Mike Figgis. I've learnt a great deal. Not on a technical level, because when you act, you just act. But regarding the fact that everybody's human. Every director will have a bad day. That's very important to know. Some directors have a bad week, or shoot! There will always be a day when you wish someone else would come and do it. I've seen it on every film set, from Shallow Grave to Braveheart to Trainspotting. You can always spot an ashen-faced director.

webTitle: Review: Rebel Code: Linux and the Open Source Revolution by Glyn Moody

fields.headline: Give it away
fields.standfirst:
Steven Poole assesses the new e-paradigm of getting stuff for free in Glyn Moody's Rebel Code: Linux and the Open Source Revolution

Read the first chapter
fields.trailText: Steven Poole assesses the new e-paradigm of getting stuff for free in Glyn Moody's Rebel Code: Linux and the Open Source Revolution
fields.body:
Rebel Code: Linux and the Open Source Revolution
Glyn Moody
334pp, Penguin, £12.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Information wants to be free, runs the old hackers' slogan. But just how free can it get? The success of Linux, a sophisticated computer operating system that is available at zero cost, raises many questions about intellectual property in the electronic era. But does the so-called Linux "revolution" extend beyond the twilight world of caffeine-guzzling, VDU-tanned geeks? Could other "content creators" - writers, painters, musicians - ever prosper by giving their stuff away gratis? Glyn Moody's diligently researched book doesn't offer answers, but it does a useful job of providing the background to the arguments.

In the early months of 1991, Finnish student Linus Torvalds bought a PC to tinker with, and decided he wanted to program a "kernel" - the heart of any operating system. He christened the project Linux. Soon Torvalds was joined by eager helpers on the internet, to whom he delegated specific tasks of debugging and coding, and within a few years there was a community of thousands working on the project in their spare time. By the end of the 1990s, Linux was so popular - owing to its adoption by behemoths such as IBM - that it was perceived in some quarters as a threat to Microsoft.

Linux initiated the "open source" movement. When you buy a Microsoft program, for example, you effectively get a very large binary number. Your computer understands this number, but it is impossible to look at the 0s and 1s and infer just how the program was written. You don't have the source code - the language in which it was programmed - and that is what protects Microsoft's rights in the software. But Linux is distributed as open source - meaning that anyone with programming knowledge can peek under the bonnet and change it. That is how the Linux system got built, without vast corporate resources and hundreds of engineers on the payroll.

The process, then, is new and interesting. But in spite of the passion evinced by the hacker priesthood, and in spite of its corporate and internet-server success, Linux is never going to be a mass-market consumer operating system like Windows or Mac OS. Torvalds's first internet posting said that Linux was going to be "a program for hackers by a hacker", and this remains true. If you are excited by the idea of typing obscure commands into a black window to dick around with your computer's guts, you'll love it. But if you just want to use your computer for word-processing, web-surfing, or whatever, you'd better avoid it like the plague.

So are the politics of this "revolution" applicable outside the computing sphere? Although its proselytisers think of free, open-source software as a potent, radically democratic ideal, this was never a democracy. As one programmer explains to Moody: "It's sort of the opposite of design by committee. You get all the benefits of this huge pool of ideas, but it's not a democratic system. There's typically one person who is the god or the tsar who has final authority." So it is clearly not the end of hierarchy.

And what of the wider applications of the open-source paradigm? An earlier free software package, known as GNU, was distributed with a freedom-granting licence wittily known as "copyleft". One programmer that Moody talks to earnestly refers to this licence as "one of the most revolutionary documents of our century". Leaving aside such alarming blinkeredness, it is hard to see just how the Linux example might apply in other fields.

If you go to Tate Britain, you can look through a glass case at William Blake's notebooks, and navigate a palimpsest of several drafts of a few of his most famous poems. In a way, Blake's poetry is thus offered as open source, because you can spy on the process that led to the finished verse - the wrong turns, the deleted lines, the sudden illumination of a key image. But this information won't help you write a better poem than Blake did. There is no code for the process of creative inspiration that went on in the poet's mind.

And open source software has certainly not had a generally virtuous effect on attitudes to other media. If you lurk at internet hacker hangouts, you'll see plenty of people saying, "If I can get Linux for free, why should I ever pay for any software ever again?" The suspicion is that many of Linux's supporters are not romantic ideologues for an open, sharing process; they're just spotty kids, drunk on the power they enjoy over an inanimate bunch of transistors, who want something for nothing. (Of course, that doesn't stop them selling their Star Wars memorabilia on eBay.)

Stephen King ran into this attitude with his doomed experiment in writing a serialised internet novel: not enough people paid their dollar, so he gave up. (Of course, it's possible that their unwillingness to pay was influenced by their knowledge of King's already fabulous wealth, and their distrust of his self-righteous e-crusade against "big publishing", without which he would never have been a multi-millionaire in the first place.) Meanwhile, why should young people go near a record store when all the nu-metal and Britney they could ever listen to can be downloaded from Napster?

Here's the problem: now that computers have made content duplication and distribution free, people don't see what else there is to pay for. Effort and time are intangibles whose stock has dropped through the floor. Even so, and quite rightly, Glyn Moody and Penguin want 13 quid for the amount of time, effort and money that went into producing the book I have on my desk. They're making the first two chapters available for free on the Penguin website - "in the spirit of the open source movement," claims the press release. But that's not open source; that's marketing.

webTitle: Cash for tissue revelations add to trials of children's hospital

fields.headline: Cash for tissue revelations add to trials of children's hospital
fields.trailText: Allegations that the troubled Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool sold human tissue to a French drug company for use in one of its profit-making products yesterday caused a further public outcry over the apparently cavalier attitude of the medical profession to patients' bodies.
fields.body:
Allegations that the troubled Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool sold human tissue to a French drug company for use in one of its profit-making products yesterday caused a further public outcry over the apparently cavalier attitude of the medical profession to patients' bodies.

Just days before the publication of a report on the removal and storage of hundreds of children's organs at Alder Hey without parents' knowledge, it emerged that supplies of the thymus gland, which is routinely removed during cardiac surgery to give better access to the heart, were regularly handed over to the pharmaceutical company Aventis Pasteur, in exchange for cash donations to the hospital.

The tiny glands were used in the manufacture of a drug for aplastic anaemia.

Alder Hey parents yesterday expressed their horror at the idea of money changing hands for body parts, no matter what the hospital's motivation might have been. They said they were appalled that the hospital would hand over human tissue without the explicit consent of the patients' parent or guardian.

"This brings us right back to the issue of openness and informed consent," said Ed Bradley of the support group Pity II. "Pity II is not against research. But the hospital has ignored the families and not taken them into account at all."

Had they been asked, he said, the parents would probably have agreed to use of the tissue.

Ministers, alarmed at yet another escalation of the Alder Hey crisis, moved swiftly to condemn any exchange of cash for organs. "This is yet another piece of deeply distressing news for the parents of children treated at Alder Hey," the health secretary, Alan Milburn, said. However, he took pains to point out that, according to the hospital, it happened between 1991 and 1993, then stopped because of concerns among staff that accepting donations for organs might be unethical.

"This was a particular practice which was happening in the early 90s at Alder Hey and, it seems, some other hospitals," he said. "The NHS already knows this practice of taking organs without consent is totally unacceptable to this government."

The government would issue further guidance to the NHS, he said, hinting that it would form part of their response to the Alder Hey report, which is published next Tuesday.

To the parents, the revelations are just one more betrayal by the hospital. They claim Alder Hey released damning information about the extent of its storage of organs with apparent reluctance and, in their eyes, only under pressure.

Mr Bradley pointed to one contradiction in the dates - the hospital said thymus glands were passed to Aventis Pasteur between 1991 and 1993. The company dates it between 1989 and 1995.

Ian Cohen, solicitor for the families, said they had noticed that the thymus gland - listed by Alder Hey as tissue removed from some children during heart surgery - was not among the organs returned to parents whose children later died. He said they had been asking what had happened for 15 months.

"I don't think the removal of the gland can be criticised if it improves the outcome of surgery," Mr Cohen added. "The issue then becomes one of informed consent. My understanding is that, in relation to the local ethics guidance, explicit consent is required before an organ can be passed on to a pharmaceutical company.

"We have to ask what has the company used the organ for? We have been told that it has been used for a commercial venture, albeit an anti-rejection drug. If money was paid, what has happened to that money? We want to see the records and have full disclosure for that."

Dr Mark Caswell, clinical director of pathology at Alder Hey, said the hospital had thought it was important to help the production of the drug until 1993. "But in 1993 concerns arose over the commercial transaction and the supply was stopped," he added. "The glands are still removed but are now treated in same way as an appendix. They are not sold for any commercial gain.

"Parental consent was sought for the operations but not for the actual removal of the gland. It is unclear who initiated the contract but it was a widespread practice and Alder Hey was not the only hospital to supply pharmaceutical companies.

"I don't think parents were told but if these things were happening at the present time everything would be fully disclosed to parents and they would have the full authority. The glands were used to develop a drug used in the treatment of very ill children. If parents feel something causes further distress then we regret that. In retrospect the fact that there was a financial aspect involved should have been stressed to parents."

But the revelations, the way they have emerged and the medical profession's surprise that anybody should feel concern underlines that the issue of how hospitals treat human bodies is still far from settled.

James Underwood, the vice-president of the Royal College of Pathologists, said that a very wide range of human tissue was increasingly sought by drug companies for use in the manufacture of medicines and for testing new drugs. If unwanted human tissue, the detritus of operations, were not used, he pointed out, then there would be still more recourse to animal experimentation.

"It is something that happens all the time and increasingly because pharmaceutical companies and the developers of new technologies are all increasingly seeking the help of hospitals and doctors to get access to human tissue," he said.

The Nuffield Council on Bioethics produced a report in 1995 which recommends that no payment should be made, although hospitals must be reimbursed for their administrative expenses. It also stipulates that patients should be told what their tissue will be used for and asked for properly informed consent.

In practice, patients or their guardians sign a form agreeing to the use of tissue for research but they may not always have been fully told what that may entail.

The Medical Research Council is also working on guidelines, but the latest row is likely to lead to something with the force of law behind it. Opposition spokesmen yesterday called for the government to issue guidelines of its own.

Last night Aventis Pasteur issued a statement saying that an annual donation of less than £10 per waste fragment was made to the hospital's cardiac department to contribute towards expenses such as "nurses' training"and the fitting out of accommodation for parents.

Vital role in babies

The thymus is a small piece of lymphatic tissue that is crucial to the health of a newborn baby, but is pretty much surplus to requirements in an adult.

The flat organ, situated in front of the heart immediately below the breastbone, gained its name from its resemblance in shape to a thyme leaf. It plays a critical role in setting up the immune system of the baby to help it fight off infection and grows rapidly during the months in the womb and the first years of life, but after puberty it slowly starts to shrink.

If the thymus is removed from a newborn baby, the consequences are disastrous. The immune system fails and the baby falls prey to a gradual, fatal wasting disease. But after the first years of life, the thymus appears to have served its purpose.

The organ is no longer needed by its owner, but has proved to be of value to the pharmaceutical industry: anti-thymocyte globulins - lifesaving drugs used to prevent and treat acute rejection in transplantations - are produced from human thymus fragments.

Just days before the publication of a report on the removal and storage of hundreds of children's organs at Alder Hey without parents' knowledge, it emerged that supplies of the thymus gland, which is routinely removed during cardiac surgery to give better access to the heart, were regularly handed over to the pharmaceutical company Aventis Pasteur, in exchange for cash donations to the hospital. The tiny glands were used in the manufacture of a drug for aplastic anaemia. Alder Hey parents yesterday expressed their horror at the idea of money changing hands for body parts, no matter what the hospital's motivation might have been. They said they were appalled that the hospital would hand over human tissue without the explicit consent of the patients' parent or guardian. "This brings us right back to the issue of openness and informed consent," said Ed Bradley of the support group Pity II. "Pity II is not against research. But the hospital has ignored the families and not taken them into account at all." Had they been asked, he said, the parents would probably have agreed to use of the tissue. Ministers, alarmed at yet another escalation of the Alder Hey crisis, moved swiftly to condemn any exchange of cash for organs. "This is yet another piece of deeply distressing news for the parents of children treated at Alder Hey," the health secretary, Alan Milburn, said. However, he took pains to point out that, according to the hospital, it happened between 1991 and 1993, then stopped because of concerns among staff that accepting donations for organs might be unethical. "This was a particular practice which was happening in the early 90s at Alder Hey and, it seems, some other hospitals," he said. "The NHS already knows this practice of taking organs without consent is totally unacceptable to this government." The government would issue further guidance to the NHS, he said, hinting that it would form part of their response to the Alder Hey report, which is published next Tuesday. To the parents, the revelations are just one more betrayal by the hospital. They claim Alder Hey released damning information about the extent of its storage of organs with apparent reluctance and, in their eyes, only under pressure. Mr Bradley pointed to one contradiction in the dates - the hospital said thymus glands were passed to Aventis Pasteur between 1991 and 1993. The company dates it between 1989 and 1995. Ian Cohen, solicitor for the families, said they had noticed that the thymus gland - listed by Alder Hey as tissue removed from some children during heart surgery - was not among the organs returned to parents whose children later died. He said they had been asking what had happened for 15 months. "I don't think the removal of the gland can be criticised if it improves the outcome of surgery," Mr Cohen added. "The issue then becomes one of informed consent. My understanding is that, in relation to the local ethics guidance, explicit consent is required before an organ can be passed on to a pharmaceutical company. "We have to ask what has the company used the organ for? We have been told that it has been used for a commercial venture, albeit an anti-rejection drug. If money was paid, what has happened to that money? We want to see the records and have full disclosure for that." Dr Mark Caswell, clinical director of pathology at Alder Hey, said the hospital had thought it was important to help the production of the drug until 1993. "But in 1993 concerns arose over the commercial transaction and the supply was stopped," he added. "The glands are still removed but are now treated in same way as an appendix. They are not sold for any commercial gain. "Parental consent was sought for the operations but not for the actual removal of the gland. It is unclear who initiated the contract but it was a widespread practice and Alder Hey was not the only hospital to supply pharmaceutical companies. "I don't think parents were told but if these things were happening at the present time everything would be fully disclosed to parents and they would have the full authority. The glands were used to develop a drug used in the treatment of very ill children. If parents feel something causes further distress then we regret that. In retrospect the fact that there was a financial aspect involved should have been stressed to parents." But the revelations, the way they have emerged and the medical profession's surprise that anybody should feel concern underlines that the issue of how hospitals treat human bodies is still far from settled. James Underwood, the vice-president of the Royal College of Pathologists, said that a very wide range of human tissue was increasingly sought by drug companies for use in the manufacture of medicines and for testing new drugs. If unwanted human tissue, the detritus of operations, were not used, he pointed out, then there would be still more recourse to animal experimentation. "It is something that happens all the time and increasingly because pharmaceutical companies and the developers of new technologies are all increasingly seeking the help of hospitals and doctors to get access to human tissue," he said. The Nuffield Council on Bioethics produced a report in 1995 which recommends that no payment should be made, although hospitals must be reimbursed for their administrative expenses. It also stipulates that patients should be told what their tissue will be used for and asked for properly informed consent. In practice, patients or their guardians sign a form agreeing to the use of tissue for research but they may not always have been fully told what that may entail. The Medical Research Council is also working on guidelines, but the latest row is likely to lead to something with the force of law behind it. Opposition spokesmen yesterday called for the government to issue guidelines of its own. Last night Aventis Pasteur issued a statement saying that an annual donation of less than £10 per waste fragment was made to the hospital's cardiac department to contribute towards expenses such as "nurses' training"and the fitting out of accommodation for parents. Vital role in babies The thymus is a small piece of lymphatic tissue that is crucial to the health of a newborn baby, but is pretty much surplus to requirements in an adult. The flat organ, situated in front of the heart immediately below the breastbone, gained its name from its resemblance in shape to a thyme leaf. It plays a critical role in setting up the immune system of the baby to help it fight off infection and grows rapidly during the months in the womb and the first years of life, but after puberty it slowly starts to shrink. If the thymus is removed from a newborn baby, the consequences are disastrous. The immune system fails and the baby falls prey to a gradual, fatal wasting disease. But after the first years of life, the thymus appears to have served its purpose. The organ is no longer needed by its owner, but has proved to be of value to the pharmaceutical industry: anti-thymocyte globulins - lifesaving drugs used to prevent and treat acute rejection in transplantations - are produced from human thymus fragments.

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Corporate training
fields.standfirst: Karen Brown, a senior manager with PricewaterhouseCoopers, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Karen Brown, a senior manager with PricewaterhouseCoopers, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Although I trained as a chartered accountant and did two years undertaking audits, it was a move into tax consulting and a brief secondment to the training department that set me on the career I have now.

Today I'm responsible for training our staff in international corporate tax across Europe. My role in the process is mostly one of consultant. I discuss with our business leaders what the performance needs are, advise them on how to structure a course or conference, then help run it.

The challenge at PricewaterhouseCoopers is to offer our global clients a high-quality, consistent service in each of the countries and offices that they operate. A multinational company using two of our offices in separate countries expects each to know what the other is doing - the training department is an important tool in making sure that happens. Mostly it's about improving the way the business communicates with itself - sharing high-quality ideas and good practice.

To this end, I run around 10 courses a year across Europe all of which are conducted in English and attended by around 40 people. Although I don't give many of the presentations myself, I usually chair the events and am on hand to advise the speakers. On top of that, I will also be involved in the running of five or six specialist industry events - again mostly in Europe.

An increasingly important part of my job is to see how technology can be used to develop good-quality training that can be used at people's desks. I spent a good deal of last year working on the creation of an intranet-based package that will deliver training on the principles of international tax to anyone in the world with a CD drive or access to the internet. While it's challenging and interesting to work with new media, it's also how we will deliver more training in the future.

While I love the job, too much travel is not great. I spent my last birthday in a fog-bound Paris airport while my friends had dinner without me. The thing I enjoy most is the fact that I am able to help create opportunities for people to develop - although the process can take much longer than I first think.

I am often working with some of the business's most dynamic people, which is stimulating - plus it also gives me a view of the bigger picture which I would probably lack working as a tax consultant.

webTitle: Help: I must be worth more than this!

fields.headline: Help: I must be worth more than this!
fields.standfirst: After six weeks in my first job, I'm starting to feel resentful about my salary. It seems poor considering I have a good degree and am expected to take on quite a bit of responsibility.  AM, marketing assistant, Sheffield
fields.trailText: After six weeks in my first job, I'm starting to feel resentful about my salary
fields.body:
As you decided to take the job knowing what it paid, you're not in a strong position to negotiate changes. It's wrong to assume that because you have a particular level of qualification you are worth more. A college course might represent better training for this type of work than your degree.

Your qualifications are not irrelevant, but less relevant than what you can actually do. To make a convincing case for extra reward you must show that you're adding value in a unique way.

It's probably too soon to do that effectively now. Give it at least six months, then arrange a review meeting. In the meantime, concentrate on working in such a way that you will have no difficulty convincing your employer you are worth more than they originally offered. Don't become resentful or negative. Remember you are gaining too. This is going to give you a leg up to your next, better-paid post within this company or for someone else.

The additions it will enable you to make to your CV will place you in a stronger bargaining position - it's always easier to find a new job when you're in work.

What you're missing out on financially you're making up for in experience. That's not a situation you can put up with indefinitely, but choose to view it as a temporary phase that's a step towards a more lucrative future.

ijk@excite.com

webTitle: Discover that raft of possibilities - especially when you go to summer camp

fields.headline: Discover that raft of possibilities - especially when you go to summer camp
fields.standfirst: Give your CV a boost this year
fields.trailText: Give your CV a boost this year
fields.body:
Standing on a snowy campus in January, it's probably difficult to imagine the summer will ever arrive. However, before you can say creme de menthe, the student bar will be selling off the dregs, the sun will have made its two-week appearance and the long vacation will be upon us. It's summer job time.

For students, the summer break has always represented something of a dilemma. Why would you want to be stuck in the offices of a city law firm, when you could be inter-railing around Europe or picking fruit in southern Spain?

Of course, the simple answer is you wouldn't. But with the graduate job market becoming ever more competitive, you've got to ask what's going to look better on your CV - two months' serious work experience or an intimate knowledge of apricots.

But while you are finding it hard to get excited about something so far away, remember lots of companies have a strict number of students they are prepared to offer work experience, and it will usually be done on a first come, first served basis. To get anything decent, you've got to act now.

A trawl through The Guardian 's job pages reveals many of the traditional employers of students - companies like Camp America or Bunac - are already advertising for this summer's intake.

Camp America and the like are considered a good first-year vacation job. The basic principle is you work three months in summer schools living with and teaching kids, collect your $500-ish and spend the last few weeks rushing around the United States with your new-found friends.

"It does look good on your CV," says ex-Southampton student Vicky Pateman, who now markets Camp America. "It shows you've got a bit of initiative and that you can work as part of a team. What's more, it's fun."

Make it into the second year and the general consensus is that the summer job should reflect your degree. Sam Haslem is in his second year of a graphics design course at the University of Central Lancashire in Preston and has worked for London-based design agency Iris during several college holidays.

"A friend who worked there knew I was available and at the time they were very busy. As well as giving me some good experience, it taught me very quickly what it is like to work in the commercial environment. Instead of having a month to do a piece of work as at college, I found I had just a day," he says.

Haslem was lucky enough to be earning £250 a week but says that, having done it, he might have worked there for expenses alone. "If you had asked me before I had started whether I would have done it without pay, I'd probably have said no. Having been there, I think I would. I learned lots of new computer skills - and they've indicated they may offer me a job when I finish, which would be great."

However, for those who don't give inter-railing a second thought, several large companies offer summer placements - although be prepared to fight to get a place as these are heavily over-subscribed. Every year Barclays Bank selects around 40 students to attend its eight-week programme and pays them £350 a week.

"We take students in the penultimate year of study to try to find some of the best with a view to getting them onto our graduate programme once they leave," says Nikki Kerlogue, marketing manager of Barclays graduate recruitment programme.

"It starts with a three-day residential induction course which includes some skills training. We always try to place the students in a business area that interests them and they are usually aligned to a manager who has come through the graduate programme themselves.

"The idea is that they become part of a team that is working on a project and they are set what we hope are challenging goals and objectives.

"It's as much a chance to let them have a look at us. We partly run the summer scheme to encourage some good PR back on campuses. Barclays has an image of being rather traditional, and while we do offer traditional banking services, we operate in many other areas, such as internet banking, that we are trying to promote to the graduates as areas to work in," she says.

But, be warned. Last year 2,000 students applied for the precious 40 places and Kerlogue says the selection process is almost as tough as for the full-time 100-150 graduate positions the bank fills every year. However if you make it and have a successful summer, the chances of getting that final job are excellent, as a "good proportion" of those undertaking the summer scheme end up being offered full-time jobs.

webTitle: How to... support the weakest link in your team

fields.headline: How to... support the weakest link in your team
fields.standfirst: Quiz them on what you can do to help
fields.trailText: Quiz them on what you can do to help
fields.body:
A good, well-balanced work team is like a happy family - that is, it's beset by petty arguments, occasional personality clashes and painful Christmas dinners, but individual members couldn't manage without each other. And, as long as each person does what's expected of them and plays their part to the best of their abilities, the cogs keep turning smoothly.

Everybody has off-days, when the simplest tasks seem impossible, you can't concentrate or can't be bothered. It's when a colleague's off-days turn into off-weeks, then off-months, that warning bells begin to sound.

"High-performance teams have clear standards of what is acceptable behaviour," says Elisabeth Marx, a director at executive search firm, Norman Broadbent. "If the rest of the team perceives that one person isn't pulling their weight or is incompetent, it affects everybody. It drags down morale, impedes motivation and builds up resentment. Other team members start to think: 'If they're not bothering, why should I?'."

That's what happened in Ian Burnett's team. Ian, a graphic designer in a small creative studio, loved his job, got on well with his team-mates and enjoyed the jovial atmosphere in his office.

Until, that is, his colleague Simon, began to let the side down. "He made lots of silly mistakes that created extra work for the rest of us," recalls Ian. He was disorganised and careless. Team morale really started to suffer when new computer equipment was installed and Simon simply couldn't get to grips with the software.

"Everybody liked him, but we lost respect for him. Eventually, other

designers began to resent covering up for his shoddy work and moaned about him behind his back. He was obviously unhappy - which made his performance even worse - but the way he dealt with it was by joking around. Things came to a head when one of the senior designers wrote out a letter of resignation. He said to our boss: 'If he doesn't go, I'll go'."

In an ideal world, any problems within your team would be noticed and dealt with by your manager. Sadly, as in Ian's case, that doesn't always happen. "In many cases it's more likely that colleagues, not the manager, pick up on the fact that someone's in trouble," says Dr Marx.

"Problems arise in companies where there is a blame culture," says Angela Baron, adviser for the Charetered Institute of Personnel and Development. "In good teams the members will recognise when someone's struggling, they'll feel able to ask for help and the whole team will rally round them. If they don't realise they're in trouble, other members should be able to point out where they're going wrong and help them put it right."

So, while the simplest solution might well be to don a red wig, vote out the offending member of your team and declare: "You are the weakest link, goodbye", it wouldn't be fair, legal or necessarily the best thing for your team.

"You need to find out the reason for your colleague's non-performance,"

says Dr Marx. "There could be a straightforward explanation for their inability to pull their weight, something which can be resolved."

If someone has suddenly stopped performing, become withdrawn or lacks motivation, it could be due to a personal problem. Your colleague may not wish to share the finer details with the team but, given time and space, should get back on track. They'll need sensitivity, support and understanding - and may need to be carried for a while.

Then again, their ineptitude could just be down to lack of experience or confidence: "Everyone needs experience to be effective," says Angela Baron. "You shouldn't try to push them out without giving them the chance to improve. Encourage them to take advantage of training, coaching or mentoring schemes within your company. If they actually want to be an effective team member, they'll make the effort to get up to standard."

If you don't remember anything else...
Ultimately, you may discover your colleague just isn't up to the job; either they were a poor recruitment choice, or will simply never be able - or have any desire - to fit in with the rest of the team. At this point, Angela Baron says it's time for your manager or team leader to step in and reassess their future.

Don't gossip about them behind their back or offer to help them clear their desk. Chances are they already know things haven't worked out and over-sympathetic looks will grate. Just wish them well, cross your fingers and pray that whoever replaces them is a superstar.

By the time Simon's manager intervened, he'd lost too much confidence to take advantage of training courses. He decided to jump before he was pushed and found himself a new job. "Last thing I heard, Simon was really happy and had been promoted," says Ian. "Nobody feels bitter or embarrassed anymore. In fact, we met up for a drink recently and he said leaving was the best thing he could have done."

fields.headline: Parlezvous interview speak?
fields.standfirst: Learn the lingo and - bingo!
fields.trailText: Learn the lingo and - bingo!
fields.body:
Do you think outside the box? If so, what are you competencies? Can you 'add value'? And, most importantly, can you work outside your 'comfort zone'?

If your answer to any of the above questions is a confused expression and a total inability to understand the question, let alone answer it, then it's time to polish up your interview-speak. Gone are the days of being asked about your good and bad qualities; these days, interviews are jargon-heavy and to have any chance of success you have to learn the lingo.

"If you're going to your first set of serious interviews, make sure you're up with the latest phrases," says Anne Hollier, consultant at the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development. "Don't expect to be asked about your skills. Instead you will need to be able to talk about your core competencies. Don't say that you're a flexible person, but that you're happy to work outside your comfort zone. It might sound pretentious, but it's important to appear au fait with the way your chosen industry is defining itself - particularly with fields such as IT and new media."

It might sound trivial, but being unaware of phrases in everyday use in a particular industry shows a lack of research, which most interviewers view very negatively. "There is a huge amount of information out there these days - on every industry imaginable," believes Richard Newman, who runs the IT test team for a large telecommunications company. "There's simply no excuse for going into an interview uninformed - it's one of the things that instantly puts me off a candidate - it smacks of not making an effort."

According to Penny Hackett, author of The Selection Interview , all interviewers want to hear a solid reason as to why you have chosen their company. "Most interviewers will ask why you have chosen to apply to their company and it's imperative to have an answer that is more than simply needing the money. Think about what appeals to you about the organisation - its aims or values system, and work that into your answer. Try to make it personal to you, rather than a general platitude about the company."

Of course, it may be possible that you do simply want the job for the money or as a stop-gap until something better comes along. There's nothing wrong with taking a job for those reasons, but if an employer can see too clearly that this is your only motivation, they will rarely offer you a position. "I have interviewed people who are clearly only in it for the money, as a temporary job - and it always shows," says Deborah Jones, advertising sales director for a radio station. "They rarely have questions about the company, and have little enthusiasm. However much I like them, I won't employ them - it simply isn't worth my while."

It can be hard to give a really good interview performance if the position is not your dream job, but you can motivate yourself by being determined to be offered the job, even if you turn it down. All interview experience is good experience - and any job offer is bound to increase your confidence. Dressing up your motivation is one thing, but remember to steer clear of any kind of dishonesty anywhere in the interview process.

"If you lie in an interview process you will invariably be caught out," says Noel Morgan, consultant at the Institute of Management. "However tempting it might seem, never lie on your CV. Employers rely on CVs as a primary source of information about potential candidates; if at the interview you cannot back up what is on your CV, you will instantly have lost any chance of getting the job. Honesty in the interview is equally important; if you don't have that much relevant experience then say so - but temper it with an example of a situation where you have used a skill that would be relevant to the job."

Deborah Jones adds: "Candidates often worry if they don't feel they have enough experience, but enthusiasm and a good understanding of the industry can be just as important. If there is an interviewee who may not have done similar work before, but is excited by the prospect of learning new things and who displays an ability to think quickly and calmly, then I may well offer them the job."

Often the most difficult aspect of an interview is getting your point across - how long to talk for or how much detail to get into. If an interviewer interrupts you mid-flow it can be hard not to take it negatively, but according to Penny Hackett, this isn't always the case. "Bear in mind that interviewers are tight on time - if they do interrupt you, it may mean they just want to speed things up.

"Try to focus on the question you are answering. It may be possible to display a skill - say, resilience in a crisis - that happened whilst you were backpacking round Africa, but remember that the interviewer doesn't want, or need, to hear all the details of the trip."

Ten or fifteen years ago it might have been unthinkable to use an anecdote from a holiday to display a work-related skill but, like most aspects of working life, the interview process has undergone deep-seated change in recent years. "It's no longer about relevant experience or starting at the bottom and working up," says Noel Morgan. "With all the new technology the job market is changing constantly and new skills are required - interviewers look for technical knowledge, but also innovative thinkers, people who can cope with change and are not unsettled by it."

The old clichés still hold true; polish your shoes, wear neutral, smart clothes, be on time - the importance of a good first impression is something that hasn't changed. "It might sound intimidating, but I generally make a decision in the first three minutes," says Richard Newman. "I may go on to change it, but in those first few moments you take so much in. I'm probably nervous, my senses are heightened, and you do get an instant feeling for the person - whether they appear positive, how they look, whether they are confident or defensive."

If that sounds worrying then take heart; interviews have never been more flexible or interviewers more free-thinking than they are today. The internet means that research is easier - no longer any need to get the dress code wrong; simply check out the company's website. "Interviews are far less predictable than they used to be," says Anne Hollier. "And if you've done thorough research, planned some responses, and stay focused then they really can be fun."

fields.headline: Pinochet tied to massacre
fields.trailText: Within hours of being directly implicated in a massacre, the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet was taken to the military hospital in Santiago yesterday suffering symptoms similar to a stroke.
fields.body:
Within hours of being directly implicated in a massacre, the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet was taken to the military hospital in Santiago yesterday suffering symptoms similar to a stroke.

General Pinochet, 85, was said to have temporarily blacked out and to be suffering from high blood pressure. He was accompanied by his family and the army commander, Ricardo Izurieta.

The accusation was made on Thursday evening by retired General Joaquin Lagos Osorio, who commanded the third army division at the time of the 1973 military coup which took Gen Pinochet to power.

He described what he said was Gen Pinochet's role in the massacres carried out by the military unit known as the "Caravan of Death", which went to the region Gen Lagos commanded soon after the coup. The taskforce toured several cities, dragging 75 political prisoners from jail and killing them.

Earlier in the week Gen Pinochet sought to implicate Gen Lagos in the affair, telling the judge investigating the case "I am not a criminal", and proceeding to blame Gen Lagos and his regional commanders for the crimes.

Gen Lagos's response, in a midnight interview on government-run Television Nacional, was full of specific allegations about Gen Pinochet's involvement and grisly details of how the murders were done.

Since 1973 Gen Lagos has kept a list of prisoners on which, he said, Gen Pinochet had personally noted which ones should be executed.

"In the last conversation I had with Pinochet, he did something I never expected. He ordered me to 'Never mention the list', and for me to sign it. In that case, I would be the only one responsible, as the crimes were committed in my jurisdiction.

"I told him that, and he said he would fix it. I said, 'What are you going to fix? They are all dead!' "

Gen Lagos proceeded to detail the crimes, insisting that they were committed by a hit squad acting on the personal orders of Gen Pinochet.

"They were torn apart. They were no longer human bodies. I wanted to at least put the bodies back together again, to leave them more decent, but you couldn't.

"They cut eyes out with daggers. They broke their jaws and legs."

Even when a firing squad was used, he said, it killed the prisoners slowly.

"They shot them to pieces, first the legs, then the sexual organs, then the heart, all with machine guns."

Gen Pinochet's admission to hospital coincides with a plan by the army to reinforce security there, to shield the former leader from the investigations of Judge Juan Guzman.

The Hospital Militar has repeatedly been used as a refuge for Chilean officers charged with human rights abuses during the 1973-90 regime.

fields.headline: Fawsley Hall, Daventry
fields.trailText: This magical building, a glorious mix of Tudor, Victorian and Georgian architectural styles, rises up in the middle of nowhere.
fields.body:
Address: Fawsley, near Daventry, Northamptonshire, NN11 3BA.
Reservations: 01327 892000.
Web Address: www.prideofbritainhotels.com
E-mail: fawsley@compuserve.com

First impressions This magical building, a glorious mix of Tudor, Victorian and Georgian architectural styles, rises up in the middle of nowhere. Alice in Wonderland manicured gardens edge on to rolling fields. Inside, it's baronial yet welcoming.

What are the rooms like? Ours was Tudor and big enough to play a game of croquet in. Exposed stone walls, wood beams and leaded windows - this is a room you won't want to leave. In fact don't - room service is lightning quick, so have breakfast in bed.

The bed test Antique, hand-painted cream-and-blue four-poster that is fit for a queen - Elizabeth 1 stayed here in 1575.

The bathroom test Huge with arched windows facing the gardens (remember to pull the blinds). Original Tudor features mix with chrome and white modern facilities.

The restaurant Elegant yet intimate. Everything from the spicy home-roasted almonds in the bar to pre-dinner canapés (foie gras mousse) and the tartare of hand-dived scallop and sevruga caviar is served with imagination and flair. The set menu of two courses for £23.95 is a good option.

The lounge The Great Hall is the highlight of the hotel. Cathedral-like arched ceiling, roaring fires and an abundance of candles make it a perfect setting to take cigars and vintage port. The only thing missing is Mr Darcy warming his breeches by the hearth.

What is there to see within walking distance Ramble through the fields and woodland of the Knightly Way to the idyllic Windmill pub at Badby for a pint of Flowers.

How much a night? A two-night Fawsley Weekender break, including dinner, B&B starts from £99pp per night.

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: Insider's advice for those heading to the slopes
fields.body:
 Skiers who swallow half an aspirin to prevent their blood thickening in high altitude resorts take note - there is a down side. Last week in Italy, a colleague who had been taking the junior version of the pill to counter another potential medical problem, fell on a hard-packed black run and gashed a cheek deeply enough to need stitches. It proved impossible to staunch the profuse flow of blood either on the slope or on the stretcher, en route to a clinic. This is not to suggest that taking aspirin is a bad idea - it is thought that the release of nitrogen into the blood at altitude, where pressure reduces, creates small bubbles which may cause it to clot. Rather, my colleague's plight served as a reminder that it is not a bad idea to ski with rudimentary first-aid essentials in a back pack or a bum bag such as gauze pads, which could have been used to apply pressure to the wound.

 More than half (56%) of all holidaymakers taking part in risky sports neglect to read the small print of their travel insur ance polices, claims American Express. It notes that you should ensure, for example, that the policy will pay for rescue from the mountain. Buyers of Amex's Centurion insurance would do well to check its small print. The policy does not cover them for some activities, including heliskiing, unless they pay a supplement.

 For skiers making their own way to the Alps, Travel Deals (0845 399 3900) is offering three-night breaks in Morzine for £147 and seven nights for £199. The price includes transfers to and from Geneva airport or the nearest station and half-board at a chalet. The deals run until late April.

 California's Lake Tahoe area is a great place to sample a cocktail of resorts. If you can get away by February 9, Ski Safari (020-7740 1221) is offering scheduled flights from London, a rental car and a week at the Viking Motor Lodge in South Lake Tahoe, which is linked by a new gondola lift to the ski area of Heavenly, for £479 - a reduction of £100 from the brochure. Accommodation is on a room-only basis but there are coffee and doughnuts for breakfast. Heavenly has excellent intermediate and tree skiing. Other resorts within easy reach are Squaw Valley, Kirkwood and Alpine Meadows.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Housing court case

fields.headline: Couple get benefit of doubt
fields.trailText: A hard-fought court case brought by Brixton couple Rizwan Ali Bhai and Cathy Cabare may have set a precedent from which thousands of housing association tenants benefit.
fields.body:
A hard-fought court case brought by Brixton couple Rizwan Ali Bhai and Cathy Cabare may have set a precedent from which thousands of housing association tenants benefit.

The couple had rented their Brixton home for about 12 years when, in 1997, they told their landlord, the Black Roofs Housing Association, that they wished to exercise their right to buy.

Black Roofs had stopped being a mutual housing association in 1991. The change in legal status meant that the couple were deprived of that right. The Housing Act 1988 provides that "secure" tenants, usually those of local authorities, mutual housing associations or other landlords, have the right to buy the property at a discount after a period of tenancy.

A non-mutual housing association is, however, treated as a private landlord. Mr Ali Bhai and Ms Cabare were particularly incensed by the refusal as Black Roofs had given assurances at the time of demutualisation that tenants would be allowed to buy their homes. A change of management, however, meant a reversal of policy.

After an arbitrator and then a county court judge had found in favour of the association, the Court of Appeal reversed the decision. It decided that obscure words in a Schedule to the Housing Act meant that existing secure tenants were not deprived of their rights when the housing associations demutualise.

Although the couple won, they have been left with a legal bill almost as great as what they gained. "Because we put our notice of appeal in late, Black Roofs tried to get our appeal disallowed. It changed its mind but made us agree to pay its wasted cost," said Mr Ali Bhai. The association is now trying to foist a high bill for £7,000 on to the couple. They had hoped the Department of the Environment would fund the appeal, but it has limited its contribution to £2,900.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Drug family that fuelled resort's deadly habit

fields.headline: Drug family that fuelled resort's deadly habit
fields.standfirst: They might have been polite and well-mannered, but Brighton's most feared dynasty was still undone by lethal addiction
fields.trailText: They might have been polite and well-mannered, but Brighton's most feared dynasty was still undone by lethal addiction
fields.body:
They remember the Comptons on the Moulsecoomb estate: Ronald, Margaret and their four sons, Ronald jnr, Stephen, Sean and Robert. The family hasn't lived there for 10 years, but mention of it has the effect of a sudden draught, sucking shut doors, delivering a bolt down the spine.

"Look at me, I'm shaking," said a resident last week, reminded of the family by news that four of the Compton men had been sentenced to join the fifth in prison. "They were polite and well mannered, but it's what they brought into the neighbourhood. They moved on and they left the problem here."

The problem was heroin. At Hove crown court in east Sussex last week, Judge Anthony Scott-Gall ruled that the Compton family business was a "vile and wicked trade" of sufficient reach to warrant sentences totalling 21 years.

The father, Ronald snr, 58, was convicted of drug trafficking. His "lieutenants" Stephen, 38, and Sean, 28, were convicted of conspiracy to supply drugs, and Robert, 36, was found guilty of possessing cash proceeds from drug trafficking. The eldest son, Ronald jnr, 39, is two years into an eight-year sentence for possessing heroin with intent to supply.

"They like to think of themselves as loveable rogues," said Detective Inspector Paul Grundy, who lead the inquiry. "But they are not. They are dealers in death."

The rise of the Compton family from the privations of Moulsecoomb to the mansions of Brighton's Tongdean neighbourhood is set against the decline of the addicts they supplied. Brighton and Hove has the highest number of heroin-related deaths of any region in the country. In 1999, the figure was over 35; by last June that record had already been beaten.

"It is easier to get a bag of heroin than a cup of tea in Brighton," said Neil Ansell, regional manager of the Big Issue. "Heroin is more available than cannabis. I know of several people who have died of overdoses since the beginning of January."

"It is recognised that seaside resorts attract an itinerant population of people with social problems," said a spokeswoman for Addaction, the needle exchange and counselling service which since last May has registered an average of 55 addicts a month. To indicate the extent of Brighton's drugs trade, the number of addicts registering at the service's east London branch, is only 40-45 a month. Into this scene came the Comptons, who over two decades would make an estimated £3m from the heroin trade. It is a commonplace of drug dealing that the higher up the supply chain you operate, the less likely you are to be drug-using yourself. The remarkable thing about the Comptons is that despite their seniority, as heroin wholesalers, members of the family were themselves taking drugs and to an extent that threatened to destroy them.

Salutary effect

In 1993, Robert Compton's wife Alison died from a heroin-related illness; Stephen Compton's partner Jacky died after an overdose of amphetamines. When Sean and Sasha Compton's baby girl was born, it was with an opiate addiction from which she is just now recovering. "I hope that fact had a salutary effect on you," said Judge Scott-Gall while sentencing Sean to four and a half years' imprisonment. Sasha Compton sobbed before retreating to her six bedroom, mock-Tudor house with intercom and video entry facilities.

The family business started three miles from the genteel lanes of Tongdean, in Brighton's Moulsecoomb estate, a district marked by the unhappy juxtaposition of frightened pensioners in well-kept houses with squalid dealers' homes bearing the scars of serial efforts to kick the doors in. The police have intelligence tracing the Compton family business back 15 years, to when the sons were teenagers and Ronald snr described himself as an antiques dealer. They did not operate on a grand scale. "It made me laugh when they described Stephen as the 'banker' in the family," said a former neighbour, still fearful enough of recriminations to withhold his name. "I remember seeing him dealing in broad daylight right outside the shop. But they were a great deal better than what came in after them."

As the sons grew up, they acquired nominal trades for themselves: Robert was a "jewellery dealer"; Sean, despite the mansion and Mercedes he later purchased, identified himself as a "handyman"; Stephen followed his father into the "antiques business".

As the dynasty grew and a steady supply of heroin was secured from London and Liverpool, the Compton parents moved to Woodingdean, a quiet hilltop area overlooking the sea, where Margaret Compton still lives. They began investing in property under the name Comptons of Brighton. Margaret Compton opened a florists in the city centre. "I did well," she said last week, still maintaining the innocence if not of her husband (he pleaded guilty to charges of trafficking), then at least of her sons. "We paid £89,000 for this house and we've got a mortgage like anyone else. I had a car on hire purchase - now if I was rolling in all this drugs money, why would I do that?"

The evidence collated by the intelligence branch of the Sussex police was incontrovertible, however. When Ronald jnr's home was raided three years ago, police found 60kg of cannabis resin with a street value of between £90,000 and £144,000. They also recovered £13,750 worth of heroin.

A year later, under Operation Sun Spot, 50 officers raided the rest of the family's homes and recovered 1.2kg of heroin worth £50,000 and a stash of £170,000, most of it stuffed into tins of instant potato mix or hidden under floorboards. The ripple effect this bust has had on crime figures in Brighton is difficult to quantify. "There will be a void," said Det Insp Grundy, pointing to Home Office figures which indicate that 1kg of heroin generates 220 victims of burglary and £220,000 worth of stolen property, and that each addicted offender executes somewhere in the region of 100 crimes a month.

Drugs charities in Brighton, while applauding police efforts, were slightly more cautious. "We haven't seen a dip yet," said a spokeswoman for Addaction. "There is no evidence that our clients are finding it more difficult to get supplies. They would be visibly suffering if that were the case. "We are coordinating with the health authority, the police and drugs charities to form a consistent approach, and ensure that action taken against dealers is not in conflict with the rehabilitation of users." The team is also working with Brighton schools to send in ex-addicts to talk to pupils about the dangers of drug taking.

Charges of trafficking against her remain on police files and the authorities are seeking to recover the rest of the money made from the business. "He did a bad thing and he paid for it," she said of her husband, before driving the three miles to her daughter-in-law Sasha's house, to help with the newly fatherless grandchildren.

webTitle: Scotland creates a new north-south divide

fields.headline: Scotland creates a new north-south divide
fields.standfirst: Free care for pensioners and a 21% rise for teachers pose a big challenge to Westminster
fields.trailText: Free care for pensioners and a 21% rise for teachers pose a big challenge to Westminster.
fields.body:
Devolution is drawing an indelible line across the UK. On one side students pay tuition fees, the teaching profession is in crisis, and many of the frail and elderly must pay to help meet the costs of their care. On the other there are no tuition fees, teachers have won a 21.5% pay deal, and now it looks as though all pensioners will enjoy free long-term care.

Scottish executive proposals to fund long-term care for all pensioners has opened up the biggest policy divide yet between Holyrood and Westminster, and raised the spectre of a two-tier UK society split along the Scotland-England border.

Yesterday, as pressure grew on the UK government to follow Scotland's lead, there were warnings that Labour risked losing the grey vote over the issue, and predictions that Scotland could become a giant nursing home as pensioners rushed north to take advantage of any better deal.

Sir Stewart Sutherland, who chaired the royal commission which recommended free personal care for the elderly, said he believed its introduction in England and Wales was now inevitable. But the health minister, John Hutton, ruled out any policy reversal in England and Wales, where nursing care is free but personal care is means-tested.

"Devolution means that it is for the Scottish parliament to make decisions on its response to the royal commission on long-term care," he said. "Both the government and the Scottish executive are committed to improving health and social care services for older people, but we are doing this in different ways."

Analysts say the government and the public have to accept that Scotland can follow a different path, however awkward it might prove. "This is exactly what the Scottish parliament was designed to do," said Malcolm Dickson, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "It was designed to take decisions that reflected the broadest strand of public opinion.

"But it is an embarrassment for Labour in the run-up to a general election and following on from tuition fees and the teachers' deal. What the Scottish parliament has done is provide a stick with which to beat the party. People will say if it's good for Scotland why is it not good for the rest of the UK? But this is something the political parties need to get used to in a post-devolution situation."

Downing Street may have been spared some difficulty by the fact that the Scottish executive will not reveal the detail of its proposals or take a final decision until August.

Yesterday, the Scottish National party and the Conservatives demanded clarification of the executive's apparent commitment on free long-term care, but the first minister Henry McLeish would not comment further. However, the Liberal Democrats, whose rebellion forced Mr McLeish to rethink his earlier refusal to fund all long-term care, said the executive's position was unequivocal.

Enormous impact

Public policy experts say this will have an enormous social impact across the UK. "This is absolutely huge," said Allyson Pollock, chair of the school of public policy at University College London. "It is really a triumph for Scotland if they really do go down this road. Over the last 20 to 30 years a lot of care has been shifted to being a personal responsilbity and what the Scottish parliament is saying is that care is now a universal collective responsiblity."

Professor Pollok said the issue would shine a light on the "covert privatisation" of the health service in England and Wales. "You have to ask why in England we are shunting more and more care into the unregulated private sector," she said.

Teachers leaders have already warned that a recent 21.5% three-year pay deal for Scottish teachers will cause deep discontent south of the border.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, has said schools in England could find it even harder to attract teachers. "I think morale of teachers in England and Wales will be severely depressed if they do not get at least equal treatment." Pensioners' groups in England have also warned that there will be great anger and bitterness if Scotland's elderly get a substantially better deal, but warnings that Scotland wll be colonised by middle class English pensioners have been dismissed.

John Curtice, a political analyst at Strathlclyde University, whose elderly mother lives in Cornwall, said: "At the point which people need that kind of care the last thing they are going to be capable of doing is making a long-distance, long-term move."

Others say the biggest question raised by the care issue is how Scotland can afford to be so generous. The country has traditionally enjoyed a favourable slice of public funds in its £17bn budget, some 25% higher per head than the rest of the UK.

Some analysts say the care issue will increase pressure for a complete review of funding, but economist Arthur Midwinter says Scotland has an appropriate share for its level of need and can afford the £110m cost of universal free care.

"If it's a priority they can find the money," he said. "I don't see any difficulty in funding it. They might have to adjust some of their other programmes, but they won't need to put up the tartan tax to do this."

Mr Curtice, however, said much of the unease at this latest policy departure comes not from Scotland's ability to pay for it but the process that allowed it to happen.

"It illustrates the impact of PR and the different power balance from Westminster," he said. "What is shows is that, boy, oh boy, haven't we got a different parliament up here."

fields.headline: Made in Scotland
fields.standfirst: The merit of doing things differently
fields.trailText: The probability that older people will need long-term nursing care is about one in five for men, one in three for women. But no one knows in advance just who will be stricken with Alzheimer's or dementia, nor the trade-in value of their home, if they own one.
fields.body:
The probability that older people will need long-term nursing care is about one in five for men, one in three for women. But no one knows in advance just who will be stricken with Alzheimer's or dementia, nor the trade-in value of their home, if they own one. Here is a shining example of an insurable risk which the private finance market is incompetent to cover. It is a job for the state. Only public authority can compel universal contributions, pool risk and, way into the future, fairly distribute resources to ensure no one in need is left exposed.

Thanks to devolution, there is now within the United Kingdom more than one state to try such a policy. The UK, moreover, has a constituent state in which social democracy is strong and, perhaps, tolerance higher for the tax or enforced contributions that free long-term care would require. It is, of course, Scotland. Response to the announcement by first minister Henry McLeish of the Edinburgh coalition's plans on long-term care has been: how audacious! They are daring to implement Sutherland - the royal commission that two years ago proposed splitting nursing from the hotel aspects of care so that elderly people cared for at home or in "homes" would no longer pay for nursing, as they do if admitted to an NHS hospital. The recommendation has now been accepted by the Scottish executive, at least in principle - details, timing and costs yet to be supplied. By implication the extra spending - £110m a year - would be found by making savings elsewhere in Scotland's budget (not as hard as it sounds, given that social policy costs there are well above need as denominated on a UK-wide basis).

Fiscal harmonisers might be shocked, but has Scotland really been bold? It is not just that Mr McLeish had to cook up a formula on Thursday to head off a parliamentary revolt, leaving himself room to dodge and weave later. Coalition is a work in progress and give a little, take a little is no bad motto for government everywhere. It is rather that Labour ministers in Scotland seem so reluctant to teach Westminster - effectively, their fellow countryman Gordon Brown - that the point of devolution is the room it makes for deviation on tax and spend. Scottish Labour leaders keep looking over their shoulders at how London will react. Instead they should be exploring the elastic bounds of the new constitutional settlement. Scottish voters have to be told they can now have generous and universal social services but their tax rates will need to be higher or more progressive than in England.

Lord Lipsey, a dissenting member of Sutherland, predicts queues of cars at the border as the English middle class rush north with granny in the back to be left on the doorstep of Dundee social services. It is unlikely. Social dumping would not happen at all if Scotland seized the freedom it now enjoys to try a made-and-paid-in-Scotland remedy for this growing problem of social provision.

webTitle: Alternative views find their place in the sun

fields.headline: Alternative views find their place in the sun
fields.standfirst:
We're not here to torch Davos, say organisers

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: We're not here to torch Davos, say organisers.
fields.body:
It's about as far from Davos as you can get, politically, socially and geographically. But the first World Social Forum, which opened this week in Brazil, has the same focus: "The future of economic neoliberalism."

Timed to coincide with its Swiss counterpart, the anti-Davos meeting aims to become an annual fixture to study and propose alternatives to globalisation. More than 4,000 delegates from 120 countries are attending the forum, including some high profile intellectuals and activists concerned with the effects of globalisation on the world's poor.

The five-day conference aims to provide the global anti-capitalist movement with an intellectual and practical reference point. Its fundamental ideas are well known, and include taxation of speculative capital, the end of tax havens, the complete cancellation of third world debt, and total opposition to liberalising agricultural markets.

Heavyweights due to appear include Portuguese Nobel literature laureate Jose Saramago, Uruguayan political writer Eduardo Galeano, Danielle Mitterrand, wife of the late French president, and the Chilean writer, Ariel Dorfman.

Brazil was considered the best host for the meeting because of its variety of social movements and experiments. As if to reinforce the point, more than 1,000 members of one of the organising groups, the Movement of Landless Rural Workers, invaded Monsanto's nearby biotech plant on Thursday night.

Porto Alegre, capital of the southernmost Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul, was chosen as the location partly because of a sympathetic local government - which contributed about £350,000. In his opening speech, Olivio Dutra, the state governor, said: "The World Social Forum is the opportunity we need to rescue history's most valuable asset: solidarity. It is the tool we need to assure ethics in politics and democracy in social action."

Organisers were keen to stress that the forum was not about concepts like left- or rightwing.

James Cavallaro, director of Global Justice, one of the eight groups on the organising committee, said it reflected a change in the global human rights movement. "The idea is not to torch Davos," he said.

Yesterday's first day of workshops kicked off with a talk on democracy by former Algerian President Ahmed Ben Bella. There were dozens of sessions on the student movement, disarmament, the environment, trade unions and other issues.

Bernard Cassenan, editor of the monthly Le Monde Diplomatique and one of the forum's organisers, said the meeting was just "the beginning of a process. Next year it will be much, much, bigger".
