webTitle: Nuclear sub keeps Gibraltar in a rage

fields.headline: Nuclear sub keeps Gibraltar in a rage
fields.trailText: International concern about HMS Tireless, the British nuclear submarine stranded in Gibraltar, has deepened with a request for the European commission to investigate its radiation hazards.
fields.byline: Owen Bowcott in Gibraltar and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
International concern about HMS Tireless, the British nuclear submarine stranded in Gibraltar, has deepened with a request for the European commission to investigate its radiation hazards.

Officials in Brussels said last night that they were studying the request from the European ombudsman, acting on a complaint by several Andalusian groups about the warship, whose broken reactor has kept it in the colony's dock for the past seven months.

As welders began repairing a fractured pipe in the reactor cooling system, diplomatic arm-twisting, cross-border protests and legal threats brought the row to a critical phase.

Permission for the repairs to proceed came not from the Royal Navy in London but, in effect, from Gibraltar's chief minister, Peter Caruana, symbolising the Ministry of Defence's humbled status in dealing with the design problems of its SSN hunter-killer submarines.

Ever since Tireless limped into the harbour on auxiliary diesel power on May 19 last year, after developing the leak which forced the crew to shut down the reactor, public unease in the region has grown.

In Spain 60,000 people took part in a protest rally last weekend in the city of Algeciras, less than 10 miles away.

Ten days ago Spanish Greenpeace activists who boarded the submarine were arrested. The issue has not only united environmental protesters on the Rock with those on the other side of the colony's border, it has also undermined the MoD's assumption that the citizens of Gibraltar will always rally round the crown to repel criticism from Spain.

The British ambassador to Spain tried to calm some of the growing unrest last night by saying that the Tireless would return to Britain in about three months' time.

"The repairs will be finished at the end of March and [the submarine] will go at the end of April," Peter Torry told Spanish state television. But he did not say whether work would be done on the reactor before that.

Caught in the middle, the Gibraltar government has established its own panel of nuclear experts in Britain to review the MoD's schedule of work on the submarine.

Mr Caruana spoke to the defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, three times last week before being assured that welding would not begin on the nuclear reactor's cooling system until the panel had assessed the programme.

The Gibraltar government said in a statement that it would "oppose, and take such steps as it can, to prevent the carrying out of works prior to the advice of the government's panel".

It finally confirmed on Tuesday that it would allow welding on Tireless, but was withholding its approval for testing and starting the nuclear reactor.

The Environmental Safety Group is worried about radiation leaks contaminating Gibraltar's main water desalination plant, and is considering legal action against the MoD.

"There should be an evacuation plan which ensures cooperation with the Spanish," said Janet Howitt, one of its leaders.

"We feel there is danger and it's being imposed on us."

Local anxiety has been reinforced by the MoD's belated admission that similar cracks have appeared in the cooling system in at least four of the 12 other SSN nuclear submarines. The authorities now concede that there is a general problem.

Vaughan Starkey, the senior MoD civil servant in Gibraltar, agreed that up to 90 litres of coolant water - at a very low radioactive level - was pumped overboard by the submarine before it docked last May.

"The [nuclear] rods were never exposed," he said. "It was never near meltdown."

"[Tireless] shouldn't be there," said Jenny Martinez, who is expecting a baby shortly and was sitting on a bench looking over the harbour.

"Everybody's worried about it. I think the MoD will have the last word and do whatever they want."

webTitle: Skills shortage on British job market

fields.headline: New labour needed to keep Britain working
fields.standfirst: Government, management bodies and local authorities agree: we are suffering from a crippling lack of skilled workers. But moves to fill the gaps may be too few and too late. Liz Stuart reports
fields.trailText: Government, management bodies and local authorities agree: we are suffering from a crippling lack of skilled workers. But moves to fill the gaps may be too few and too late. Liz Stuart reports
fields.body:
In the States things are so bad that recruiters need to offer diamond rings to girlfriends and luxury cars to spouses as part of the deal. So desperate is the situation that companies advertise jobs on lunch bags in the dot.com corridors of San Francisco and hire planes to blaze sits-vac ads through the skies.

We're talking the skills gap, and as well as being a major headache in the US, it's the biggest problem facing Britain plc today. Companies simply cannot find people to employ, and this problem now extends way beyond the lack of people fluent in specialised computer languages or even the well-known difficulty the government is experiencing in recruiting newly qualified teachers and nurses. The country is now running dry of occupational therapists, doctors, accountants, social workers, engineers and even recruitment consultants: positions which just five years ago graduates and second and third jobbers were clamouring to fill.

A report from The Cranfield School of Management this week reveals that 81% of manufacturers say it is difficult to recruit at the senior managerial level and that junior and middle managers are even harder to find. The latest Mori poll tells the same story. The problems are similar in the blue-collar industries: hotels, restaurants and the leisure industry in general are thirsty for staff who, once trained, often quit the country for a warmer working environment.

Jobs which in the past have been filled by school leavers are going begging as demographics and the increase in numbers of young people going into higher education squeeze the labour supply at source. This week the Institute for the Management of Information Systems, which represents IT companies, said it would press Chancellor Gordon Brown to use his pre-election Budget to give tax relief to employers and staff for IT training, making the skills shortage an election issue.

So seriously does the government view the problem, that industry minister Kim Howells will next month launch a tour promoting, among other things, workforce training and retraining. The Cabinet Office's Performance and Innovation Unit has set up a task force which has nine months to report on the skills shortage problem in the UK. So-called third-leg funding for universities to liaise with businesses to ensure that degree courses teach relevant skills to students has been tripled.

The problem has been bubbling under for the past 10 years as the country moved from recession in the early 90s into a period of full employment, as defined by economist John Maynard Keynes. Companies which slashed recruitment and training budgets in the lean times failed to reinflate them as the economy picked up.

Neil Barnes, director of media recruitment specialists Phee Farrar Jones, says the problem has arisen because of a lack of investment in graduate recruitment. "The underlying reason is because companies have not pre-planned graduate recruitment in the past so they don't have the talent coming through the company. Particularly in the area of new media there has also been the problem of sheer growth. It would have been a very brave person indeed who could have predicted numbers needed even three years ago. Although some start-ups have failed, others have grown beyond their wildest dreams."

Kevin Hogarth, national resourcing director at professional services group Ernst & Young, agrees: "We're trying to recruit people who started their training in the early 90s and effectively we're reaping what we sowed. Numbers of graduate recruits were much reduced in all the accountancy firms because of economic conditions. Now we're trying to broaden the net of people we can attract who may have relevant experience."

In the public sector, recruitment difficulties have more to do with poor pay and overwork. A spokeswoman for the public sector workers' union Unison says: "There is a huge problem with a lack of social workers, particularly in inner city areas. Pay is always an issue, but there is also the problem of caseloads. Lisa Artherworry, the care worker involved in the Anna Climbie case, had 50% more work that she should have done, although I'm not excusing what happened. With residential social work there is even more of a problem: it is even worse paid and the environment is very difficult - you often find that there will be just one person sleeping in the home alone when there should be two people there."

Separately, the Cabinet Office this week published a paper on the role immigrants can fill in helping slake the staffing drought as more and more blue-chip companies are actively recruiting in Europe, Australia, New Zealand and India. Essex County Council is already forced abroad by staffing gaps: it employs social workers from South Africa. Ernst & Young is launching its first careers round in India next month. But Mr Howells warns that for Britain simply to import workers from overseas would mean that "we have not convinced enough of our people there are viable careers here and they should retrain for them".

Tom Hadley, senior policy adviser and manager of the Employee Relocation Council at the CBI, says: "We are keen to stress that bringing in foreign labour needs to be seen in conjunction with a number of other solutions. It is part of an on-going debate. But we see this as a positive thing. It is an advantage to get people from overseas: a lot of companies are operating in a global marketplace and it is an advantage to have multicultural teams." He adds that the international exchange of personnel is just that, an exchange, and that British companies are using overseas relocation as one of their development tools.

But back to the US, and New York recruitment consultant Rohit Sawhney says there has been a dire shortage of IT experts in the US for two years. The government has relaxed quotas on its business visa, meaning that 190,000 immigrants are now allowed into the country to work compared with 65,000 previously. "The situation has altered slightly, however. Whereas last year companies would just take on anyone, employers are now far more selective. This is because the website infrastructure is now in place and people are needed just to enhance it, which can wait. There is no longer a mad rush for staff," say Mr Sawhney.

But he adds that the upshift in the number of immigrants allowed in the US has not had the anticipated effect in the major cities such as New York and New Jersey: large corporations are increasingly unwilling to go to the expense of relocating an IT expert from India or New Zealand who is under no contractual obligation to stay.

Mr Hogarth says overseas recruiting will be just one way of plugging the gap. His company has also been forced to accept beefing up the quality of jobs offered to graduate employees, as well as taking on non-graduates into areas where a degree has, in the past, been a pre-requisite for working. "To fill vacancies we're not frightened of paying. What does frighten us more is the number of vacancies unfilled. We have literally hundreds of vacancies - I would say that vacancies are up 25% on this time last year." Qualified accountants with experience, tax and corporate finance specialists are particularly in short supply.

"Now we're trying to broaden the net of people we can attract who may have relevant experience. We're also looking at the way we undertake audits. We're defining separate roles so we can now focus graduates on developing skills for their longer term career, whereas in the past they had to do some tedious stuff as well," he says.

Where it's hurting worst

City

"There are skills shortages across the board in the City, whether you are looking for professional accountants, bankers or legal personnel," says Alison Smith, director of recruitment consultants Badenoch & Clark. The situation is a vicious circle: increasingly people are rejecting the City's long working hours, which means employers demanding more of their staff as they cannot find enough people to do the work. "But if firms were more willing to train those with potential or retrain those with redundant skills, flexible working practices have more chance of happening," she says.

IT

Recruitment consultants Computer People say the most sought-after IT experts are people with Java, C++, telecoms and Wap knowledge. High-level database skills such as Unix and Linux are also much in demand. "The increased demand for Java skills does not seem to be abating, but companies are now being more realistic about the availability of such people and are prepared to look at candidates with OO and procedural programming skills. Graduates with OO skills are finding it easier to get first-time work and training on the job," says a spokeswoman. The average hourly rate for a Java developer in London is £70, but can be as high as £90 with experience in some sectors.

Charities

While higher salaries in the sector, plus growing interest in jobs which benefit the community or environment, should mean a glut of candidates, charities are experiencing "severe recruitment difficulties", according to the Voluntary Sector National Training Council in England. "There have been particular problems with charities in London and the south-east, where applications for jobs have declined severely in the last six to nine months. Charities are being forced to be far more lateral in the way in which they look for staff: they will take on people with sales experience to work in fundraising," says a spokesman.

Hospitality

"The hospitality and tourism industry is the fastest-growing job sector in the world," according to Anne Walker, managing director of Springboard UK, an independent organisation promoting career opportunities in the leisure industry. "There are skills shortages at almost all levels and with every category of staff. There are currently 30,000 vacancies for chefs in this country: one of the problems is that cooking is not on the national curriculum."

Media

John Foscolo, tutor at the Cardiff Centre for Journalism Studies, says there are more jobs on weekly papers than at any time in his eight years in teaching. "I've never seen anything like it. There are far more jobs than students to fill them. It's because so many have been going into dot.coms because they pay so much better than weekly papers. On daily papers the jobs market is pretty good too as people are moving round so much. You've got to be trained, though. Papers want to put you straight to work. In PR there are so many jobs you can name your price."

Teaching

Education secretary David Blunkett last year admitted that had salaries of £6,000 not been introduced for teachers in training the situation would have been "very close to meltdown".Stories of schools cancelling classes because of staff shortages are increasingly common. Areas with shortfalls are London and the south-east in maths, technology, science and foreign languages: trainees in these areas now receive a golden hello of £4,000.

Occupational therapy

"We have noticed a huge increase in the number of posts for occupational therapists advertised in our publications and we know there are not enough to deliver the service users need. We believe that nationwide the shortage is running at 20%," says Sheelagh Richards, chief executive of the College of Occupational Therapists. An Audit Commission report published last June showed that the gravest shortages were at the most senior level. According to NHS figures, the highest vacancy rates are in London, followed by the east, then the west midlands.

Social work

According to an Employers' Organisation survey published in April 2000, there was a 16% vacancy rate nationally for social workers, rising to almost 20% in London, the south east and east Anglia - that is, one in five positions was unfilled. According to a spokesman for the organisation, there is no evidence that this has changed in the nine months since, but the problem had doubled in severity in the 18 months since the previous survey. In London and the home counties there are now around 500 vacancies for field social workers.

webTitle: Superdrug to pioneer selling morning-after pill on internet

fields.headline: Superdrug to pioneer selling morning-after pill on internet
fields.trailText: Superdrug, the high street chemist, yesterday added the morning-after pill to the bunion pads and headache tablets available on its website, becoming the first retailer to sell emergency contraception over the internet.
fields.body:
Superdrug, the high street chemist, yesterday added the morning-after pill to the bunion pads and headache tablets available on its website, becoming the first retailer to sell emergency contraception over the internet.

Priced at £19.99 for a pack of two pills, the product will only be available in the London area bordered by the the M25 motorway. Customers will be charged a further £7.50 for an express four hour delivery. To be effective, the pills must be taken within 72 hours.

The superdrug.com service takes advantage of a change in law which came into effect on January 1 removing the drug Levonelle from prescription-only control and permitting women to buy it over the counter. There is no charge for the drug when it is prescribed by a GP or family planning clinic.

While the Family Planning Association welcomed the initiative as a sensible way of giving women access to emergency birth control, the anti-abortion group Life raised concerns that it could be exploited by under-age customers and encourage promiscuity. This week, it emerged that two underage boys from West Sussex were sold Levonelle over the counter after claiming to have had unprotected sex with fictitious girlfriends. "This service will be open to abuse, with people getting the pill for other people and underage girls," a spokesman for Life said.

Superdrug pointed to its strict purchasing procedure. Women will register on the website and be called back by a web pharmacist, who will take them through a series of questions set out in the Royal Pharmaceutical Society's guidelines. These include the chemist's duty to satisfy himself that the client is 16 or over, is buying the drug for her own consumption and is not allergic to levonorgestrel, an ingredient in Levonelle.

In what Superdrug identified as a further filter for the underage, customers will be asked to pay by credit or debit card. After the pharmacist has approved the sale, women will either order an express delivery or go to their nearest chemist to pick up the pill.

Barry Simner, head pharmacist at superdrug.com, said: "We can help people with their planned contraception methods and the availability of Levonelle allows us to help people who need emergency contraception."

Juliet Hillier, of the Family Planning Association, said: "If a pharmacist calls you back to discuss your order, it's not an anonymous service open to abuse. It looks like a very innovative approach to ensure that women have access to emergency contraception."

Ann Furedi, of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, said: "We think it is a great initiative and welcome it hugely."

After the pharmacist has approved the sale, women will either order an express delivery or go to their nearest chemist to pick up the pill. Juliet Hillier, of the Family Planning Association, said: "If a pharmacist calls you back to discuss your order, it's not an anonymous service open to abuse. Ann Furedi, of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, said: "We think it is a great initiative and welcome it hugely."

fields.headline: 2,000 dead - and rising
fields.standfirst:
Republic day ends in tragedy as Gujarat earthquake is felt from Madras to Nepal

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Republic day ends in tragedy as Gujarat earthquake is felt from Madras to Nepal.
fields.byline: Luke Harding in Ahmedabad. Additional reporting by Jeevan Vasagar
fields.body:
At 8.46am yesterday Nirav Parikh was sitting down to breakfast with his family at his home in the Sidhi apartments in Ahmedabad. India was a little later getting up than usual - the country was celebrating Republic Day.

And then the building started to sway. "I could see the glasses shaking. I was absolutely clear there was an earthquake. I grabbed my five-year-old son and managed to get out into the courtyard in 25 seconds," he said.

Fifteen seconds later, the Sidhi apartments collapsed. There was a silence, followed by screaming. "People were asking each other 'Are you all right? Are you all right?'"

But not everyone was all right. By last night the death toll in India's worst earthquake in 50 years was put at 2,000 and rising. More than 3,200 people have been injured.

The quake in the western state of Gujarat, measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale, could be felt as far away as the capital Delhi, in the Himalayas and in tropical Madras.

The two worst affected areas were the ancient walled city of Bhuj, 12 miles from the epicentre, where 150 people died when a single four-storey building collapsed, and the city of Ahmedabad.

But even in Ahmedabad the earthquake was selectively destructive; some 40 buildings had collapsed but the rest of the city was intact. The victims had been unlucky - or slow.

At Chandrama Flats, the fire brigade, armed with nothing more sophisticated than metal buckets, were last night excavating what had been the second floor of the apartment block. A boy's leg protruded from a ceiling, while two old women whose bodies could not be freed lay where the earthquake had caught them, in their beds.

Rescuers were trying to reach Asish Shah, 21, who was still alive in the rubble. "His brother Jiggar survived the initial quake but died a couple of hours later. We could not free him," Officer Dewang Lakhia said. "There were 16 families living here. There are still at least 20 people we cannot locate. They are under four storeys of debris."

It is clear that the authorities were catastrophically unprepared for the earthquake, even though tremors had been reported over the past week. Gujarat has suffered severe earthquakes in the past, including one in 1819 in which tens of thousands died.

Hundreds of people besieged the fire station yesterday asking for help to dig out their relatives, according to the Ahmedabad fire chief, Rajesh Bhat. "This is an emergency. We are facing a riotous crowd. A fear psychosis is developing in the city. People have fled their homes and are taking refuge in open fields."

But in most areas volunteers were pulling away masonry by hand, surrounded by a sea of household objects.

Over at Ahmedabad's main hospital, more than 500 patients arrived in the five hours after the earthquake struck.

"This is my worst day in seven years here," Kaushal Anand, the casualty doctor on duty, said. "There are 120 dead here alone. Most of the injuries are bone injuries or head injuries. I was on the ward when the earthquake struck. I ran away. The patients already here ran away."

In the hospital courtyard, those with nowhere to sleep were being served chapatis and rice.

As darkness fell, families camped out on pavements and in public parks, afraid to return to buildings as 13 aftershocks rocked the state. More are expected throughout the week.

In Delhi, the prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, called an emergency cabinet meeting to discuss the crisis while relief teams were airlifted by helicopter to the worst-affected areas near Bhuj. He asked "all people to rally together at this time of national calamity".

The extent of the death toll is not likely to become clear until later today: much of the devastation has been in Kutch, the westernmost part of Gujarat - an isolated, sparsely populated expanse of salt flats.

"We expect unimaginable damage at the epicentre," SK Srivastav, a senior meteorologist and quake expert, said. "All buildings, including strong buildings, will suffer damage in the epicentre area and all weak buildings will most likely to collapse."

In Ahmedabad, electricity was restored yesterday afternoon but across much of the state phone and power lines were down. Across the state as a whole, 100 buildings were destroyed with the heaviest damage within a 125-mile radius of the epicentre.

Across the border in Pakistan at least two people were killed in the city of Hyderabad.

Meanwhile, Asian communities in Britain last night faced an agonising wait to hear whether relatives were safe, as the disaster slowed the flow of personal news to a trickle. Gujarat is home to the extended families of many British Indians.

Prayers were offered in temples yesterday and community leaders pledged to raise funds for earthquake victims.

The Foreign Office issued a helpline number for relatives which was quickly swamped by inquiries, forcing officials to set up a replacement line by 11am yesterday.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said last night that no British fatalities had been reported but callers are being asked to leave their contact details in case bad news came through from the region.

Nilesh Shukla, from the Federation of Hindu Priests, said they were preparing to offer prayers for the families of those affected by the earthquake. "I am sure there are a very large number of people who want to know what is happening and also to know what the number of people killed actually is."

More than 500 members of Leicester's Gujarat Hindu Association were due to meet at 7pm last night at the Belgrave Neighbourhood Centre to celebrate Republic Day, which marks the 51st anniversary of the adoption of the Indian constitution. Following the earthquake, they met only to swap news.

Maganbhai Patel, president of the association, said: "The first I knew of the earthquake was when a friend called me from Gujarat. He is OK because he is in a small village but he said a lot of big buildings are shattered."

Jagtar Singh Deol, the chairman of trustees at the Guru Gobind Sikh temple in Bradford, said there were hundreds of people in the city who had relatives in Gujarat. "Everyone is shocked by the news. We really feel sorry for people who have lost their lives. There will also be terrible economic losses."

• The Foreign Office helpline number is 020 7008 0000.

webTitle: Eating out: The Trouble House Inn

fields.headline: The Trouble House Inn, London
fields.standfirst: One simple lunch at The Trouble House Inn proves a remarkable cure for the post-festive season bickering that has blighted Matthew Fort and family
fields.trailText: One simple lunch at The Trouble House Inn proves a remarkable cure for the post-festive season bickering that has blighted Matthew Fort and family.
fields.body:
It was a dull old Saturday. The fever of post-Xmas sale shopping was on the wane. Domestic chores palled. Ordeal by PlayStation and other strenuous activities didn't get much of a vote. A spot of unarmed combat? Couldn't be bothered. Sloth was winning. Inertia was on the agenda. Lunch? What about it? Well, let's go out, for a change. So we did, to The Trouble House Inn, just outside Tetbury on the Cirencester road, and changed everything.

I hope you won't mind visiting yet another pub that has seen the light when it comes to the eating department. I can't seem to get away from them. Stands to reason, I suppose. There are lots of pubs, and bright young chefs seem to like taking them over and setting out a simpler, happier stall than usually appreciated by Monsieur Michelin or the fogeys who run the Good Food Guide. I had come across the name of The Trouble House Inn in the pages of the august organ of the hospitality trade, the euphoniously named Caterer & Hotelkeeper. Michael and Sarah Bedford had taken it over a couple of months back. In the pictures, they both look about 15, but they have some serious form behind them. He was head chef at the City Rhodes in London and she had been the smiling face of Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons, where he had also worked. Obviously, he knew how to cook and she would know how to handle one discomposed husband, one distracted wife and one disputatious daughter.

It's possible that Mr and Mrs Bedford have been at the Trouble House for such a short time that they haven't had much time to work on a revamp of the place. With the possible exception of the plastic-effect wood veneer around the front of the bar, my advice would be not to touch a thing. There's some nice tongue-and-groove, some pleasant cream-and-dusty pink paintwork, a happily haphazard selection of tables and chairs, the odd odd photograph and a proper fire popping away quietly in the grate. And it's warm and sort of lived-in, without being shabby, and just really rather nice.

Good Wadworth beer, too - 6X and IPA - a couple of pints of which put me well back on track to general cheerfulness. My distracted wife, with her customary restraint, made do with half a pint and my disputatious daughter made do with a limeade and then an orange juice, so our booze bill came to the grand total of £7.70. It's a very long time indeed that I managed that. There is a perfectly decent wine list on which, if you discount the two champagnes, the most expensive wine is £18.90, a figure at which many a metropolitan wine list actually starts.

There's nothing startling about the menu, aside possibly from the prices: the most expensive dish is £12. There are many staples of the contemporary kitchen - salmon fishcakes, mushroom risotto, lamb chump with ratatouille and rosemary gravy, pan-fried cod with olive oil mash, capers and parsley, sticky-toffee pudding, et al - along with the disarming disclaimer, "As all dishes are cooked and prepared to order, your meal may take extra time during busy periods". In other words, there's only me in the kitchen, so please don't get ratty if you have to wait.

We waited a while, but not long, for a mushroom risotto for the disputatious daughter, an onion tart with mixed salad (nominally a first course, but transformed on request into a main by the addition of an extra tart) for the distracted wife, and a duck confit with white beans and lentils for me. This is where the quality of Mr Bedford's pedigree really told. The risotto had that perfect balance between the liquid and the solid, was made with top-grade stock and was packed with squidgy chunks of field mushrooms. It was decimated by the daughter, who suddenly became all sunshine and smiles.

The onion tart was a disk of puff pastry with a wodge of sweet, mulchy onion packed on top. It went the way of all good onions tarts. The salad that came with it was a delightful mix of leaves, without a ruffle of lollo rosso to be seen, and impeccably dressed. I have eaten (and cooked) a fair number of confit duck's legs in my time and consider myself well qualified to judge another. Another two, in point of fact, because The Trouble House Inn generously supplied me with two. The meat on both was beautifully cooked, fibrous, juicy, teasing out the flavour of the duck. Curiously, the skin on one was crisp and devoid of fat, while the other was white and flabby, a minor criticism. The beans were, I think, the rather more refined coco beans than the grosser cannellini or haricots blancs, and mixed admirably with the grainy lentils, providing lots of health-giving fibre to offset the large chunks of bacon and the well braised shallots.

Cheerfulness had broken out all through the Fort family by now, and to cement the change in domestic temperature the obedient and delightful daughter had vanilla cream parfait with marinated pineapple, the cheerful and diligent wife had a sticky-toffee pudding and the expansive husband had a chocolate tart: a serious chocolate tart, a high-born chocolate tart, indeed one of the very best chocolate tarts - thin, crisp pastry, soft, deep, dark, intoxicatingly chocolatey chocolate - that I have ever eaten, and all for £5. In fact, the bill came to £50.70, which, let's face it, is not bad for a successful session of family therapy.

webTitle: Focus shifts to future of Galapagos Islands

fields.headline: Disaster averted
fields.standfirst: Galapagos saved but focus shifts to the islands' future
fields.trailText: Galapagos saved but focus shifts to the islands' future.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman on Santa Cruz Island
fields.body:
Visitors to the Galapagos Islands could be forgiven for asking what all the fuss was about. Disaster workers and ecologists may outnumber tourists, but there are few visible signs of a disaster; the wrecked oil tanker, stranded on rocks a mile offshore, is blotting the tropical landscape rather than destroying it.

"We were very, very lucky," says Carlos Valle, regional director of the environment organisation WWF, and part of the army of international environmentalists that has descended on the archipelago after last week's oil spill from the ship.

Simply keeping catastrophe at bay was never going to satisfy an environmental movement that wants the Galapagos Islands to remain as they were when Charles Darwin visited in 1839, particularly since most of the credit for the narrow escape is thanks to the winds and currents that carried the spill out to sea.

About a third of the islands' 600 or so native plant species are found only there. Of the 57 species of reptiles, land birds and mammals, more than 80% are found nowhere else. Among these is the world's only marine lizard, the only species of penguin and albatross found in the tropics, and a cormorant that has lived so long without predators that it has lost the ability to fly. All are uniquely vulnerable, hence the unique concern.

The Galapagos Islands were declared a national park in 1959, and developed an apparently model ecotourism industry - groups are sent island hopping to designated sites and always with a guide.

The local conservationists appeared confident at the helm, and the international environmental groups were pleased to have one less place to worry about. That was until the rusting Jessica ran aground on January 16, and, three days later, began leaking its cargo of 885,700 litres (234,000 gallons) of diesel and bunker fuel.

The oil-spill woke people to the realisation that the Galapagos was far from secure. The question is how to prevent a future disaster.

Some want to create a rapid reaction team ready to contain any emergency. But maintaining such a force would be expensive and the Ecuadorean government in Quito is already smarting at the estimated £350,000 bill owed to the US coast guard for services rendered. When this particular crisis is over, a request for international aid will certainly be made.

Others issues, such as fishing rights, could rattle the uneasy peace between science, tourism and the locals.

Increasingly strict quotas on fishing attest to the power of the conservationists, but clandestine catches of lobster, sea cucumbers and shark fins, much prized in Japan, show that victory is far from complete.

"What future?" ask graffiti scrawled by fishermen. "Our patrimony massacred," they continue, asserting people's right to fish freely, challenging the claim that the Galapagos belongs to the world.

Sitting on his porch surrounded by nets, Washington Escaraby is bitter about the constraints on his traditional fishing habits.

"If there aren't any other jobs how can they expect us not to fish?" He is also angry because the spill has kept him on dry land all week. A spill, he points out, caused by a ship delivering fuel for tourist boats.

While this raises the possibility of banning such deliveries, conservationists generally favour tourism to fishing, and would like the fishermen to switch roles.

But there is a problem, says Bishop Manuel Balarezo: until the big tour operators on mainland Ecuador relinquish control of the industry, the benefits for locals will be small.

"Often the people don't even get off the boat. They eat, sleep, and even buy their souvenirs right on board," the bishop says.

The islands, 600 miles off the coast of Ecuador, were uninhabited when Darwin spent five weeks here. Discovered by a Spanish bishop by accident in 1535, they acted as shelter for whalers and English pirates.

Up until 15 years ago, there were only 6,000 inhabitants. The number has since tripled prompting strict migration rules.

Scientists would prefer to deport everyone. But, as the locals are keen to point out, crime is almost unheard of and wages are far higher than on the mainland.

Bishop Balarezo says science must accept that near perfect is perfect enough.

fields.headline: Hacked down
fields.standfirst: "The UK press ranges from the worst examples you could imagine of the printed word being abused, to relatively high degrees of sainthood"
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor : "The UK press ranges from the worst examples you could imagine of the printed word being abused, to relatively high degrees of sainthood"
fields.body:
You must forgive me for mentioning Auberon Waugh, but he was my friend, and I want to be sure that he gets into the Guinness Book of Records as the journalist whose death has generated more column inches in the British press than any other. Journalists tend to get longer obituaries and gushier tributes than they probably deserve, but the coverage devoted to Bron Waugh since his death last week has been truly extraordinary. Even the Guardian, a newspaper he didn't like and claimed not to read, devoted three pages to him the day after he died. And these were hardly less admiring than the five pages in the Daily Telegraph, the newspaper he felt closest to and for which he had been writing for some 30 years.

No wonder Polly Toynbee felt outraged. She and Bron had for ages been slugging it out in print, each convinced that the other was some kind of monster. That her own, dear Guardian could join in the general kowtowing to her mortal enemy was perhaps more than she could bear. In any event, the next day she burst out on the Comment page with a fierce onslaught against the departed Waugh and his "coterie of reactionary fogeys centred on the Spectator and the Telegraph" (a coterie that, by implication, includes me, since I was for eight years Bron's editor at the Spectator). This, in turn, generated a spate of anti-Toynbee comment, some of which - like Keith Waterhouse's column in last Monday's Daily Mail - gave her at least as good as she had given Bron in terms of invective.

Waterhouse's argument was basically that journalists exist to throw bottles at those in authority over us, not to cosy up to them. Toynbee's argument was that Waugh and his "coterie" did "mighty damage to British political life, journalism, and discourse in the postwar years" by "spitting poison at anyone vulgar enough to want to improve anything at all".

She was quite wrong about some things. Waugh had many fans and admirers, as well as a few enemies, but he was not a member of a "coterie" of "effete, drunken, snobbish, racist and sexist" fogeys. His was a unique and unpredictable voice, and he was never part of a gang. He would have been flattered by her belief that he had done "mighty damage", for he was always doubtful about the ability of journalists to influence anything at all. In any case, what damage does she think he did? Political life, journalism and discourse have continued in this country much as before. All Waugh has done is to puncture a few balloons and expose prejudice, hypocrisy and stupidity whenever the opportunity has presented itself, and this strikes me as a positive contribution to make to British political life, journalism, etc. He has hurt people in the process, which is another matter and may not be nice, but why should Toynbee seek to criticise anybody for being "witty" and "clever".

Waugh, of course, had his own prejudices, just as Toynbee has hers. But they were conservative prejudices, which is what makes them unacceptable to her. It is true, as she said, that he did not generally want "to improve anything at all" and opposed most forms of progress. But is every journalist in the world required to be a radical and an activist? Is there no room for the journalist who basically abhors change? Of course there is, so long as we still believe in democracy. What Toynbee apparently fails to understand is that there is room in journalism for both Waugh and herself. There are as many kinds of journalist as there are kinds of people - some serious, some frivolous; some committed, some detached. Art critics, book reviewers, science writers, gossip columnists, diplomatic correspondents, crime reporters, political pundits, fashion writers, humorists: these are all journalists with a place in the great scheme of things.

As Harold Evans, who wrote for the Guardian from New York during the American election, once said during a debate about the influence of British journalism in the US, there is much greater diversity in the British than in the American press. "The British press ranges from the worst examples you could possibly imagine in the world of the printed word being abused, to relatively high degrees of sainthood," he said.

But where does "sainthood" lie? You could think it is with Toynbee, if you wish to change the world and agree with her ways of wanting to do it. But you could equally well have thought it was with Waugh, if you agreed with him that most change was likely to be for the worse and ought to be stopped. The point is, it doesn't matter. The British press, for all its defects, still offers a rich choice. You decide.

fields.headline: Mid-Atlantic rift
fields.standfirst: "All sensible people will readily admit that to be American is an essentially hellish state to which no one in their right mind would aspire"
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill : "All sensible people will readily admit that to be American is an essentially hellish state to which no one in their right mind would aspire"
fields.body:
I don't care what people say - I like All Saints. The girl group may or may not currently exist, of course, after one spat too many over whether Shaz or Nat got to wear the gold combat jacket, but even this is cool. Unlike the Spice Girls Mk II and their endless, depressing show of Friends Foreverish phoniness, the All Saints reflect the awful but unremarkable truth that people who work together for any length of time come to get on each other's nerves something awful. They are a refreshing refutation of that disgusting "We work together, we play together, and work's just like play because we're all such good mates!" ethos that has seen such a comeback in recent years with the Natural Nylon mob, the Richard Curtis Notting Hill set and Blair's stinking cackle of cronies.

Furthermore, I love the way the Saints were presented as a "natural", organic alternative to the Spices, when, of course, they are nothing of the sort. If you see photos of Baby or Scary when they were unknown, they look more or less the same, give or take a Versace jacket and a decent haircut. But when you see a photograph of the young Natalie Appleton - to my mind, literally the most beautiful woman in the world today - there is absolutely no point of connection whatsoever with the current appearance. She looks as much like a whole other person as does a supergrass who's been sent off to have a new face put on before he lives out his days incognito in Spain. That's so much more cool, I reckon, than the timid little habit of having a bit of cowardly tweaking here and there, and hoping that it looks "real".

So, the point is that I would basically forgive the All Saints anything. Anything, that is, except their latest single, All Hooked Up. Ooo! Ouch! I'm talking real-time minor-league trauma here. Because, over and over again, some old Saint keeps singing (and you should, gentle English reader, forgive the expression), "I know that you want a piece of my ass." Oh me! Oh my! as Craig David would say.

I'm by no means a prude, but I find this little toe-tapper only slightly less perturbing than the legendary Je T'Aime duet between Serge Gainsbourg and Jane Birkin, during which a decent young Englishwoman tried to explain how she could possibly ever feel one iota of sexual attraction towards a Frog twice her age who regularly beat her up and made records about how much he wanted to have sex with his daughter.

"I know that you want a piece of my ass." Missus! Surely it's not only me who, against all odds, draws back, puts on a Kenneth Williams whine and shrieks, "Oooo! Not even with two saveloys and a portion of mushy peas, luv!" If it was Mary J Blige, we wouldn't turn a hair, but the fact that All Saints are English, and attempting to communicate in a minority American vernacular, should strike anyone with the least bit of feeling for the fitness of things as extremely amusing and grotesque.

All Saints habitually sing with American accents, of course, an occurrence so common in English popular music that it's barely worth commenting on. However, I don't quite understand why Ali G is obviously funny while, say, Scots Londoner Rod Stewart pretending to be a dead old black man isn't. Age hasn't withered the habit, either. Anyone addicted to the fantastic PopStars programme will have noticed that, while the hopeful youngsters speak in the broadest Scots, Irish and northern English accents imaginable, when they begin to sing they all sound like the same confused, yowling moose. That is, they all sound American.

Now, all sensible people will readily admit that to be an American is an essentially hellish and moronic state to which no one in their right mind would aspire. To be born British, especially, and aspire to this low condition would seem rather like throwing a platinum bracelet back in the face of an admirer and demanding a Perspex bangle instead. Only two types of people move there: the morally bankrupt, such as Amis and Rushdie; and the monumentally dim, such as Vinnie Jones, who hope with good reason that their stupidy will pass for normal in such a sea of dunces. Why, then, when it comes to crooning, does every damned warbler - with the odd exception such as Bryan Ferry and Steven Morrissey - aspire to having been born on the other side of the pond? And often, the most apparently anti-American and intelligent singers, such as Elvis Costello, are the most blatant offenders.

The obvious answer is that rock'n'roll was born in the US and therefore it's a sort of living homage. But that's obviously not true of, say, the chanson, which is, of course, French in origin. But if an English singer stood up and performed a chanson in a French accent, he'd get bottled off. It would seem like he was making fun of French people - a noble occupation, admittedly, but there's a time and a place for everything.

No, the reason why American is the natural language of pop is that the character of its people - babyish, petulant, shallow - is echoed so resonantly in the I-want-I-need-I'm-gonna-scream-and-scream-until-I'm-sick ethos of pop itself. With her typical tin-ear, Madonna is reported to be taking English lessons. It'll never catch on.

I was happy to see that the very clever writer Lorna Sage, who died recently, named her only child Sharon. And also that my favourite ever EastEnders character, Sharon Watts, is about to return. Sharon is a beautiful name; as is Tracey, as is Debbie. Sharon, Tracey, Debbie, Julie - silky, sinuous, mellifluous. And quite beyond the pale, taste-wise. There are many irritating things about the Daily Mail, but surely a contender for most irritating item is Keith Waterhouse's recurrent Sharon and Tracey column, in which two monumentally thick working-class shopgirls demonstrate that they have the IQ of a sock. From time to time, highly-qualified young Sharons and Traceys write in to the paper and request that Waterhouse desists. But the tired old routine drags on and on.

Can we imagine Waterhouse being allowed regularly to spoof two stupid, idle West Indians or Irishmen in his column, even in the Daily Mail? Of course not. And talk about pots and kettles. Isn't "Keith" a bit of a joke name itself? But then, no old Fleet Street geezer ever finds himself ridiculous. "Wayne" will always sound funnier than "Auberon" to them.

I'll never forget the delightful spectacle of Hunter Davies trying to humiliate the boy pop star Marilyn and having the tables roundly turned on him. "What kind of name is Marilyn?" he sneered unpleasantly.

"I don't know, Hunter," came back the response. "What kind of name is Hunter?"

fields.headline: Pearly white
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery on deserved hype in White Teeth, plus Preston Falls, Flying, Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid and Steven Poole on jazzy minatures in Anthropology
fields.body:
White Teeth

Zadie Smith

(Penguin, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Far too much has already been said about Zadie Smith for anybody to read a couple of pages of this debut without prejudice. Is Smith the new Salman Rushdie or simply a clever imitation with a great dust-jacket image? Orange and Booker prize judges wrong, the Guardian and the Whitbread right? What is immediately obvious is that Smith's absurdist, multiethnic comedy of Cricklewood is an extraordinary novel for a 23-year-old to have written and reaches far wider than most first-time novelists dare. Certainly readers can find fault: Smith can be an over-zealous polisher and chaser after easy humour. But these are the tiniest of quibbles over a novel that deserves all the hype it has received.

Preston Falls

David Gates

(Phoenix, £6.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

A four-hour drive out of New York, Gates's Preston Falls is clearly in Richard Ford country - a place where men scrabble after the things they mislaid when the wife, the kids and the job took over. A two-month break from the job should be a chance for Doug Willis to restore the house, read Dickens and see where his marriage is headed, but an argument with the ceiling and a night in jail pitch him into an apocalypse of drugs, paranoia, motel rooms and all-night fast-food stops. It is the familiar topography of an American male's mid-life crisis, but sharply observed and pertinent enough to make the reader see this well-travelled landscape anew.

Flying

Henry Sutton

(Sceptre, £6.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

The crew of a jumbo flying to New York and back. What do they think about in between safety demonstrations, handing out meals and watching the sky rush past? Sutton has taken the idle thoughts of any passenger who looks up from the seat-back screen to give the crew a second's attention to make a novel that captures the anxieties and liberation of travel. We follow ageing pilot Greg; soon-to-be married hostess Becky; Selina, scared rigid by her promotion to cabin manager; and uptight Nigel, the first-class purser, as their aircraft slips from one air traffic-control sector to another. Sutton's sense of tempo makes Flying far more than a neat premise.

Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid

Tibor Fischer

(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Fischer's title acknowledges that he falls into the "oh-so-clever" camp of writers. The reaction that he wants from the reader is, I suspect, envy at his elegance and admiration for his ease. The collection - novella-length opener and final story sandwiching five shorter pieces - is very funny, slick and unremittingly vicious. Fischer takes characters who are jaded and disillusioned, suffering that familiar end-of-century unease, and dispatches their stories with cold-blooded nonchalance. Fischer's trick is mockery through compression: neither as fiction nor as people do they merit more.

Anthropology

Dan Rhodes

(Fourth Estate, £5.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Doubtless named after the careening bebop standard by Dizzy Gillespie and Charlie Parker, Anthropology is a gleaming box of jazzy miniatures. Its 101 stories are tiny flights of absurdist fancy, mostly about the size of this review. They are demented romances, with looping repetitions of style and action, and some great first sentences. The male narrators have girlfriends with names like Tortoiseshell or Foxglove, and don't know what to do with them apart from stroking their long hair and pledging eternal passion. The girlfriends, as long as they're not dead, viciously exploit such foolishness. Exquisitely funny, though you'll read it in half an hour.

Steven Poole

webTitle: Why Men Don't Listen & Women Can't Read Maps, by Allan and Barbara Pease

fields.headline: Why Men Don't Listen & Women Can't Read Maps, by Allan and Barbara Pease
fields.standfirst:
Orion, £8.99, 180mn
Buy the book at BOL
fields.trailText: Allan's chirpy Aussie delivery trips lightly, but what really jollies it up are the acted sketches on PMT, silent husbands, map wars etc.
fields.body: A diverting pop explanation for those generalised human-gender divides beloved of old Punch cartoonists. Understand why your man/woman does/doesn't want to blather for England and can/can't do many tasks at once. The cover bills Allan as "the world's foremost expert on body language", so add salt to taste. He claims many differences, eg spatial awareness and map skills, were fixed when cavemen were killing tomorrow's lunch and the women guarded the kids. Women still have better peripheral vision. Allan's chirpy Aussie delivery trips lightly, but what really jollies it up are the acted sketches on PMT, silent husbands, map wars etc. The unanswered question: if women are so much keener on talking than men are, why did Allan, not Barbara, record this audiobook?

fields.headline: Truth in the broken mirror
fields.standfirst: When  Günter Grass  revisited his home town, Gdansk, the pre-war memories evoked were poignant. On Holocaust Memorial Day, he reflects on the painful paradox of collective recollection
fields.trailText: When Günter Grass revisited his home town, Gdansk, the pre-war memories evoked were poignant. On Holocaust Memorial Day, he reflects on the painful paradox of collective recollection
fields.body:
I remember... or else perhaps there is something which makes me remember, something which runs through my being, leaving behind its smell, or something which was hiding, sheltering in old letters, just waiting to be reawakened by some sly little word. It's a kind of trap, one of a number of things that can make us stumble. Something emerges from this background world, something to which we can at once put a name. Mute objects come to meet us, things that had been lying dormant around us for years - or so we thought - reveal their secrets. It can be a bit of a nuisance! There are dreams as well, dreams in which we fail to recognise ourselves, which we cannot grasp, but which demand to be interpreted and constantly reinterpreted.

Even when we are travelling through places that we have left behind, places which have been destroyed or lost, which sound unfamiliar or have names that are new, even then we may suddenly be seized by a memory. That is what happened to me in the spring of 1958 when I visited the city of Gdansk for the first time since the war, as it slowly emerged from its heaps of rubble, and I hoped that here and there I might come across some surviving trace of what Danzig had once been.

Sure enough, the schools were still where they had been, and that characteristic school smell still infested the corridors. But the journey to school seemed shorter than I remembered it. Then I set off to find Brösen, which used to be a fishing village, and I found that the Baltic lapped against it as gently as it ever had. Suddenly I was standing outside the closed bathing station, beside the entrance next to the kiosk, likewise chained and padlocked. And all in a moment I could feel once more the thrill of one of the modest pleasures of my childhood: lemonade crystals tasting of strawberry, lemon and lily of the valley; you could buy them in sachets in the kiosk for a few pfennigs. But the minute this refreshing drink began to sparkle in my memory, it began to stir up stories, deceitful stories, which had been waiting, needing only a single word of recognition to bring them to the surface. This simple, innocuous lemonade powder, meant to be dissolved in water, set off a chain reaction in my brain: that first trembling love, that sparkle, repeated over and over, but never experienced.

A recollection, no matter how deeply buried or fragmentary it may be, is more than just a matter of forcing your memory to work with precision. A recollection is allowed to cheat, to embellish or to pretend, whereas the memory is happy to be seen as a scrupulously trustworthy accountant. However, we know that powers of memory diminish with age, whereas recollections of all that had long been buried, recollections of childhood, now seem to come closer and often cluster around moments of happiness.

Although I'm still fond of going out to look for mushrooms, even today I am taken unawares by the sudden memory of a moment when, as I child, I used to go off into the Kaszubska forest and suddenly came across a single cep. It was bigger and a more magnificent specimen than any that I have found since, and so I keep looking. Recollection provides me with the measure of what to look for.

When it comes to recollection, the writer is a past master. Since narrative is what he writes, he has been trained in the craft. He knows that recollection is like a cat that has to be stroked - sometimes in the wrong direction - until it starts to tremble, and then to purr. This is how he uses his own recollections and, when needed, the recollections of people whom he invents as fancy takes him. Recollection is his quarry, his compost heap, his archive. He nurtures it as carefully as if it were a second crop.

Of course he is aware that literature is a greedy beast, prepared to gulp down even newspaper articles and reports before they are at all ripe, before they have been licked into shape; but when the lean years come, chewed-over recollections are his staple diet, he recalls memories that have already been raked over once. Perhaps it goes with the job, this ability to turn painful or shameful moments or even the memory of some past failure into something that has entertainment value.

That is why my lost homeland is something that forces recollection upon me, imposes an obligation to write out of obsession. That homeland, lost for ever, which has left a void that cannot be filled by a substitute, by some ersatz homeland or other, had to be recalled once more and then exorcised, banished on to paper, sheet after sheet and, though shattered, it had to find its reflection in a shard from a broken mirror. The recollection had to be drawn off in a way so carefully measured as to keep a narrator supplied with great cupfuls of it, quenching his thirst for his former self, allowing him to use his own particular perspective to see as great that which was small, to see as small that which was great. Every sluice gate is opened. The tramlines of Danzig, the cinemas in the old town and in the working-class districts.

In recollection, the image of that Kashubian uncle seems quite different. He was a man who, at the beginning of the war, had been reluctant to be declared a hero for his defence of the Polish post office. When he died, the family said nothing. There was only chatter about blockades, special communiques, continual victories, banal, everyday events drawn out endlessly, and all that remained of these were scraps of words that hung in the air.

There was the language: a patois that would die out a few decades after the end of the war with the oldest of the refugees, a Plattdeutsch that would be pushed further and further back into east and west Prussia. The Kashubian version of it I heard when my family spoke German has remained in my memory down to the finest detail. I remember, for example, what an aunt whispered in my ear in 1958, something that loses in the translation into standard German: " Ech waiss, Ginterchen, em Wasten is basser, aber em Osten is scheener (Günter, love, I know the west is better, but the east is more beautiful)." This carefully balanced summing-up has not only stuck in my memory but, what is much more, it still runs through my books, weighing up the east and the west, and still today gives me a perspective on them.

That's enough of "professional recollection", the phrase that sums up the writer's obsession. But there is also such a thing as collective memory. Throughout Europe it serves as a pretext: you either strive to evoke it or refrain from doing so. Wars and war crimes are laid at its door. There are entire ideological frameworks that it cannot shake off. This is particularly true of the still painful collective memory of the previous generation.

Perhaps that is why we Germans had the idea of coining a neologism as hackneyed as "the duty of remembrance". It is required as "admission of responsibility" and rejected as insulting, and this is all done conscientiously: for decades now, for as long as the past has constantly caught up with us, it has been carried out as if it were a duty, since the 1960s, even by what was then the younger generation, the one which we used to term "uncompromised". It is as if children and grandchildren wanted to do the remembering in place of their parents and grandparents, who remain silent. Not a week passes that we are not warned about the dangers of forgetting. Once we have sufficiently fulfilled expectations by remembering the Jews who were persecuted, forced to emigrate, murdered in immeasurably large numbers, as an afterthought we remember the murder of 10,000 Gypsies. And now, too late according to many, we are forced to remember what happened to thousands of forced labourers who came from Poland, from the Soviet Union and many other countries to take their places on the production lines in factories working for the German war effort.

It is as if the crimes carried out over a period of just 12 years take on more and more weight the further we move in time from deeds which all the world recognises as shameful. Attempts to give concrete form to recollection by means of memorials seem doomed to failure. In Berlin, for example, conflict broke out, and it was not only matters of aesthetics that loomed large. "Remember!" cried one side; "Enough!" the other side shouted back. It happens that foreigners, observing the Germans' dealings with their past, speak of "self- flagellation", which makes the point that a process of recollection is a torture. But there is really no end in sight. Whenever we make our plans for the future, the past has left its mark on what we thought was virgin territory; it has set up signposts that just lead us back to what we have already lived through.

It is strange and disturbing to hear it said that it is only ever late in the day and with much hesitation that the sufferings inflicted on the Germans during the war are recalled. The consequences of the war, begun without scruple by Germany and criminally pursued, that is, the destruction of German towns, the deaths of thousands of civilians as a result of bombing, the expulsion and distress of the 12m Germans in the east who had to flee: all this was only ever mentioned as a background. In postwar literature, the memory of the many who died in the nights of bombing and the mass exodus was never reflected in the same way. Experience shows that victims of violence, whoever was responsible for it, do not wish to remember the atrocities they have undergone.

And so many things remain unsaid, even when they keep forcing themselves into our consciousness like painful memories. Since there never really was a peace, since, in the Balkans, in the Caucasus, in so many theatres of horror around the world, the present is given over to murder, to evacuation and deportation, then recollection, the echo of the sufferings we have lived through will never cease.

Recently, the Hungarian writer György Konrad wrote about Europe: "To remember is human, we could even say that it is the essence of humanity." While nature treats history with indifference, it is, he insists, a specific human characteristic to be able to remember in two ways, as if this ability were both a benefit and a curse. It is a curse because it will not leave us in peace and a benefit because it overcomes death. Thus, in recollection, we may speak with both the living and the dead. As long as we are remembered, we live on. Forgetting puts the seal on death.

fields.headline: Piqued at the post
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: Has my mother taken up lesbianism, as she once took up badminton and feminism?
fields.body:
Tuesday, January 16, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Clive Box, the postman, banged on the door at 6.15 this morning, which startled me out of my sleep. For some reason, I keep expecting to be raided at dawn by the police, though I have done absolutely nothing wrong. Clive had no proper letters for me, only a multicoloured envelope that informed me in fat multiple exclamation marks that I had won £1,000,000.

I said irritably, "Couldn't you have just put it through the letterbox?"

"Sorry," Box mumbled, "but I wanted to ask you sommat important."

Behind Box's uniformed back, I could see that the estate was covered in frost. Box looked longingly at the radiator in the hall. I asked him in and shut the front door. He put his sack of letters on the floor and blew on his hands. He looked at the self-portrait of Van Gogh that hangs on the wall.

"Who's that? Your granddad?" he said.

"No!" I said. "That's Van Gogh, whose genius went unrecognised in his lifetime. He only ever sold one of his paintings before he died."

"I'm not surprised," said Clive Box, after looking more closely at Gogh's haunted expression. "He's an ugly bugger."

The hall is tiny. We stood in too close proximity. I led the way into the kitchen and plugged in the kettle. Box sat at the table and said, "You're an educated man, ain't you, Mr Mole?"

I replied that I was a bit of an autodidact.

"I ain't interested in your sex life," he said, "but I've seen them letters from book clubs, so I've chosen you to 'elp me out. Do you speak French?"

"Mais oui," I replied.

He took out a sheet of paper from his uniform pocket and pushed it across the table. "'Ow do you pronounce this?" he asked, stabbing with a stubby finger at a word in block capitals in the middle of a paragraph. I looked at the word. I wasn't familiar with it. "CONSIGNIA." I said it out loud, slowly. "Con-sig-nia."

He then said it many times, like a toddler learning the word hippopotamus. "What does it mean?" he asked, eventually.

I told him that I had no idea. I read the paper in front of me. It said that the Post Office had given itself a "modern and meaningful title". And that the words, "Post" and "Office" no longer described the work that this organisation did.

Box looked at me with bewilderment in his eyes. "So I ain't a postman now?" he said. "Apparently not," I replied. "You're a consignée."

Wednesday, January 17

On the train to London to visit my mother in Holloway, I noticed that that ticket collector wore a badge that said "Roger Morris, Revenue Protection Officer".

My mother was in good spirits. She has made friends with her cellmate, a woman called Yvonne, who is in prison for not having a TV licence. Yvonne's defence - that she never watched BBC1 or BBC2 - was thrown out by the court. My mother pointed her out across the visiting room.

Yvonne saw us looking at her and blew my mother a kiss.

My mother blew one back!

I said to my mother, "You and Yvonne appear to be very fond of each other." She looked me in the eye and said, "Yes, we are very, very, very fond of each other." I took a closer look at Yvonne. She looks like Diana Dors, the black-and-white film star. I stumbled through the prison gates - has my mother taken up lesbianism, as she once took up badminton and feminism? And, if she has, will she tire of it, as she so quickly tired of aforementioned hobbies?

fields.headline: Shoot on sight
fields.trailText: John Dugdale on government injustice in Those Are Real Bullets, Aren't They?, plus Clean and Decent and Authentic Decor
fields.body:
Those Are Real Bullets, Aren't They?

Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobson

(Fourth Estate, £7.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Tens of millions of pounds are currently being paid out in lawyers' fees by the Saville inquiry, investigating the slaughter of unarmed civilians by British troops in Derry on January 30, 1972. As a result of the decision to use gung-ho Paras firing live rounds to control an anti-internment march, 13 Catholics were killed and 16 wounded - some hit in the back while fleeing, others shot while helping the injured. Given that this moving, meticulously researched reconstruction of the events of Bloody Sunday already exists, it's easy to share the authors' doubts as to whether Lord Saville's dosh has been "wisely spent".

John Dugdale

Clean & Decent

Lawrence Wright

(Penguin , £4.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

At last reprinted, Wright's essential analysis of the development of bath and loo: he was the first to explain the medieval shallow basin on the floor, with water poured from spouted ewer, used to take harfabarf ; first to print the woodblock diagram for Harington's 1596 water closet (fish swim languidly in its cistern); and first to note that, since the Puritans deplored vanity, Cromwell severely taxed soap. Crisp, brisk, and with swish, snobbish quotes from Tiffin & Son, bug destroyers to Queen Victoria: "I work for the upper classes only... I have noblemen's names, the first in England, on my books".

Vera Rule

Authentic Decor: The Domestic Interior 1620-1920

Peter Thornton

(Cassell, £19.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Say you were designing a stage set for an Ibsen play, or writing a novel set in 19th-century Sweden, and you needed to know what a Scandinavian home looked like. Well, here it is, in a fabulously detailed and panoramic survey by furniture historian Peter Thornton, whose expertise was gathered from long periods as a curator, both at the V&A and of London's Sir John Soane's Musuem. The Ibsen reference isn't plucked from the air, because as anyone who has worked on A Doll's House could tell you, its dramatic structure is intimately connected with the use of doors in Norwegian domestic architecture . A must-have.

Harriet Porter

fields.headline: Ceramic Water Closets, by Munroe Blair
fields.trailText: Blair has been in sanitaryware all his life, so nobody better to debate the relative merits of the Cummings and Bramah valve closets
fields.body: Blair has been in sanitaryware all his life, so nobody better to debate the relative merits of the Cummings and Bramah valve closets, nor celebrate Thomas William Twyford, first mass manufacturer of the one-piece, freestanding, washout pedestal closet in 1883 - the loo as we know it, albeit transfer-printed for the superior household with designs adapted from Japanese teabowls and Cantonese ginger jars. Shouldn't there be a statue to Tom, imperialist of the flush? Made us feel unkindly towards the fashion for US-penitentiary stainless-steel urinals in minimalist bathrooms.

webTitle: A life in writing: Jamila Gavin

fields.headline: Stories of multiple attachments
fields.standfirst: Jamila Gavin tells Julia Eccleshare why childhood ain't what it used to be
fields.trailText: Jamila Gavin tells Julia Eccleshare why childhood ain't what it used to be
fields.body:
A chance remark started Jamila Gavin off on the trail that, 15 years later, would lead her to the winner's podium at the Whitbread awards. It went: "The highways and byways of England are littered with the bones of little children."

The chilling picture it evoked stuck in her mind, and was reinforced during a visit to Hebden Bridge, when she saw the decaying mills where children had been worked to death. She began to look into 18th-century England. "I'm not a scholar, but everything I read confirmed my view. The mortality rates for children looked after by the parishes were shocking. The way babies were treated was horrific. They were totally neglected in a way that immediately made me think of the dying rooms of China."

It was against this background that Gavin wrote Coram Boy, which this week won the Whitbread Children's Book prize. It is the dramatic, interwoven story of how two babies survive, thanks to the philanthropic work of Thomas Coram, founder of the Foundling Hospital. Their survival, which is largely a matter of luck, is in stark contrast to the dismal plight of most illegitimate babies at the time. Coram Boy reflects Gavin's contempt for a society riddled with corruption that held the lives of individuals cheap, whether children or adult, unless they had power.

The 18th-century children Gavin describes are shown taking on physical and social responsibility well beyond the capabilities of their modern European counterparts. Gavin argues that she has seen children in India, and other third world countries, do as much. "Very young children in India have to take on adult responsibilities, not just by earning but also in the domestic tasks they have to do. Exactly the same thing happened in the 18th century here."

The parallels between India now and England as it was are of particular interest to Gavin, who was born in India in 1941 and spent the first five years of her life growing up on the border between India and Pakistan.

Her English mother and Indian father had met as teachers working for the CMS, and her father went on to found and run a teachers' training college near Amritsar. By 1946 it became obvious that it was too dangerous to stay, so Gavin and her mother and brother came to England while her father stayed on, despite the risks, right through Partition. In 1949 the family was reunited in Poona, but by 1953 Gavin's mother had begun to worry about her children's education and the whole family moved to England for good.

"I never found it difficult to adjust to being in England because I had been brought up with entirely English Christian values," Gavin says. "Inside, I thought of myself as English. My mother had taught us not to be thin-skinned, so even children calling me 'blackie' didn't seem abusive. It was just what I was. Mostly people thought I was 'exotic'. I rather liked that."

Writing came late to Gavin. She was a gifted pianist who went on from school to study the piano, first as an exhibitioner at Trinity College, London, and then on scholarships in Paris and Berlin. But she lacked the confidence to be a concert pianist. It did, however, lead her to programme-making for the BBC Music and Arts Unit, which she loved.

She describes herself as "a slow burner", and admits it took 15 years to turn the idea for Coram Boy into a book - a process that involved rethinking her own and others' experience of racism. "In the late 1960s and early 1970s I begun to realise how much racism there was. I read a newspaper story about a class in which the black children drew themselves as white in their self-portraits. It made me realise there were not enough stories about 'black' children - which, for me, meant any non-whites.

"Then my own children were born and I began to realise that there was nothing that really reflected them in the books we had. Unlike me, they see themselves as very multi-cultural. So I wrote a short book for young readers about an Afro-Caribbean family discovering its history."

The Magic Orange Tree fitted well into an emerging market for multi-cultural writing for children, and Gavin followed it up with others of a similar kind, making a reputation for herself as someone who could write authentically about different cultural backgrounds.

It was a publisher's request for a story about migrating families that triggered Gavin to write The Wheel of Surya, the first in a trilogy about Partition. Its starting point is the relationship between an English and an Indian family, with the youngest child in the Indian family helping with the children in the English family. "The English family is quite like my own, especially the mother," Gavin says. "She was very good with staff and had lots of Indian friends." The subsequent titles, The Eye of the Horse and The Track of the Wind, are less domestic and more political, including an understanding account of a young man's involvement in Sikh terrorism.

Other titles, such as The Singing Bowls and Three Indian Princesses , also draw directly on Gavin's knowledge of India, and on the idea of children having identities and attachments from more than one place. Though Coram Boy ostensibly tells a very different story, it is fired by the same intelligence.

"I can use what I know about India and transfer it across to another time or place or situation, being fairly sure that it's the same experience," she says. "My link to Coram Boy lies in understanding a different view of childhood from that of the 20th-century European."
