fields.headline: The peoples' champion
fields.standfirst: Born into a Jewish family but raised as an Anglican, a home-lover who continually travels the globe, he is a passionate ambassador for endangered cultures from Africa to the Arctic.  Nicholas Wroe  on the double life of Hugh Brody, an anthropologist with a gift for storytelling
fields.trailText: Guardian profile: Hugh Brody Born into a Jewish family but raised as an Anglican, a home-lover who continually travels the globe, he is a passionate ambassador for endangered cultures from Africa to the Arctic. Nicholas Wroe on the double life of Hugh Brody, an anthropologist with a gift for storytelling
fields.body:
In 1971 Hugh Brody was in the tiny settlement of Rankin Inlet in Canada's high Arctic zone, learning the local language, Inuktitut. The young anthropologist had been employed by the Canadian government to give policy advice on the indigenous people. A few weeks after arriving he was invited on a hunting trip by some local men. Brody found himself thrilled at, "the small way I transformed the awesome, silent and immense 'wilderness' into bits of language and culture, things I knew or could imagine getting to know." But "nemesis soon followed," as he puts it.

After a brief and successful hunt for ptarmigan - "the grouse of the north" - Brody looked round to find himself utterly alone in a landscape, "that repeated itself in every direction; flat, white, broken by many low ridges". Although he knew that panic and haste were his enemies and that sweat would quickly degrade the insulation of his clothes, he still found himself dashing wildly from one small point of high ground to another looking for signs of his companions.

After an hour or so he managed to regain some composure and eventually identified the tracks of a snowmobile, which he followed back to the camp. When he got there his fellow hunters hadn't even noticed he was missing and he was too embarrassed to tell them what had happened. "I handed over the three ptarmigan, then went and lay down. I was filled by a mixture of relief and shame. I had everything to learn."

Brody tells this story in his new book, The Other Side Of Eden: Hunter-Gatherers, Farmers And The Shaping Of The World. It is a summation of his 30 years experience of working with indigenous peoples and of the other elements in his extraordinarily varied career. The book is a tour de force of storytelling, as befits a writer of fiction as well as of anthropology. Its politics are sophisticated yet retain their passion. He stylishly exhibits a breadth of cultural awareness: he has written and directed films about Henry Moore and a feature film about Sigmund Freud's patients as well as six documentaries about Arctic peoples; he has been a civil servant, acted as an expert witness in complex land-claim legal cases and authored influential environmental reports.

Anthony Smith, former director of the British Film Institute and now president of Magdalen College, Oxford, has known Brody and his work since the mid-70s. "Hugh is perfectly academically respectable, but he isn't an academic anthropologist," says Smith. "When he is wandering around the Arctic he is as much looking into his own society as he is the society of the people he is with. And he sees things in it that we can't. What Hugh is really interested in is directly confronting the fundamental question of what it entails to be alive."

He attracts praise - although not as much as his friends and admirers say he deserves - from all points of the political spectrum. The conservative intellectual Roger Scruton describes Brody's new book as, "extremely good and important for us to reflect on. Although hunter-gatherers have more or less been wiped out by various forms of colonisation, their experience is still embedded in our semi sub-conscious and we need to revisit it and understand it. I think a failure to do so is responsible for many of our modern ills."

From the left, John Berger, who has collaborated with Brody on several film projects, is equally impressed and enthusiastic. "I would recommend his book Maps And Dreams [about his work with the Dunne-za and Cree peoples of the eastern Rockies] to anyone, not just people interested in anthropology. Because Hugh takes such enormous time and care, his voice is from the inside of these people and, because he is an anthropologist, also from the outside. He is trusted enough to share their wonder. It allows him to be fully aware of both the positive and the tragic in their lives."

In The Other Side Of Eden, Brody probes the historical, cultural, political and social relation ships between agricultural societies (categorised as potato-growers and comprising most of the rest of us) and hunter-gatherers - those who colonise and cultivate the land and those who live within its resources. With a foot in both camps he draws on a vast array of sources from local myths to the Bible, citing Genesis as, "the key text that identifies the condition of farmers and explains aggressive, restless agriculture".

Ursula Owen, editor of Index on Censorship, has known Brody for nearly 30 years and says that his ability to operate successfully in more than one world is at the heart of him. "He's from a Jewish family but was given a traditional English education, he loves both the Arctic and European intellectual life, he wants to be home with his family and away on his travels. These ambivalences and divisions can be quite hard on him, but he knows that resolution is no kind of answer. He never wants to short-circuit things and always wants the complexity. He knows he must operate within the splits."

Brody acknowledges the high levels of diversity in his life. He was born in Sheffield in 1943 where his father - whose family had originated in the Ukraine where Brody is the name of a town - was a hospital doctor. His mother had come to Britain from Austria after the 1938 Anschluss and still lives in Sheffield. His parents met when his mother was assigned to his father's hospital to do nursing work. They got engaged three weeks later.

Brody's maternal grandmother always lived with the family and he says his childhood benefited enormously from her determination that he would not be "merely English". He says she came from a well-connected family, was very central European in her attitudes and, "thought England was a bleak rock in the Atlantic. And as for Sheffield..." She spoke to Brody in French, taught him Latin and played chess with him. "So I ended up having borscht and gefilte fish and goulash and being sent to Hebrew classes three times a week, but I also went to a Church of England school and my brother and I were both given very English Christian names. It was a double existence."

Tony Brody is three years older than Hugh and, after an initial career as a nuclear physicist, is now a heart surgeon in Illinois. Hugh says there was always an unspoken bias towards achieving and contributing to society in the family. "My father was rarely at home where we wanted him. He was always out doing good as a doctor. I'm sure that planted something in me about 'doing good' being what really mattered. I have to fight against that to spend more time with my own children."

After attending Montessori nursery and then a C of E prep school - where Michael Palin was a fellow pupil - Brody was sent as a boarder to Uppingham public school in Rutland. "It was a middle-class, middle-ranking school in the middle of England. I had my barmitzvah and then I prayed to a Christian god twice a day in chapel." He says his best friend at school was, coincidentally, also Jewish but they encountered little obvious anti-Semitism apart from having to take the roles of a pair of merchants with heavily exaggerated London Jewish accents in a school play. "That probably was a little exercise in anti-semitism," he says now. "People were probably more aware of it than I realised. But at the time I thought my brother encountered more because he looked more Jewish than me."

Unsurprisingly the move from his liberal, intellectual, multi- lingual home to a very illiberal authoritarian, Anglican school wasn't easy. He left as soon he could and took a job in an accountants' office in Sheffield where he "wore a suit and had a miserable life". This drove him to return to education and he successfully sat the Oxford entrance exams. Before taking up his place he spent six months in Israel doing a series of manual jobs on a kibbutz. His father was a strong Zionist and Brody says he remembers having a "surge of Zionist anxiety during the 1967 war. But after that I came to a more considered view of Israel which put an end to any simple-minded Zionism."

The opening story in Brody's 1991 collection of fiction, Means Of Escape, features a woman not unlike his grandmother and deals with the destruction of her family during the holocaust. Is it too pat to say that his interest in and empathy with endangered peoples comes from this family history? "It has been said that it is Highland Scots and Jews that have done most of the work on social theory going back to the 18th century because in their background is this huge displacement and dispossession," he says. "In my case there is an echo."

His grandmother had lived an ostensibly very comfortable and safe life in an assimilated Jewish family in Vienna. "They thought they had nothing to fear," Brody says: "As that great line has it, they thought they were Germans. The fact that my grandmother was not safe after all was a big thing for her. When I was a child, people from the Jewish community with tattoos would come to the house. My grandmother always made a point of showing them to me, but while I was alerted to the Holocaust I wasn't given the details."

When he went up to Oxford to read PPE he says he felt, "as if life had begun". He also claims he was lucky to be there before the 60s really kicked in. "Things were loosening up but we still took the work seriously and we were subservient enough to actually read our books and write our essays. If I had gone five years later I wouldn't have read my books or done my essays, but would have been involved in street activism or whatever. When I was there working hard was taken for granted."

He was, nevertheless, socially concerned - committed to the peace movement and inspired by the CND Committee of 100. "In my first term at Oxford I did a public fast with five other students over Christmas to publicise how much was spent per second on defence. We were outside all of Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and Boxing Day."

He was quickly identified as someone to watch and was invited to meet Isaiah Berlin. "There was a part of me at Oxford that was quite depressed, but there was another part that just gorged on it," he remembers. "It can be a very lonely place, but intellectually it seemed there were things to be had. I was very reluctant to take my finals because I thought it might lead me to a path I couldn't get off. I painted and wrote a lot of fiction and wanted to pursue this side of my life, but all these people were saying 'join us', so in the end I convinced myself that that is what I wanted."

After his degree he undertook research into social theory but soon moved to more practical work. "I realised I didn't want to spend my life in libraries. I wanted to work with people. I also didn't want to hang on the coat-tails of great thinkers and I didn't want to write about what one person has written about another person."

He got a job at Belfast University teaching social philosophy and began field work into rural communities in the west of Ireland. Six months later he quit the job and went to work full time on his writing and research. "There was a feeling of coming home with the field work. I realised that the most interesting thing in the world is what people have to say. Listening to people is what I wanted to do."

Out of this period came his first book, Inishkillane: Change And Decline In The West Of Ireland. While in Ireland he began a nine-year relationship with art student Christine Moore. She went on to become a student of Chinese, moved to China and now lives in Canada. In 1980 he met Miranda Tufnell, a dancer who is the mother of his first two children. His son Tomo is 17 and works as a volunteer in a home for children with epilepsy, and Jonah is 15 and at school. He and Tufnell were together for 10 years and after they broke up he lived alone and travelled a great deal - "there is nothing like a broken relationship to throw you into field work" - before he met the actress Juliet Stevenson at a dinner party in London in 1993. When Stevenson was profiled in these pages in 1998 she said, "I walked into the room and my heart went boom. Something weird seemed to happen in my gut."

After they met they didn't see each other for a couple of months because she was working in California. "This was pre email," says Brody, "so there were lots of letters and phone calls and faxes." The couple now live together in Highgate, north London, and have a six-year-old daughter, Rosalind, and a new baby son, Gabriel, born just before Christmas. "The baby was a bit of a surprise," concedes Brody, "and we did worry at first that we were too old, and would we have enough money. But we then realised what could be greater than spending time with a new baby?"

The former England cricket captain - now psychoanalyst - Mike Brearley is working with Brody on a film about psychoanalysis. He is struck by the different worlds Brody inhabits and the number of areas of thought he is interested in. "And of course it is striking that he has small children and he goes off to the Arctic or Africa every now and again," adds Brearley. "In a way one feels slightly envious that he can go off and live in a different world and understand it to a great degree. But it must be very unsettling for him and unsettling for the family."

Brody agrees. "So much of my work depends on travel. When the boys were young they did come on trips, and even in the last year my three older children have been to Africa with me. The greatest joy for me is to include them and the greatest pain is leaving the children. Missing them eats into my heart."

As a result of his work in Ireland he decided he wanted to go to a colonial frontier and in 1969 made his first major trip to Canada. His first book from the region, Indians On Skid Row, about alcoholism and crime among Indian migrants in Edmonton, was published in 1971. That same year he was offered a post with the Canadian department for Indian and northern affairs, researching and advising on government policy. "I went to the Arctic to see what the problems were and that was a timely thing to do. Problems had accumulated over the years and no-one had listened. People were very alarmed as to what was happening to their land, to their children, to their homes and to their culture."

He went on to write The People's Land in 1975 before moving south to the eastern foothills of the Rockies, where his work preparing cultural and hunting maps with the Dunne-za and Cree was written up in his highly acclaimed Maps And Dreams in 1981. In 1987 he wrote the book Living Arctic to accompany an exhibition of the same name at the British Museum.

His first film, The Eskimos Of Pond Inlet, made in 1975, was directed by the respected documentary maker Mike Grigsby for Granada's Disappearing World series. Brody has gone on to make a series of documentaries. "I saw Mike Grigsby's film about fishermen in Fleetwood and it opened my eyes to what documentary film could do," he explains. He always works in collaboration with his subjects, and sometimes gives them powers of veto. He sees himself more as an ambassador than a journalist. "I do try to be as true as possible to what people say they want."

The writer Anthony Barnett, Brody's friend for over 30 years, says the self-effacing way Brody has worked in both film and in print makes it sometimes difficult to catch his voice: "He has always tried to avoid the sterility of institutionalisation and always wants to allow for a knight's move to escape. But there's also an argument he wants to have, and it's now time for him to stand and argue his ground. One of the great things about this new book is that he is really beginning to speak as Hugh Brody."

Brody says the three key issues facing indigenous peoples are land rights, the ramifications of abuse some of them suffered in residential schools and other government programmes over the last century, and the loss of language. "Everywhere - in Australia, Africa, Canada or the US - you find people in individual and collective crises about language. It is a source of dismay and despair because what does it mean to live in an oral culture and lose your language? They want their account of the facts to be acknowledged, their place in history to be acknowledged and their losses to be acknowledged. Language is crucial for all these. When I was learning Inuktitut my teacher would say all the time, 'I'm not teaching you for fun. I want you to speak for us'."

Brody says that learning native languages reverses the colonial relationship, as these peoples' experience of life had been shaped and embittered by always being regarded as ignorant. "They didn't know English, how to use pots and pans, orderly time, how to give their children formula milk, cure their diseases, repair their guns, or 'the true religion'. Colonialism constitutes them as ignoramuses - vessels to be filled with the truth. But if you ask them to teach you their language you give them a chance to reverse this - you are the one who doesn't know anything. Instead of saying 'seal' you say 'penis' and they all laugh at you."

It is partly through his facility for languages - he speaks French, German, Hebrew and two Inuktitut dialects - that he has been able to infiltrate so effectively the communities he has worked in. John Berger notes that he is also a "fantastic storyteller. But unlike many people gifted with languages he doesn't feel obliged to talk; instead he listens a great deal. The relationships he is able to establish inspire confidence. People recognise that he is going to be dependable."

Leslie Pinder is a Canadian lawyer and novelist who has worked on several landmark legal cases. She first met Brody in the mid 70s when, as an expert witness, he was called to explain how the indigenous people lived in a case concerning Indian land given to soldiers returning from the second world war which subsequently yielded substantial oil and gas revenues. She says he was an ideal witness. "He's not always looking at notes or historical records but has an easy command of first-hand knowledge. And he's also such a good storyteller. The Crown assumed a lot of things about these people that was completely wrong. But Hugh took the judge and the whole court on a metaphorical hunting trip to explain how the people related to this land."

Perhaps the most significant public project he was involved with was the massive Sardar Sarovan dam in western India. At the time it was the largest water project in the world and proposed raising a huge river by 145m so gravity could feed 75,000kms of canals to bring water to 30m people. But by 1988 it had become the most hotly contested environmental project in the world and the funder, the World Bank, was forced to hold an independent review.

Brody was one of four experts the bank brought in to assess the complex issue of resettlement for those who would lose their lands and livelihoods from the proposed dam. He exploded the claim that "only" 70,000 people would be displaced - it would have been nearer to 400,000 - while making clear that irrigation was still needed. "I was very moved by the desperate pleas for water," he says. "We didn't say in our report that these people shouldn't get water. But we did say that there was a cost in that many others would lose their land, their resources and their livelihoods."

The experts' core recommendation that the World Bank withdraw from the project was "unequivocal and unexpected", wrote Arundhati Roy, the Booker prizewinner, two years ago, in an account of the environmental and political battle. What their report revealed, she wrote, "is scandalous". Last October, after years of legal wrangling, India's Supreme Court ruled that construction of the dam should be completed as "expeditiously" as possible.

Brody was brought to the project by the inquiry's vice-chair, the former Canadian judge, Thomas Berger, who had first encountered him in the mid-70s while chairing an inquiry into a proposed pipeline through the western arctic. Brody was an expert witness for the aboriginal people. "We couldn't have done it without Hugh," Berger says of the World Bank report. "He was absolutely invaluable and had a tremendous input. He is truly a renaissance man and a citizen of the world. He's an international treasure."

A large part of Brody's work has revolved around getting to know exactly how people relate to their resources and mapping their relationships with the land. Since 1997 he has been visiting the southern Kalahari desert three to four times a year for up to six weeks, working with bushmen who have been displaced by large parks. But it is clear that more northern latitudes still entrance him.

"I felt deeply content in the Arctic," he says. "While working on this book I thought much more directly about why I was so at ease with people who don't like schedules, who decide what they are going to do while they are doing it, who are in some sense disorganised although are of course highly organised underneath. It is partly because I am disorganised, but there was also something that spoke to me and not just to me.

"I have talked to lots of people who have done similar fieldwork and nearly all of them have found something deeply satisfying and compelling there. It has a hold on you. There is something about hunter-gatherer lives and languages that grabs you and keeps hold of you, and writing about this convinced me there was something about the life that is immensely to be admired and learnt from."

Roger Scruton says that while Brody is a wonderful guide to these worlds he is not blindly romantic. "He is a modern person but nevertheless has a lyrical sense of what has been lost. And he is a genuinely philosophical writer about these things. He brings them into relation with our experience and meditates on what it means for us."

Brody acknowledges the fundamental division. "My attraction to hunter-gatherer life doesn't displace my love of European civilisation or my desire to be in a community of people who are similar to myself," he says. "My life hasn't been dedicated to an idea that there is another sort of life we should all live. I don't commit to any wild romanticism about it. At one stage I did decide to stay in the north but in the end I suppose it's interesting that I didn't do it. I've always liked the far north, I have always felt I could breath in the Arctic. But when it comes down to it, I know I'm a potato-grower as well."

 The Other Side Of Eden: Hunter-Gatherers, Farmers, And The Shaping Of The World by Hugh Brody is published by Faber at £20.00.
fields.bodyText: In 1971 Hugh Brody was in the tiny settlement of Rankin Inlet in Canada's high Arctic zone, learning the local language, Inuktitut. The young anthropologist had been employed by the Canadian government to give policy advice on the indigenous people. A few weeks after arriving he was invited on a hunting trip by some local men. Brody found himself thrilled at, "the small way I transformed the awesome, silent and immense 'wilderness' into bits of language and culture, things I knew or could imagine getting to know." But "nemesis soon followed," as he puts it. After a brief and successful hunt for ptarmigan - "the grouse of the north" - Brody looked round to find himself utterly alone in a landscape, "that repeated itself in every direction; flat, white, broken by many low ridges". Although he knew that panic and haste were his enemies and that sweat would quickly degrade the insulation of his clothes, he still found himself dashing wildly from one small point of high ground to another looking for signs of his companions. After an hour or so he managed to regain some composure and eventually identified the tracks of a snowmobile, which he followed back to the camp. When he got there his fellow hunters hadn't even noticed he was missing and he was too embarrassed to tell them what had happened. "I handed over the three ptarmigan, then went and lay down. I was filled by a mixture of relief and shame. I had everything to learn." Brody tells this story in his new book, The Other Side Of Eden: Hunter-Gatherers, Farmers And The Shaping Of The World. It is a summation of his 30 years experience of working with indigenous peoples and of the other elements in his extraordinarily varied career. The book is a tour de force of storytelling, as befits a writer of fiction as well as of anthropology. Its politics are sophisticated yet retain their passion. He stylishly exhibits a breadth of cultural awareness: he has written and directed films about Henry Moore and a feature film about Sigmund Freud's patients as well as six documentaries about Arctic peoples; he has been a civil servant, acted as an expert witness in complex land-claim legal cases and authored influential environmental reports. Anthony Smith, former director of the British Film Institute and now president of Magdalen College, Oxford, has known Brody and his work since the mid-70s. "Hugh is perfectly academically respectable, but he isn't an academic anthropologist," says Smith. "When he is wandering around the Arctic he is as much looking into his own society as he is the society of the people he is with. And he sees things in it that we can't. What Hugh is really interested in is directly confronting the fundamental question of what it entails to be alive." He attracts praise - although not as much as his friends and admirers say he deserves - from all points of the political spectrum. The conservative intellectual Roger Scruton describes Brody's new book as, "extremely good and important for us to reflect on. Although hunter-gatherers have more or less been wiped out by various forms of colonisation, their experience is still embedded in our semi sub-conscious and we need to revisit it and understand it. I think a failure to do so is responsible for many of our modern ills." From the left, John Berger, who has collaborated with Brody on several film projects, is equally impressed and enthusiastic. "I would recommend his book Maps And Dreams [about his work with the Dunne-za and Cree peoples of the eastern Rockies] to anyone, not just people interested in anthropology. Because Hugh takes such enormous time and care, his voice is from the inside of these people and, because he is an anthropologist, also from the outside. He is trusted enough to share their wonder. It allows him to be fully aware of both the positive and the tragic in their lives." In The Other Side Of Eden, Brody probes the historical, cultural, political and social relation ships between agricultural societies (categorised as potato-growers and comprising most of the rest of us) and hunter-gatherers - those who colonise and cultivate the land and those who live within its resources. With a foot in both camps he draws on a vast array of sources from local myths to the Bible, citing Genesis as, "the key text that identifies the condition of farmers and explains aggressive, restless agriculture". Ursula Owen, editor of Index on Censorship, has known Brody for nearly 30 years and says that his ability to operate successfully in more than one world is at the heart of him. "He's from a Jewish family but was given a traditional English education, he loves both the Arctic and European intellectual life, he wants to be home with his family and away on his travels. These ambivalences and divisions can be quite hard on him, but he knows that resolution is no kind of answer. He never wants to short-circuit things and always wants the complexity. He knows he must operate within the splits." Brody acknowledges the high levels of diversity in his life. He was born in Sheffield in 1943 where his father - whose family had originated in the Ukraine where Brody is the name of a town - was a hospital doctor. His mother had come to Britain from Austria after the 1938 Anschluss and still lives in Sheffield. His parents met when his mother was assigned to his father's hospital to do nursing work. They got engaged three weeks later. Brody's maternal grandmother always lived with the family and he says his childhood benefited enormously from her determination that he would not be "merely English". He says she came from a well-connected family, was very central European in her attitudes and, "thought England was a bleak rock in the Atlantic. And as for Sheffield..." She spoke to Brody in French, taught him Latin and played chess with him. "So I ended up having borscht and gefilte fish and goulash and being sent to Hebrew classes three times a week, but I also went to a Church of England school and my brother and I were both given very English Christian names. It was a double existence." Tony Brody is three years older than Hugh and, after an initial career as a nuclear physicist, is now a heart surgeon in Illinois. Hugh says there was always an unspoken bias towards achieving and contributing to society in the family. "My father was rarely at home where we wanted him. He was always out doing good as a doctor. I'm sure that planted something in me about 'doing good' being what really mattered. I have to fight against that to spend more time with my own children." After attending Montessori nursery and then a C of E prep school - where Michael Palin was a fellow pupil - Brody was sent as a boarder to Uppingham public school in Rutland. "It was a middle-class, middle-ranking school in the middle of England. I had my barmitzvah and then I prayed to a Christian god twice a day in chapel." He says his best friend at school was, coincidentally, also Jewish but they encountered little obvious anti-Semitism apart from having to take the roles of a pair of merchants with heavily exaggerated London Jewish accents in a school play. "That probably was a little exercise in anti-semitism," he says now. "People were probably more aware of it than I realised. But at the time I thought my brother encountered more because he looked more Jewish than me." Unsurprisingly the move from his liberal, intellectual, multi- lingual home to a very illiberal authoritarian, Anglican school wasn't easy. He left as soon he could and took a job in an accountants' office in Sheffield where he "wore a suit and had a miserable life". This drove him to return to education and he successfully sat the Oxford entrance exams. Before taking up his place he spent six months in Israel doing a series of manual jobs on a kibbutz. His father was a strong Zionist and Brody says he remembers having a "surge of Zionist anxiety during the 1967 war. But after that I came to a more considered view of Israel which put an end to any simple-minded Zionism." The opening story in Brody's 1991 collection of fiction, Means Of Escape, features a woman not unlike his grandmother and deals with the destruction of her family during the holocaust. Is it too pat to say that his interest in and empathy with endangered peoples comes from this family history? "It has been said that it is Highland Scots and Jews that have done most of the work on social theory going back to the 18th century because in their background is this huge displacement and dispossession," he says. "In my case there is an echo." His grandmother had lived an ostensibly very comfortable and safe life in an assimilated Jewish family in Vienna. "They thought they had nothing to fear," Brody says: "As that great line has it, they thought they were Germans. The fact that my grandmother was not safe after all was a big thing for her. When I was a child, people from the Jewish community with tattoos would come to the house. My grandmother always made a point of showing them to me, but while I was alerted to the Holocaust I wasn't given the details." When he went up to Oxford to read PPE he says he felt, "as if life had begun". He also claims he was lucky to be there before the 60s really kicked in. "Things were loosening up but we still took the work seriously and we were subservient enough to actually read our books and write our essays. If I had gone five years later I wouldn't have read my books or done my essays, but would have been involved in street activism or whatever. When I was there working hard was taken for granted." He was, nevertheless, socially concerned - committed to the peace movement and inspired by the CND Committee of 100. "In my first term at Oxford I did a public fast with five other students over Christmas to publicise how much was spent per second on defence. We were outside all of Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and Boxing Day." He was quickly identified as someone to watch and was invited to meet Isaiah Berlin. "There was a part of me at Oxford that was quite depressed, but there was another part that just gorged on it," he remembers. "It can be a very lonely place, but intellectually it seemed there were things to be had. I was very reluctant to take my finals because I thought it might lead me to a path I couldn't get off. I painted and wrote a lot of fiction and wanted to pursue this side of my life, but all these people were saying 'join us', so in the end I convinced myself that that is what I wanted." After his degree he undertook research into social theory but soon moved to more practical work. "I realised I didn't want to spend my life in libraries. I wanted to work with people. I also didn't want to hang on the coat-tails of great thinkers and I didn't want to write about what one person has written about another person." He got a job at Belfast University teaching social philosophy and began field work into rural communities in the west of Ireland. Six months later he quit the job and went to work full time on his writing and research. "There was a feeling of coming home with the field work. I realised that the most interesting thing in the world is what people have to say. Listening to people is what I wanted to do." Out of this period came his first book, Inishkillane: Change And Decline In The West Of Ireland. While in Ireland he began a nine-year relationship with art student Christine Moore. She went on to become a student of Chinese, moved to China and now lives in Canada. In 1980 he met Miranda Tufnell, a dancer who is the mother of his first two children. His son Tomo is 17 and works as a volunteer in a home for children with epilepsy, and Jonah is 15 and at school. He and Tufnell were together for 10 years and after they broke up he lived alone and travelled a great deal - "there is nothing like a broken relationship to throw you into field work" - before he met the actress Juliet Stevenson at a dinner party in London in 1993. When Stevenson was profiled in these pages in 1998 she said, "I walked into the room and my heart went boom. Something weird seemed to happen in my gut." After they met they didn't see each other for a couple of months because she was working in California. "This was pre email," says Brody, "so there were lots of letters and phone calls and faxes." The couple now live together in Highgate, north London, and have a six-year-old daughter, Rosalind, and a new baby son, Gabriel, born just before Christmas. "The baby was a bit of a surprise," concedes Brody, "and we did worry at first that we were too old, and would we have enough money. But we then realised what could be greater than spending time with a new baby?" The former England cricket captain - now psychoanalyst - Mike Brearley is working with Brody on a film about psychoanalysis. He is struck by the different worlds Brody inhabits and the number of areas of thought he is interested in. "And of course it is striking that he has small children and he goes off to the Arctic or Africa every now and again," adds Brearley. "In a way one feels slightly envious that he can go off and live in a different world and understand it to a great degree. But it must be very unsettling for him and unsettling for the family." Brody agrees. "So much of my work depends on travel. When the boys were young they did come on trips, and even in the last year my three older children have been to Africa with me. The greatest joy for me is to include them and the greatest pain is leaving the children. Missing them eats into my heart." As a result of his work in Ireland he decided he wanted to go to a colonial frontier and in 1969 made his first major trip to Canada. His first book from the region, Indians On Skid Row, about alcoholism and crime among Indian migrants in Edmonton, was published in 1971. That same year he was offered a post with the Canadian department for Indian and northern affairs, researching and advising on government policy. "I went to the Arctic to see what the problems were and that was a timely thing to do. Problems had accumulated over the years and no-one had listened. People were very alarmed as to what was happening to their land, to their children, to their homes and to their culture." He went on to write The People's Land in 1975 before moving south to the eastern foothills of the Rockies, where his work preparing cultural and hunting maps with the Dunne-za and Cree was written up in his highly acclaimed Maps And Dreams in 1981. In 1987 he wrote the book Living Arctic to accompany an exhibition of the same name at the British Museum. His first film, The Eskimos Of Pond Inlet, made in 1975, was directed by the respected documentary maker Mike Grigsby for Granada's Disappearing World series. Brody has gone on to make a series of documentaries. "I saw Mike Grigsby's film about fishermen in Fleetwood and it opened my eyes to what documentary film could do," he explains. He always works in collaboration with his subjects, and sometimes gives them powers of veto. He sees himself more as an ambassador than a journalist. "I do try to be as true as possible to what people say they want." The writer Anthony Barnett, Brody's friend for over 30 years, says the self-effacing way Brody has worked in both film and in print makes it sometimes difficult to catch his voice: "He has always tried to avoid the sterility of institutionalisation and always wants to allow for a knight's move to escape. But there's also an argument he wants to have, and it's now time for him to stand and argue his ground. One of the great things about this new book is that he is really beginning to speak as Hugh Brody." Brody says the three key issues facing indigenous peoples are land rights, the ramifications of abuse some of them suffered in residential schools and other government programmes over the last century, and the loss of language. "Everywhere - in Australia, Africa, Canada or the US - you find people in individual and collective crises about language. It is a source of dismay and despair because what does it mean to live in an oral culture and lose your language? They want their account of the facts to be acknowledged, their place in history to be acknowledged and their losses to be acknowledged. Language is crucial for all these. When I was learning Inuktitut my teacher would say all the time, 'I'm not teaching you for fun. I want you to speak for us'." Brody says that learning native languages reverses the colonial relationship, as these peoples' experience of life had been shaped and embittered by always being regarded as ignorant. "They didn't know English, how to use pots and pans, orderly time, how to give their children formula milk, cure their diseases, repair their guns, or 'the true religion'. Colonialism constitutes them as ignoramuses - vessels to be filled with the truth. But if you ask them to teach you their language you give them a chance to reverse this - you are the one who doesn't know anything. Instead of saying 'seal' you say 'penis' and they all laugh at you." It is partly through his facility for languages - he speaks French, German, Hebrew and two Inuktitut dialects - that he has been able to infiltrate so effectively the communities he has worked in. John Berger notes that he is also a "fantastic storyteller. But unlike many people gifted with languages he doesn't feel obliged to talk; instead he listens a great deal. The relationships he is able to establish inspire confidence. People recognise that he is going to be dependable." Leslie Pinder is a Canadian lawyer and novelist who has worked on several landmark legal cases. She first met Brody in the mid 70s when, as an expert witness, he was called to explain how the indigenous people lived in a case concerning Indian land given to soldiers returning from the second world war which subsequently yielded substantial oil and gas revenues. She says he was an ideal witness. "He's not always looking at notes or historical records but has an easy command of first-hand knowledge. And he's also such a good storyteller. The Crown assumed a lot of things about these people that was completely wrong. But Hugh took the judge and the whole court on a metaphorical hunting trip to explain how the people related to this land." Perhaps the most significant public project he was involved with was the massive Sardar Sarovan dam in western India. At the time it was the largest water project in the world and proposed raising a huge river by 145m so gravity could feed 75,000kms of canals to bring water to 30m people. But by 1988 it had become the most hotly contested environmental project in the world and the funder, the World Bank, was forced to hold an independent review. Brody was one of four experts the bank brought in to assess the complex issue of resettlement for those who would lose their lands and livelihoods from the proposed dam. He exploded the claim that "only" 70,000 people would be displaced - it would have been nearer to 400,000 - while making clear that irrigation was still needed. "I was very moved by the desperate pleas for water," he says. "We didn't say in our report that these people shouldn't get water. But we did say that there was a cost in that many others would lose their land, their resources and their livelihoods." The experts' core recommendation that the World Bank withdraw from the project was "unequivocal and unexpected", wrote Arundhati Roy, the Booker prizewinner, two years ago, in an account of the environmental and political battle. What their report revealed, she wrote, "is scandalous". Last October, after years of legal wrangling, India's Supreme Court ruled that construction of the dam should be completed as "expeditiously" as possible. Brody was brought to the project by the inquiry's vice-chair, the former Canadian judge, Thomas Berger, who had first encountered him in the mid-70s while chairing an inquiry into a proposed pipeline through the western arctic. Brody was an expert witness for the aboriginal people. "We couldn't have done it without Hugh," Berger says of the World Bank report. "He was absolutely invaluable and had a tremendous input. He is truly a renaissance man and a citizen of the world. He's an international treasure." A large part of Brody's work has revolved around getting to know exactly how people relate to their resources and mapping their relationships with the land. Since 1997 he has been visiting the southern Kalahari desert three to four times a year for up to six weeks, working with bushmen who have been displaced by large parks. But it is clear that more northern latitudes still entrance him. "I felt deeply content in the Arctic," he says. "While working on this book I thought much more directly about why I was so at ease with people who don't like schedules, who decide what they are going to do while they are doing it, who are in some sense disorganised although are of course highly organised underneath. It is partly because I am disorganised, but there was also something that spoke to me and not just to me. "I have talked to lots of people who have done similar fieldwork and nearly all of them have found something deeply satisfying and compelling there. It has a hold on you. There is something about hunter-gatherer lives and languages that grabs you and keeps hold of you, and writing about this convinced me there was something about the life that is immensely to be admired and learnt from." Roger Scruton says that while Brody is a wonderful guide to these worlds he is not blindly romantic. "He is a modern person but nevertheless has a lyrical sense of what has been lost. And he is a genuinely philosophical writer about these things. He brings them into relation with our experience and meditates on what it means for us." Brody acknowledges the fundamental division. "My attraction to hunter-gatherer life doesn't displace my love of European civilisation or my desire to be in a community of people who are similar to myself," he says. "My life hasn't been dedicated to an idea that there is another sort of life we should all live. I don't commit to any wild romanticism about it. At one stage I did decide to stay in the north but in the end I suppose it's interesting that I didn't do it. I've always liked the far north, I have always felt I could breath in the Arctic. But when it comes down to it, I know I'm a potato-grower as well."  The Other Side Of Eden: Hunter-Gatherers, Farmers, And The Shaping Of The World by Hugh Brody is published by Faber at £20.00.

webTitle: The rise and rise of the memoir

fields.headline: My life as a story
fields.standfirst: Claire Armitstead  on the rise and rise of the memoir
fields.trailText: Claire Armitstead on the rise and rise of the memoir
fields.body:
The late Lorna Sage was a professor of English with some distinguished academic books to her name. But the work she will be remembered for is a childhood memoir. Bad Blood carried off the Whitbread biography award, only narrowly missing the overall prize. What is it about the book that has so caught the imagination? Why are memoirs so popular? What exactly is a memoir? These are question that prompt some head-scratching. According to one publisher, the memoir boom started with St Augustine and was given a new impetus in the 20th century by Freud's emphasis on self-revelation. According to another, it is a largely American phenomenon.

In fact, it is a dizzyingly broad genre, ranging from ghosted autobiography to what might be called interpretative fiction - a form that allows the possibility that someone else might have an entirely different reading of the same events. One of its few common denominators is that it shows a life refracted through a particular experience - whether that be childhood, war or sleeping with a Rolling Stone.

Thousands pour off the world's presses every year: Frank McCourt's two instalments of his Irish childhood and American youth have taken up permanent residence at the top of the bestsellers lists on both sides of the Atlantic; Nick Hornby's series of memoirs chronicling the obsessions of the young urban male have created a whole new sub-genre of their own.

You can find specific reasons for the success of individual memoirs - McCourt's was driven by America's sentimental attachment to its Irish roots. But Angela's Ashes and 'Tis are not alone in appearing to feed a ravenous hunger for personalised history. We wolf down terrible stories of abuse and neglect, we gobble up lives that somehow chime with our own; we nibble at the exotic, the strange and the exciting.

Last year's crop gives a sense of the huge range of memoirs, from the pedigree literary excitement of Martin Amis's Experience to the puppyish cavortings of Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius . But one feature of the genre is that it is not the preserve of the big international publishing house. The Road from Nab End, one man's reminiscences of growing up in the Lancashire weaving heartlands in the depression, has sold 19,000 copies for Eland Press, while an amusing anecdotal memoir of National Service, Brasso Blanco and Bull , has notched up 30,000 sales for Constable Robinson, after initially being self-published by its author Tony Thorne. These might not be the McCourt millions, but it puts the unknown Thorne neck-and-neck in sales terms with Amis.

Amis's Experience represents one of the most common forms of memoir - it offers celebrity, a recognisable sensibility and the private version of stories that have already been played out in public. Kingsley Amis, it has been said, emerges from the book like a character in a Martin Amis novel - hardly surprising, since memoir is all about the appropriation of memory.

More problematic is Amis's appropriation of the story of his cousin, Lucy Partington, who was murdered by Fred West. It is uncomfortable because he admits he hardly knew her - so, in a macabre inflation of memoir's intrinsic untrustworthiness, he is not really telling her story at all, but is toying with the feelings it evokes in him (and us).

It is the lot of the memoirist to ruffle feathers. If Amis ruffled them by venturing beyond his strict first-hand knowledge, John Bayley's memoir of his wife, Iris Murdoch, offended some with its skewed intimacy, its immodest rummaging in the marital sock-drawer.

Iris is a loving account of the indestructibility of an individual, even when most of what she represented has been blotted out. Yet because Murdoch is famous for something quite other than Alzheimer's disease, it also appeals to our prurience, our love of gossip, our sneaking, vindictive delight in seeing the the mighty fall. Does the quality of its writing make this memoir any nobler than, say, Ike Turner's squalid (ghosted) account of his drugs, violence and adultery?

On the contrary, in some ways its literary quality makes it less noble. As Frank Kermode said in his autobiography: "My belief is that the honest truth, insofar as this suggests absolute fidelity to historical fact, is inaccessible; the minute you begin to write it you try to write it well, and writing well is an activity which has no simple relation to truth. For memory cannot do the necessary work independently of fantasy..."

Bayley is a well-known writer writing about another well-known writer. But the startling point about many of today's star memoirists is that they are not famous. Who has ever heard of Andrea Ashworth, unless they happen to be one of the 175,000 people who have bought copies of her memoir Once in a House on Fire?

One of the most familiar tricks of the genre is to appear to be self-deprecating while actually painting a picture of heroic endurance. Dave Eggers plays the trick in reverse - he declares himself heroic and then constantly undermines his own plausibility by pratting around and openly improvising. He flies so close to the invisible boundary between fact and fiction that his book was reviewed several times as a novel.

If Eggers's games with truth and invention offer one perspective on relationship between fiction and memoir, Margaret Drabble's latest novel offers another. The Peppered Moth calls itself a novel, but is so clearly a settling of family scores that it is, at the very least, flirting with the conventions of memoir.

Drabble has admitted that Bessie - northern scholarship girl turned shrewish wife and sour, suffocating matriarch - is based on her own mother, but has not declared it a memoir, preferring to clothe her memories in the figleaf of fiction.

Yet is it possible that, in its open-endedness, the memoir is actually more generous than fiction, and that is what we instinctively value about it? Certainly, some of the best-selling memoirs tell stories that are so grim or so apparently incredible that they would be unsellable as fiction. Dave Pelzer's A Child Called It is one of these - a best-seller fashioned from the most appalling child abuse. Significantly, over three books (the latest out this month), Pelzer traces an arc from horror to forgiveness. It is an odd quirk of these hard-luck tales that the very fact they are memoirs means the writer must have pulled through. We can read them as survivor stories.

This is not true of the biggest horror story of the last century: the holocaust, which is almost too massive to be put into fiction at all. Yet the words tumble out, from survivors and, more recently, from the children of survivors. Anne Karpf's The War After is one of these.

Karpf's parents had survived the death camps, but would never talk about them. They existed in her childhood as a silent reproach for any malady or complaint. She thought the experience was unique to her, until hundreds of readers wrote to her saying they recognised the experience but had never before been able to articulate it. "I feel I tapped into the zeitgeist," she says.

In this case, the memoir carries the burden of witness: by asserting itself as part of the documentation of atrocity it becomes part of the healing process. Only by hearing thousands of such accounts will we be able to understand the incomprehensible. This gives the memoir a troubling but also privileged position.

Perhaps the key to the memoir boom lies in the crisis of historical confidence that the last century wreaked on us. We no longer believe in objectivity; we don't trust the history books to tell the story of ourselves, whether because it is too disturbing or merely too mundane. But we are desperate for that story to be told, so we look for lives that intersect with the bits of history that affect us. The great power of the memoir is that, when it works, it reaches far beyond the bright, tight world of the regular book-buyer. It touches a common humanity we sometimes fear no longer exists.

Me, myself, I: Frank Conroy's Stop-Time (1967) is a story of adolescence, credited with starting the post-war memoir boom.

Into the history books: As I Walked Out One Midsummer Morning (1969). Laurie Lee takes the Spanish Civil War in his stride.

It's cold up north: Catherine Cookson's Our Kate (1969) is a typical memoir of childhood deprivation, set in Tyneside. Her many novels repeated the theme.

All boys together. Nick Hornby's Fever Pitch (1992) made male emotion a legitimate pitch for the literary memoir and led the middle-class assault on the football terraces.

Near-death experiences: Jean Dominique Bauby's The Diving-Bell and the Butterfly (1997) is an account of life after a stroke. Typifies the now-familiar memoir of living with catastrophic illness.

Kiss and tell: The Kiss (1997), by Kathryn Harrison. Spills the beans on a four-year affair the novelist had with her own father. A prime example of the confessional memoir that was so popular in the 1990s.

Biting the hand: Sir Vidia's Shadow (1998). Paul Theroux traces this catty literary memoir of his one-time mentor back to being snubbed by Naipaul on a London street. "His rejection of me meant I was on my own. He had freed me, he had opened my eyes, he had given me a subject."

More problematic is Amis's appropriation of the story of his cousin, Lucy Partington, who was murdered by Fred West. It is uncomfortable because he admits he hardly knew her - so, in a macabre inflation of memoir's intrinsic untrustworthiness, he is not really telling her story at all, but is toying with the feelings it evokes in him (and us). It is the lot of the memoirist to ruffle feathers. If Amis ruffled them by venturing beyond his strict first-hand knowledge, John Bayley's memoir of his wife, Iris Murdoch, offended some with its skewed intimacy, its immodest rummaging in the marital sock-drawer. Iris is a loving account of the indestructibility of an individual, even when most of what she represented has been blotted out. Yet because Murdoch is famous for something quite other than Alzheimer's disease, it also appeals to our prurience, our love of gossip, our sneaking, vindictive delight in seeing the the mighty fall. Does the quality of its writing make this memoir any nobler than, say, Ike Turner's squalid (ghosted) account of his drugs, violence and adultery? On the contrary, in some ways its literary quality makes it less noble. As Frank Kermode said in his autobiography: "My belief is that the honest truth, insofar as this suggests absolute fidelity to historical fact, is inaccessible; the minute you begin to write it you try to write it well, and writing well is an activity which has no simple relation to truth. For memory cannot do the necessary work independently of fantasy..." Bayley is a well-known writer writing about another well-known writer. But the startling point about many of today's star memoirists is that they are not famous. Who has ever heard of Andrea Ashworth, unless they happen to be one of the 175,000 people who have bought copies of her memoir Once in a House on Fire? One of the most familiar tricks of the genre is to appear to be self-deprecating while actually painting a picture of heroic endurance. Dave Eggers plays the trick in reverse - he declares himself heroic and then constantly undermines his own plausibility by pratting around and openly improvising. He flies so close to the invisible boundary between fact and fiction that his book was reviewed several times as a novel. If Eggers's games with truth and invention offer one perspective on relationship between fiction and memoir, Margaret Drabble's latest novel offers another. The Peppered Moth calls itself a novel, but is so clearly a settling of family scores that it is, at the very least, flirting with the conventions of memoir. Drabble has admitted that Bessie - northern scholarship girl turned shrewish wife and sour, suffocating matriarch - is based on her own mother, but has not declared it a memoir, preferring to clothe her memories in the figleaf of fiction. Yet is it possible that, in its open-endedness, the memoir is actually more generous than fiction, and that is what we instinctively value about it? Certainly, some of the best-selling memoirs tell stories that are so grim or so apparently incredible that they would be unsellable as fiction. Dave Pelzer's A Child Called It is one of these - a best-seller fashioned from the most appalling child abuse. Significantly, over three books (the latest out this month), Pelzer traces an arc from horror to forgiveness. It is an odd quirk of these hard-luck tales that the very fact they are memoirs means the writer must have pulled through. We can read them as survivor stories. This is not true of the biggest horror story of the last century: the holocaust, which is almost too massive to be put into fiction at all. Yet the words tumble out, from survivors and, more recently, from the children of survivors. Anne Karpf's The War After is one of these. Karpf's parents had survived the death camps, but would never talk about them. They existed in her childhood as a silent reproach for any malady or complaint. She thought the experience was unique to her, until hundreds of readers wrote to her saying they recognised the experience but had never before been able to articulate it. "I feel I tapped into the zeitgeist," she says. In this case, the memoir carries the burden of witness: by asserting itself as part of the documentation of atrocity it becomes part of the healing process. Only by hearing thousands of such accounts will we be able to understand the incomprehensible. This gives the memoir a troubling but also privileged position. Perhaps the key to the memoir boom lies in the crisis of historical confidence that the last century wreaked on us. We no longer believe in objectivity; we don't trust the history books to tell the story of ourselves, whether because it is too disturbing or merely too mundane. But we are desperate for that story to be told, so we look for lives that intersect with the bits of history that affect us. The great power of the memoir is that, when it works, it reaches far beyond the bright, tight world of the regular book-buyer. It touches a common humanity we sometimes fear no longer exists. Me, myself, I: Frank Conroy's Stop-Time (1967) is a story of adolescence, credited with starting the post-war memoir boom. Into the history books: As I Walked Out One Midsummer Morning (1969). Laurie Lee takes the Spanish Civil War in his stride. It's cold up north: Catherine Cookson's Our Kate (1969) is a typical memoir of childhood deprivation, set in Tyneside. Her many novels repeated the theme. All boys together. Nick Hornby's Fever Pitch (1992) made male emotion a legitimate pitch for the literary memoir and led the middle-class assault on the football terraces. Near-death experiences: Jean Dominique Bauby's The Diving-Bell and the Butterfly (1997) is an account of life after a stroke. Typifies the now-familiar memoir of living with catastrophic illness. Kiss and tell: The Kiss (1997), by Kathryn Harrison. Spills the beans on a four-year affair the novelist had with her own father. A prime example of the confessional memoir that was so popular in the 1990s. Biting the hand: Sir Vidia's Shadow (1998). Paul Theroux traces this catty literary memoir of his one-time mentor back to being snubbed by Naipaul on a London street. "His rejection of me meant I was on my own. He had freed me, he had opened my eyes, he had given me a subject."

webTitle: The role of the post-colonial novel

fields.headline: Shadows of the empire
fields.standfirst: D J Taylor looks at the post-colonial novel's hold over recent literary history
fields.trailText: D J Taylor looks at the post-colonial novel's hold over recent literary history
fields.body:
Instant categorisation is one of the cardinal critical sins, of course, but Matthew Kneale's Whitbread award-winning novel summons up the adjective "post-colonial" just as surely as chicken summons up bread sauce. English Passengers transports a varied collection of early Victorians by boat to Tasmania. En route their creator explores imperial complicity in what, it is implied, is a policy of genocide: the removal, by means of persecution and disease, of the aboriginal population of Tasmania.

The collection of eccentrics and do-righters, the crisp Victorian certainties, the conversion of imperial enlightenment and good intentions into something base and despicable - no disrespect to Matthew Kneale's achievement (as any pundit will tell you, this was a hot year for the Whitbread), but we have been here before. Repeatedly. In fact, English Passengers is a distinguished addition to a vein of post-war British writing that has featured in the literary prize lists these 30 years or more: a spreading clump of historical fiction whose underlying assumption might be characterised not as "my country, right or wrong" but, quite simply, as "my country, wrong".

The origins of the post-colonial novel can be traced back to a period well before the post-war imperial retreat. The great early 20th-century studies of anglo-imperial attitudes tend to be more or less contemporary: Leonard Woolf's Ceylon-set The Village in the Jungle (1913), E M Forster's A Passage to India (1924), George Orwell's Burmese Days (1934). They were also fairly even-handed.

Subsequently, the chronological clock swung backwards. The real empire was fast disintegrating. Most of the Eastern possessions went in 1947. Advance warning having been given by Harold Macmillan's famous "Winds of Change" speech, the African dependencies soon followed. The job of colonial secretary, formerly a prize plum in government, dwindled and died. The fictional empire, on the other hand, was repeatedly reinvented. The literary landscapes of the past 40 years are littered with novels that, set variously in India, Ireland and even further-flung nooks and crannies of the old pink-tinted colonial map, mine these themes of imperial duplicity and decay: J G Farrell's The Siege of Krishnapur (Booker Prize 1973) and his earlier Troubles (1970), William Boyd's An Ice-Cream War (Booker shortlist 1982), Marianne Wiggins's John Dollar (1989), Barry Unsworth's Sacred Hunger (Booker Prize 1992), and Peter Carey's Oscar and Lucinda (Booker Prize 1988).

What kind of books are these, in which the white man's burden, taken off into a quiet clearing and stealthily unpacked, turns out to contain all kinds of alluring plunder? In her penetrating study, Traces of Another Time , the American critic Patricia Scanlan defined this genre as the "sceptical historical novel". The public past it outlined is not one of triumph and achievement, but one inglorious and violent. It focuses on defeat rather than victory (The Siege of Krishnapur is loosely based on events at Lucknow), and draws attention, however subtly, to stupidity and arrogance rather than to heroism. Throughout, private consciousness intersects with public events in a deeply unsettling way.

Often the novels' action stems from some disturbing incident whose "truth" will never be established - the murder of the child in Francis King's Act of Darkness, of the rape at the centre of Paul Scott's Raj quartet, which itself nods at the incident in the Marabar Caves in A Passage To India. And at each individual novel's core lies a powerful deconstruction of long-standing myths: English superiority and "civilisation", benign colonialism, the scrupulous conduct of public life, even - and this is perhaps the most profound deconstruction of all - the idea that there is such a thing as shared history. To the average British reader, it goes without saying, these things hurt. To be told that the Empire your forefathers administered was a sham is one thing, but to be told that this Empire imposed a view of history on its subjects that was merely false raises this iniquity to a philosophical level.

Appropriately enough, for a genre concerned to subvert long-cherished myths and illusion, the post-colonial novel has tended to sidestep conventional narrative forms. Its favourite vehicles are allegory, fable, the whole post-modern bag of tricks in which the angle on "past time" is often determinedly oblique. Farrell's Troubles , for example, examines the Irish Uprising of the 1920s through the lives of a group of Irish men and women closeted in the backwater of a seaside hotel. The allegorical focus is a gang of cats. Early sections of the novel feature a pack of dogs that are seen milling round the outbuildings. The dogs, which have British names, are clearly intended to symbolise the Ascendancy. Eventually they are put to flight by the cats, led by a ferocious orange female with "bitter green eyes" - Mother Ireland, you imagine, taking her revenge.

This note note resounds through the post-imperial j'accuse . Barry Unsworth's 18th-century mariners and slaves trying to establish their "free" colony in Florida often sound as if they are discussing 1980s monetarism , and it is perfectly possible to read Sacred Hunger as an attack on free-market economics. The sea captain in Wiggins's John Dollar, who winds up on the beach with a broken spine, ministered to by a group of shipwrecked schoolgirls, eventually becomes the victim of a cannibalistic re-enactment of the Sacrament.

The focus of the Unsworth/Farrell/Booker Prize view of past time also ignores a highly respectable - if undervalued - tradition of right-wing novels of empire. Simon Raven's Sound the Retreat (1973), set in the India of the immediate postwar period, sounds a note of realism, of life suddenly not conforming to the mythical patterns novelists like to invent for it.

The major-league status of the post-colonial novel in any estimate of post-war fiction has not gone unnoticed. In her recent collection of essays On Histories and Stories, A S Byatt notes that "writers are writing historical novels, but much of the discussion of why they are doing this has been confined within the discussion of the Empire or Women, or to the debate between 'escapism' and 'relevance'". Byatt proposes a redrawing of the historical-fiction map, taking in Anthony Burgess, Penelope Fitzgerald, William Golding, Muriel Spark and Lawrence Norfolk. Meanwhile, meticulous unravellings of imperial myth will continue to interest the prize juries. You have a feeling, though, that English Passengers is an example of a literary tradition in late maturity, rather than a dazzling new strike into the historical unknown.

Core text: Joseph Conrad's "Heart of Darkness" (1899) modernised a vision of white men in extremis already determined by books like Robinson Crusoe.

The empire strikes back (I): Things Fall Apart (1958) by Chinua Achebe showed the interplay of Western and African culture. He called Conrad "a bloody racist".

In trouble: Graham Greene's The Heart of the Matter (1948) showed us the colonial official at bay.

The empire strikes back (II): A Bend in the River by V S Naipaul (1979) and Salman Rushdie's Midnight's Children (1981).

In trouble again: see William Boyd's A Good Man in Africa (1981) and Giles Foden's The Last King of Scotland (1998).

Bad company: Lawrence Norfolk's Lemprière's Dictionary (1991) accounted for the British East India Company's brutal creed of expansion - an ethos that would enable many a future colonial narrative.

Bad trip: next to English Passengers , read Robert Edric's Elysium (1995): the last Tasmanian Aborigine awaits the arrival of the English scientist who'll record his life story.

Honourable mention: US citizen Paul Theroux, who from Jungle Lovers (1971) to his Hong Kong withdrawal fable Kowloon Tong (1997) has made this territory his own. His new novel is out in April.

fields.headline: No Packdrill
fields.trailText:
Something to do with shaving tackle
- the brush the razor...
fields.body:
Something to do with shaving tackle

- the brush the razor

the stick of soap

halfwrapped in tinfoil

and then the fact he was the stranger

in my house

- I should call him Roger

though he wasn't that

a canny dope

an early jogger

reminding me that objects

which are both ugly and utile

often leave you feeling slightly soiled

I saw his razor

- a bit brassy bit genital

and imagined soldiers

- raw squaddies - no style

not genteel

or I should say not gentle

but beefier a lot stronger

than I was or am

and each as obvious

as a tin of oil

- I reach out now what

six seventeen years later?

reach out to collect

my own tackle

from the glass shelf

in a hotel bathroom

and see a version of myself

touched by fear and guilt

like a face at a window

worried and in shadow

- the window of a house

where all too soon

maybe more blood will be spilt?

 Tom Paulin's latest collection of poetry, The Wind Dog, is published by Faber & Faber, price £7.99.

webTitle: Pick of the week: Brunelleschi's Dome, by Ross King

fields.headline: Dome alone
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard on Ross King's  marvel of architecture, Brunelleschi's Dome
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Ross King's marvel of architecture, Brunelleschi's Dome
fields.body:
Brunelleschi's Dome
Ross King
(Pimlico, £10)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Towering over the streets of Florence - visible, on clear days, up to 16 miles away - the dome of Santa Maria del Fiore is one of the greatest man-made wonders of the world; and, after reading this book, you may consider it the greatest of them all. Thirty-seven thousand tons of marble in an unsupported dome, the largest of its kind in the world. St Paul's manages a diameter of 112 feet, thirty feet smaller; the Capitol in Washington DC is a pipsqueak at 95 feet across. And Brunelleschi had it constructed without a supporting scaffolding, his masons virtually swinging in the void as they worked. Yet during the period of construction overseen by Brunelleschi, only three men died in work-related accidents.

It was this very achievement, a massive confidence-booster for a people who had assumed the wisdom of the ancients had been forever lost, that inspired Vasari to use the term that has described the era ever since: the renascita, the renaissance.

Architecture had always been considered the lowest of the arts, and architects were traditionally anonymous: Brunelleschi became the first of the modern era to be publicly celebrated and renowned - and why not? The tricks he used to haul the enormous blocks up to where they belonged were well in advance of anything currently available.

There is certainly room, in the genre of popular books about scientific achievement, for a work with this title. This one slots in nicely: it has the advantage of being not just about theory, but about physicality, for architecture is about technical problems as much as it is about aesthetics; and also about the sheer presence of stone, brick, and mortar.

For those who get off on such things, King does a good, understated job with his portrayal of 15th-century Florence, giving us an idea of what it was like then, but without drowning us in particulars, or overawed or overblown prose. (This must have involved some self-restraint on his part, as he usually writes fiction which, if I remember correctly, is entertainingly rich in atmosphere and detail.) I also salute the way he alerts us to the fact that "buildings of large dimensions have always posed moral problems": a proposal that deserves to be more widely circulated in this age of empty monument.

As for his portrait of Brunelleschi itself, it is certainly plausible. You get the feeling that he has done his research, however concise the book is. Its price is justified by the classy design and colour plates for you to sigh over. Vasari, while the first source one should turn to in such matters, can be somewhat unreliable. Not that one reads him for reliability; anyway, we are a little more priggish about the accuracy of the historical record than we used to be.

"Heaven adorned him," Vasari writes of Brunelleschi, "with the best virtues, among which was that of kindliness, so that no man was ever more benign or amiable than he... when he saw worth and merit in others he would sacrifice his own advantage and the interest of his friends." Hmm, you might say to that after reading King.

His Brunelleschi is perhaps a little less saintly (although a touching lack of concern for keeping track of his money emerges): touchier, ready for a round of insulting sonnets, and prepared to execute the most elaborate and humiliating practical jokes on people for the smallest of reasons. But then Ross King, unlike Vasari, was not commissioned to paint an enormous fresco of the Last Judgement on the underside of Brunelleschi's dome.

webTitle: Review: The Brontë Myth  by Lucasta Miller

fields.headline: Wuthering on and on
fields.standfirst: Kasia Boddy  on a witty deconstruction of Brontëmania in Lucasta Miller's  The Brontë Myth
fields.trailText: Kasia Boddy on a witty deconstruction of Brontëmania in Lucasta Miller's The Brontë Myth
fields.body:
The Brontë Myth

Lucasta Miller

335pp, Jonathan Cape, £18.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

If the Brontë myth has a long and enduring history, so too does its debunking. In 1904 Henry James spoke disparagingly of readers' "beguiled infatuation" with the story of the sisters, and Miller claims her own starting point was Terry Eagleton's 25-year-old Myths of Power , a study of the "literary industry" surrounding the Brontës.

Perhaps the funniest of recent demythologisations was that undertaken in the early 1980s by comedian Victoria Wood. In a sketch (available on LP) she plays a guide whose tour of the Parsonage largely involves pointing at the window and telling the group that the wind out there is probably "wuthering", and that in the restaurant the health-conscious might like to try the Branwell burger. Miller provides both her own critical biography of the Brontës, with an inevitable emphasis on Charlotte, and what she calls a metabiography - a consideration of the way that the writers' lives, as well as their works, have, over the years, been appropriated for all sorts of cultural purposes.

She digests a plethora of material on the Brontës and their cultural "afterlife", not only in the biscuit tins and tea-towels of Howarth, but also in film, all manner of fiction and, indeed, literary criticism itself. She also draws on recent scholarly work on mid-Victorian culture. All this is done with a deft and light touch, and the excesses and bizarre confusions of Brontëmania are revealed with wry and engaging humour. This image was challenged in 1913 when a group of passionate if ambiguous letters to the Belgian schoolteacher Constantin Heger allowed a post-Freudian Charlotte to emerge. In the 1970s, the balance of power between the siblings shifted again, when in the wake of the women's movement a proto-feminist Charlotte was revived. Anne, it must be said, has never contributed much to "the Brontë myth".

Fair enough, we might think, but isn't there also an abundance of work on the writings - and, more generally, is the reading and the writing of not entirely accurate biographies really so damaging for writers? Miller begins by confessing that she used to read books on the Brontës "compulsively", and her sometimes vehement condemnation of biography-lovers has a little of the reformed addict about it.

Ironically though, books such as this, designed to chastise readers enthralled by the writer's life rather than work, end up simply feeding their obsession. Who, after all, will buy this book? Furthermore, writers themselves are often as guilty, if not more so, of mythologising as their lowbrow readers, and with often fruitful results.

Both Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath were fascinated by the life as well as the work of Emily Brontë, and that fascination fed into their poetry. And in her own search for literary models, Emily Brontë drew almost as extensively on Thomas Moore's heavily mythologised life of Byron as on the poet's works. A good story is a good story, whether or not it happens to be true.

However precise literary biography may become, and however much readers are exhorted to focus on the text, the text and nothing but the text, it seems that myths surrounding authors will not be easy to dispel. We still crave "exemplary lives", and it is not clear that that is actually as bad a thing as Miller claims it to be.
