webTitle: Review: The Idea of Louis Sullivan and Atget by John Szarkowski

fields.headline: Cities of light
fields.standfirst: Geoff Dyer  sees the life-facts of skyscrapers in John Szarkowski's books The Idea of Louis Sullivan and Atget
fields.trailText: Geoff Dyer sees the life-facts of skyscrapers in John Szarkowski's books The Idea of Louis Sullivan and Atget
fields.body:
The Idea of Louis Sullivan

John Szarkowski

162pp, Thames & Hudson, £39.95

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Atget

John Szarkowski

224pp, Callaway/The Museum of Modern Art, £42.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

If you've read Hemingway and Fitzgerald, then - whether or not you've heard of him - you have an inkling of the part played in determining the shape of modern American fiction by Max Perkins, their editor. In the same way, anyone who has seen pictures by Diane Arbus or Garry Winogrand has an inkling of the part played by John Szarkowski in the development of post-war photography.

Szarkowski took over as director of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, New York, in 1962. He curated landmark exhibitions such as "New Documents" (1967), which aimed to show how a "new generation of photographers" - Arbus et al - had "directed the documentary approach toward more personal ends". It's not just that Szarkowski provided a forum for photographers; he also established a new sense of what photographs could look like, and he practised the art he championed.

In the 1950s he made a series of photographs of buildings by the architect who pioneered the development of the skyscraper, Louis Sullivan (1856-1924). Frank Lloyd Wright - who worked for and revered Sullivan - considered them the best photographs of "the Master's" buildings that he had come across. It's easy to see why. Instead of simply showing a building, these photographs encourage you visually to walk round it. A door glimpsed in one picture becomes the vantage point from which another facet of the building is viewed in the next. It is like a virtual experience in two dimensions. One's sense both of the intricacies of the buildings' design and, crucially, of their histories as buildings - what Szarkowski calls their "life-facts" - is constantly enhanced by the little human dramas being played out in and around them.

This is impressive enough. Sullivan's importance, however, lies not just in what he built but in the vision his buildings embodied. Architects had built high before but, as Wright put it, until Sullivan they "were fighting height instead of gracefully and honestly accepting it". As far as Sullivan himself was concerned, a skyscraper had to "be tall, every inch of it tall." Rarely can William Carlos Williams's credo - "no ideas but in things" - have been so vertiginously realised. When he expressed these ideas in writing, Sullivan had a tendency to sub-Whitman grandiloquence, but Szarkowski interpolates quotations in such a way that his book does not just describe but realises Sullivan's genius both photographically and critically.

Sullivan fell into ruin, ended up as a drunk. In Szarkowski's pictures, the interior of the Chicago Auditorium is peeling, decaying. These glimpses are like portents of the decline that will become the subject of photographs in Camilo Jose Vergara's American Ruins. Already, by the time Szarkowski saw it, Sullivan's famous Prudential Building in Buffalo, New York, was sufficiently dilapidated to persuade him to photograph it "immediately, before it was further defaced". This task of photographic preservation makes one think of Eugene Atget in Paris.

First published in 1956, The Idea of Louis Sullivan came into existence partly due to Walker Evans who, according to Szarkowski, was "closest to becoming Atget's artistic successor". By a happy coincidence, a new edition - a visual equivalent of a re-mix - of the young man's work comes out at the same time as his latest book, on Atget.

Atget photographed a Paris that had become abruptly old in the wake of Baron Haussmann's civic planning. Modestly providing "documents" for artists and other commercial clients, Atget built up a massive inventory of the city's streets, statues, alleys, and courtyards that has since become the ghostly reservoir of a distinctive aesthetic sensibility. Intended as an objective record, his work so fascinated Man Ray that he wanted to publish it in La Révolution Surréaliste (Atget agreed, reluctantly, on condition that his name was not used). Through Ray it came to the attention of Berenice Abbott, who intervened to ensure the preservation of Atget's archive after his death in 1927.

Little is known about Atget. He is another of those photographers, like Bellocq and William Gedney, who exist almost entirely in terms of what they saw. Embodying this in the conception of his book, Szarkowski provides only the briefest of introductions. The rest of the text comprises "captions" that cast, as it were, sidelong glances at the accompanying pictures in order to "name some of the qualities that reside in them". Just as Atget's vision of Paris is made up of incremental views and details, so Szarkowski's idea of Atget emerges gradually (there are no overviews), subtly. We respond to the book in kind: it is so original that it takes a while to realise that this is not simply a great photography book but a work of genius.

Walter Benjamin famously remarked that Atget photographed Paris as if it were the scene of a crime. He was referring to the fact that Atget's deserted streets (a result, in part, of long exposure times that erased moving people or carriages) are photographed "for the purpose of establishing evidence". As such, Benjamin continues, "free-floating contemplation is not appropriate to them". On this score Szarkowski proves Benjamin wrong beyond reasonable doubt. His captions are simultaneously oblique parables and historical musings, investigations of photographic technique and metaphysical essays that can, at any moment, develop into exquisite, unpeopled fictions. Reading them is like watching the photos breathe. Idiosyncratic, speculative ("I do not think that empty chairs meant the same thing before photography as they mean to us now"), they might even seem whimsical were it not for the immense foundation of technical understanding on which they are based.

It is often said that historians bring their learning to bear on the subjects they discuss. That needs to be modified here. Szarkowski proceeds with such delicacy that each photograph is brushed with his forensic knowledge of the period and the medium. Looking at a picture made in 1921-2 of cypress trees and a slightly broken white fence, Szarkowski notes that many critics and photographers assume that Atget was a 19th-century photographer. In fact, much of his greatest work was done while Ray, Edward Weston and others "were defining the character of photographic high modernism". When Szarkowski adds that this photo "was made six or seven years after the great Paul Strand picture 'White Fence', which Atget surely never saw", we see exactly what he means.

These books are about two figures who made historic contributions to their respective disciplines; the same, now, must be said of their author.

webTitle: Review: The Many-Headed Hydra by Marcus Rediker and  Peter Linebaugh

fields.headline: Revolution at the docks
fields.standfirst: Sukhdev Sandhu  on the slaves and radicals at the heart of Empire in The Many-Headed Hydra by Marcus Rediker and  Peter Linebaugh
fields.trailText: Sukhdev Sandhu on the slaves and radicals at the heart of Empire in The Many-Headed Hydra by Marcus Rediker and Peter Linebaugh
fields.body:
The Many-Headed Hydra: Sailors, Slaves, Commoners, and the Hidden History of the Revolutionary Atlantic

Marcus Rediker and Peter Linebaugh

352pp, Verso, £20.31
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Who now remembers labour? Both its dignity and its many indignities rarely feature in public discourse. In a matter of decades the nation has been virtually deindustrialised. Leisure is sovereign. Docks, where for centuries so many people toiled and lived, are in most British cities merely places to go to for a drink and to eyeball the luxury riverside apartments opposite.

The older world of docks and quays is the territory of Marcus Rediker and Peter Linebaugh's magnificent study, The Many-Headed Hydra . The authors chart the process by which powerless and dispossessed peoples - commoners, felons, religious radicals, pirates, urban labourers, soldiers, sailors, and African slaves - were, from the early 15th to the 17th centuries, marshalled into serving the cause of colonial expansion. A common metaphor, used by philosophers such as Francis Bacon, was the need for Hercules (regal authority, imperial rule, mercantile self-interest) to "strangle the Hydra of misrule". Hydra, in this context, refers to anyone - lippy prole and conscientious objector alike - who stood in the way of profit.

A central chapter of the book is concerned with what came to be known as the New York Conspiracy. In March 1741, radicals set fire to New York. Fort George, the prime military fortification in British America, was reduced to ashes. Soon, other metropolitan landmarks were torched. These were no random conflagrations. Lying on the west side of Manhattan, Fort George was a site of huge strategic importance for the Atlantic trade and a nodal point of the Britain-Africa-Americas triangle. Slaves and slave products were imported there. It was also populated by a swarm of people whose labours underwrote the city's wealth, but who themselves were wholly despised.

These "outcasts of the nations of the earth", as the authorities called them, feasted and caroused in wharf taverns. Practising a form of proto-communism, they allowed the poor to eat for free. Some, such as John Gwin, a black American slave who had a child by a young Irish prostitute, gleefully hopped the colour line. What bound them together was their desire to overthrow the system that made these pleasures so hard-won.

They hailed from all corners of the globe: Africans from the Gold Coast of West Africa who, before being shipped across to America, had served as local soldiers; Irish men and women who had taken to the oceans after the famine of 1728, and who were eager to take revenge on the Protestant English; Spanish-American sailors, skilled in both seamanship and fighting, who had been captured and enslaved by the British Navy.

Social and political instability was not confined to the east coast. Throughout the 1730s and 1740s revolts had been springing up all across the Americas. Men who had either witnessed or helped to foment rebellion across the world were to play a large part in the New York Conspiracy. Men such as "Will", who in 1733 was involved in a slave revolt on Danish St John, in which black rebels seized control of the island's military installation. He was captured and sold first to a planter in Antigua and then to a trader in New York, where he passed on to dock-workers the seditious lesson he had picked up over the years.

Despite the revolutionary acumen of its participants, the New York Conspiracy failed. There were tactical mistakes and, perhaps, they did not enjoy the support of enough city dwellers.

Retribution was swift and harsh. Many rebels were hanged or exiled. Those of European origin were made to join the British army. The authorities produced a series of measures to stop such uprisings ever happening again: dockside alehouses were rigorously patrolled or shut down; merchants began to trade directly with Africa rather than sending ships to the rebellious Caribbean; whites who fraternised with people of other races were demonised.

Yet at the very moment of defeat, something very strange happened. Three weeks after the gibbeted bodies of John Hughson and John Gwin, two of the ringleaders, had been put on public display to warn off those thinking of challenging the system, their remains began to change colour. According to one contemporary source, New Yorkers marvelled at how the features of Hughson, a white man, had taken on "the symmetry of a negro beauty; the nose broad and flat, the nostrils open and extended". Africa-born Gwin, in contrast, "was at the time somewhat bleached or turned whitish".

This mutability is to the point. The authors posit the existence of an Atlantic proletariat, motley in dress and ethnic composition, landless but mobile, female as well as male, routinely terrorised but endlessly resourceful, who were essential to the rise of capitalism and the modern, global economy.

This new class of people, flung together by circumstance, fought for control of those spaces of exploitation, such as prisons, ships and plantations, in which they suddenly found themselves. Irishmen and Africans hatched escape bids on Barbados estates. In Chesapeake the tobacco proletariat of Quakers, Newgateers and sailors frequently attacked their masters. So common was marriage between Englishwomen and slaves in Maryland that a law forbidding it had to be passed in 1664.

A pidgin language emerged, made up in equal parts of nautical slang, underworld cant and African grammar. Solidarities were forged and ideas about suffrage and freedom developed, many of them bearing the imprint of those many English Ranters and radicals who had left for the West Indies around 1660. Truth, according to the authors, in one of many evocative passages, "swayed on the decks of deep-sea ships; it rubbed shoulders with the poor in the taverns of the divaricated port cities; it strained for a hearing on the benches of the Great Awakening, or on stools on the dirt floors of slave cabins at night".

Rediker and Linebaugh are celebrated American scholars whose pioneering studies over the last two decades have helped to shift labour history from its skilled, white, male moorings. Their interest in the intellectual lives of working people and in the forms of knowledge shared at sea, the place Derek Walcott labelled "that grey vault", has influenced the likes of Paul Gilroy, whose The Black Atlantic calls for bottom-up, historically inflected and non-nationalistic forms of black identity thinking.

As with all partisan histories, Rediker and Linebaugh's account sometimes strains credibility. Their portrait of life aboard pirate ships in the 1720s veers towards the utopian. So eager are they to champion the radicalism of the ex-slave Olaudah Equiano that they omit to mention that he came from a slave-owning family in Africa, and that he bought and set to work a number of slaves long after he himself had been freed.

Nonetheless, The Many-Headed Hydra is a wonderful book. Its passion and commitment encourage the reader to think associatively, to make progressive connections. Just after I finished it, I suddenly recalled a scene from Naomi Klein's No Logo , where she describes the international networks of resistance that have sprung up in recent years to combat exploitative labour practices and human rights violations. Those involved in these campaigns are also named after a multi-tentacled creature. They call themselves spiders.

Irishmen and Africans hatched escape bids on Barbados estates. In Chesapeake the tobacco proletariat of Quakers, Newgateers and sailors frequently attacked their masters. So common was marriage between Englishwomen and slaves in Maryland that a law forbidding it had to be passed in 1664. A pidgin language emerged, made up in equal parts of nautical slang, underworld cant and African grammar. Solidarities were forged and ideas about suffrage and freedom developed, many of them bearing the imprint of those many English Ranters and radicals who had left for the West Indies around 1660. Truth, according to the authors, in one of many evocative passages, "swayed on the decks of deep-sea ships; it rubbed shoulders with the poor in the taverns of the divaricated port cities; it strained for a hearing on the benches of the Great Awakening, or on stools on the dirt floors of slave cabins at night". Rediker and Linebaugh are celebrated American scholars whose pioneering studies over the last two decades have helped to shift labour history from its skilled, white, male moorings. Their interest in the intellectual lives of working people and in the forms of knowledge shared at sea, the place Derek Walcott labelled "that grey vault", has influenced the likes of Paul Gilroy, whose The Black Atlantic calls for bottom-up, historically inflected and non-nationalistic forms of black identity thinking. As with all partisan histories, Rediker and Linebaugh's account sometimes strains credibility. Their portrait of life aboard pirate ships in the 1720s veers towards the utopian. So eager are they to champion the radicalism of the ex-slave Olaudah Equiano that they omit to mention that he came from a slave-owning family in Africa, and that he bought and set to work a number of slaves long after he himself had been freed. Nonetheless, The Many-Headed Hydra is a wonderful book. Its passion and commitment encourage the reader to think associatively, to make progressive connections. Just after I finished it, I suddenly recalled a scene from Naomi Klein's No Logo , where she describes the international networks of resistance that have sprung up in recent years to combat exploitative labour practices and human rights violations. Those involved in these campaigns are also named after a multi-tentacled creature. They call themselves spiders.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.trailText: Chris Petit rounds up the best new spine-tinglers
fields.body:
After Martin Cruz Smith who needs Russia? Because of Gorky Park and what followed, I never gave Donald James's Monstrum much of a chance, which shows what I know. With Vadim (Century, £10), James's Russian Inspector is on his third outing, with sales rivalling those of that other combination of English author and foreign policeman, Dibdin and Zen.

As with Martin Cruz Smith's last outing - a static trip to Cuba - James also has his man abroad: Vadim is dispatched to the US in 2020, where the usual Jamesian talent for historical sweep and political speculation is on display, sometimes at the expense of the nitty-gritty of plotting. Vadim becomes involved with a presidential candidate whose campaign is threatened by a series of mad murders, and this time the love interest is blind rather than waiting to be killed off. Purists may be disappointed by the non-Russian setting, and with an overstretched plot it's easy to pick holes, but Vadim has more verve and humour than its predecessors, and better weather.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Conspiracy Theories by Robin Ramsay (Pocket Essentials, £3.99) is a slim guide to the subject, a useful overview and counter to the wiggy delirium of US conspiracy theory publications such as Psychic Dictatorship in the USA and The Gemstone File, both mind-boggling (Aristotle Onassis as JFK's and Howard Hughes's nemesis). The conspiracy theory - and its corollary, paranoia - were bound to grow in popularity, given the political cover-up after the Kennedy assassination, the subsequent emergence of an international counter-culture and a burgeoning information technology, to the point where they are almost mainstream. The gunman on the grassy knoll hasn't yet been used to sell Coca-Cola/Nike, but that day can't be far away.

Ramsay, who has done good digging into the world of the cover-up as editor of Lobster and author of Smear! Wilson and The Secret State, takes a sceptical view of the wilder speculations, arguing that conspiracy in reality is more prosaic and closer to home. The coup d'état is still the most common form of government takeover and, in this country, the most successful conspiracy is plain for all to see in those fluent protectors of self-interest, the Establishment and its intellectual orthodoxy.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

With thrillers especially, readers find themselves bombarded by worldwide bestselling authors they've never heard of: witness Matthew Reilly, touted as an "international phenomenon" at the age of 26. To go by the absence of critical comment on the back cover of Temple (Pan, £5.99), its predecessor Ice Station achieved success without the benefit of reviews. Actually, there is very little to say, or recommend, about Temple except that it reads more like a computer game than a book, an update of Rider Haggard/Indiana Jones high adventure for the video age, which would be fine if it were any good. Boring good people, boring bad people, no wrinkles, remedial prose, too skippable.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

fields.headline: Snap, crackle and pop
fields.trailText: No sooner had Sir Tim Rice addressed his "remarks" to the assembled worthies at the 30th Whitbread Book of the Year Awards than speculation began as to his definition of the "casting vote"
fields.body:
 No sooner had Sir Tim Rice addressed his "remarks" to the assembled worthies at the 30th Whitbread Book of the Year Awards than speculation began as to his definition of the "casting vote". In particular, those smarting at Matthew Kneale's "microscopic" precedence over the late Lorna Sage - including judges who rushed over to Fourth Estate's table to commiserate - wondered at the etiquette of a chairman who both participated in the initial voting and then moved in to break the tie. Indeed, who was it who insisted that the prize could not be awarded jointly, as, in rare instances, has happened with the Booker? Presumably, those eminences grises intent on making the Whitbread resemble a sporting tournament rather than a literary prize.

 If Fourth Estate took defeat graciously, then so too did also-rans Zadie Smith, John Burnside and Jamila Gavin, all somewhat glossed over in the big build-up to the two-horse race. Smith, of course, still has the thrill of the WHSmith Awards to look forward to, and is reassuringly nominated for both New Talent and Literary categories. Public voting began this week; so intense is the giant retailer's desire for democracy that, should your fancy fail to be tickled by the shortlists on offer, you can nominate your own replacement, although quite how much weight this process will have remains unclear. All of which makes the Whitbread look like a model of simplicity and fair play.

 "It is not an autobiography, but it is an extremely insightful and intimate portrait of a great performer." It will be accompanied by a Channel 4 documentary. It is the result of much earnest persuasion from eager publishers, undeterred by the spectre of Anthea. Its subject is signed up to write a volume of poetry for Virgin Books. He is Robbie Williams. Let him entertain you and who knows what might crop up on the Whitbread Biography Award shortlist.

 Nobrow author John Seabrook has revealed plans for a canny marketing strategy - appearing on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? Apparently, it works wonders for your Amazon rating. Publicists, take note.

fields.headline: Fowler faces trial by firepower
fields.standfirst: The striker who had it all and threw most of it away has another shot at redemption today
fields.trailText: The striker who had it all and threw most of it away has another shot at redemption today.
fields.body:
Salutary tales are 10 a penny in football but there is still a certain piquancy to the one which maps out the rise and fall of Robbie Fowler. The Liverpool striker is facing the most crucial period of a once brilliant career that has lurched recently from crisis to crisis.

Brief respite from the rumours and intrigue was provided by Wednesday's Worthington Cup semi-final against Crystal Palace in which the Fowler of old fleetingly emerged, but Leeds United will hope to prove in today's FA Cup fourth-round tie at Elland Road that what was unquestionably his finest single performance in years was a one-off.

Two seasons ravaged by ankle and knee troubles have lessened his effectiveness to such an extent that it is still conceivable that his manager Gérard Houllier will sanction his departure come season's end, with Chelsea and Rangers possible destinations. In essence, one of English football's most gifted, most natural footballers will spend the next four months on trial. If he can become the main man on the pitch and the invisible man away from it, he may yet put his troubles behind him.

That his seemingly inevitable transformation from local hero to world star has been savagely interrupted by unfortunate injuries is not open to debate, but at least five summers ago a Merseyside public which had come to marvel at the young striker's prodigious talent was first warned that, where Fowler was concerned, though you could take the boy out of Toxteth you would never be able to take Toxteth out of the boy.

At the time it seemed little more than a neat, smart-arse quip. However, though the sage responsible has long been forgotten, his words are arguably more potent and more relevant today. It is hardly surprising that Fowler is struggling to score goals for, despite being only 25, he has spent so much time walking towards crossroads, watersheds, defining moments and points of no return that his feet must be blistered and sore.

The less sympathetic might also suggest that he has spent so long supping in the last-chance saloon that he is too often found to be tired and emotional - usually in the wee small hours. To suggest that he has developed the unfortunate habit of being in the wrong place at the wrong time would be to understate matters. Liverpool has become a city of bars and 24/7 revelry; its vibrancy is addictive and those supportive of Fowler argue that he is doing no more than falling prey to the temptations of youth and so deserves not wholesale condemnation and abuse but patience and understanding.

"I honestly believe he has been so unlucky in his personal life," says Fowler's most illustrious former strike partner Ian Rush. "It's not as though he's out roaming the streets with a gang of lads. On the last occasion he was attacked he was out with his wife - something we all do. I don't believe he is a marked man in Liverpool; he's growing up now, he's happily married and has two young children. Different people mature at different rates.

"On the playing front he has struggled for so long with injuries; now he's struggling to adapt to a squad rotation system, an alien system to players like him and Michael Owen. He'll make it back to what he was, I'm sure of that. Why? Well, because he's one of the finest forwards we have ever seen in this country."

Jan Molby, the former Anfield midfielder and now Kidderminster's man ager, strikes a more cautious note. "There always comes a point in life where we have to deliver on our promise. Robbie has done so much for Liverpool but he now finds himself in a situation where he must prove himself all over again.

"He doesn't necessarily have to prove himself to the fans but to the manager. I believe in him and so do the fans, but it is results which matter to a manager. The rumours about his future have been going around for more than a year now and the only thing he can do is to put Gérard Houllier in a position where he could not even consider selling him."

Those who really know Fowler invari ably speak in almost reverential tones about his love of Liverpool the city, Liverpool the club, his wife and his two young kids. Of course, the postscript is always that he is simply misunderstood and seeks nothing more than a shed-load of goals while working and the quiet life when off duty. In short, though friends, apologists, call them what you may, acknowledge he is hardly angel material, they see him as a non-malevolent free spirit.

Many players have chosen to walk on the wild side but they were invariably the game's mavericks - players such as George Best, Stan Bowles, Alan Hudson, Rodney Marsh and Eric Cantona. Fowler is more tenderfoot than maverick, the Peter Pan of Anfield who is reluctant to grow up and now faces the very real prospect of being classified as one of English football's most celebrated lost boys. There is genuine fear within his club that at 25 his best days may already be available on video cassettes in the Anfield souvenir shop.

As even the most dedicated of his tormentors would concede, Fowler is undemonstrative, polite and self-effacing when in company and one can only conclude it is the unsuppressible childish streak within him which tends to land him in bother. And there has been plenty of that these past couple of seasons: two late-night assaults on him in bars, sendings-off, suspensions, fines, dressing-downs, warnings, threats, ultimatums.

The footballing fraternity is still prone to throwing a comfort blanket around his shoulders when invited to discuss an apparent obsession with self-destruction. That, perhaps, is understandable, for amid all the tales of dark deeds it is easy to forget what a truly brilliant footballer he can be.

"He is one of the best strikers I have ever seen," says the former Liverpool manager and striker Kenny Dalglish. "He's certainly one of the most intelligent in footballing terms. He was only 15 or 16 when we were together at Liverpool but he used to come and train with the first team and you could see that he had something very special. You don't lose that sort of thing."

Dalglish is not usually wrong. Indeed, he prides himself on an ability to have the last, telling word. He may well be proved right again, but for now at least the doubts linger.

The highs and lows of a player who had the world at his feet

1993 Makes league debut in September. Later scores five goals for Liverpool against Fulham.

1994 Fined £1,000 for baring backside at Leicester City fans.

1995 Scores 31 goals and is voted the PFA's young player of the year.

1996 England debut In March and later voted PFA young player of the year again, after scoring 35 goals in 53 games.

1997 Praised for sportsmanship when he tries to persuade referee Gerald Ashby not to award a penalty against Arsenal's David Seaman.

1997 Fined £900 after lifting his shirt to display a vest in support of striking Liverpool dockers.

1998 Injures knee in February and misses rest of the season and World Cup.

1999 Charged with misconduct after making insulting gestures towards Graeme le Saux (left).

1999 Two months later fined £32,000 and banned for six matches after pretending to snort the white line of the six-yard box in a clear reference to drug-taking (below).

2000 Attacked in the toilets of a Liverpool hotel.

2000 Chelsea's bid of £12m is rejected after he insists he wishes to remain at Anfield.

2001 Assaulted in the early hours while out in Liverpool with his wife.

2001 Aston Villa become the second Premiership club to lodge a bid of £12m but he reiterates his desire to remain on Merseyside.

fields.headline: White ' s week
fields.standfirst: Pope ensures Irish wings have a prayer
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle, in his early days as England manager, when he was still capable of engaging his mouth without putting his foot in it, was asked by our own Mark Lawson about the power of prayer in a sporting context. Lawson wanted to know whether, as a born again whatever he is born again as, Hoddle would be enlisting the Almighty's support, for instance, during a penalty shoot-out.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle, in his early days as England manager, when he was still capable of engaging his mouth without putting his foot in it, was asked by our own Mark Lawson about the power of prayer in a sporting context. Lawson wanted to know whether, as a born again whatever he is born again as, Hoddle would be enlisting the Almighty's support, for instance, during a penalty shoot-out.

Amused by the idea, Hoddle replied that he thought God would be too busy to worry about such trivial things, he had major work on his hands after all - presumably deciding who should be reincarnated as a disabled person.

With the way things turned out in St Etienne, when God moved in mysterious ways thus completely confusing David Batty, Hoddle was wise to be circumspect. Yet, despite the obvious hostage it offers to fortune, sports teams still try to seek celestial blessing before big games.

The Irish rugby squad is the latest to believe that alongside a high carbohydrate diet, intensive fitness coaching and last-minute intake of Jaffa cakes, God's approval is just what is required to complete their preparations.

They will all be seeking an audience with the Pope this weekend, hoping to benefit from the old boy's special relationship with upstairs ahead of their first Six Nations game against Italy next Saturday.

Whether, in a sort of Whitehall farce in the Vatican, the Italians themselves will be coming in through one set of doors looking for their slice of benediction as the Irish leave through another is not yet known.

Nor will we actually know whose side God is on until next Saturday afternoon when, you would think, He will be exhausted after being obliged by millions of supplicants across the world to adjudicate on behalf of their favoured team.

But, even if nothing comes of it, the meeting with God's ambassador on earth will be one which several Ulster-born members of the squad will find something of a novelty. Indeed, with its cross-border make-up, the Irish rugby team has always answered the question about which side God is on with an enigmatic "both".

Despite the Papal blessing, this is, after all, an entirely ecumenical outfit in an island riven with sectarianism. It is Irish rugby's great strength that for 80 minutes it unites Irishmen of all persuasions. The crowd at Lansdowne Road for internationals has traditionally been swollen by RUC officers, standing underneath fluttering tricolours, willing on the green-shirted boys to give the English a good kicking, before returning north over the border to defend the union by cracking a few nationalist heads.

Elsewhere on these islands the position that God takes on sporting matters has been disputed in a much less inclusive manner. In Glasgow, back to the beginnings of organised sport, religion has been an ever-present fig leaf for prejudice. Tommy Docherty remembers playing in an Old Firm match in the 50s when the atmosphere was so poisonous it made Chernobyl seem a paragon of the clean air act.

Docherty played for Celtic who, unlike Rangers, have never adopted a policy of recruiting players after first taking into account their position on transubstantiation. Before this particular game in the corner of the dressing room one of Docherty's colleagues, who happened to be a Protestant, was looking terrified. Docherty tried to comfort him.

"But you don't understand," said the full-back, "I can't stand all the abuse. They always call me a Fenian bastard."

"Oh, that," said Docherty. "For me that's just water off a duck's back."

"It's all very well for you to say that," said the player. "You are one."

At Ibrox in the past God was always reckoned to wear a bowler hat, carry a furled umbrella and have an edition of the collected speeches of Ian Paisley tucked under His arm. Yet, despite what some old-timers in attendance expected, when the Italian player Lorenzo Amoruso trotted on to the pitch on his debut, kissed his crucifix for good luck and extravagantly crossed himself, the ground did not open up, the turf remained intact and the south stand was not engulfed in the fires of hell.

In fact, these days, now that it has become commonplace for certain members of Rangers' multi-national squad to engage in Catholic practices, crossing and re-crossing themselves as they search for the divine inspiration, the crowd barely bother with a sharp intake of breath - which, in many ways, counts as progress.

And for those who maintain that even so it will be some time before we see Dick Advocaat winding up Rangers' winter break in Florida with a quick detour via the Vatican, I say this: with a 12-point deficit to overcome, nothing can be ruled out at this stage of the season.

Whether, in a sort of Whitehall farce in the Vatican, the Italians themselves will be coming in through one set of doors looking for their slice of benediction as the Irish leave through another is not yet known. Nor will we actually know whose side God is on until next Saturday afternoon when, you would think, He will be exhausted after being obliged by millions of supplicants across the world to adjudicate on behalf of their favoured team. But, even if nothing comes of it, the meeting with God's ambassador on earth will be one which several Ulster-born members of the squad will find something of a novelty. Indeed, with its cross-border make-up, the Irish rugby team has always answered the question about which side God is on with an enigmatic "both". Despite the Papal blessing, this is, after all, an entirely ecumenical outfit in an island riven with sectarianism. It is Irish rugby's great strength that for 80 minutes it unites Irishmen of all persuasions. The crowd at Lansdowne Road for internationals has traditionally been swollen by RUC officers, standing underneath fluttering tricolours, willing on the green-shirted boys to give the English a good kicking, before returning north over the border to defend the union by cracking a few nationalist heads. Elsewhere on these islands the position that God takes on sporting matters has been disputed in a much less inclusive manner. In Glasgow, back to the beginnings of organised sport, religion has been an ever-present fig leaf for prejudice. Tommy Docherty remembers playing in an Old Firm match in the 50s when the atmosphere was so poisonous it made Chernobyl seem a paragon of the clean air act. Docherty played for Celtic who, unlike Rangers, have never adopted a policy of recruiting players after first taking into account their position on transubstantiation. Before this particular game in the corner of the dressing room one of Docherty's colleagues, who happened to be a Protestant, was looking terrified. Docherty tried to comfort him. "But you don't understand," said the full-back, "I can't stand all the abuse. They always call me a Fenian bastard." "Oh, that," said Docherty. "For me that's just water off a duck's back." "It's all very well for you to say that," said the player. "You are one." At Ibrox in the past God was always reckoned to wear a bowler hat, carry a furled umbrella and have an edition of the collected speeches of Ian Paisley tucked under His arm. Yet, despite what some old-timers in attendance expected, when the Italian player Lorenzo Amoruso trotted on to the pitch on his debut, kissed his crucifix for good luck and extravagantly crossed himself, the ground did not open up, the turf remained intact and the south stand was not engulfed in the fires of hell. In fact, these days, now that it has become commonplace for certain members of Rangers' multi-national squad to engage in Catholic practices, crossing and re-crossing themselves as they search for the divine inspiration, the crowd barely bother with a sharp intake of breath - which, in many ways, counts as progress. And for those who maintain that even so it will be some time before we see Dick Advocaat winding up Rangers' winter break in Florida with a quick detour via the Vatican, I say this: with a 12-point deficit to overcome, nothing can be ruled out at this stage of the season.

webTitle: The odd couple out to get even

fields.headline: The odd couple out to get even
fields.standfirst: Frederic Kanoute talks to  Roy Collins about the telepathy he shares with Paolo di Canio
fields.trailText: Frederic Kanoute talks to Roy Collins about the telepathy he shares with Paolo di Canio
fields.body:
Frédéric Kanouté and Paolo Di Canio are quintessential West Ham players: highly skilful, quick-footed, quick-witted and with an eye for the spectacular. But, as they prepare to take on Manchester United tomorrow at Old Trafford, it would be pushing things to call them a striking partnership in the traditional sense. They are not, for instance, a partnership like the one Alan Shearer and Teddy Sheringham formed for England, contrasting players who complement each other's skills and work to feed each other's strengths. Kanouté and Di Canio are two individual spirits often vying for the same small circle of spotlight at centre stage and who succeed almost in spite of each other - though they have not yet argued over who should take a penalty kick as Di Canio and Frank Lampard once did.

There is, at least, a mutual admiration, with Kanouté saying: "I really like playing with Paolo, even though it is sometimes difficult for us to agree. Sometimes he does his own thing when he gets the ball and sometimes I do mine. We have to work harder to agree together but at this level you should be able to play with anybody."

They certainly lack the near-telepathic understanding which a scientific experiment once tried to prove existed between Kevin Keegan and John Toshack at Liverpool, but nor do they seek one, rarely passing to each other in some matches. But their individual talents somehow form a perfect whole since they have contributed 10 goals each to the West Ham cause this season.

Although both are West Ham types, Di Canio has the more typical profile of a player bought by the manager Harry Redknapp: someone with a troubled history and in the twilight of his career. But in signing Kanouté, 23, Redknapp almost tore out a leaf from Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger's book, by plucking an unknown from France and polishing him into a Premiership gem.

Kanouté, who joined Lyon as an 11-year-old and played in their first team at 16, admits: "No one in France knew I existed. Despite starting early, I did not play many games and it is only since I came to England that people have noticed me." He felt, too, that he had become part of the furniture at Lyon, with the chairman treating him in the same patronising manner as when he was a young boy. So when he fell out with the coach his departure became a formality.

Playing top-level football so young also brought physical problems, earning him an injury-prone reputation. But when he was recommended last season, Redknapp wanted only the usual West Ham question answered: can the boy play? He had his answer when Kanouté made an outstanding debut against Wimbledon last March, joining Di Canio in scoring in a 2-1 win. He was just as impressive in his other seven games last season, scoring once more, and though Redknapp felt that he could not afford the £3.7m fee to sign him permanently, the deal went through after Marc Vivien Foé agreed to travel in the other direction.

Kanouté turned down a move to Celtic before the loan deal at Upton Park and his form last season alerted Rangers, Chelsea and Liverpool. But, despite rumours that he is seeking a bigger stage, he insists: "I am very happy at West Ham and I am very grateful to Harry Redknapp for giving me a chance and for improving my career." Rumours were fuelled when he made the hardly novel claim that he would have more chance of playing for France if he were at Manchester United, Arsenal or Liverpool. But Kevin Phillips recently made a similar comment vis-à-vis his England prospects without anyone suggesting he wanted a move from Sunderland.

Kanouté should recover from a hamstring injury to play tomorrow, having scored the consolation goal in a 3-1 defeat at Old Trafford on New Year's Day. West Ham have failed to beat United in any of their 14 Premiership encounters and Kanouté subscribes to the Wenger theory that, though players may not lie down in front of their presumed masters, they are cowed. "I really believe that players have it in their mind before the match that they are going to lose. But we must not feel like that on Sunday. I would think we should be able to beat them one time in five and maybe that occasion will be this time."

Even though United play a more continental style of game, Kanouté expects his normal bruising encounters with defenders. "In France the game is more calculated; the coach tells the players when to challenge for the ball and when to play forward. In England defenders know only how to fight and be strong." That certainly sums up the Neville brothers, who may have their hands full. If Di Canio and Kanouté actually learned to work together they could be even more devastating, but perhaps that is the secret of their partnership; if one rarely know what the other will do next, how can defences be expected to read them?

webTitle: League to give help over foreign passport worries

fields.headline: League to give help over foreign passport worries
fields.trailText: The Premier League is to contact all its clubs with guidance on identifying foreign players with false passports. A letter will tell clubs how to get advice from the immigration service if they have any doubts over particular players.
fields.body:
The Premier League is to contact all its clubs with guidance on identifying foreign players with false passports. A letter will tell clubs how to get advice from the immigration service if they have any doubts over particular players.

There is increasing concern about the number of players from outside Europe who are playing in England on EU passports, thereby avoiding the need to obtain a work permit.

A Premier League spokesman said: "We are looking at any future ways we can to tighten up procedures but there is a finite amount the game can do."

Investigations by the immigration service last night confirmed that the passports of two Arsenal players, the Lithuanian Tomas Danilevicius and the Brazilian Edu, are genuine. Danilevicius holds a Greek passport, while Edu's is Portuguese.

The Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger earlier said he would not play Danilevicius until doubts about his passport had been resolved.

"When players arrive here we send their passports to the Football Association in good faith. If we check out all the passports ourselves we might as well check every detail of everybody else's life. I don't think that is our obligation.

"But now that this doubt has been raised I will be more wary of signing players from certain parts of the world in future."

Over 70 players in France are currently under investigation over passport problems. Recently St Etienne were docked seven points for fielding an ineligible Ukrainian goalkeeper. Numerous cases have also arisen in Portugal and Italy, where South American players, including Juan Veron of the champions Lazio, were found to have used falsified documents to obtain passports.

While it is relatively straightforward for immigration officials to check whether passports issued by another country are forged or genuine, it is less easy to discover whether a bona fide passport has been granted due to false information given at the application stage.

Coventry City are refusing to comment on a report that Carlton Palmer has been given a free transfer for publicly criticising manager Gordon Strachan. Local newspaper reports claim the transfer-listed Palmer has left the club following comments made about Strachan to match sponsors after the defeat by Everton last weekend.

Leicester City are to seek new sponsors after ending their 10-year association with Walkers Crisps. The club has said that it will announce a new deal within the next month.

webTitle: David Lacey's guide to the pick of the ties

fields.headline: David Lacey's guide to the pick of the ties
fields.trailText: Everton v Tranmere Rovers
fields.body:
Everton v Tranmere Rovers

1967-68: Fifth round: Everton 2 Tranmere Rovers 0

No wonder seasoned Everton fans pine for the quality of football regularly produced by the team of the late 1960s, including as it did the classical midfield combination of Alan Ball, Colin Harvey and Howard Kendall. Tranmere then were struggling to stay in the Third Division and drawing them at home, having beaten Southport and Carlisle United away, further convinced Everton that this was their year in the Cup. Sure enough they reached Wembley but only to lose in extra time to West Bromwich Albion.

Leeds United v Liverpool

1964-65: Final: Leeds United 1 Liverpool 2 (aet)

Beatlemania was at its height when Bill Shankly's Liverpool met the Leeds of Don Revie in a final which struggled to live up to its billing and saved the main drama until extra time. For 90 goalless minutes the game was dominated by defences built solidly around the imposing figures of Ron Yeats and Jack Charlton. Then early in extra time Roger Hunt headed Liverpool in front and although Billy Bremner brought the scores level another header, from Ian St John, took the Cup to Anfield for the first time.

Manchester United v West Ham United

1963-64: Semi-finals: Manchester United 1 West Ham United 3

This result offered a clue to the qualities in Ron Greenwood's West Ham team which were crucial to England winning the 1966 World Cup. The game was played on a Hillsborough mudheap far from helpful to either side. That was the season when Manchester United fully realised the possibilities of having Law, Charlton and Best at their disposal. Yet two goals from Ronnie Boyce and one from Geoff Hurst sent West Ham to Wembley and a 3-2 triumph against Preston.

Queens Park Rangers v Arsenal

1989-90: Fourth-round replay: QPR 2 Arsenal 0

This result may appear to belong to a remote age, yet QPR remained fair-to-middling members of the top division until six years ago. Trevor Francis's side included the considerable experience of Ray Wilkins and Kenny Sansom and caught the champions in a new year slump. Having forced a scoreless draw at Highbury, QPR achieved a notable win at Loftus Road four days later when Sansom scored against his old club. Rangers eventually lost to Liverpool in a quarter-final replay.

Some FA Cup games have louder echoes than others. At least four of this weekend's fourth round ties are repeats of past Cup encounters - one a final, another a semi-final - and in one of the other two the winners have gone on to reach the final. Precedent suggests that at least one of the victors this weekend will be appearing at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff on May 12.

webTitle: Cheap prices reflect value of tarnished trophy

fields.headline: Cheap prices reflect value of tarnished trophy
fields.standfirst: Cup needs to show its true worth, writes  David Lacey
fields.trailText: Cup needs to show its true worth, writes David Lacey
fields.body:
There are two ways of looking at the Football Association's decision to reduce ticket prices for this season's FA Cup final as well as increasing the allocation for the supporters of the teams involved.

Either the FA has at last taken to heart the pleas of fans who for decades have grumbled about the scarcity of Cup final tickets or this is a tacit admission that the competition is no longer a guaranteed bestseller.

The supporters who fill the extra, cheaper seats in the Millennium stadium in Cardiff on May 12 will not be complaining. Yet the FA is unlikely to have reduced the tickets for corporate hospitality and the county associations without checking the market first. And the market may have indicated that while the Millennium stadium is practically everything Wembley is not, the idea of trekking over or under the Severn does not have universal appeal.

In addition, Soho Square has possibly heeded the evidence of the third round, when attendances did not bounce back to normality merely because the idiocy of playing it a fortnight before Christmas in 1999 had been abandoned.

Three weeks ago several ties were watched by crowds which were well below the average home gates of the clubs concerned. There were only 30,000 at Liverpool and Sunderland, a paltry 19,000 at Manchester City and as few as 7,000 at Bradford.

If the best-looking fourth round ties fail to revive greater interest in the Cup this weekend the FA may start to fear empty seats in Cardiff and a repeat of 1993, when the replayed final between Arsenal and Sheffield Wednesday found Wembley 10,000 below capacity.

As it turned out those who stayed away that night were not bad judges. Even so the presence of Arsenal in this season's final would go far towards ensuring a decent turn-out and the FA will also be watching anxiously for the results of tomorrow's ties involving Chelsea and Manchester United as well as the outcome of today's lunchtime meeting between Leeds United and Liverpool.

Again, however, the question has to be put: to what extent are clubs seeking success in this season's Champions League, or a part in next season's tournament, prepared to put themselves out for a trophy which brings them little more than a free ride around town in an open-top bus and a Uefa Cup place which they might not need?

At least the commitment of the players at Elland Road today should provide a positive answer. It is not in the nature of David O'Leary's Leeds side to soft-pedal and Gérard Houllier knows that his credibility at Anfield could do with some silver on the sideboard.

An open, entertaining encounter should be the outcome. At the beginning of November, on the same ground, Leeds and Liverpool produced a Premiership match of extraordinary fluctuations. Mark Viduka scored four times for Leeds, his last two goals enabling them to win 4-3 after being 3-2 down with 17 minutes to go.

The absence of Steven Gerrard and Emile Heskey, both doubtful, from Liverpool's midfield and attack would increase the chances of another, maybe less nerve-racking Leeds victory. But if Robbie Fowler, in such good form when Liverpool demolished Crystal Palace on Wednesday to reach the Worthington Cup final, is still in the team and in the mood, anything might happen.

Both Arsenal and Chelsea should survive their fourth- round visits to Nationwide First Division clubs who have other things on their minds. Queens Park Rangers, who take on Arsène Wenger's off-target artillery, can barely afford to glance at the Cup given their parlous league position while Gillingham's tie with Chelsea has been over shadowed by an FA investigation into alleged financial irregularities at the Kent club.

Should the attendance at Old Trafford tomorrow not reach its usual 67,000-plus it will be because West Ham supporters, possibly tiring of public executions, have not taken up their full quota of tickets. Either way, defeat for Manchester United would be almost as big a shock as Dagenham and Redbridge knocking out Charlton in a third-round replay or Kingstonian winning at Bristol City.

An early clue to at least one of this season's finalists could come at the Stadium of Light, where Sunderland will expect to eliminate Ipswich, having beaten them 4-1 on New Year's Day. Peter Reid's team have come on song at the right time for the FA Cup - except that this time the lyric will be about welcomes in hillsides and coming home to Wales.

webTitle: Gregory fumes as Ginola gets his kicks

fields.headline: Gregory fumes as Ginola gets his kicks
fields.trailText: John Gregory and David Ginola looked on course for the divorce courts last night after the Frenchman was spotted having a filmed kick-about with the television presenter Jeremy Clarkson 24 hours before a game that could make or break Aston Villa's season and their manager's career.
fields.body:
John Gregory and David Ginola looked on course for the divorce courts last night after the Frenchman was spotted having a filmed kick-about with the television presenter Jeremy Clarkson 24 hours before a game that could make or break Aston Villa's season and their manager's career.

While Gregory conducted his media briefing in advance of his side's fourth-round tie with Leicester City, Ginola was bending free-kicks past Clarkson for the cameras at Villa Park. The manager, clearly unimpressed as he watched the scene from a box in the stands, did not know about Ginola's appearance on the programme which is due to be broadcast in April.

Ginola's involvement in the filming so soon before such an important game is more evidence that he appears to operate under his own set of rules at Villa Park. Gregory is already annoyed that, while all the other members of his squad have moved to the Midlands, Ginola commutes from his north London home.

The Frenchman's latest escapade follows on from Gregory describing him as overweight before one game. And now another humiliation appears on the cards as Ginola is unlikely to be named even as a substitute for today's game.

"The signing of Juan Pablo Angel and return to fitness of Ian Taylor and Julian Joachim means I've got my widest choice of substitutes for several months," Gregory said before he had spotted the maverick's latest indiscretion.

Gregory did confirm that Dion Dublin, who was rested for Wednesday's game against Leeds, would return to lead the attack in a game Villa must win if they are to keep their season alive after slipping to 14th in the Premiership and losing five league games on the trot.

Gregory's opposite number at neighbouring Coventry, Gordon Strachan, will find their tie against their fellow strugglers Manchester City a welcome diversion after the abuse he has received this week. Strachan views the game at Maine Road as a chance for his players to rehabilitate themselves after last week's dismal display against Everton. fields.headline: Dyer still on injured list
fields.trailText: The England midfielder Kieron Dyer, who has been suffering from a cyst on his shin, remains doubtful for Wednesday's trip to Chelsea after Newcastle's medical staff ruled out a return to first-team training.
fields.body:
The England midfielder Kieron Dyer, who has been suffering from a cyst on his shin, remains doubtful for Wednesday's trip to Chelsea after Newcastle's medical staff ruled out a return to first-team training.

The 22-year-old has been sidelined for two weeks and was yesterday urged to rest until Monday. "It's a bit of a worry that he's not done any football work," said the United manager Bobby Robson. "We just hope the three-day rest will be beneficial."

Shefki Kuqi, the striker who was Finland's Footballer of the Year last year, has joined Stockport County from Jokerit in a £250,000 deal.

"My goal is to be in the first XI at national level and I can't do that playing in Finland so I think I have a better chance being in England," said the 21-year-old yesterday.

Gary McAllister is set to sign a new one-year contract with Liverpool. The 36-year-old, capped 57 times by Scotland, signed a one-year deal when he moved from Coventry on a free transfer last summer.

"It's fair to say we are very close to agreeing to keep me being here for another year," said the midfielder. "There's not really been a great deal to negotiate, to be honest. I've always hoped to add another season to my contract."

West Bromwich Albion's manager, Gary Megson, has signed a new five-year contract with the Baggies. Since taking charge at The Hawthorns last March, Megson has guided the club away from the relegation zone and transformed them into promotion contenders, picking up the manager of the month award for November.

"Gary has done a very good job in his 11 months here and the success that he has generated on the field has complemented off-the-field projects," said the club's chief executive, John Wile.

webTitle: Morrow's search for pride after fall

fields.headline: Morrow's search for pride after fall
fields.standfirst: QPR defender has no hard feelings for his old captain, says  Jon Brodkin
fields.trailText: QPR defender has no hard feelings for his old captain, says Jon Brodkin
fields.body:
Were Tony Adams to step aside at Loftus Road this afternoon and allow Steve Morrow to score the winner for Queens Park Rangers it would be a fitting gesture. The Arsenal captain owes his former team-mate a favour when it comes to the FA Cup.

By famously dropping Morrow on his shoulder at Wembley after the Irishman had won the Coca-Cola Cup for Arsenal in April 1993, Adams not only hinted that he might be on more than fizzy pop but denied Morrow a chance to repeat the trick against Sheffield Wednesday in the following month's FA Cup final.

When Wednesday were beaten 2-1 in a replay, memories of Morrow being rushed off in agony with an oxygen mask over his face were still fresh. Less a fallen hero than one who had been dropped from a great height, he received an FA Cup winner's medal but celebrations were muted. Since then he has not been beyond the fourth round.

"Obviously I missed all the Coca-Cola Cup celebrations because I was under the knife," the 30-year-old says, "but the worst thing for me was that I missed the FA Cup final a few weeks later. That was hard to take at the time."

Not that he was tempted to hire a crane to exact revenge on Adams. "Tony was devastated," he recalls. "He was first down at the hospital the next day to see me. People think I must have been really angry with him but there was none of that. It was a complete accident."

This will be Morrow's first meeting with Arsenal since he left for QPR in March 1997, six months after Arsène Wenger's arrival. In more than 12 at Highbury, which began as a schoolboy and included cleaning David O'Leary's boots, he made only 85 appearances. Yet, as well as scoring that Wembley winner, he played in two European Cup-Winners' Cup finals.

Though the second against Zaragoza in 1995 ended in defeat, the first saw George Graham's team beat a Parma side including Faustino Asprilla, Gianfranco Zola and Tomas Brolin. Given QPR's plight, second from bottom of the First Division, today's tie is a rare return to the high life for the versatile, articulate Irishman.

"That's a great memory," he says of the Parma match. "It was a good game to play in and we came through it when we weren't expected to win. I'd be the first to admit the squad then didn't have the ability or the talent the one now does but we were organised with George and tactically for the Parma game he got things spot on.

"We got an early goal [through Alan Smith] and defended well for the rest of the match. George played to the players' strengths but I think we got unfair criticism that we were a long-ball team, didn't pass as much as we should have done and all the rest."

Morrow is one of four former Arsenal players at QPR, joining Chris Kiwomya, Matthew Rose and Lee Harper, yet of them all he might feel the change of career direction most acutely. He turned down Premiership offers to go to Loftus Road and expected a quick return to the top flight.

When he arrived the team featured Trevor Sinclair, Andrew Impey, John Spencer and Danny Dichio among others. Now, after severe financial cutbacks caused by annual losses of around £8m, Morrow is surrounded by astute signings such as Stuart Wardley, a one-time removal man, and Jermaine Darlington, who was working as a glazer and turning out for Aylesbury two years ago.

"It was a big wrench to leave Arsenal," says Morrow, who still visits the club's training ground. "It had a lot to do with the fact that Stewart Houston was manager here with Bruce Rioch, and I don't regret it in any way. Arsène Wenger had just taken over and I wasn't playing regularly, so when the offer came up it wasn't too hard a decision.

"When I came here the club were doing well. We just missed out on the play-offs in my first season. Unfortunately, for a number of reasons, it's gone downhill since then but it's been more of a challenge. You can get into a rut some times and hang around being part of a squad."

Trying to break into the renowned Highbury backline involved more hanging around than even Godot might inflict on anyone. Morrow made his Northern Ireland debut against Uruguay before he had played for Arsenal and appreciates what special mentors he had.

"I wouldn't say it was a doddle coming into the back four now and again when I was really young but it was much easier because there were experienced players around you like David O'Leary and Tony Adams," he says. "They helped me out a hell of a lot. You look out there now for replacements for people like Tony but who is there who can just walk in and fill his shoes?"

With Adams and Co wobbling a little, QPR will fancy their chances, though it seems inconceivable these days that they finished above Arsenal in 1993 and 1995. Their manager Gerry Francis, a man twice sounded out by England, does not even watch Premiership matches now, instead taping lower-division games and taking himself to non-league grounds.

Morrow hopes a rare release from the pressure of fighting relegation will inspire QPR and he is due a turn in fortune after missing much of last season with a shoulder injury.

It does, he admits, upset him a little that his cup-final goal tends to get forgotten because of the crash landing that followed. If he gets the winner this time, it will be Adams who comes to earth with a bump.

fields.headline: Keegan wins £150,000 for 'gambling ring' libel
fields.trailText: Former England manager Kevin Keegan yesterday won £150,000 libel damages against a Sunday newspaper which alleged that he was the ringleader of a betting school of England players.
fields.body:
Former England manager Kevin Keegan yesterday won £150,000 libel damages against a Sunday newspaper which alleged that he was the ringleader of a betting school of England players.

The News of the World claimed last November that the gambling ring was running during his time as manager from March 1999 to last October.

The newspaper also alleged that Keegan allowed players to visit the bookmakers on the eve of matches and that thousands of pounds was gambled by the England squad, with those not taking part ostracised by fellow players. It said Keegan organised gambling nights at the team hotel with large amounts of money wagered on the outcome of videoed horse races.

Alasdair Pepper, representing Keegan, told Mr Justice Gray at the high court in London that the claims had a devastating impact on the former manager and represented a serious attack on his professional and personal probity and integrity.

The News of the World was also ordered to pay Keegan's legal costs. If the case had been contested, several England players would have given evidence on his behalf.

Outside court, Keegan, accompanied by his wife Jean, said that the claims had caused misery to him, the England players and the Football Association. He said: "The article made me look like somebody who did not care... everybody who works with me knows that is not true. Today has been a great day for us. It should never have happened. They published it. They paid the price."

The court heard that the players gambled on cards long before Keegan's arrival. Nothing had been organised by Keegan and he made no profit from gambling with members of the squad.

The newspaper's solicitor, Robert Clinton, said it recognised that there was nothing "improper in the conduct of Mr Keegan or the harmless race nights and card games which the players enjoyed".

Stuart Kuttner, managing editor of the News of the World, said in a statement: "What we published we believed at the time to be true, but now accept that it was wrong in those respects set out in court... We are glad to have settled the dispute with Kevin Keegan quickly and in a civilised fashion."

webTitle: Hoeness went and drooled but Wilko won't go

fields.headline: Hoeness went and drooled but Wilko won't go
fields.trailText: The FA Cup this season is unlikely to be won on the playing fields of Andalucia. Yet, should Derby County achieve a favourable result in their fourth-round tie at Blackburn this afternoon, it will bring a quiet smile of satisfaction to the man who has managed to turn one corner of a Marbella field that is not a golf course into a winter paradise for footballers.
fields.body:
The FA Cup this season is unlikely to be won on the playing fields of Andalucia. Yet, should Derby County achieve a favourable result in their fourth-round tie at Blackburn this afternoon, it will bring a quiet smile of satisfaction to the man who has managed to turn one corner of a Marbella field that is not a golf course into a winter paradise for footballers.

This week Derby, followed closely by Nottingham Forest, became the first English club to avail themselves of the facilities offered by Marpafut, a new training and fitness centre which is attracting rave reviews from all who visit it. David Pleat, Tottenham's director of football, has described the centre as "idyllic", and Athletic Bilbao insist that it is superior to Clairfontaine, the sophisticated home of the France national squad outside Paris.

So why all the fuss? English football folk are hardly a novelty on the Costa del Sol and Ron Atkinson would probably be mayor of Marbella by now had not Jesus Gil, his one-time boss at Atletico Madrid, got there first. And La Manga Club, where England trained before the last World Cup and will do so again before their qualifier in Greece on June 6, is just along the coast.

The point about Marpafut is that it offers a package which is unique among footballing campuses: part-therapeutic, part-medicinal and part-cultural, with a dab of history thrown in. And, when Uli Hoeness, the former West Germany international now managing director of Bayern Munich, who marked the opening ceremony last weekend with a friendly against Hertha Berlin, feels moved to declare that the new centre has clearly been designed by a footballer for footballers, then clearly this is something special.

The man whose dream has been realised in Marbella once played for the outstanding Red Star Belgrade team of the 70s. An injury ended Miroslav "Kimi" Nestorovic's playing career when he was in his twenties, whereupon he gained coaching qualifications and, with Dragoslav Sekularac, one of Yugoslavia's greatest players, worked in several countries before becoming the coach at Malaga.

After the Spanish league club went bankrupt Nestorovic, now 53, moved to Marbella where eventually he spotted the piece of land which is now his Xanadu.

But surely anyone can build a football practice ground: all that is needed are a few pitches, decent changing rooms and reliable showers. Nestorovic, however, has created not so much a training centre as a shrine to the global game.

At the entrance to Marpafut stands an obelisk with Spain's royal coat of arms at its head, a portrait of Pele at its base and the names of the world's football federations in between. Just inside, on the right, are sculptures of 34 of the greatest footballers of all time, including George Best, Bobby Charlton and, naturally, Sekularac.

In the basement of the three-storey centre is a wine cellar, which also depicts, through sculptures and ceramics, the history of the game. Prominent among the exhibits is an enlarged reproduction of the original rules of Association Football as drawn up at the Freemasons' Tavern in Lincoln's Inn Fields in 1863.

For the coaches, players and backroom staff visiting Marpafut the artistic accoutrements are less important than playing surfaces which are the equal of the present superb pitch at Highbury and what Wembley was before it closed.

This was what impressed Hoeness, along with the thought which had gone into providing special areas for goalkeeper training and practice at corners, with all measurements conforming to Fifa standards. So much time during a training session can be taken up with moving goalposts and generally rearranging the furniture. This centre is designed to eliminate all that.

And, while Marbella is hardly alone among Iberian resorts in assuring visitors of sunshine for most of the year, Nestorovic's centre is the only football place in the area where superior drainage guarantees that the pitches will still be playable after a day of torrential rain. Only last week local teams were clamouring to use Marpafut because their own grounds were waterlogged.

Add in such facilities as an on-site laundry, which makes life much easier for the kit man, and a helicopter pad from which a seriously injured player can be whisked to a German-run clinic within five minutes and clearly this is not just another excuse for footballers to get a winter tan.

Nestorovic's dream has been realised for around £6.5m. The estimated price of the new national football centre which the Football Association is planning for the east Midlands is £40m, so the FA needs to make sure it gets things right.

A visit to Marbella to see what Nestorovic has built would appear to be in order, and Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, was intending to go. But then he told Sava Popovich, the contact in England, that this would not be necessary as the FA had its own plans.

Maybe Wilkinson and others at Soho Square should think again. After all, he has just called for a winter break and anything which has Hoeness positively drooling praise is surely worth a look. And Hoeness did not even bring a beach towel.

fields.headline: Farewell, focus groupie
fields.standfirst:
What a fuss about a man who turned the Labour party into an airbrushed bulldog

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: What a fuss about Peter Mandelson, a man who turned the Labour party into an airbrushed bulldog.
fields.body:
Out with the New, in with the old. "Knock Knock!" "Who's there?" "Peter!" "Peter who?" "That's politics for you." The people cleaning out Peter Mandelson's offices at Labour party headquarters had a bit of a shock when they unlocked the stationary cupboard. Confiscated flat caps, old CND banners, Red Flag song sheets and donkey jackets covered in "Coal not dole" badges had all been guarded under lock and key. Behind all of that were a number of bound and gagged union leaders who'd been held captive in there since the 70s. "Are Boney M still number one?" asked the vaguely familiar Northerner with the big lapels who wanted to get straight back to "collective pay bargaining" with something he called "British Rail".

The Labour party has changed a great deal since Peter Mandelson joined as director of communications after the debacle of 1983. It was his focus groups that first revealed the earth shattering news that angry hecklers booing Michael Foot did not do the party's image any good. And after all that effort that Labour had gone to; handing out bags of flour for members of Militant to throw over Denis Healey, it turned out that this didn't increase Labour's poll rating at all; quite the reverse in fact. Only a genius like Mandelson could have discovered this.

No one individual can take the credit for making Labour seem electable, although Peter Mandelson seems to feature heavily in most versions of the story. It always raises suspicions when the person in charge of publicity gets lots of publicity. But in a way the need for a Peter Mandelson has withered since the great sea change in British politics that occurred in 1997.

Four years on many members cannot understand why the task of making Labour electable has continued so long after the party was elected. Peter Mandelson did a lot to help Labour come to power, but whether he helped a Labour government make the most of that power is another matter. You didn't watch him walking into Downing Street and think: "Great, that'll get the minimum wage up!"

During the 1997 campaign he had the idea of using a bulldog to symbolise New Labour's patriotism. However, to avoid embarrassment the animal's testicles were airbrushed out of the photos. So that was Mandelson's idea of what the Labour party should be. A proud and patriotic beast but with no bollocks.

At the last Labour conference Tony Blair promised a second term more radical than the first and now there is one less voice in cabinet arguing against this. And now that he's gone, many members of the Labour party will start to think: "Okay - can we have our party back now please?" Out with the "New" and in with the old. Not the old Labour that was badly run and faction ridden but a Labour party that was proud to be associated with ordinary people rather than millionaire businessmen. Labour voters want their ministers to be angry about injustice, angry about the gap between rich and poor, not angry because the waiter served red wine with the fish.

And those voters who are now the greatest worry for Labour are not more likely to abstain now that he resigned. There aren't many ex-miners in Barnsley saying: "Well I were goin' t'vote Labour, but now that Mandelson's gone, there's not one member of t' government who's a friend of Charles and Camilla."

Perhaps this is why Tony Blair feels able to let him go. In any case, to paraphrase Lady Bracknell, to lose one ministerial job is unfortunate. To lose two is just carelessness. It does have to be said that the standards we have come to expect from our ministers are far higher than those the rest of us pursue.

You don't get Gary from accounts resigning because two years ago he took home some Post It notes and then subsequently denied it. "On News at Ten tonight, the Post It note scandal continues. Did Gary's friend play solitaire on his computer during office hours?" Yes, Peter Mandelson acted inappropriately and tried to deny it, but compared to the Archers and the Aitkens, the Hamiltons and the Asil Nadirs, none of Labour's scandals would make the top 40.

But now Mandelson's career is in an even bigger mess than his hair was when he walked out of Downing Street. That's not to say that he has nothing left to offer British politics. His contacts in Northern Ireland and his experience of political rebranding could offer new opportunities. Frankly, after years of kneecapping and random bombing, Sinn Fein's image could use a bit of a makeover. Perhaps he could help the political wing of the IRA discover its softer, more reassuring side. Tough on informers, but also tough on the causes of informers. Focus groups could be used to discover that black balaclavas and Armalite rifles were not going down very well with Daily Mail readers in the key marginals. New Sinn Fein - yes, it has a certain ring to it.
