webTitle: Family aims to set up British bank

fields.headline: Family aims to set up British bank
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The billionaire Hinduja brothers are understood to harbour ambitions to set up their own bank in Britain, and have made numerous informal approaches to City regulators over the past decade.
fields.body:
The billionaire Hinduja brothers are understood to harbour ambitions to set up their own bank in Britain, and have made numerous informal approaches to City regulators over the past decade.

Yet, despite talks with the Bank of England and more recently the financial services authority, which regulates banking, a coveted licence to take deposits from the public still eludes the businessmen, say senior City sources.

Such is the enthusiasm of SP and GP Hinduja to open a bank in Britain that they have even tried to set one up in partnership with mainstream banks, which could simplify the licensing process.

One attempt was with HSBC, the high-street bank that also has strong links with Asia. Talks were held between the two sides about creating a new bank aimed at wealthy Asians in Britain, but an agreement was never reached.

It is believed that a formal application, requiring the businessmen to disclose full details of their financial arrangements to regulators in order to be deemed "fit and proper", has never been made for any of the banking ventures the Hindujas have considered since the early 1990s.

After failing to reach an agreement with HSBC about the new Asian bank, the Hindujas looked for other ways to take deposits. As recently as November last year, the Hindujas were said to be preparing to extend their existing international banking empire, known as Amas and specialising in providing services for wealthy individuals, to the UK. The bank was founded in Switzerland 13 years ago.

To receive a banking licence, stringent criteria must be met. These include demonstrating that they are "fit and proper" as well as prove they are committed to running the business with "integrity and skill".

The FSA said it could not comment on banking licence applications. A spokeswoman for the Hindujas refused to comment.

fields.headline: Made in Scotland
fields.standfirst:
The merit of doing things differently

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The probability that older people will need long-term nursing care is about one in five for men, one in three for women. But no one knows in advance just who will be stricken with Alzheimer's or dementia, nor the trade-in value of their home, if they own one.
fields.body:
The probability that older people will need long-term nursing care is about one in five for men, one in three for women. But no one knows in advance just who will be stricken with Alzheimer's or dementia, nor the trade-in value of their home, if they own one. Here is a shining example of an insurable risk which the private finance market is incompetent to cover. It is a job for the state. Only public authority can compel universal contributions, pool risk and, way into the future, fairly distribute resources to ensure no one in need is left exposed.

Thanks to devolution, there is now within the United Kingdom more than one state to try such a policy. The UK, moreover, has a constituent state in which social democracy is strong and, perhaps, tolerance higher for the tax or enforced contributions that free long-term care would require. It is, of course, Scotland. Response to the announcement by first minister Henry McLeish of the Edinburgh coalition's plans on long-term care has been: how audacious! They are daring to implement Sutherland - the royal commission that two years ago proposed splitting nursing from the hotel aspects of care so that elderly people cared for at home or in "homes" would no longer pay for nursing, as they do if admitted to an NHS hospital. The recommendation has now been accepted by the Scottish executive, at least in principle - details, timing and costs yet to be supplied. By implication the extra spending - £110m a year - would be found by making savings elsewhere in Scotland's budget (not as hard as it sounds, given that social policy costs there are well above need as denominated on a UK-wide basis).

Fiscal harmonisers might be shocked, but has Scotland really been bold? It is not just that Mr McLeish had to cook up a formula on Thursday to head off a parliamentary revolt, leaving himself room to dodge and weave later. Coalition is a work in progress and give a little, take a little is no bad motto for government everywhere. It is rather that Labour ministers in Scotland seem so reluctant to teach Westminster - effectively, their fellow countryman Gordon Brown - that the point of devolution is the room it makes for deviation on tax and spend. Scottish Labour leaders keep looking over their shoulders at how London will react. Instead they should be exploring the elastic bounds of the new constitutional settlement. Scottish voters have to be told they can now have generous and universal social services but their tax rates will need to be higher or more progressive than in England.

Lord Lipsey, a dissenting member of Sutherland, predicts queues of cars at the border as the English middle class rush north with granny in the back to be left on the doorstep of Dundee social services. It is unlikely. Social dumping would not happen at all if Scotland seized the freedom it now enjoys to try a made-and-paid-in-Scotland remedy for this growing problem of social provision.

webTitle: Home Office refuses to publish record of key call

fields.headline: Home Office refuses to publish record of key call
fields.standfirst:
Release of papers is 'basically, not something we do'

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Release of papers is 'basically, not something we do'.
fields.body:
The Guardian has applied for a copy of the official record of the key conversation between Peter Mandelson and the Home Office minister Mike O'Brien over the Hinduja passport application.

Mr Mandelson has said he would be happy to see the note of this telephone conversation to be made public, but the Home Office has refused to publish it.

The conversation in June 1998 is at the centre of this week's resignation by Mr Mandelson over his role in brokering a British passport for Srichand Hinduja, a major donor to the Millennium Dome.

The Guardian's application was submitted earlier this week under the open government code introduced in 1994.

Under the code, government departments can refuse to release information if they believe that its publication would prevent ministers and officials from discussing matters "candidly and frankly".

Whitehall argues that ministers and officials would be inhibited in their internal deliberations if they feared that individual opinions would be exposed to the public gaze.

Asked why the note of the conversation was not being published, the Home Office said yesterday: "Basically, it is not something we do. We are not making an exception in this case. The Home Office does not, and never has done, published details of ministerial correspondence."

The Guardian has also applied to Jack Straw, the home secretary, for all the submissions on the Hinduja passsport application from Jack Cunningham, the former Cabinet Office "enforcer"; Sir Paddy Ashdown, the former Liberal Democrat leader; and the former Tory prime minister Edward Heath. All three signed the passport application from Mr Hinduja.

Mr Mandelson maintains that during his two-minute conversation with Mr O'Brien he did not promote the passport application by the wealthy businessman, but merely asked how such an application might be viewed.

The Tory open government code is being replaced by the Freedom of Information Act, which is expected to come into force next year. Despite criticism, the government says the public will have a much stronger right to obtain information under the new act.

webTitle: Ministers reveal full extent of contacts

fields.headline: Ministers reveal full extent of contacts
fields.standfirst:
Politicians rush to give details of meetings with brothers

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Politicians rush to give details of meetings with brothers.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Vikram Dodd and Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Cabinet minister Stephen Byers has met them at his place and their place, in offices and at receptions, in London and in Cambridge. His deputy, Patricia Hewitt, has enjoyed a snack at their Bombay home and lunch at their London home.

The extensive contacts between the billionaire Hinduja brothers and ministers were detailed last night by a meeting-by-meeting account released by the Department of Trade and Industry. A former adviser to the billionaire brothers explained the brothers' attitude to politicians, revealing that the Hindujas see them "as a commodity to trade with".

Mr Byers, the trade secretary, authorised publication of the list as officials, mindful of how Peter Mandelson's evasiveness cost him his career, insisted that the department wanted to be open.

The two brothers at the centre of the passport row, who are now being questioned by Indian police investigating an arms deal, arranged 13 meetings in less than two years with three named ministers - and also saw them at countless other events.

Mr Byers even paid a visit to the Cambridge academic institute founded in memory of SP's only son, Dharam, who in 1999 set fire to himself and his Anglo-Indian Catholic wife.

Any of the ministers could face serious problems if the list proves inaccurate - and other departments will face pressure to compile their own versions as the spotlight turns on the networking of Britain's richest Asian family.

Contacts continued even after October 2000 when it became known that the Indian police wanted to question them over kickbacks in the Bofors scandal.

Mr Byers met SP and GP at the DTI on April 14 1999; attended a reception at their New Zealand House HQ on September 22 1999; spoke on the phone to GP on October 27 1999; met SP and GP again at the DTI on November 24 1999; spoke to GP during the Cambridge visit on October 4 2000; and saw GP at the DTI on November 25 2000.

Ms Hewitt visited the home of SP and GP with the British high commissioner during a Treasury trip to India in February 1999; had lunch with SP at his London home on July 7 1999; spoke after she moved to the DTI on the phone to GP on July 26 2000; and met GP at the DTI on July 31 2000.

Richard Caborn, like Ms Hewitt a minister of state, met SP and GP at the DTI on March 21 2000.

The DTI added ministers had hosted or attended a series of events at which one or both brothers were present, including a speech by Mr Byers to an Asian Trader anniversary dinner on November 14 2000, and a visit to Oldbury's Balaji temple in the West Midlands on April 30 1999.

All contact, maintained the DTI, was to discuss ministerial responsibilities and departmental business - not passports. That was the topic that cost Mr Mandelson so dear as his approaches on behalf of SP, while soliciting cash for the millennium dome, led to him misleading voters and Downing Street and paying the ultimate political price.

As Tony Blair agreed to the widening of Sir Anthony Hammond's inquiry to cover the Hindujas' passport applications, and as Europe minister Keith Vaz was fighting for his political life, other politicians admitted links to the brothers.

Robin Cook has met the brothers as prominent members of the Asian community but says he was not involved in anything to do with their passport applications.

"We are not aware of any involvement by the foreign secretary on this issue," said a foreign office spokesman.

The Foreign Office also disclosed that Peter Hain, who was moved to the energy portfolio this week in the reshuffle triggered by Mr Mandelson's fall, met the brothers last Christmas when they went to his official drinks party despite not being on the official invitation list.

A spokesman for the former prime minister Sir Edward Heath, who has known the family 20 years and helped GP Hinduja with his passport application, confirmed he received "a couple of thousand pounds" from the brothers in late 1994 or early 1995 which he put towards the running costs of his Old Bexley and Sidcup constituency office.

"Sir Edward cannot remember the exact date. The payment was for the constituency rather than himself. We cannot find the correspondence and Sir Edward's memory is a little shaky about something six years ago," he said.

The sensitivity among ministers over past contacts that excited no interest then but could now threaten careers has created panic in Westminster and Whitehall.

Ms Hewitt, tipped as a future cabinet minister, came close on Thursday night to repeating Mr Mandelson's error when she attempted to play down links with the Hinduja brothers before confirming she visited their Bombay home.

Through a spokesman, the Hindujas said they had not donated money directly to the Hindujas, but they financially supported all three parties by bidding at fund-raising auctions held by the parties.

Barry Gardiner, the Labour MP for Brent North, confirmed the Hindujas sponsored an event in honour of the Labour Friends of India, which he chairs.

GP Hinduja hosted a dinner at St James' Hotel in London last year for a group of Labour MPs after they returned from a trip to India.

The Hindujas yesterday fired their public relations firm after tabloid revelations that their PR man, Howell James, was a former partner of Peter Mandelson's boyfriend, Reinaldo da Silva.

The brothers have hired Luther Pendragon to represent them, a firm which specialises in crises. It previously tried to improve the image of McDonald's during its libel case and British Beef after the BSE crisis. Charles Stuart-Smith, the new spokesman for the Hindujas, said: "They've been to political party functions at which they've made auction bids for pictures and things like that, to all parties."

Mr Stuart-Smith said the brothers were at the Kumbh Mela in India. After speaking to them he said: "They sounded very spritely and in very good form. They're surprised at the escalation of events."

An increasingly frustrated Mr Blair, angry that attempts to focus on issues such as the economy and education have been completely overshadowed by the affair, tried to bolster Keith Vaz's position yesterday during a trip to north east England.

"When the media gets into one of these feeding frenzies this is what happens," he said.

"I have to say that, having a look at the papers I've seen, I can't see anything wrong with the things that are supposed to have been done."

But with an inquiry under way, the affair is unlikely to die down just yet.

A former adviser to the Hindujas in Britain explained their thinking in courting politicians.

"They see no difference between Britain and India, politicians are no different, they are commodities that you trade with," he said.

The ex-aide, who also knows Mr Vaz, added: "Keith is well-meaning and sometimes abused by people around him. Keith will always try to help anyone - he is a good-natured sort and that is misinterpreted as venal."

Charles Stuart-Smith, the new spokesman for the Hindujas, said: "They've been to political party functions at which they've made auction bids for pictures and things like that, to all parties." Mr Stuart-Smith said the brothers were at the Kumbh Mela in India. After speaking to them he said: "They sounded very spritely and in very good form. They're surprised at the escalation of events." An increasingly frustrated Mr Blair, angry that attempts to focus on issues such as the economy and education have been completely overshadowed by the affair, tried to bolster Keith Vaz's position yesterday during a trip to north east England. "When the media gets into one of these feeding frenzies this is what happens," he said. "I have to say that, having a look at the papers I've seen, I can't see anything wrong with the things that are supposed to have been done." But with an inquiry under way, the affair is unlikely to die down just yet. A former adviser to the Hindujas in Britain explained their thinking in courting politicians. "They see no difference between Britain and India, politicians are no different, they are commodities that you trade with," he said. The ex-aide, who also knows Mr Vaz, added: "Keith is well-meaning and sometimes abused by people around him. Keith will always try to help anyone - he is a good-natured sort and that is misinterpreted as venal."

webTitle: Comment: Bush's first executive order is no jeans

fields.headline: Jeans are off, then, in the White House
fields.standfirst:
Clinton may have dropped them, but Bush intends to do it differently

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Clinton may have dropped them, but Bush intends to do it differently.
fields.body:
A blue dress from Gap became the garment on which the Clinton presidency hinged. After a few days in office, President George Bush has staked his reputation on a pair of trousers of a lighter shade. Allaying fears that his first act in office would be to ban abortion or abolish Nato, the son who also rose gave an executive order outlawing the wearing of jeans by staff or guests in the Oval Office.

Denim has played a small but important part in the iconography of the presidency. "Those guys in suits" or (at today's prices) "in $1,500-suits" has become shorthand in recent times for Washington politicians in the rhetoric of political outsiders. Running on a post-Watergate clean-up ticket, Jimmy Carter was photographed in jeans to establish himself as a farmer, an outsider, a young man in comparison with Ford and Nixon.

Ronald Reagan, although a traditionalist, was pictured in jeans on horseback to underline his cowboy credentials. But the greatest political users of denim were Clinton and Gore, who also became the first candidates routinely to remove their jackets and ties while making speeches or shaking hands. The jeans and shirtsleeves were part of a deliberate dress-down campaign, intended to emphasise their youth and vigour alongside the 68-year-old George HW Bush. The message was that the sitting president was literally as well as metaphorically buttoned-up.

Tony Blair, not for the first time stealing Clinton's clothes, wore jeans in the kitchen scenes of Molly Dineen's fly-on-the-wall campaign commercial four years ago. Once prime minister, he wore denim alongside Clinton at summit photo-calls. In a culture in which many of the major wealth-creators - Bill Gates, Steven Spielberg, Richard Branson - were conscientious objectors to suit and tie, turning out in cowboy trousers was a way of saying that the world had come to the young.

But now Clinton's successor has declared that only cloth can rest on the seats of power. Although it is a brave man over 40 who wears denim, this is unlikely to be a fashion statement, coming, as it does, from a president who favours cowboy boots.

Declaring war on Levi's is code. The Republicans like to suggest that Clinton filled the White House with pot-smoking ex-hippies and students. Guess what those kinds of guys hang in their closets? There may also be a deeper sneer at Clinton. Photographs and articles suggest that President Clinton sometimes wore jeans when working in the Oval Office at weekends. Most of his encounters with Ms Lewinsky took place on Saturdays and Sundays. So it may have been jeans that Monica unzipped. What Dubya is saying is that not only will he wear regular pants - the uniform of the men who built America - but that he will keep them up. Another possible reason why Bush was coming on like a parent - "You're not coming in wearing that!" - was that, as we only learned later, he had arrived in Washington to find that classic mum-and-dad nightmare: the house had been trashed by young people.

The revelation that the W key had been removed from White House keyboards and hidden is amusing, West Wing stuff. Suggestions that rooms were vandalised or defaced by outgoing Clinton employees is more serious. One of the working assumptions of observers of American politics has always been that the office and fabric of the presidency were ecumenically respected. If departing Clinton employees - who surely wish, in the words of their master, to "maintain their viability within the system" - really did attack the nation's most famous residence, then we get a sense of the level of anger present in America at the dubious Dubya. The president should be worried about this. If this is what young lawyers who hope to enter politics will do against him, imagine what civilians might be planning.

An American commentator once acutely remarked that American women were reluctant to vote for the first President Bush because "he reminds them of their first husbands". That is snippy, fussy and out-of-touch. With his dress-codes and tut-tutting over the state of the place, the second President Bush seems determined to remind the American electorate of their fathers and - perhaps even more damagingly - of his father.

When an unusually young leader is elected (Kennedy, Clinton, Blair), it's common to say that politics has skipped a generation. One of the few presidents not to be significantly younger than the man he replaces, George Bush seems oddly committed to skipping back a generation. Packing his cabinet with retreads from his dad's failed presidency - plus, for variation, someone who served President Ford - he makes his first policy decision the abolition of denim.

President Clinton's pursuit of the babyboomer vote made good electoral sense. Turning the White House into the political equivalent of the kind of restaurant where they make you wear a tie seems merely to secure the support of the sort of older Republicans who would vote for him anyway, if they're still around in 2004. It really can't be smart politics for a man whose main political vulnerability is that his dad was someone to start coming on like someone's dad. Clothes may unmaketh the man.

webTitle: Comment: Eurosceptics one up in Mandelson's wake

fields.headline: Sceptics one up in Mandelson's wake
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Is the departure of Peter Mandelson significant to the euro-debate?
fields.body:
Is the departure of Peter Mandelson significant to the euro-debate? Does it alter the balance in terms of when (whether?) the referendum will take place and the nature of the debate within government? The newspapers were almost totally united in not mourning Mandy's passing, but they all felt that in European terms the winners were the Eurosceptics, and, in this context, Gordon Brown.

"The cabinet has lost its most passionate pro-European," said the euro-supportive Financial Times, "and Mr Blair has been left more vulnerable." Some of Blair's friends had said they feared it would make Brown over-powerful, especially in decisions such as whether Labour would call a referendum on the euro if re-elected.

The euro-sceptic Daily Telegraph agreed: "The prime minister will grieve for his friend...The pro-euro cause has lost an advocate, and New Labour no longer has a champion. In all this the prime minister is the loser. The winner is Gordon Brown."

The Sun felt that Mandelson's firing would be "a blow to the pro-euro brigade", although his backers were insisting he would continue to bang the Brussels drum.

The Mirror saw the sacking as a setback for the euro. "The shock departure of the pro-euro minister could hit the campaign to join the single currency," it said. But opponents of the euro still thought the government was preparing for a pro-euro push after the election, and Mandelson would still be "whispering in the prime minister's ear".

The Guardian agreed that Mandelson's exit was good for Brown. "Mr Mandelson was also one of the government's most enthusiastic supporters of the euro," it said. "With Mr Cook and the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, he championed the benefits of campaigning to sell the euro to the public against the cautious approach of the chancellor. So Mr Mandelson's exit in all likelihood will strengthen the hand of the chancellor."

By yesterday that was the prevailing view. The FT said Brown would exploit the resignation by "pressing for stiff political and economic tests" before Labour called a referendum. The chancellor, it said, feared Labour might be punished at the election, and was considering a sixth criterion for entering the euro.

The Guardian 's Hugo Young was almost alone in saying he regretted seeing Mandy go. Mandelson was "right about Europe, being one of the few ministers to give that keynote subject the priority it deserves."

For those interested, it must have seemed odd that a Northern Ireland secretary with a previous career in spin should be portrayed as so central to the politics of the UK joining the euro.

And yet Nissan and Joschka Fischer would have been the most significant players of the week in a debate about Europe which is gathering in volume and intensity, had it not been for Peter Mandelson.

Fischer, the German foreign minister, came to Britain playing politics in several directions at once. He had messages for Europe, for Britain and for France, indicating how far from "federal" are relations between the EU's two dominant states.

His speech was widely trailed. Fischer intended to "take up cudgels against the Eurosceptics," said the Times, despite urgings from Britain to tone down his comments. The Telegraph found Labour sources confirming that approaches had been made to Mr Fischer's office "stressing that remarks which might seem acceptable in Germany could provoke lurid headlines in Eurosceptic newspapers here."

Then he made the speech, and the same newspapers reported it. The Times reported "Fischer soothes fears of British Eurosceptics". The Telegraph said "Fischer taunts Tories on Europe". He insisted that Tory fears of a European superstate had nothing to do with reality. And the Guardian said that Fischer "refused to water down his proposals for a federal Europe, even though he was speaking in Britain, home of the most committed Eurosceptics".

Same speech, three interpretations. Often the way with Europe.

The week's silliest story was in the Sunday Telegraph. "EU blamed for eggs that taste of fish". EU regulations banning the feeding of synthetic health supplements to chickens had "forced" producers to resort to fishmeal, said the paper.

Nissan was probably the most significant story. The Independent's Donald Macintryre, writing ahead of the car maker's decision, said that "Nissan has made no attempt to disguise the fact that our exclusion from the euro zone has been fundamental to Nissan's problems".

Nissan decided to continue manufacturing in this country. Had it been tipped off that the government had decided to get on with joining the single currency? Nobody accused Peter Mandelson of clandestine trips to Tokyo.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University.

webTitle: Third minister named in Hindujas row

fields.headline: Third minister named in Hindujas row
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's embarrassment over the Hinduja affair deepened last night when it emerged that a senior cabinet minister met one of the billionaire Indian businessmen a month after he had been formally named in a corruption scandal in Delhi.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd, Nicholas Watt and Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
Tony Blair's embarrassment over the Hinduja affair deepened last night when it emerged that a senior cabinet minister met one of the billionaire Indian businessmen a month after he had been formally named in a corruption scandal in Delhi.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, met Gopichand Hinduja at his department in November last year, six weeks after the businessman had been named by the Indian authorities as a major beneficiary of bribes in the Bofors gun scandal. Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, said last night: "Unless there were compelling circumstances this was unacceptable. This shows a lack of judgment and a lack of fastidiousness."

Details of the meeting were disclosed by the DTI in a press release that outlined contacts between the department's ministers and the billionaire brothers in 1999 and last year. Mr Byers had six meetings or phone calls with them, all on official departmental business.

The disclosure of Mr Byers' contacts with the Hindujas came as the Europe minister Keith Vaz fought for his political life over his support for the brothers' passport application.

Amid growing fears in Whitehall that the affair could claim a second ministerial scalp, Mr Vaz abandoned his caution to mount a strong defence of his conduct. He said he had no regrets about the inquiries he made on behalf of the brothers. "Some of you are going to look very foolish when the report comes out," he told reporters as he said he would be happy for his letters to be published. "Frankly some of the stuff you said about Peter [Mandelson] and others and me, you'll regret very much when the facts come out."

Mr Vaz, the MP for Leicester East, who came to Britain from India at the age of nine, implied that his critics were racist. "I don't like this underlying hint of 'Should an Indian get a passport?' " he said. "I am proud of my links with the Asian community and will continue to do what I can to help them."

As Mr Vaz defended his reputation, Tony Blair signalled yesterday that the government may have played down his role in securing passports for the brothers. The prime minister said that Mr Vaz had made "representations" on behalf of the Indian businessmen. In its original response to questions of ministerial involvement in the Hindujas' passport applications, the government said Mr Vaz and Mr Mandelson had merely made "inquiries" on their behalf.

Mr Blair said: "Keith is a prominent Asian MP, they [the Hindujas] are prominent people from the Asian community. I cannot see anything wrong in him making representations on [behalf] of other members of the Asian community."

webTitle: Comment: Israel's survival is far from assured

fields.headline: Israel's survival is far from assured
fields.standfirst:
A Guardian commentator reads the signs in the intifada downfall

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Guardian commentator reads the signs in the intifada downfall.
fields.body:
Israel has existed for 52 years. It would surely by now be as secure a nation-state as any other but for the way it came into existence. As a response to European anti-semitism, Zionism may have been a very special, high-minded kind of European colonialism but, in its consequences for an indigenous people, it was as bad as any other.

The settler-state to which it gave birth has also been very special, indeed unique, in that it continues to exist at all. All other such polities have disappeared during European decolonisation. Those who peopled them have either been driven out in a bloody liberation war or yielded their political supremacy to majority rule.

The supreme measure of this success has been the official acceptance of its right to exist the enterprise eventually won from its indigenous victims. The achievement is all the more remarkable in that these victims are not just the Palestinians, who were directly dispossessed in the ethnic cleansing that accompanied Israel's birth, but a much larger community, the Arabs, who identified with them in their anti-colonial struggle.

There were always rejectionists in the region, now most potently typified by Hamas or Hizbullah, but the dominant players are accepters. Their acceptance is an accomplished fact in the case of Egypt and Jordan, who have made formal peace with Israel; it remains an intent with Palestine, Syria and Lebanon, who have yet to do so. But all subscribe to a broad consensus of what constitutes a "just, lasting and comprehensive" settlement.

Clearly, however, the success cannot be permanently assured until those for whom acceptance is still an intent convert it into an accomplished fact. Short of that, the risk is not merely that the enterprise will remain incomplete; it is that, sooner or later, the success it has achieved will be challenged and, in the end, instead of its consolidation as the great exception in the annals of European colonialism, it will suffer the same fate as all the rest.

The al-Aqsa intifada has the makings of that challenge. It is no accident that it erupted just when, on the face of it, Zionism's ultimate triumph had come within its grasp. The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, had laid his historic, take-it-or-leave-it compromise before the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, at Camp David in July. In return for "generous concessions" by Israel, the Palestinians were to have renounced all further claims on it. He failed, because the concessions fell so far short of the Arab-Palestinian accepters' consensus.

At the heart of the consensus is a Palestinian state, with Jerusalem as its capital, in the West Bank and Gaza. Mr Arafat first proclaimed it in 1988, and in the 1993 Oslo agreement, he agreed to work towards it through a series of "interim" arrangements paving the way for "final status". Though it was the fruit of Arab/Palestinian weakness, the offer was by any reckoning a magnanimous one. Mr Arafat had begun his career at the head of a "popular liberation struggle" whose objective had been full recovery of the homeland and dismantling of the settler-state. Here he was offering to yield up a full 78% of original Palestine. But throughout the "interim" stages, Israel spurned the offer.

In the Camp David "final-status" talks Mr Barak may have ceded more than ever before, but he was still demanding much more than the 78%, plus a whole array of other gains, ideological or security-related, making the compromise even more imbalanced than the one the Arab-Palestinian consensus had already acquiesced in. From this Israeli rejection grew the intifada. To what extent Mr Barak triggered it for his own ends, or Mr Arafat manipulated it for his, is detail. To the Palestinians, its purpose has become clear. This is their "war of independence".

Liberal Israelis liken it to their own of 52 years ago. "The tanzim [young Palestinian fighters]," forecast one, "will no more demobilise before Israel recognises the borders of the Palestine state than the pre-1948 Jewish underground would have done before Israel was established."

The Palestinians have therefore regressed, in some degree, to the methods with which Mr Arafat began his career. But their aims are still essentially Oslo by other means. Hamas, believers in "complete liberation", have ceded the main role to Mr Arafat's Fatah. And Fatah proclaims no ambitions beyond that 22%. It wants its state to co-exist with Israel, not to destroy it. But can this restraint withstand the rising violence, passions and chaos that the intifada threatens to unleash?

The first instinct of colonial regimes is to react to indigenous violence with a more effective violence of their own. Israel enjoys military superiority over its adversaries. Just how long it would need to reconquer the territories is little more than a question of tactics, and its strength makes it more than a match for any combination of Arab armies. Zionism has been fashioned by its most dramatic military exploits; two wars - 1948 and 1967 - were brilliantly successful. The intifada has brought Israel psychologically close to some new such exploit. To listen to the rhetoric is to grasp the depth of the temptation to go for the absolute solution which such military superiority presents.

It says, in effect, that Israel again faces an existential threat. It contends that the Palestinians never changed, their aim is still to "drive the Jews into the sea" and, for Mr Arafat, the peace process is just a means of "dismantling Israel in stages".

"Let the army win," is the rallying cry of the settlers and their political allies.What that really means, says Zeev Schiff, military analyst of Ha'aretz newspaper, is "the conquest of the territories under Palestinian control, the forced collapse of the Palestinian Authority and the expulsion of the Palestinian population".

According to the same newspaper, the deputy chief of staff, Moshe Ya'alon, thinks in rather apocalyptic terms. Israel, he argues, is now engaged in "the most critical campaign against the Palestinians, including Israel's Arab population, since the 1948 war"; indeed, it is "the second half of 1948". Given that, in the first half, Israel committed the original sin from which all its troubles ultimately stem, what the second half might bring is a necessarily grim surmise.

It would also very likely lead to a regional war. Because of the wider Arab identification with Palestine, the arena in which Israel's "deterrent power" must apply "does not" - as one commentator put it - "begin and end at the Netzarim Junction [in Gaza], but extends from Tehran to Damascus and Cairo."

But regional war could prove disastrously counter-productive. At the least, it would defer for a generation any prospect of Israel's final acceptance in the region. At worst it would create the existential threat it was supposed to ward off.

Among its possible consequences: Iraq would complete its comeback in the region as the standard-bearer of rejectionism; turmoil in Jordan would force King Abdullah to repudiate the peace treaty with Israel; the US would forsake Israel in a bid to rescue what is left of its influence in the region, and if it failed to do so Saudi Arabia would unsheath the oil weapon; it would sap Israel's cohesion.

Yet Israel is now less likely than ever to achieve acceptance through negotiation. If that was going to happen, it would have done so before the intifada broke out. Now, after so much blood, Mr Arafat cannot sell his people's sacrifices short. And the concessions Mr Barak can sell to Israel are even fewer than they might have been, for society has shifted rightwards.

The only alternative is what is already happening: a low-intensity war of attrition waged against a background of diplomatic deadlock. Some believe it could go on for years. Israel will presumably persist in its tactics: selective attacks on personnel and installations, harassment, economic blockade, designed to weaken the Palestinians to the point where they return on Israel's terms to negotiations.

But who will weary first? The pain the Palestinians are enduring is infinitely greater, but so is their capacity to endure it. Accustomed to privation and imbued with hatred of Israeli oppression, they face an adversary which has largely forgotten the self-denying zeal of its pioneering years, which quit "the mud" of south Lebanon because it was losing about 20 dead a year - and has lost 47 in three-and-a-half months of intifada.

The longer this struggle goes on, the more the Palestinians will perceive any Israeli retreats as weakness. The more weakness, the more retreats they will press for, to the point where they will be tempted to regress to their original goals. The rejectionists already think this way. But for the still-dominant accepters, there is still a way to save themselves and Israel from all-out conflict; the formation of an American-led "fact-finding commission" was a first, timid pointer towards it.

There must be, they say, international - as opposed to merely American - sponsorship of an historic compromise; and it must if necessary be imposed by force. This is seen as not merely practicable, but historically proper too. Israel has made it plain that it would resist any encroachment on its sovereignty. But the record shows that it was the child of the UN, that the general assembly's 1947 Partition resolution was the founding charter of its international legitimacy, and that it formally acknowledged that its sovereignty was subordinate to a higher obligation - internationally sponsored redress for the Palestinians.

Such an outcome is a long way off yet. Meanwhile, argues the Jordanian columnist Rami Khouri, the longer the intifada continues, "the more self-evident it becomes that the underlying policy of colonial occupation - outdated, counter-productive, morally and politically rejected by the entire world - is unsustainable and nearing its end". But, if so, what end? One that, through international fiat, preserves this last great exception in the history of European colonialism - or one that ends the exception itself?

As a response to European anti-semitism, Zionism may have been a very special, high-minded kind of European colonialism but, in its consequences for an indigenous people, it was as bad as any other. The settler-state to which it gave birth has also been very special, indeed unique, in that it continues to exist at all. All other such polities have disappeared during European decolonisation. Those who peopled them have either been driven out in a bloody liberation war or yielded their political supremacy to majority rule. The supreme measure of this success has been the official acceptance of its right to exist the enterprise eventually won from its indigenous victims. The achievement is all the more remarkable in that these victims are not just the Palestinians, who were directly dispossessed in the ethnic cleansing that accompanied Israel's birth, but a much larger community, the Arabs, who identified with them in their anti-colonial struggle. There were always rejectionists in the region, now most potently typified by Hamas or Hizbullah, but the dominant players are accepters. Their acceptance is an accomplished fact in the case of Egypt and Jordan, who have made formal peace with Israel; it remains an intent with Palestine, Syria and Lebanon, who have yet to do so. But all subscribe to a broad consensus of what constitutes a "just, lasting and comprehensive" settlement. Clearly, however, the success cannot be permanently assured until those for whom acceptance is still an intent convert it into an accomplished fact. Short of that, the risk is not merely that the enterprise will remain incomplete; it is that, sooner or later, the success it has achieved will be challenged and, in the end, instead of its consolidation as the great exception in the annals of European colonialism, it will suffer the same fate as all the rest. In return for "generous concessions" by Israel, the Palestinians were to have renounced all further claims on it. He failed, because the concessions fell so far short of the Arab-Palestinian accepters' consensus. At the heart of the consensus is a Palestinian state, with Jerusalem as its capital, in the West Bank and Gaza. According to the same newspaper, the deputy chief of staff, Moshe Ya'alon, thinks in rather apocalyptic terms. Israel, he argues, is now engaged in "the most critical campaign against the Palestinians, including Israel's Arab population, since the 1948 war"; indeed, it is "the second half of 1948". Given that, in the first half, Israel committed the original sin from which all its troubles ultimately stem, what the second half might bring is a necessarily grim surmise. webTitle: Comment: Mandelson's resignation - It's a gay thing

fields.headline: It's a gay thing
fields.standfirst:
It takes one to know one, and believe me, Mandelson's behaviour has been recognisable

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: It takes one to know one, and believe me, Mandelson's behaviour has been recognisable.
fields.body:
It takes one - truistically - to know one and I'm afraid he could not have been queenier if he tried. The tousled locks, the quivering lower lip, the nostrils poised to flare: all signalled a gay at bay. This was a camp High Noon. But it was that "fuck you" look in the eyes that compelled as he looked into the cruel lens - for there one saw contempt for the spirits he had conjured out of the media shallows. Lunching with journalists may be less fun than feasting with panthers - but by such means the necromancer had risen. Now they had him in their maws. And so he blamed them for their appetites.

The beguiler's fall has no significance in the politics of thought. The heterosexual commentating heavies miss the Mandelson point. Which is why they're bemused by the folly of the telephone call on the wild side, the silly daring of that two-minute surrender of judgment. What Peter Mandelson did was the political equivalent of bare-backing. And as with all such discovered episodes of unprotected sex, it's the presumption of further unrevealed audacity which thrills both voyeur and victim. How many other times did he do it? Whether his departure makes the euro more or less likely really seems rather boring by comparison.

Tony Blair invokes Peter Mandelson's place in the great sweep of history. He might be a subject for a thesis on the role of the courtier in democratic culture, but little more. New Labour - the provisional arrangement he fathered - looks strangely passé as Labour finally settles in as a government. No - Peter Mandelson's real significance is other. This is a gay thing - the story of a man who politically was once one man's bitch and then became another's.

The Mandelson manner and appearance (arch, equivocal, layered in suggestive meaning), was a historically specific product. It came from the gender-bendering 80s when there was enough liberation around to step outside the closet, but not enough for the orthodox careerist to swing the door behind him.

Older gays, such as the travel writer Gavin Young who died earlier this month, arrived at a different accommodation with the genes. Enjoying the homosexuality traditional among Arabists of his class and generation, Gavin travelled for it. But at home it was drinks at the Cavalry Club and dinner at Pratt's. He was an old-school masculine gay - the kind who embraced physical toughness in travel as an affirmation of character. No "fem" he. Conventional thought - both pro and anti gay - would have judged him "repressed" but though racked by self-doubt he sailed through life with discipline and flair. Most schools have a PE teacher or two who, liking "lads who keep themselves fit", are rather similar.

The interim ethics of Mandy-gaydom seems a sadder thing. The fact that he never acknowledged his gayness only confirmed a reputation for deceit. And in politics the coat fashioned for you by others can slip on all too easily, until the day arrives when you suddenly look in the mirror. As the most famous gay man in Britain he was a cardboard cut-out figure, the political Village People's Machiavelli, a parody of the gay man as the shifty fudge-packer in the corner. He had fed meat in his time to the political vultures of the Sun and the Daily Mail. But Mandy-gayness also suited their caricaturing homophobic purposes.

The party he chose found him exotic - which says more about that party's Methodist dullness than it does about the Hendon boy. Chris Smith and Nick Brown show how in New Labour even the gay men are strait-laced. Old Labour had a brave stab at it all with Tom Driberg - a cruiser of ocean-going capacity but there have been no worthy successors to that prodigy of the cottage epiphanies. That Tories are camper is a law of British politics. But campery is the carapace of repression, put in place to release what might otherwise be anarchic.

Cod psychology tries to explain the gay fascination with politics as a question of tatty operetta charms, charged emotions and episodic fits of drama, of quarrels and reconciliations. The queeny stereotype is pre- "post-gay" and reveals a present partial truth. Perhaps when everything turns "virtually normal" we'll all be living on joint mortgages shared with accountants in Barnstable. But for the moment gay life has an existentialist quality with its choices of the moment.

Perhaps - as one who can't see a collectivity without wanting to run away - I romanticise. But politics appeals to gay men for two reasons, both of them dangerous. Like sex, religion and drugs, politics seems to confirm the self. It gives it a platform of heightened self- importance. But all four are also an escape from the burdensome real self - the one you have to deal with on a daily basis. Their dangerous attraction is the offer of absorption in something greater.

Political groupings are often substitute families for gay politicians - hence the virulence of the squabbling. They minister to the need to belong - even when, as in Mandelson's case, the herd mind rejects.

Of course the security is a sham, which is why the systematic rejectors of shelter - such as Peter Tatchell - are heroic. Sooner or later the price is too high. It's not just a gay thing. Politics attracts chancers of all kinds. But when it comes to gay identity there's a double discharge of drama. Here the sexual is the political. Hence the flight to the common and the race to the heath. At some level there is actually a desire to be found out. Mandelson's call was both exploitation of office and a challenge to be discovered in an amoral world. He was gagging for it. Hence Pink Wednesday.

Equivocal interim gaydom both made and unmade Peter Mandelson. "Don't forget, dear," said an elderly theatrical dresser to me once, "we queens have all the talent." The 20th century was certainly the age of the gay artist. Proust, Musil, Mann, Auden, Wittgenstein: all spoke to the century of dispossession. Frustration is good for art and as gay gets mainstream, so the art dwindles. Armistead Maupin seems a limping companion to the pink giants of old. But the dresser's counsel was always a silly consolation - though kindly meant, it came from a time of marginalisation and there was a pathos in the conceit.

Mandelson's lonely sadness is that he believed in a unique talent to deceive. He was the man of the gay interim ethic - a period which is passing. As the arch-exponent of that ethic, Joe Orton, puts it in Loot: "We wouldn't have been nicked if you'd kept your mouth shut. Making us look ridiculous by telling the truth. Why can't you lie like a normal man?" Artists are allowed their lies as redemptive fictions. But Mandelsonian deception was caught in the web spun by its own time and condition.

webTitle: Gates empire hit by new hacker assault

fields.headline: Gates empire hit by new hacker assault
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The FBI is investigating a damaging computer assault on Microsoft after hackers overwhelmed the company's connection to the internet, leading to the closure of several popular websites such as MSN.com and expedia.com.
fields.body:
The FBI is investigating a damaging computer assault on Microsoft after hackers overwhelmed the company's connection to the internet, leading to the closure of several popular websites such as MSN.com and expedia.com.

The attack comes after a difficult week for the Seattle-based company. Its services, used by millions of people and businesses, also broke down for two days this week because of a technical error, prompting complaints from across the globe. Microsoft said the two problems were unrelated.

The company called in the FBI yesterday when it realised that its system was the victim of a "denial-of-service" attack on Thursday. Hackers had managed to overwhelm the company's extensive network with so much fake traffic that legitimate users were blocked. This increasingly common form of hacking is described as similar to hundreds of people calling one telephone line.

The company said in a statement: "It is unfortunate that an individual or group of individuals would engage in this kind of illegal activity."

Microsoft blamed its earlier problems, which knocked out its main corporate site and its MSN.com portal, on employee error. Complaints flooded in after the company's websites started producing unexpected results. For example, the central clock on Asheron's Call, a multiplayer role-playing game hosted on Microsoft's gaming zone, started to go backwards.

Microsoft said a technician made a "mistaken configuration change" to the computers that guide web surfers to its sites.

The Seattle-based company was subject to a daring hacker assault last October. Although the case is still under investigation, it emerged that the unidentified intruders had been able to study Microsoft's network unobserved for six weeks. Using stolen passwords, they then used Microsoft's Hotmail service to send snippets of the company's source code to an email address in Russia.

webTitle: Bush brothers at odds on oil exploration

fields.headline: Bush brothers at odds on oil exploration
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush and his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, have been set on a political collision course by plans to extend oil and natural gas drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.
fields.body:
President George Bush and his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, have been set on a political collision course by plans to extend oil and natural gas drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.

The new president arrived in office on a pledge to extend oil drilling rights, in an effort to make the United States self-sufficient in energy and avoid power supply crises like that affecting California.

But Jeb Bush has written to his brother's new administration calling on it to abandon the efforts begun by the Clinton administration to open up more of the eastern Gulf of Mexico to offshore drilling near the Florida coast.

The brothers are at odds because George Bush's presidential campaign was heavily backed by oil interests which are now looking for a return in the form of easier drilling rights in the Gulf, off the California coast, and in Alaska.

Jeb Bush, meanwhile, is facing a bitter re-election battle in November 2002 which will be dominated by the aftermath of the presidential election crisis in Florida. He is struggling to rebuild his popularity with the voters.

The governor is looking for support from the state's environmental lobby, which has made the protection of Florida's famous beaches, one of the most important attractions in the state, whose economy is heavily dependent on tourism, a top priority.

New offshore drilling is opposed by the Republicans and the Democrats in Florida, but Governor Bush clearly fears that he would take the blame if his brother's administration gives the go-ahead.

At issue in the stand-off is the future of a plan, put forward by the US department of the interior, to auction the drilling rights to 2.4m hectares (5.9m acres) of sea bed in the Gulf of Mexico, known as "Sale 181".

The area is divided into more than 1,000 separate blocks in a region "which contains potentially significant oil and gas resources that are largely unexplored", according to the department.

The area runs south from the Alabama coast, and most of the blocks are at least 100 miles from the Florida panhandle coast and more than 200 miles west of Tampa's shores.

If approved, it will be the first new drilling in the eastern Gulf of Mexico since 1988.

Among the bidders are likely to be the three oil multinationals - Chevron, Conaco and Murphy Oil - already drilling in other areas of the eastern Gulf. All three corporations gave money to George Bush's presidential campaign and to other Republican election funds.

"Florida's economy is based upon tourism and other activities that depend on a clean and healthy environment," Jeb Bush wrote in his letter this week. "I am confident that the new administration will recognise the need to protect sensitive natural resources located both offshore and along Florida's coastline for the benefit of the entire nation."

He told reporters in Tallahassee yesterday; "These are leases that are close to Florida waters and I think it's appropriate for the Florida governor to represent Florida's interests in that regard."

His intervention was welcomed by local environmental campaigners. "The governor is very strong against drilling, but he has not gone this far before," Mark Ferrulo, a spokesman for the Florida Public Interest Research Group, said.

"It's one of the most unifying issues in Florida, and there aren't that many of those right now."

The stand-off will be an early test of President Bush's nominee at the interior department, Gale Norton.

Her nomination caused consternation among environmentalists because of her record of strong support for new exploration and exploitation of natural resources, including a statement that property owners could have "a right to pollute".

At her confirmation hearings in Washington last week, however, Ms Norton disarmed her critics by disavowing and reversing many of her previous stands on environmental issues, including the "right to pollute" comment.

Though Friends of the Earth continues to dub her "a wolf in sheep's clothing," her nomination was approved 18-2 by a Senate committee on Wednesday, and is now waiting for full Senate approval.

 President Bush will meet the the prime minister, Tony Blair, next month, the White House announced yesterday.

Mr Blair and his wife will meet the president and first lady at Camp David on February 23-24 during what was described as a working visit.

Jeb Bush, meanwhile, is facing a bitter re-election battle in November 2002 which will be dominated by the aftermath of the presidential election crisis in Florida. He is struggling to rebuild his popularity with the voters. The governor is looking for support from the state's environmental lobby, which has made the protection of Florida's famous beaches, one of the most important attractions in the state, whose economy is heavily dependent on tourism, a top priority. New offshore drilling is opposed by the Republicans and the Democrats in Florida, but Governor Bush clearly fears that he would take the blame if his brother's administration gives the go-ahead. At issue in the stand-off is the future of a plan, put forward by the US department of the interior, to auction the drilling rights to 2.4m hectares (5.9m acres) of sea bed in the Gulf of Mexico, known as "Sale 181". The area is divided into more than 1,000 separate blocks in a region "which contains potentially significant oil and gas resources that are largely unexplored", according to the department. The area runs south from the Alabama coast, and most of the blocks are at least 100 miles from the Florida panhandle coast and more than 200 miles west of Tampa's shores. If approved, it will be the first new drilling in the eastern Gulf of Mexico since 1988. Among the bidders are likely to be the three oil multinationals - Chevron, Conaco and Murphy Oil - already drilling in other areas of the eastern Gulf. All three corporations gave money to George Bush's presidential campaign and to other Republican election funds. "Florida's economy is based upon tourism and other activities that depend on a clean and healthy environment," Jeb Bush wrote in his letter this week. "I am confident that the new administration will recognise the need to protect sensitive natural resources located both offshore and along Florida's coastline for the benefit of the entire nation." He told reporters in Tallahassee yesterday; "These are leases that are close to Florida waters and I think it's appropriate for the Florida governor to represent Florida's interests in that regard." His intervention was welcomed by local environmental campaigners. "The governor is very strong against drilling, but he has not gone this far before," Mark Ferrulo, a spokesman for the Florida Public Interest Research Group, said. "It's one of the most unifying issues in Florida, and there aren't that many of those right now." At her confirmation hearings in Washington last week, however, Ms Norton disarmed her critics by disavowing and reversing many of her previous stands on environmental issues, including the "right to pollute" comment. Though Friends of the Earth continues to dub her "a wolf in sheep's clothing," her nomination was approved 18-2 by a Senate committee on Wednesday, and is now waiting for full Senate approval.  President Bush will meet the the prime minister, Tony Blair, next month, the White House announced yesterday. Mr Blair and his wife will meet the president and first lady at Camp David on February 23-24 during what was described as a working visit.

webTitle: Capital Letters: Rome didn't learn to bilk in a day

fields.headline: Rome didn't learn to bilk in a day
fields.trailText: Already the morning sun arrives a bit earlier. Cherries and strawberries are starting to splash the fruit stalls red. Spring is on its way, and with it that tender meat so relished by Romans: tourists.
fields.body:
Already the morning sun arrives a bit earlier. Cherries and strawberries are starting to splash the fruit stalls red. Spring is on its way, and with it that tender meat so relished by Romans: tourists.

The Colosseum and Circus Maximus verge on deserted, but not for long. Lambs to the slaughter, tourists are booking flights, buying Lonely Planets and dreaming of the sites, unaware that the city is still bleeding visitors.

The Roman pickpocket and handbag snatcher are figures of legend, as clichéd as the scooters and ice-cream. That's no reason to think they are fictional. Whether forking out for a bus ticket, an apple, or a shoe repair, beware. Vigilance pays.

The owner of my local grocery is a rogue. A neighbour warned that when giving change he tends to pause before handing the final note, long enough for the unwary customer to leave but short enough to deny wrongdoing. A common trick.

Conventional wisdom says if you want to send packages, and want them to arrive, use the Vatican's postal service. Restaurants are notorious for unrequested starters, inflated cover charges, and accidental additions to the bill.

These are anecdotes. Many counter-examples exist, of dropped wallets handed in to police stations, magnanimous taxi drivers and kindness towards strangers, but there is no denying the perception that Rome squirms with crooks.

Surveys repeatedly show it to be one of Europe's safest cities, with relatively low rates of burglary and mugging, yet there is something about the attitude here which suggests the poor image is deserved. It is not that fleecing is widespread so much as the accompanying glee.

Tourists in a feelgood haze may not notice. Not so other Italians. They say the emblem SPQR stands not for senatus populusque Romanus ("the senate and people of Rome") but sono porci, questi Romani ("they are pigs these Romans").

Some historians suggest that Romans are conditioned to opportunism by centuries of tyranny, invasion, poverty and uncertainty. Others say the cause is more recent, the product of breakneck growth since being woken from a provincial snooze in 1871 to become the newly unified country's capital.

For all their bragging about imperial ancestry most Roman families are new arrivals, here for less than two generations, so they lack the rootedness which is said to give other Italians a stronger civic spirit.

Romans would not be Romans if they did not shrug off such hostility as ingratitude. Were it not for their pulsing energy the city, not an easy place to live in, would become a sterile tourist theme park. They feel entitled to some payback.

webTitle: It's someone else's fault, French sleaze trial is told

fields.headline: It's someone else's fault, French sleaze trial is told
fields.standfirst: Forest of finger-pointing by six accused from murky Mitterrand era
fields.trailText: Forest of finger-pointing by six accused from murky Mitterrand era.
fields.body:
If you believed the evidence in the first five days of France's biggest post-war sleaze trial, seven people have been charged with corruption but only one of them is to blame, and he was not in court.

Alfred Sirven, who was number two at the formerly state-owned petroleum company Elf-Aquitaine in the late 80s and early 90s, is believed to be living in the Philippines while the former foreign minister Roland Dumas, Mr Dumas's former lover, and four senior Elf officials are in danger of being jailed for five years and heavily fined.

Described as "le grand absent" in the French press, Mr Sirven was shown on national television this week sipping a cocktail on the beach while he was tried in absentia in a small wood-panelled courtroom in the palace of justice in Paris. His co-defendants lined up to blame him for setting up a secret slush fund to promote Elf's global influence.

The court drama, which is likely to run for another three weeks, has entranced the French with tales of high living, sexual betrayal, slush money and dubious arms sales. It has also cast a harsh light on the prevalence of high-level corruption during François Mitterrand's 1981-95 presidency.

France had only just got to grips with the "Angolagate" arms scandal involving the late president's son, when Mr Dumas, Mitterrand's foreign minister in the early 90s and a close friend, appeared in court to face corruption charges. He is accused of using his position to get his mistress, Christine Deviers-Joncour, 53, hired by Elf.

Mr Dumas, 78, is also charged with profiting from the money Elf paid her to lobby him to support the controversial sale of six frigates to Taiwan by another state-controlled firm, Thompson, in 1991.

The prosecution claims that he shared a sumptuous Left Bank flat with Ms Deviers-Joncour in the Rue de Lille, paid for from Elf funds, and that she bought him lavish presents, including five antique statues worth £26,400.

On Wednesday one particular gift attracted the court's attention. Mr Dumas agreed that Ms Devier-Joncour had given him a pair of Italian shoes costing £1,100, but added that he had reimbursed her. Such expensive shoes were necessary, his lawyer said, because Mr Dumas had orthopaedic problems.

Mr Dumas and his former lover, whose eyes he has studiously avoided during the trial, have become the focus of this trial: he a sleek and cultured Frenchman, she a fraught yet fragrant Mary Archer figure with a career of lingerie modelling behind her.

And yet she helped the old rake's case on Monday when she told the court that he had not pressed Elf to hire her, contradicting the evidence she gave to investigating magistrates before the trial began.

As gallantry demanded, Mr Dumas did not point the finger at Ms Deviers-Joncour when he gave evidence later in the week, but at the absent Mr Sirven. "She was the least of my worries. She was an emissary. But not for Floch-Prigent [director-general of Elf-Aquitaine at the time], rather for Sirven."

The silver-haired politician who was for 20 years one of France's leading barristers, skilfully tried to seduce the court. "It is heartbreaking to find myself here at the end of a life that began in difficulty and was built up by hard work," he declared. "To run the risk of being dishonoured at my age is untenable."

Then he tried scorn. "The investigating judges were far more interested in the anonymous letters that kept arriving in their offices than in verifying the truth."

Then he tried denial. "I reiterate on my honour that I never asked anyone for anything."

Least of all, he claimed, did he demand that his lover be hired by Elf.

This was undermined by the evidence of another of the accused, a former senior Elf official, Andre Tarallo, who said that he had signed Ms Deviers-Joncour's employment contract at Mr Dumas's behest.

Loik Le Floch-Prigent, also on trial for corruption, told the court that he was not aware of Ms Deviers-Joncour's recruitment and had never required her lobbying services. Asked if he had been betrayed by Mr Sirven, he replied: "It would seem so, yes."

But he will need to explain to the court how he came to charge £6,800 for CDs to his company credit card in a single afternoon. Similarly, Mr Dumas will have to account for the flat where he lived with his lover, and gifts beyond those considered orthopaedically necessary.

Ms Deviers-Joncour has denied that she was used by Mr Sirven to lure Mr Dumas to back Elf in selling frigates to Taiwan, but at the same time and confusingly she has argued that she was a victim of "Sirven's network".

Whether "le grand absent" carries the can for all this corruption will become the grand drama of the next three weeks.

webTitle: Japanese PM threatened by 'fun fund' revelations

fields.headline: Japanese PM threatened by 'fun fund' revelations
fields.trailText: The Japanese government failed to quell a damaging embezzlement scandal as details emerged yesterday of the widespread misuse of public funds.
fields.body:
The Japanese government failed to quell a damaging embezzlement scandal as details emerged yesterday of the widespread misuse of public funds.

The revelations pose a threat to the future of the already unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, six months before the upper house elections.

On Tuesday the minister in charge of economic and fiscal policy, Fukushiro Nukaga,resigned after being implicated in a cash-for-favours scandal.

On Thursday Katsutoshi Matsuo, who was responsible for planning overseas trips by previous prime ministers, resigned after a foreign ministry report claimed that he had transferred as much as 560m yen (£3.2m) from discretionary funds kept by the foreign ministry and cabinet secretariat to eight private accounts.

Mr Matsuo is suspected of using some of the money to pay for golf club memberships, yachts, and a plush apartment in central Tokyo. The report accused him of using some of the money to buy racehorses, several of which he named after a mistress.

There was also criticism of the discretionary funds, the size and use of which is not revealed by the government.

But Mr Mori insisted that there was no need to investigate or cut the fund. "It's not that necessary," he said. "That's a separate question."

Although the report said that only Mr Matsuo had acted improperly, opposition parties believe that the abuse runs deeper.

Yohei Kono, the foreign minister, offered to take responsibility by returning six months of his salary. But he will come under pressure to resign if, as some believe, a police investigation implicates other senior officials.

Mr Mori, who flew to Davos yesterday to attend the World Economic Forum, pointed out that the alleged embezzlement took place before his government took office 10 months ago.

But the Japanese media were reporting "rampant" misuse of the foreign ministry's fund yesterday, claiming the money was used "daily" to pay for private entertainment.

Diplomats overseas said the money was often spent on lavish parties for visiting politicians and ministry officials.

Last year the ministry and secretariat received almost 7bn yen in discretionary funds, which are dispensed with minimal supervision or regulation.

A former chief cabinet secretary, Koken Nosaka, recalled in Asahi Shimbun handing politicians envelopes stuffed with cash, sometimes running into millions of yen, to pay for overseas trips. He said the payments were seldom recorded.

webTitle: Child of the revolution returns to haunt Fischer

fields.headline: Child of the revolution returns to haunt Fischer
fields.standfirst: One woman's struggle to keep the foreign minister's radical past in the spotlight
fields.trailText: One woman's struggle to keep the foreign minister's radical past in the spotlight.
fields.body:
In the week that the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, was wined and dined by politicians in London, the woman behind the exposé of his militant past pledged to press on with her campaign to topple him from power.

Bettina Röhl, the daughter of the urban guerrilla leader Ulrike Meinhof, who co-founded the Red Army Faction (RAF), said she is motivated by a desire to break a leftwing clique that for years has protected Mr Fischer s reputation.

In one of her first newspaper interviews since she sparked controversy over Mr Fischer's days as a radical Marxist by procuring film reels and photos of him beating up a police officer in 1973, Ms Röhl yesterday told the Guardian that she had become the focus of a nationwide hate campaign.

"I have been defamed by the 'Fischer system' - a mass of people in both politics and the media who, without being asked to, defend Fischer to the hilt and attack anyone who says anything against him," she said. "They're trying to destroy me."

Ms Röhl, 38, a freelance journalist, has been portrayed in the German media as a daughter seeking revenge for a wretched childhood, who has focused her anger on Mr Fischer. Meinhof committed suicide when Ms Röhl was 13.

Small, neat, attired in delicate gold jewellery and claiming to be apolitical, Ms Röhl, who lives in Hamburg with her "conservative businessman" partner appears the antithesis of her anarchic, depressive chain-smoking mother.

She insisted yesterday that she had "dealt with the past in a private way", and 20 months ago, in her capacity as a journalist, had simply "stumbled across a fascinating story which I've researched very thoroughly and want now to bring to light, but that has nothing to do with my mother".

"I'm capable of separating the personal and professional, but all anyone wants to say is: 'you can't trust her motivation because she's the terrorist's daughter'."

Mr Fischer has vehemently denied Ms Röhl's claim that he was behind the Frankfurt militant scene's molotov cocktails, advocating their use at a 1976 demonstration - in protest at the suicide of Meinhof - at which a policeman, Jürgen Weber, nearly died after his car was engulfed in flames.

Two weeks ago Ms Röhl began pressing for Mr Fischer to be investigated on suspicion of the attempted murder of Mr Weber, whom she has befriended. She says she has taped accounts from three witnesses who say that Mr Fischer had called for the use of violence.

"He was the criteria for the violence," says Ms Röhl. "But cleverly he remained the éminence grise who managed to appear to not get his hands dirty."

She dismisses his claims that he turned his back on violence in 1977. "There are plenty of witnesses I have on tape who say that from his days as a Frankfurt radical, through to his rise through the Green party in the 1980s, Mr Fischer has always had his bully boys who would come in and beat up his opponents or anyone standing in his way. It's too late for him to claim he's changed."

Mr Fischer's past keeps coming back to haunt him. Allegations surfaced last weekend that he had given refuge to the RAF terrorist Margrit Schiller in his Frankfurt apartment. Last week he gave evidence at the murder trial of his former friend, Hans-Joachim Klein, who abandoned Mr Fischer's radical group in favour of hardcore terrorism.

Ms Röhl says that the foreign minister, who has apologised for his past, is one of thousands of Germans suffering from the "Baader-Meinhof complex". "It's in the heads of many those who are traumatised by the roles they played during the student demonstrations, and all the more so because they are horrified by the recognition that they enjoyed the violence and are somehow nostalgic for it."

And she claims Mr Fischer's metamorphosis is deceptive. She interviewed him in 1998, before he was foreign minister, during research for a book. "I knew then that he had been a 1970s demonstrator, but knew nothing of the serious role he had really played. I simply wanted to interview him as a politician, and had my questions prepared.

"But he didn't let me ask any questions. He treated me as if I was Ulrike Meinhof reincarnated, and he wanted to defend the role he had played in the scene. With his eyes closed, he seemed to go on a nostalgia trip and said: 'I certainly wasn't unviolent', and got quite cross when I tried to brush the subject aside. He wanted me to see him as a hero of the 70s."

Mr Fischer and Meinhof belonged to different radical circles in Frankfurt, Meinhof to the RAF, Mr Fischer to the Marxist "Cleaning Brigade".

Ms Röhl said: "They didn t know each other, but I've come across a letter from my mother written from prison, where she requests the text of a speech given in 1972 by someone from the Revolutionary Fight [RK] in which it was said that the battle of the RAF should be firmly defended. The speech was Fischer's."

She believes that the support shown to Mr Fischer is evidence of a propaganda campaign which intends to "play up the crimes of the right in order to cover up the crimes of the left".

"Of course, it's necessary to fight against the far right, but an exaggerated view of the right is portrayed, which serves the left very well, providing figures like Fischer with a veil behind which to hide and there's a type of brain-washing at play."

While Mr Fischer s life story reads like a thriller, Ms Röhl's early life was equally dramatic. She was reluctant to elaborate on her childhood yesterday. But she has described life at home in the 70s, along with her twin Regine - now a Hamburg doctor - as "like living in a constant state of emergency".

Her childhood was punctuated by traumatic events: her parents' divorce when she was seven; Meinhof's escape underground when her children were eight; the sisters' abduction to Sicily for four months; Meinhof's arrest for murder when the girls were 10, and an imprisonment during which they saw her only a handful of times before she hanged herself in 1976.

But an analysis of Ms Röhl s current actions in the light of her past deeply anger her. "I now have the feeling that I've conquered my past, but that doesn't mean that I'll say the pain was never there. But to say I've redirected that on to Fischer is absurd."

And she is adamant it is not her past that needs to be scrutinised. "I'd be happy simply if someone started to look properly at Mr Fischer's past, but the trouble is that the system that should investigate him is riddled with people with similar pasts who today are also very powerful."
