"But he didn't let me ask any questions. He treated me as if I was Ulrike Meinhof reincarnated, and he wanted to defend the role he had played in the scene. With his eyes closed, he seemed to go on a nostalgia trip and said: 'I certainly wasn't unviolent', and got quite cross when I tried to brush the subject aside. He wanted me to see him as a hero of the 70s." Mr Fischer and Meinhof belonged to different radical circles in Frankfurt, Meinhof to the RAF, Mr Fischer to the Marxist "Cleaning Brigade". Ms Röhl said: "They didn t know each other, but I've come across a letter from my mother written from prison, where she requests the text of a speech given in 1972 by someone from the Revolutionary Fight [RK] in which it was said that the battle of the RAF should be firmly defended. The speech was Fischer's." She believes that the support shown to Mr Fischer is evidence of a propaganda campaign which intends to "play up the crimes of the right in order to cover up the crimes of the left". "Of course, it's necessary to fight against the far right, but an exaggerated view of the right is portrayed, which serves the left very well, providing figures like Fischer with a veil behind which to hide and there's a type of brain-washing at play." While Mr Fischer s life story reads like a thriller, Ms Röhl's early life was equally dramatic. She was reluctant to elaborate on her childhood yesterday. But she has described life at home in the 70s, along with her twin Regine - now a Hamburg doctor - as "like living in a constant state of emergency". Her childhood was punctuated by traumatic events: her parents' divorce when she was seven; Meinhof's escape underground when her children were eight; the sisters' abduction to Sicily for four months; Meinhof's arrest for murder when the girls were 10, and an imprisonment during which they saw her only a handful of times before she hanged herself in 1976. But an analysis of Ms Röhl s current actions in the light of her past deeply anger her. "I now have the feeling that I've conquered my past, but that doesn't mean that I'll say the pain was never there. But to say I've redirected that on to Fischer is absurd." And she is adamant it is not her past that needs to be scrutinised. "I'd be happy simply if someone started to look properly at Mr Fischer's past, but the trouble is that the system that should investigate him is riddled with people with similar pasts who today are also very powerful."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: US candidate to lead nurses
fields.body:
US candidate to lead nurses

Former US nurses' leader Beverly Malone was named yesterday as the next general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing. Ms Malone, 51, will join the RCN in March.

Cash hope for slashed child

Francesca Quintyne, eight, attacked with a machete at St Luke's primary school, Wolverhampton, in 1996, should have her £8,100 compensation increased to £80,000, Cherie Booth QC told the criminal injuries compensation appeals panel yesterday. Judgment was reserved.

Detectives face perjury charge

Two RUC detectives are to be charged with perjury over a sectarian murder almost 15 years ago. Thomas Green was found guilty of battering Catholic painter John O'Neill, 25, to death in 1986. He was released in 1998, still insisting he was innocent.

Marque of fairness

German car giant DaimlerChrysler AG, owner of the Mercedes car name, yesterday lost a high court case to block a clothing shop in Carnaby Street, London, being called Merc.

£240,000 spirits swindle

Former racehorse trainer Geoff Huffer, 53, was yesterday found guilty at Croydon crown court of dodging £240,000 duty when importing spirits.

webTitle: Day when the red dragon awoke

fields.headline: Day when the red dragon awoke
fields.standfirst: 40th anniversary of the bitterly resented flooding of a Welsh community rekindles anger at the brutality of power
fields.trailText: 40th anniversary of the bitterly resented flooding of a Welsh community rekindles anger at the brutality of power
fields.body:
Forty years ago today, a steam-hauled passenger train chugged slowly for the last time through Cym Tryweryn, a lonely valley in mid-Wales, on its way from Blaenau Ffestiniog to Bala.

It was the end of the line for the village of Capel Celyn, home to 67 Welsh-speaking people whose families had lived in the valley for generations.

Within five years, the village, with its farms, cottages, post office, school and Calvinistic Methodist chapel, was submerged beneath the waters of a new reservoir. Sixty-five million gallons a day were then pumped to homes and factories in Liverpool.

"Everyone deplores the fact that in the interests of progress some people must suffer," the Liverpool MP Bessie Braddock told the Commons at the time. "But that is progress."

The locals, rooted in the landscape they loved, did not agree. They went by bus to Liverpool and marched with banners through the city's streets. Gwynfor Evans, soon to be an MP, interrupted a meeting of the city council and was thrown out by police.

During construction, one transformer was sabotaged and another was blown up; two men were jailed, a third was put on probation.

The reservoir was opened on October 21 1965, but the city decided against a royal or a big-name politician. They sent instead Alderman Frank Cain, the biblical significance of whose name was not lost on the protesters who gathered for one of the biggest anti-English revolts since the days of Owain Glyndwr.

Cars were mobbed, the Free Wales Army made its first appearance and speeches went unheard after microphone cables were cut. The event ended in chaos but the water flowed on.

Nationalists have not forgotten Capel Celyn. One, unconscious of the pun, now describes it as a watershed in Welsh politics: when the red dragon awoke.

They see the destruction of the village as a brutal act of thuggery by a dominant power and say it led directly to the rise of Plaid Cymru as a major political force, the formation of Cymdeithas yr Iaith Gymraeg (the Welsh Language Society), and the creation of the Welsh assembly.

Some also claim that such tyranny lives on, which is why a rally today on the shores of the Llyn Celyn reservoir will be attended by Kurdish representatives opposing the construction of the Ilisu dam in Turkey, which they claim will force 25,000 people from their homes.

On a bright winter day, the sun reflects brilliantly on Llyn Celyn and a razor-sharp wind whips up its dark waters. At the western end, a chapel built from the stones of the old village contains tablets recording the names of all who were buried in Capel Celyn's graveyard. Some were exhumed; others still lie beneath the water.

In a walled garden stand headstones taken from the graveyard: seven remember families named Jones, five honour Robertses. One stone is inscribed in memory of Cadwaladr Evans and his wife Catherine.

At the east end of the reservoir, recent and not quite obliterated letters lie on the road that runs across the 130-yard dam: "Welsh water for Welsh people" reads the emphatic message.

"They razed the village to the ground because they did not expect that anyone would ever see Capel Celyn again," said Gwyn Sin Ifan, Welsh language activist and one of the organisers of today's event. "But water levels fell during the 1976 drought and we were able then to walk along the old road that ran through the village. We could see broken crockery from the farmhouses still lying on the ground. The feeling of the community had not gone away.

"They [Liverpool's councillors] killed everything that was here and tried to uproot everything that belonged to the community. No one would ever dream of such a plan in Wales again. But we must always be aware of what the water companies are up to."

There are already rumours that officials from Severn Trent Water have been examining other Welsh valleys for suitable reservoir sites, although the company says it is "not looking for anything in particular".

"They never learn, do they?" said Elwyn Edwards who bunked off school in 1956 to join that Liverpool demo. He can be seen in contemporary photographs trying to hide behind his banner.

"I was given a hiding by the headmaster the next day," he said. "I was 13 at the time and felt passionately about the scheme.

"My mother grew up in the valley and went to school there. There were 13 children on one farm and they were my second cousins. I used to play there all the time. I thought they would never drown the place."

webTitle: Drug family that fuelled resort's deadly habit

fields.headline: Drug family that fuelled resort's deadly habit
fields.standfirst:
They might have been polite and well-mannered, but Brighton's most feared dynasty was still undone by lethal addiction

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: They might have been polite and well-mannered, but Brighton's most feared dynasty was still undone by lethal addiction
fields.body:
They remember the Comptons on the Moulsecoomb estate: Ronald, Margaret and their four sons, Ronald jnr, Stephen, Sean and Robert. The family hasn't lived there for 10 years, but mention of it has the effect of a sudden draught, sucking shut doors, delivering a bolt down the spine.

"Look at me, I'm shaking," said a resident last week, reminded of the family by news that four of the Compton men had been sentenced to join the fifth in prison. "They were polite and well mannered, but it's what they brought into the neighbourhood. They moved on and they left the problem here."

The problem was heroin. At Hove crown court in east Sussex last week, Judge Anthony Scott-Gall ruled that the Compton family business was a "vile and wicked trade" of sufficient reach to warrant sentences totalling 21 years.

The father, Ronald snr, 58, was convicted of drug trafficking. His "lieutenants" Stephen, 38, and Sean, 28, were convicted of conspiracy to supply drugs, and Robert, 36, was found guilty of possessing cash proceeds from drug trafficking. The eldest son, Ronald jnr, 39, is two years into an eight-year sentence for possessing heroin with intent to supply.

"They like to think of themselves as loveable rogues," said Detective Inspector Paul Grundy, who lead the inquiry. "But they are not. They are dealers in death."

The rise of the Compton family from the privations of Moulsecoomb to the mansions of Brighton's Tongdean neighbourhood is set against the decline of the addicts they supplied. Brighton and Hove has the highest number of heroin-related deaths of any region in the country. In 1999, the figure was over 35; by last June that record had already been beaten.

"It is easier to get a bag of heroin than a cup of tea in Brighton," said Neil Ansell, regional manager of the Big Issue. "Heroin is more available than cannabis. I know of several people who have died of overdoses since the beginning of January."

"It is recognised that seaside resorts attract an itinerant population of people with social problems," said a spokeswoman for Addaction, the needle exchange and counselling service which since last May has registered an average of 55 addicts a month. To indicate the extent of Brighton's drugs trade, the number of addicts registering at the service's east London branch, is only 40-45 a month. Into this scene came the Comptons, who over two decades would make an estimated £3m from the heroin trade. It is a commonplace of drug dealing that the higher up the supply chain you operate, the less likely you are to be drug-using yourself. The remarkable thing about the Comptons is that despite their seniority, as heroin wholesalers, members of the family were themselves taking drugs and to an extent that threatened to destroy them.

Salutary effect

In 1993, Robert Compton's wife Alison died from a heroin-related illness; Stephen Compton's partner Jacky died after an overdose of amphetamines. When Sean and Sasha Compton's baby girl was born, it was with an opiate addiction from which she is just now recovering. "I hope that fact had a salutary effect on you," said Judge Scott-Gall while sentencing Sean to four and a half years' imprisonment. Sasha Compton sobbed before retreating to her six bedroom, mock-Tudor house with intercom and video entry facilities.

The family business started three miles from the genteel lanes of Tongdean, in Brighton's Moulsecoomb estate, a district marked by the unhappy juxtaposition of frightened pensioners in well-kept houses with squalid dealers' homes bearing the scars of serial efforts to kick the doors in. The police have intelligence tracing the Compton family business back 15 years, to when the sons were teenagers and Ronald snr described himself as an antiques dealer. They did not operate on a grand scale. "It made me laugh when they described Stephen as the 'banker' in the family," said a former neighbour, still fearful enough of recriminations to withhold his name. "I remember seeing him dealing in broad daylight right outside the shop. But they were a great deal better than what came in after them."

As the sons grew up, they acquired nominal trades for themselves: Robert was a "jewellery dealer"; Sean, despite the mansion and Mercedes he later purchased, identified himself as a "handyman"; Stephen followed his father into the "antiques business".

As the dynasty grew and a steady supply of heroin was secured from London and Liverpool, the Compton parents moved to Woodingdean, a quiet hilltop area overlooking the sea, where Margaret Compton still lives. They began investing in property under the name Comptons of Brighton. Margaret Compton opened a florists in the city centre. "I did well," she said last week, still maintaining the innocence if not of her husband (he pleaded guilty to charges of trafficking), then at least of her sons. "We paid £89,000 for this house and we've got a mortgage like anyone else. I had a car on hire purchase - now if I was rolling in all this drugs money, why would I do that?"

Contaminated

The evidence collated by the intelligence branch of the Sussex police was incontrovertible, however. When Ronald jnr's home was raided three years ago, police found 60kg of cannabis resin with a street value of between £90,000 and £144,000. They also recovered £13,750 worth of heroin.

A year later, under Operation Sun Spot, 50 officers raided the rest of the family's homes and recovered 1.2kg of heroin worth £50,000 and a stash of £170,000, most of it stuffed into tins of instant potato mix or hidden under floorboards. Some 95% of the notes were contaminated with traces of heroin. It was the biggest seizure in Sussex for 10 years and the end of one of Brighton's most extensive organised crime families.

The ripple effect this bust has had on crime figures in Brighton is difficult to quantify. "There will be a void," said Det Insp Grundy, pointing to Home Office figures which indicate that 1kg of heroin generates 220 victims of burglary and £220,000 worth of stolen property, and that each addicted offender executes somewhere in the region of 100 crimes a month.

Drugs charities in Brighton, while applauding police efforts, were slightly more cautious. "We haven't seen a dip yet," said a spokeswoman for Addaction. "There is no evidence that our clients are finding it more difficult to get supplies. They would be visibly suffering if that were the case. The sad fact is that it doesn't take long for someone else to come in and take over the Comptons' territory."

"Arresting the Comptons is a hiccup in the drugs trade," said Mr Ansell. "I have never known an addict in Brighton to say, 'I've been trying all day and I can't get a bag of heroin.' The street dealers will just get their supplies from someone else."

He added: "I've known dealers to have been put away in the morning, and by the afternoon, for their mobile phones to have been in use by other dealers who have taken over the good will of the business."

The demand for heroin in Brighton has pushed prices to £15-£20 for a fraction of a gram and crack has started making an appearance. "The way we are tackling it is to come down extremely hard on the dealers," said Glynn Jones, chief executive of Brighton and Hove council and chair of the Drug and Alcohol Action Team. "We are coordinating with the health authority, the police and drugs charities to form a consistent approach, and ensure that action taken against dealers is not in conflict with the rehabilitation of users." The team is also working with Brighton schools to send in ex-addicts to talk to pupils about the dangers of drug taking.

Margaret Compton, meanwhile, continues to plead persecution. Charges of trafficking against her remain on police files and the authorities are seeking to recover the rest of the money made from the business. "He did a bad thing and he paid for it," she said of her husband, before driving the three miles to her daughter-in-law Sasha's house, to help with the newly fatherless grandchildren.

webTitle: Controllers to vote on air safety strike

fields.headline: Controllers to vote on air safety strike
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's air traffic controllers are to be asked to issue a strike threat against government plans for a partial privatisation of the system later this year.
fields.body:
Britain's air traffic controllers are to be asked to issue a strike threat against government plans for a partial privatisation of the system later this year.

This is one of several plans which will be discussed by members of the controllers' union, the IPMS, at a special conference at Stockport next weekend.

The controllers say the plan will undermine safety and they fear a repetition of what happened to the rail system.

Iain Findlay, IPMS national officer responsible for the controllers, said yesterday that morale was extremely low and that the plans were "getting up the noses of staff".

Other points in the protest are strikes against the National Air Traffic Services' introduction of performance-related pay - and a 10-day training course, which they reject despite an offer of £8,000 for doing it.

The controllers have to be trained to work at a new centre at Swanwick in Hampshire from the beginning of next year. But a shortage of staff means that some would have to give up leave to complete the training in time.

Mr Findlay said there was a 98% vote against the £8,000 among controllers because they were already working too hard.

A Nats spokeswoman said that it had not seen the contents of the resolution and was unable to comment.

The government's plans for a partial privatisation were put on hold last month for three months after being defeated twice in the Lords. Parliament has agreed to the breathing space to allow for further talks.

There are three final bidders: the consortium of seven British airlines, Lockheed Martin and Serco. Ministers have started to press ahead with the plan again, so that it can be in place in March.

But pro-hunt campaigners claimed the high court judgment was at most a partial victory for the RSPCA as Mr Justice Lightman stopped the charity from arbitrarily excluding anyone it believed had suspicious motives for joining.

Instead the animal welfare group will have to give all applicants a chance to explain their primary motives for becoming members.

The RSPCA took the unusual step of seeking guidance from the high court to clarify its membership rules after officials suspected the charity had fallen victim to "entryism" by the pro-hunting Countryside Animal Welfare Group, led by the Olympic equestrian medallist Richard Meade.

Last year the charity put on hold 600 applications for membership, which it believed were part of a campaign to overturn its opposition to hunting with dogs, a keystone policy of the RSPCA since 1976.

Mr Meade, who denies the allegation of entryism, claims the CAWG was formed by those in rural areas who believed the RSPCA had "lost its way".

The group was represented at the hearing, together with two applicants whose membership had not been confirmed, to oppose the RSPCA move.

The society told the judge that any infiltration campaign to change the official policy and promote field sports was damaging.

Mr Justice Lightman said the society did have the right to exclude or remove members under its rules but to do so meant every case would have to go before the full 25-strong council, which cannot delegate its powers.

The RSPCA had asked the judge to approve a scheme to exclude anyone who fell within categories it thought indicated they were joining to promote hunting with dogs - without giving them a chance to deny this.

But the judge said: "After long and anxious consideration, I have concluded that it is not in the interests of the society or conducive to its good name to adopt such an arbitrary and unattractive method of implementing the membership policy."

He said applicants must be given the chance to explain their motives "to meet the real risk of injustice arising from wrong categorisation".

Malcolm Phipps, chairman of the RSPCA's ruling council, said he welcomed the ruling. "The RSPCA is a democratic organisation, but clearly concerted efforts to join the society for any overriding reason other than animal welfare makes a mockery of this democracy. Today's ruling has given the society a mechanism to protect itself against infiltration and ensures that the society's vital work is not hindered."

A friend of Mr Meade, who has been a member of the RSPCA since 1970, said he would not be commenting until he had digested the contents of the ruling.

The case, which was heard in November, was initially delayed after two judges scheduled to hear the case disclosed their involvement with hunting. One admitted he was a member of the Countryside Alliance while the other admitted he allowed hare coursing on his Norfolk land.

fields.headline: Windsor chapel gets £69,000 repair boost
fields.standfirst: St George's offered English Heritage grant for first time
fields.trailText: St George's offered English Heritage grant for first time
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
St George's chapel, which is within the walls of Windsor castle, has been included for the first time in the annual round of cathedral grants from English Heritage.

It has been offered £69,000, part of the £2.5m total announced yesterday, towards work including a fire detection system.

The grade I listed medieval building, containing the tombs of Henry VIII and Charles I, was not damaged in the fire which gutted the main castle buildings in 1992. The restoration of the castle was financed by opening Buckingham palace to tourists.

Richard Halsey, head of the English Heritage cathedrals programme, said: "People might be a little surprised at this, but the chapel is actually owned by the dean and canons of Windsor, who are responsible for the repairs, and they are quite hard up.

"When the cathedrals scheme was established in 1991, the Church asked that both Westminster abbey and St George's be included, but it is only this year that St George's has become eligible."

The total bill will eventually run into millions of pounds. Much of the ornate stonework is in decaying Reigate stone, and roof and cloisters repairs are needed.

The grant will also help pay for a conservation plan, to determine a programme of repairs.

Announcing the grants, the head of English Heritage, Sir Neil Cossons, yesterday challenged the government to give back a fraction of the tax revenue from tourism in conservation grants, in order to wipe out the backlog of repairs to the nation's most important listed buildings.

If the government gave just £75m a year, 2.5% of the estimated £3bn tax revenue from tourists, Sir Neil said, it could clear the repairs backlog on grade I and grade II listed buildings in 10 years, instead of the 60 years which it will take on current grant levels.

He said the cathedrals were "some of the most successful tourist attractions in the country", and praised the jobs they created, the training their workshops provided in crafts, and the choral tradition they preserved. Last year, cathedrals attracted 18.2m visitors. The largest grant, more than £400,000, has been offered to Salisbury cathedral for repairs to the roof and cloisters.

Lincoln will get £259,000, and Peterborough £214,000 for work on its unique 13th century painted nave ceiling.

The 11th century Hereford cathedral, home of the Mappa Mundi, receives a £148,000 grant for stonework on its Lady chapel.

St Paul's in London gets £100,000 for repairs to the dome, including Wren's iron chain which helps hold the vast structure together.

Grants will go to several 20th century cathedrals, including Guildford and "Paddy's Wigwam", the Roman Catholic cathedral in Liverpool, whose early problems with roof leaks became notorious.

fields.headline: At this price?  London Bridge
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Times are hard for London Bridge Software, the retail banking IT specialists. The company is part of a sector experiencing widespread correction, and technology stocks are likely to be hit first if a recession does bite.
fields.body:
Times are hard for London Bridge Software, the retail banking IT specialists. The company is part of a sector experiencing widespread correction, and technology stocks are likely to be hit first if a recession does bite.

Yesterday its shares dropped 15p to 390p taking the value of the company to £661.8m, a long way off its high of £2.6bn during last year's investment madness.

The shares fell after the company reported shrunken revenues in the US had dragged profits for the year down to £9.25m before tax, a figure barely reaching a revised forecast the company was forced to issue earlier this month.

Management remained positive, emphasising that there had been areas of progress. Revenues for the year were £56.7m, a third higher than the year before, but 10% lower than the company's original forecast, due to a delay in signing four US licensing deals, according to LBS. The first half was strong, and the level of business activity had remained high into the new year. Not high enough, however, to prevent a profits warning and to keep the share price buoyant.

But, the company is looking better for the coming year. Sales have grown 37% over the year and analysts say the company is a leading player in its field with a good customer base. Continued growth is expected at about 30%, and there is likely to be further growth when the company completes its acquisition of Phoenix International in February.

LBS does, however, have to get clients to buy the software and prove it can expand in the US - not an easy thing to do. A recent Information Week survey of IT executives found that they expect IT spending growth to slow from 11% in 2000 to 7% this year.

The stock is in a volatile sector, but if you are prepared to ride the roller coaster of the technology sector, hold. If more cautious, wait for further proof of LBS's potential.

fields.headline: Take care
fields.trailText: Pensioners throughout Britain will rightly see the Scottish parliament's decision to introduce free personal care to all pensioners north of the border as a victory for justice, equality and compassion (Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly, January 26).
fields.body:
Pensioners throughout Britain will rightly see the Scottish parliament's decision to introduce free personal care to all pensioners north of the border as a victory for justice, equality and compassion (Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly, January 26). By adhering to the recommendations of the royal commission on the funding of long-term care, Holyrood's MSPs have given a clear lead to their Westminster counterparts. In so doing, pensioners in England and Wales will now be able to ask why they should have to pay to receive help to bathe or eat a meal - when the same services are free to their Scottish neighbours.

Surely a national health service means just that. Failure to introduce the same provision throughout Britain will highlight one of the worst cases of postcode-related care ever seen. That is why personal care should be available to all, free at the point of need. Nothing less will do.
Jack Jones
 President, National Pensioners Convention

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Cartoons' online sale

fields.headline: Drawing a good deal of interest online
fields.standfirst:
Original cartoons and illustrations are Chris Beetles' passion and next month sees his first internet sale. Stewart Dalby reports

More net news
fields.trailText: Original cartoons and illustrations are Chris Beetles' passion and next month sees his first internet sale. Stewart Dalby reports.
fields.body:
Chris Beetles, at his gallery in London's St James's, is the world's foremost dealer in illustrations and cartoons - not lithographs or prints but original drawings and paintings. Each year he holds a two-month sale of well over 500 illustrations and this year's show, just ending, realised more than £700,000

The items range from Georgians such as Thomas Rowlandson and Isaac and Robert Cruikshank, by way of Victorian illustrators such as Edward Lear and Arthur Rackham, Winnie the Pooh illustrator EH Shephard, to 20th century cartoonists like Ronald Searle, David Low and Frank Dickens. They include political cartoonists from Punch, John Leech and Sir John Tenniel and illustrators such as Kate Greenaway and Mabel Lucie Atwell.

The shows, however, are just the tip of the iceberg. Mr Beetles has been collecting and buying for a long time and has the largest archive anywhere. He writes books and articles and, for more than 20 years, has worked to popularise what he believes is an undervalued area of English art.

His originals have clearly been shrewdly amassed and prices for original illustrations have rocketed in recent years. Any Winnie the Pooh illustration by EH Shephard would now fetch anything from £50,000 to £125,000 at auction, depending on condition and rarity - twice or even three times what they would have realised five years ago. Similarly, Arthur Rackham pieces can realise £30,000 against £10,000 years ago.

But most are still affordable. Pen ink or drawings by Arthur Rackham can be bought for a few hundred pounds. A cartoon by Sir John Tenniel, who lived a long life and was extremely prolific, would cost between £500 to £1,000, a lot more than five years ago. Mr Beetles reckons prices have been rising by 20% a year.

Now, in collaboration with Sotheby's, he is holding his first online sale which runs from Wednesday February 7 to Wednesday February 28. There will be 100 lots reflecting a wide range of artists. Most are modestly priced, ranging from a few hundred dollars to several thousand and there are no really expensive pieces.

Why is he going on to the internet? "I have a lot of illustrations which nobody sees and view the internet as a new and exciting vehicle for promoting and selling them. They are affordable and lend themselves very well to digital reproduction. Cartoons have bold colours and strong lines."

Sotheby's has been holding internet-only auctions for a year. A unique feature of the sales is that associates, namely dealers and smaller auctioneers, can participate in auctions that would have once been exclusively supplied through Sotheby's. Mr Beetles has become another of the 4,000 associates.

Sotheby's research shows that the majority of online bidders are not normally Sotheby's clients.

Moreover, 80% of bidders are from the US. Mr Beetles has been selling more and more pieces to American collectors, particularly in New York and New England. This sale therefore, in theory, offers the chance for him to push into new areas and expand in established growth markets.

But there is a danger in going online. I put it to him that, in tracking previous online sales, I noticed that everyone seemed to wait until the last minute before bidding and that there seemed to be a preponderance of dealers, rather than collectors. Sotheby's confirmed that 80% of bids came within the last hours of an internet auction. This tended, it seemed to me, to act as a dampener on prices. The Royal Doulton sale before Christmas ran from December 5 to December 29, but on December 27 half the lots were still open and most bids were around or slightly below the estimates.

Has Mr Beetles put the less expensive pieces on the sale? "Well yes," he says, adding: "There would be little point putting an EH Shephard Winnie up for sale because I suspect I would find the difference between the buying and selling price too small. There is a risk, frankly, that I will be selling pieces for little more than I paid for them, or even as loss-leaders to publicise the art form. But I am interested in finding out."

 For further information telephone Sothebys 0202 7293 6185. Or telephone the Chris Beetles Gallery 020 7839 7551.

fields.headline: Kazoo3D faces sale or closure
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The first stockmarket-listed company born out of the First Tuesday networking group yesterday admitted that it could be sold or closed after failing to live up to its own expectations.
fields.body:
The first stockmarket-listed company born out of the First Tuesday networking group yesterday admitted that it could be sold or closed after failing to live up to its own expectations.

Kazoo3D was founded by a group of software developers who met at a First Tuesday event in late 1999 and floated on AIM in April last year. The company said it was "reviewing all strategic options" after attracting an "extremely disappointing" number of customers and generating negligible revenues.

Shares in the Sheffield firm, which was worth £52m when it floated, fell 58% to 10.5p, valuing it at less than £7m.

Kazoo3D's software enables PC users to download 3D images of cartoon characters such as Rocky and Bullwinkle from the internet. They can insert the images into their photographs or stationery. Market research shows that the product has been well received by people who have tried it, but that the forecast mass take-up has not materialised.

"I guess it's ahead of its time," said one insider. In the six months to June 2000, before the launch of its website, Kazoo3D recorded losses of £2m and zero revenues. Of the £10m raised at flotation £6.9m remains in the bank. It may be returned to shareholders if a buyer cannot be found.

Adobe and Hewlett Packard, with whom Kazoo3D has partnership arrangements, are seen as possible white knights.

Kazoo3D's declining fortunes mirrors those of First Tuesday, which may itself be forced to close, after the sharp fall in the value of internet companies.

Members of the networking group are trying to buy the company back from Yazam, the Israeli investment firm which five months ago paid £33m for control but could now receive only £2m if a deal is reached.

webTitle: Scientists unravel genetic code of rice

fields.headline: Scientists unravel genetic code of rice
fields.standfirst:
Hunger charity concerned that diet of poorest will be preserve of big business

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Hunger charity concerned that diet of poorest will be preserve of big business.
fields.body:
The entire genetic code for the crop that feeds half the planet - rice - has been unravelled by the European agribusiness giant Syngenta and an American firm that patented two breast cancer genes, it was announced yesterday.

They finished the project two years ahead of a publicly-funded consortium of scientists in Japan, China, Korea, Europe and the US.

Rice is the first crop plant, and only the second plant of any kind, to be sequenced. This means that scientists now have the grain's entire 430m-letter DNA code to an accuracy of 99.5%. In that code could be up to 50,000 genes which will almost certainly hold the secrets of higher yields, better pest-resistance and richer nourishment for the 3bn for whom rice is a staple of survival. The researchers promised seeds with new properties in about five years.

The announcement triggered alarm from Action Aid, the hunger charity, which pointed out that there were already 229 patents on rice and that the diet of some of the world's poorest people should not become the preserve of big business. Nor should companies patent genes or DNA. Syngenta has its headquarters in Basle, Switzerland. It entered a $33m [£20m] deal with Myriad Genetics of Salt Lake City, Utah, to race through the genome of rice ahead of the international rice genome sequencing project led by Japan. Myriad Genetics triggered uproar among genetic researchers and cancer charities in the 1990s when it claimed patents on two genes linked with breast cancer, and developed diagnostic tests.

Genetic scientists have so far decoded the genomes of yeast, viruses, bacteria, a fruit fly, a nematode worm, a human being and a small weed related to the mustard family. An intimate understanding of how rice grows, flowers, sets seed and ripens will be of incalculable importance both to commercial growers and to subsistence farmers everywhere.

But what began as international co-operation to understand more about life's machinery turned into a series of races as big corporations began to scent huge profits in the "intellectual property" behind biotechnology. The international researchers began co-operating seven years ago. Syngenta and Myriad joined forces and finished the job in a year and a half, relying on new techniques, state-of-the-art computer power and the spur of huge potential rewards.

Syngenta said yesterday that it would sell data on the rice genome to seed businesses and other commercial groups, and make the information available to scientists "through research contracts". It also said it would provide information "without royalties or technology fees" to scientists helping subsistence farmers. Rice is grown in 100 countries but nine tenths of the world's crop is produced in Asia.

The two companies said that they would not attempt to patent the rice genome but they could patent particular uses of genes as they were identified.

"Understanding cereal genetic structure and associated proteins will enable plant breeders to produce crops that are more nutritious, more productive and easier to process," said David Evans, head of research at Syngenta. "We will also research new ways to protect crops from diseases or pests and discover new uses for crop plants..."

Humans have been growing rice for 5,000 years. A member of the grass family, it provides four-fifths of south-east Asia's calories, and research groups everywhere are working on ways of stepping up the crop's protein and vitamin content. One Swiss team, working with a US foundation, recently announced a genetically-modified strain enriched with vitamin A, which could reduce blindness among children in the developing world. New varieties developed in the so-called "green revolution" of the last 30 years have doubled world production. But demand is expected to increase by 70% over the next 30 years, as the population of the planet soars to 8bn or more.

Nor should companies patent genes or DNA. Syngenta has its headquarters in Basle, Switzerland. It entered a $33m [£20m] deal with Myriad Genetics of Salt Lake City, Utah, to race through the genome of rice ahead of the international rice genome sequencing project led by Japan. Myriad Genetics triggered uproar among genetic researchers and cancer charities in the 1990s when it claimed patents on two genes linked with breast cancer, and developed diagnostic tests. Genetic scientists have so far decoded the genomes of yeast, viruses, bacteria, a fruit fly, a nematode worm, a human being and a small weed related to the mustard family. An intimate understanding of how rice grows, flowers, sets seed and ripens will be of incalculable importance both to commercial growers and to subsistence farmers everywhere. But what began as international co-operation to understand more about life's machinery turned into a series of races as big corporations began to scent huge profits in the "intellectual property" behind biotechnology. The international researchers began co-operating seven years ago. Syngenta and Myriad joined forces and finished the job in a year and a half, relying on new techniques, state-of-the-art computer power and the spur of huge potential rewards. Syngenta said yesterday that it would sell data on the rice genome to seed businesses and other commercial groups, and make the information available to scientists "through research contracts". It also said it would provide information "without royalties or technology fees" to scientists helping subsistence farmers. Rice is grown in 100 countries but nine tenths of the world's crop is produced in Asia. The two companies said that they would not attempt to patent the rice genome but they could patent particular uses of genes as they were identified. "Understanding cereal genetic structure and associated proteins will enable plant breeders to produce crops that are more nutritious, more productive and easier to process," said David Evans, head of research at Syngenta. "We will also research new ways to protect crops from diseases or pests and discover new uses for crop plants..." Humans have been growing rice for 5,000 years. A member of the grass family, it provides four-fifths of south-east Asia's calories, and research groups everywhere are working on ways of stepping up the crop's protein and vitamin content. One Swiss team, working with a US foundation, recently announced a genetically-modified strain enriched with vitamin A, which could reduce blindness among children in the developing world. New varieties developed in the so-called "green revolution" of the last 30 years have doubled world production. But demand is expected to increase by 70% over the next 30 years, as the population of the planet soars to 8bn or more.

fields.headline: Gentlemen and players
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen (G2, January 24) shows antiquated knowledge of the recruitment policy of MI6. He claims "the procedures are clearly designed to weed out provincial oiks and favour bumptious chaps", preferring candidates from Oxford than Cambridge.
fields.body:
Francis Wheen (G2, January 24) shows antiquated knowledge of the recruitment policy of MI6. He claims "the procedures are clearly designed to weed out provincial oiks and favour bumptious chaps", preferring candidates from Oxford than Cambridge. The truth is, as even the KGB found out in the mid-70s, that the majority of candidates for the Foreign Office, MI6 and MI5 are recruited from the provincial universities. Each KGB agent was provided with a list of those universities in their attempts to acquire informers-to-be in their early age, like they did in the 30s, recruiting the notorious Cambridge Five.

Wheen calls the MI6 an "absurd circus". Meanwhile just gathering intelligence on the Falklands situation alone, MI6 is saving Britain many millions of pounds. But this example is merely a fraction of its achievements in other areas. MI6 appears as the most profitable department of the British government, returning the taxpayers' monies with great interest.
Oleg Gordievsky
London

When Whitehall manderins recommended that Jimmy Greaves's transfer from Milan to Tottenham should be treated as an invisible import (Report, January 26), did they by an chance use a Pentel (Pen mightier than the sword, January 26)? His name seems to have been eradicated from every honours list since.
John Hamlett
Manchester

webTitle: Letters: The subtext of free CDs

fields.headline: The subtext of free CDs
fields.trailText: I would like to echo my father's sentiments (Letters, January 25), for I too was enthralled by the free Fatboy Slim CD, despite being a generation younger (somewhat inevitably).
fields.body:
I would like to echo my father's sentiments (Letters, January 25), for I too was enthralled by the free Fatboy Slim CD, despite being a generation younger (somewhat inevitably). My drug of choice when listening to it was ibuprofen, and I had to take it off in the end for fear of over-excitement; I could so easily have put my back out again. For some reason the words, "What were they thinking, giving this to Guardian readers?" kept drifting into my mind.

One free CD and 10,000 teenagers would hurl away their condoms and MP3s, and be hooked for life on the unbridled joy that can be found by reading about political unrest in central Asia. Many of us grew up knowing that A was for Arucaria without any free gifts and stuck with the paper because it is witty, incisive, caring and human; as long as it remains so, it will find readers of all ages.

Perhaps the next time include samples from Peter Gabriel, Joyce Grenfell and Delius, to please everybody. Now that'd be worth putting my back out for.
Cathy Bryant
Manchester

I was pleased that the CD appealed to "mature readers". My two-year-old loved it. While he was dancing round the kitchen, I was actually able to read the paper for once.
Kevin Rush
Mountsorrel, Leics
kevin_rush@lineone.net

If readers in Germany are spared (Letters, January 26), so should the rest of us!
Graham Small
London

I was thrilled to receive the free disc. Tied to the raspberry canes in summer, it will make a perfect bird-scarer!
Mary Duthoit
Teignmouth, Devon

fields.headline: War Child replies again
fields.trailText: We write again in relation to further allegations (Charity returns £41,000, January 17).
fields.body:
We write again in relation to further allegations (Charity returns £41,000, January 17).

You state that War Child UK has refused to pay some £41,000 for over a year to the project for which the money was raised, but has now "agreed to hand it back" after protests. This is quite wrong.

War Child UK received this money only very recently, just before Christmas. It has been sent out in full to the Pavarotti Music Centre in the proper way. It was not held up at the charity (for a year). Once the cheque arrived, we sought guidance from the charity commission as to whether we could pass on funds without monitoring or accounting for them in the usual manner. War Child UK was anxious to properly implement the required procedures and operate wholly within the spirit and letter of the law. As soon as War Child UK received the charity commission's guidance the money was sent.

Nor has War Child UK ever said that it would not pay such money to the Pavarotti Music Centre. A simple call to our office would have established these facts.
Peter Smith, chair
Rosie Boycott, trustee
Nessa O'Neill, trustee
Gill Avis, trustee
Neil Morrissey, patron
Hugo Speer, patron
War Child UK

fields.headline: So much for never again
fields.trailText: I remember a radio programme in which Nazi concentration camp survivors recalled liberation (Memories aren't made of this, January 26).
fields.body:
I remember a radio programme in which Nazi concentration camp survivors recalled liberation (Memories aren't made of this, January 26). Among the aid parcels which arrived at one camp was a consignment of lipstick. Red Cross workers were baffled such frivolous items had been sent, but were amazed by the response. The day after, emaciated women could be seen all around the camp, infested with lice and clothed in rags, but proudly adorned with scarlet lips. This small item had made them feel human again.

This came into my mind at the check-out in Tesco. A young woman asylum seeker from Kosovo was being told she could not buy mascara with her vouchers. I was told a government list barred such "luxury" items. Other shoppers stared at the young woman with ill-concealed hostility. She may as well have been wearing a yellow star on her jacket. Perhaps one way this government can meaningfully commemorate the Holocaust is to scrap the degrading voucher system and restore some dignity to those who have fled victimisation.
Jenny Sutton
London

Michael Warburton (Letters, January 25) complains of the paucity of Holocaust Memorial Day events. A quick scan of the website shows 34 different events in 16 London boroughs. He also dismisses one event as "a gathering outside a pub in Soho". The pub was the Admiral Duncan where three people were murdered and 60 injured in an horrific nail bombing, part of series of attacks on London's minority communities. The ceremony on Thursday was attended by representatives from London's many diverse communities, including Trude Levi, a Holocaust survivor, and the three brothers of Nic Moore, one of those killed in the bombing. We remembered the victims of the Holocaust and read a statement of commitment affirming the resolve of Londoners to work together to challenge intolerance and bigotry.
Angela Mason
Stonewall

Holocaust Day should be to commemorate not only the horrors of genocide but the indifference or complicity which allowed them. Not the least telling example was the killing of 800,000 Tutsi in Rwanda in 1994. The UN, alerted by the commander of its mission in Rwanda that such genocide was planned, failed to take action, effectively encouraging the massacres.

The French and Belgian governments have held enquiries. The British government should now examine how and why the lessons it now urges on us were so deplorably still unlearned a mere seven years ago.
Ronald Segal
Walton-on-Thames, Surrey

Holocaust Day was an opportunity for British Armenians and Turks to enter into dialogue and start some sort of reconciliation process on the events 1915 (A question of cause and casualties, January 25). Such an initiative could have paved the way for normalisation in relations between Turkey and Armenia also. Instead the Foreign Office decided to support the intransigent Turkish government position which does not wish to examine the "disappearance" of the Armenians or enter into dialogue with the Republic of Armenia.
Andranik Ohanian
London

So from now on my birthday is to be heralded by images of genocide and horror. If lessons were truly learned, if "never again" did not carry the proviso "unless it's done by us", it would be right to observe this day. Until such a time, thanks a bunch.
Richard Ainslie
Holsworthy, Devon

webTitle: Leader: The Holocaust is part of our history too

fields.headline: In solemn recollection
fields.standfirst: The Holocaust is part of our history too
fields.trailText: Today, the first Holocaust Memorial Day will be marked with a national ceremony, exhibitions, local talks and educational programmes promoted by the government throughout the country. This is not just about remembrance of the victims of a terrible atrocity; what lies behind today's events is a hugely ambitious attempt to mould the country's political culture.
fields.body:
There is a compelling photograph included in the government's educational pack for Holocaust Memorial Day: it is a close up of the face of an elderly man as someone measures the width of his nose with a special instrument. It is the man's eyes which transfix: he is looking straight into the face of the human being subjecting him to this indignity with calm penetration. The photograph encapsulates that vicious strand in European culture which has stigmatised, persecuted and murdered whoever could be categorised as different. This Christian European tradition found perfect expression for its unquestioning superiority in its anti-semitism and in its racism. Science was harnessed in the 19th and 20th centuries to justify and legitimise this supremacy of white Europeans - hence the pseudo-science of measuring the man's nose. The warning is clear: the Holocaust was a unique historical event in a particular country, but the racism, anti-semitism and eugenics which motivated it were common to all Europe. More importantly, fragments of them all persist; even, in places, flourish.

It has taken many decades to achieve such clarity. For years after the second world war, the Holocaust was not discussed. That changed in the 80s, and now, the further from 1945 we get, the more the Holocaust is moving into the mainstream, with dedicated museums around the world and Hollywood box-office hits. The shift in Britain has been equally dramatic; in the immediate post-war period, the commonly held British view was that this was an event unique to German history with little relevance to the UK. Yet today, the first Holocaust Memorial Day (HMD), the event will be marked with a national ceremony, exhibitions, local talks and educational programmes promoted by the government throughout the country. This is not just about remembrance of the victims of a terrible atrocity; what lies behind today's events is a hugely ambitious attempt to mould the country's political culture.

This was made explicit at the conference in Stockholm last year which has led to several European countries fixing January 27 - the day Auschwitz-Birkenau was liberated - as Holocaust Memorial Day. They are using history for a contemporary political purpose: the message is that the spectrum of racism starts with individual tragedies, such as the murder of Stephen Lawrence, and ends in the horror of the Holocaust. The Chief Rabbi, Dr Jonathan Sacks, made exactly this point on the BBC Today programme yesterday. The intention is to use the shock provoked by this unique historical event to inculcate the virtues of tolerance and individual responsibility into political consciousness.

The reason why this is happening now is that globalisation has created an acute need for both. Firstly, the increasing movements of populations around the world underline the importance of tolerance: just this week it was reported that the biggest source of British population growth now is immigration, and last year the UK absorbed the highest number of asylum seekers ever - 76,000. This is a Europe-wide phenomenon, and many governments are having to consider how to assimilate these populations and promote racial harmony. HMD is one strategy, heavily weighted with emotion and idealism, to facilitate this increasingly multicultural Europe.

Secondly, throughout the educational and promotional material the responsibility of the individual is stressed. This is an attempt to challenge the "walk-by culture" which Jack Straw blamed for the fate of Damilola Taylor. Globalisation by its scale reduces our sense of agency and induces apathy: "there's nothing I can do" is the common refrain. Combating this resignation and insisting on the individual's responsibilities has always been central to New Labour philosophy; it spans the local, in Peckham, through to the global and to Tony Blair's insistence on our international responsibilities in Kosovo or Sierra Leone.

Any project as heavily loaded with ambition and idealism as this one is inevitably riddled with contradictions. Most noticeably, the admirable promotion of racial tolerance rings hollow given this government's asylum policy; vouchers, dispersal, putting asylum seekers in prison are all contributing to stigmatise migrants and put obstacles in the way of their absorption into Britain. There are also intractable issues. What abuse of human rights should or should not be included: Armenia? Cambodia? Rwanda? Does it belittle the unique scale of the Holocaust to put it alongside Bosnia? In the end, such questions will be subordinated to the day's political purpose; hence Bosnia is included to spell out a recent experience of ethnic persecution.

This day will serve the purpose of public remembrance and reaffirmation of ideals, much like Remembrance Day. But will it be a remote, establishment event or have the popular resonance necessary to shift political consciousness? That depends precariously on the strength of the links between the Lawrence case and the Holocaust: on how and whether people connect everyday experiences of racist prejudice with the horror of Nazi policies to exterminate an entire race. The historian Peter Novick's shrewd assessment is this: "If there are, in fact, lessons to be learnt from history, the Holocaust would seem an unlikely source... because of its extremity. Lessons for dealing with the sorts of issues that confront us in ordinary life, public and private, are not likely to be found in this most extraordinary of events." Admirable though its purpose and the intentions of its creators may be, this innovation's chance of lasting success remains uncertain.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Sir Edward Heath has asked us to point out that, contrary to the impression which may have been given in a report headed, Hinduja passport inquiry ordered, page 1, January 25, he acted as a referee only for Gopichand Hinduja and not for Strichand Hinduja.
fields.body:
Sir Edward Heath has asked us to point out that, contrary to the impression which may have been given in a report headed, Hinduja passport inquiry ordered, page 1, January 25, he acted as a referee only for Gopichand Hinduja and not for Strichand Hinduja.

In a column, The news in numbers, page 4, The Editor, yesterday, we suggested that the Hatfield train was exceeding the speed limit by 100mph when it crashed. As we said in our own report of the inquiry (January 24) no speed limit had been imposed. We reported that Railtrack had conceded that had a speed restriction of 20mph been in force a fatal accident would have been avoided.

In an article about recycling, page 2, Jobs & Money, January 3, we said that wine drinkers who put their empties into a bottle bank were wasting their time and that the glass was used for landfill. British Glass public affairs committee says this is not the case. In the 12 months to the end of September last year, 300,000 tonnes of green glass were collected for recycling, most of which was used to make new bottles and jars containing up to 85% recycled glass.

There was a mistake in the first table that accompanied our article on teacher shortages, Heads will roll, pages 8 and 9, Education, January 23. The table purported to show the age distribution of London's teachers. Each age group was divided into short- and long-term teachers (based on a survey of teachers' intentions). Somehow the "long-term" and "short-term" teachers were exchanged, making it look as though there were a lot of young long-term teachers, and a good many older short-term teachers, whereas in fact the reverse is true.

Keith Vaz was not "Britain's first ethnic Asian minister", as he was described on page 1 yesterday. Baron Sinha of Raipur was, in 1919, as an under secretary at the India Office.

 It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Fax 020-7239 9897.

fields.headline: Rumours rock Allied Domecq
fields.trailText: It will only be four lines long but Allied Domecq's trading update, due to appear with Monday's AGM statement, caused all sorts of consternation in the market yesterday.
fields.body:
It will only be four lines long but Allied Domecq's trading update, due to appear with Monday's AGM statement, caused all sorts of consternation in the market yesterday.

The hot rumour was that the update would reveal trading had fallen below market expectations in the first five months of the present fiscal year.

With a share price that outperformed the market by 50% in 2000, anything negative in the statement could spark something dramatic. Some are suggesting the shares could fall all the way back to 350p.

Add to that the recent reports filtering back from north America about disappointing Christmas sales and the mix becomes dangerous.

A combination of bad weather and falling consumer confidence meant Americans were buying fewer Allied products - which range from Ballantine's whiskey to Sauza tequila. More than half of Allied's profits came from north America last year, so a bad Christmas could prove devastating.

Analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Wassertein do not believe the reports, and were yesterday advising their clients to pick up as many Allied shares as they could. Nonetheless, Allied shares ended the day some 12p lower at 402p.

Elsewhere, leading shares were bucking the global trend.

In a break from the usual routine, blue chip shares brushed aside a weak start to trading in New York and moved higher. Senior traders attributed the move to another big switch - out of technology stocks after disappointing figures from Ericsson and into safe havens like pharmaceuticals and oils.

With investors warehousing cash in the likes of GlaxoSmithKline, 63p better at £18.39p, AstraZeneca, 18p higher at £30.50p, and Shell, 6p stronger at 560.5p, the FTSE 100 closed the session up 38.7 points at 6,294.3. Other strong blue chip performers included International Power, up 12p to 260.25p, tobacco outfit BAT, 20.25p higher to 481p, and gas pipeline company Lattice, which rose 7p to end the day at 140p.

It was a rather different story for the FTSE Techmark 100, which ended 36.21 points weaker at 2,780.26, unsettled by the Ericsson figures and mounting losses at Bookham Technology, down 207p at £11.

ARM Holdings, off 26.5p to 533p, Autonomy, down 140p to £21.40, and Misys, 19.5p lower at 639.5p, were among the worst affected.

Pace Micro slipped 79.5p to 610p after being hit by reports that the company had lost its exclusive deal to provide Telewest, down 3p to 141p, with set-top boxes.

Lower down the corporate ladder, another bout of speculation was swirling around Mayflower, the truck body maker which boasts former prime minister John Major as a director. A couple of months ago, the stock had a good run on the back of a stake building exercise by a mysterious private investor named John Harvey.

At the time nobody could work out what Mr Harvey's real intentions were.

Was he a value investor or a corporate raider? Well, the gossips reckon Mr Harvey has lined up a corporate buyer for his 6.29% stake, who intends to use the holding as a platform to launch a bid and Mayflower shares ended 11p higher at 95.5p.

Another takeover story that sprang back to life was Scottish Radio Holdings, down 20p to £17.05, following news that DC Thomson, publisher of the Beano and Dandy comics, has increased its stake to almost 9.6%.

Punters were again having a nibble at Navan Mining, 1p better at 115.5p, following reports that it is likely to confirm an important gold find in Bulgaria within the next few weeks.

webTitle: Mandela rages at Tomlinson's claim of MI6 link

fields.headline: Mandela rages at Tomlinson's claim of MI6 link
fields.standfirst: African leader says claims made in renegade officer's book are racist and challenges anyone to produce evidence to substantiate them
fields.trailText: African leader says claims made in renegade officer's book are racist and challenges anyone to produce evidence to substantiate them.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor, Ian Traynor  and  Anthony Sampson
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela last night dismissed allegations that he had a longstanding relationship with MI6 as slanderous and a "disgraceful fabrication".

The allegations are contained in The Big Breach, a book by the MI6 renegade officer, Richard Tomlinson, published in Russia.

There are undoubtedly "conservative elements" in Britain who think "only whites, not blacks, should enjoy international recognition and respect", he told the Guardian.

Those elements, he said, were "deeply uncomfortable with the idea of a black person being hailed as one of the outstanding figures of our time. In order to undermine or destroy that image, they are prepared to resort to slander without any facts to substantiate it."

He said the allegation in the book that he had spent a day in Kent in 1990 having secret discussions with MI6 was a "disgraceful fabrication".

He continued: "If we had such relations with British or any other intelligence agencies there should somewhere be some evidence of the contract or of payments made." The fabrications, Mr Mandela added, "should be dismissed with the contempt they deserve".

Mr Tomlinson claims the South African nationalist leader had a "longstanding" relationship with MI6 and that the agency uncovered a white supremacist plot by the AWB, or Afrikaaner Weerstandsbeweging, to assassinate him in 1993.

He alleges that Mr Mandela paid a visit to Britain three years earlier for secret talks with MI6. Mr Mandela did visit England in June 1990 after a tour of European capitals which had included a grand reception by the then French president, François Mitterrand, in Paris.

He stayed for two days in a house in Kent, arranged by the British government.

His purpose was not to talk to MI6 but to see Oliver Tambo, then president of the ANC, and his wife Adelaide, and to rest before travelling to the US.

Late in the evening of June 16 he wanted to talk to the then prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, and made contact with a private secretary. She had a friendly conversation with Mr Mandela for half an hour on the phone early next morning, when she warned him about his hectic timetable.

"If you keep this up, you will not come out of America alive," she told him. A senior official who was in Downing Street at the time says no intelligence report was received after the visit.

In a separate passage of his book, Mr Tomlinson also alleges that MI6 officers orchestrated a smear campaign against the Egyptian diplomat and politician, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, in an futile effort to sink his chances of becoming the United Nations secretary-general in 1992.

The MI6 campaign, which entailed planting stories in the media reflecting unfavourably on the Egyptian, was carried out at the request of the CIA - requests that Britain's Secret Intelligence Service is always eager to satisfy, the renegade spy alleges.

Mr Boutros-Ghali got the top job at the UN, but US and British opposition to the UN chief helped to torpedo his at tempt to secure a second term and left him embittered at his treatment.

The MI6 operation was handled by the Information Operations section, MI6's spin doctors, says Mr Tomlinson.

"The CIA is constitutionally prevented from manipulating the press, so it asked MI6 to help. Using its contacts in the British and American media, I/OPS planted a series of stories to portray Boutros-Ghali as unbalanced, claiming he was a believer in the existence of UFOs and extraterrestrial life."

The allegations of MI6 servility to the Americans and its hostility towards and espionage against Britain's European Union partners run all through Mr Tomlinson's bitter, self-aggrandising book.

Soon after joining MI6 in 1991, Mr Tomlinson says, the then chief, Sir Colin McColl, told the new recruits: "Our relationship with the Americans will always be more important than that with the various European intelligence services."

The MI6 chief is also quoted as saying: "The relationship between the CIA and MI6 is central to the special relationship between our countries.

"Our greatest allies will continue to be our American cousins."

Mr Tomlinson writes that the CIA exploited its British counterpart as its "Euro-mole".

webTitle: Bush fails to show at Davos conference

fields.headline: The South rises as Bush fails to show
fields.standfirst:
Behind the cordon, a confession. Globalisation is not delivering

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Behind the cordon, a confession. Globalisation is not delivering.
fields.body:
It was like Hamlet without the Prince in Davos yesterday. Everything else was in place for the great annual celebration of the global economy - snow, tight security around the brutalist conference centre, sessions on the next internet revolution - but there were no Americans.

Or rather there were none of the Americans that people wanted to see, the men and women who will be running the world's biggest economy under the new president. If last year's Davos was dominated by the three Ws as faith in the money-making capacity of the world wide web, this year the focus was on one W - the W in George W Bush.

The absence of the new movers and shakers in Washington was only to be expected after the protracted wrangling over the election meant a shorter-than-usual transition. Bush's cabinet and his policy wonks are not yet ready for a few days schmoozing in the Swiss Alps. But it gave the first full day of proceedings an unreal feel. As one participant said: "It's all a bit flat. How can you talk about globalisation without the globalisers?"

In previous years Davos has been turned into a orgy of American self-congratulation as the performance of the US economy and the pioneering role of Silicon Valley has allowed the Clinton administration to lecture the rest of the world on the benefits of the unfettered Anglo-Saxon model. Clinton himself was in town last year; his treasury secretary, Larry Summers, was an ever-present.

This year it has been different for two reasons. First, the US economy has run into its first serious trouble for a decade, which has meant that those Americans who have turned up have had some explaining to do. Second, participants at Davos have been unable to ignore the fact that 10 years after the collapse of communism ushered in globalisation's year zero, old problems such as inequality, remain unsolved, while new problems, such as the spread of HIV/Aids and the threat to the environment, have emerged.

As such, it was inevitable that some different voices would have been heard this year, even had the Bush team turned up in force. Had the anti-globalistion protesters been able to break through the security cordon set up by the Swiss authorities after Seattle and Prague, they would have found the opening session given over to voices of the south, not the north. It began with a film so right-on it could have been made by any committed NGO (with a big enough budget) in which scenes of technological breakthroughs in the West were juxtaposed with starving children and human rights abuses in the developing world.

The protesters would have liked the blunt acknowledgement by Claus Smadja, managing director of the World Economic Forum, that "globalisation is not delivering the goods and cannot be dictated by the priorities and concerns of only one part of the world."

Finally, it was the turn of Benjamin Mkapa, president of Tanzania, one of the world's poorest countries. Obviously sick of hearing the platitude that globalisation was good for everybody, Mr Mkapa said: "Globalisation can deliver, just as Tanzania can play in the world cup and win it."

John Sweeney, the American trade union leader, made similar heretical comments a few years ago to stony silence. Mkapa was cheered, though there were no protesters in sight. To the chagrin of locals, Davos has been turned into an armed camp, with road blocks on the streets and all trains cancelled.

Despite the security, the message seems to be getting through. Globalisation is not a homogeneous take-it-or-leave-it product. The American way is not the only way. And while Hamlet without the prince is not much of a play, Shakespeare wrote plenty of others.

webTitle: EU to investigate high CD prices

fields.headline: EU to investigate high CD prices
fields.trailText: Fears that the world's big five record companies operate an illegal cartel to keep compact disc prices artificially high have prompted the European commission to investigate, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Fears that the world's big five record companies operate an illegal cartel to keep compact disc prices artificially high have prompted the European commission to investigate, it emerged yesterday.

Although Brussels admits that it has so far failed to find firm evidence that Europeans are paying far too much for their CDs, it strongly believes that there is more than enough circumstantial evidence to warrant a full inquiry.

The five music labels under suspicion are Britain's EMI Group, Germany's Bertelsmann, Warner Music, Sony Corp and Universal together with five online retailers and 13 traditional retailers.

The commission is particularly interested to find out why there are such wide disparities in CD prices within Europe and why music costs so much more to buy in Europe than it does in the US. It also wants to know why a CD costs almost a third more than a cassette for exactly the same content.

A UK Consumers' Association survey looked at the Britney Spears' best-selling album, Oops, I did it Again, which cost an average of £10.77 in US music stores compared to £12.08 in the EU. In Italy the same album costs and average of £14.16 while in London it costs £12.26.

The commission has sent out letters of inquiry to all of the firms under suspicion. but it will be months before it reaches a conclusion at which point it will either decide to drop the case or issue a formal warning to the big five and step up its inquiries. Any investigation could last up to two years.

"If we find evidence to support these claims we could fine the companies concerned a maximum of 10% of their annual turnover and force them to change their ways," said a commission official, who stressed that the investigation was still at a very early stage.

The issue caught Brussels' eye last year when it vetted a massive merger between EMI and Warner Music which it subsequently rejected on the grounds that it would harm competition.

It was also encouraged by a similar investigation in the US which concluded that American consumers had paid £320m over the odds for their CDs since 1997.

The US authorities discovered that the big five music firms had been setting minimum retail prices for CDs for at least five years and encouraging retailers to fall into line by funding chunks of their advertising budgets.

The big five agreed to stop fixing minimum prices in May of last year and the US authorities told Brussels that there might be a problem in Europe too.

The commission has not received any formal complaints about CD prices but argues that it has the power to initiate its own investigation since consumer groups in Europe, have voiced serious concerns.

The music industry is already fighting a rearguard action from internet sites offering free music downloads.

If Brussels did find evidence that the big five are colluding on prices it would be far less likely to authorise big industry mergers in the future.

webTitle: Supermarket giants pave the way for 'GM-free' Britain

fields.headline: Supermarket giants pave the way for 'GM-free' Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Britain moved significantly closer to becoming GM-free yesterday after supermarket chains Tesco and Asda announced they would no longer sell the meat or milk of any animal fed with genetically modified soya or maize.
fields.body:
Britain moved significantly closer to becoming GM-free yesterday after supermarket chains Tesco and Asda announced they would no longer sell the meat or milk of any animal fed with genetically modified soya or maize.

The two companies, who between them control 42% of the grocery market and import more than 1m tons a year of GM animal feed, will switch their imports from the US to Brazil where commercial GM plantings are illegal.

"It is the beginning of the end of GM in Britain," said Greenpeace yesterday. Other retailers were sure to follow, it added. "Widespread rejection of GM animal feed will spell disaster for US importers who supply the bulk of the GM soya and maize to the UK."

US soya exports to Europe have already fallen from 9.85m to 6.75m tonnes between 1995 -1999, following concern about GM crops. Brazilian soya exports to the EU have risen from 2.99m tonnes in 1996 to 6.87m in 1999.

The first stage of the Asda phase-out of GM-fed products covers fish, poultry and eggs by the summer and pork by the autumn. Tesco plans to do the same by the summer.

Iceland, Marks & Spencer, McDonald's and Burger King have already acted to remove GM in animal products. The only major supermarket which has not yet made a commitment to phase out GM-fed animal products is Somerfield.

fields.headline: The subject of success
fields.standfirst: Business studies is popular at school, while its teaching at degree and masters level ranks with the best in the world. Eileen Sheridan reports
fields.trailText: Business studies is popular at school, while its teaching at degree and masters level ranks with the best in the world. Eileen Sheridan reports.
fields.body:
As the business of learning about business grows even faster than dot.com shares used to do, there are more and more options available to students who see their path to success through a specialist course.

Business and management studies are still streets ahead of all other subjects in popularity among A level students looking for a degree subject - 11.5% of the student population are in the throes of their first business studies degree.

And the number of school students taking A levels in business studies is still rising - this year saw 38,226 of them take those exams.

This year's students will be able to see what colleges have to offer them at the Guardian sponsored Get into Business Fair, organised by UCAS and the Association of Business Schools and held at the Business Design Centre in Islington on January 29 and 30. There will be 32 colleges exhibiting.

One thing that UK business schools can pat themselves on the back for is the quality of the teaching they offer. A recent worldwide survey put eight British business schools in the top 50, while mainland Europe could only produce eight top-flight performers.

"Our schools have a world class reputation for the wide-ranging qualifications and executive development programmes they offer students," says Jonathan Slack, chief executive of the Association of Business Schools.
