webTitle: Jobs and Money: From the top

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Carole Pemberton: What a difference a year makes. A year ago a cliché of human resource-speak, "winning the war for talent", meant: How can blue chips compete with the sex appeal of dot.coms in attracting young talent?
fields.body:
What a difference a year makes. A year ago a cliché of human resource-speak, "winning the war for talent", meant: How can blue chips compete with the sex appeal of dot.coms in attracting young talent? Small start-ups with informality, lack of structures and few perks, were winning out in the recruitment market.

A year on and the failure of high-profile dot.commers is leading to a shake-out of talent back into the marketplace. US figures from NY outplacement firm Challenger Gray & Christmas show that month-on-month the number of employers losing dot.com jobs is rising, and the appeal of the market is waning.

However, to dismiss the intensity of the dot.com hothouse period as a blip before MBAs make their way back into FTSE 100s and management consultancies is to underestimate what recruits were looking to gain in joining a start-up.

Recruiters have long known that in attracting talent the employer brand is a key ingredient. For many years, annual league tables of the most attractive employers for graduates were headed by Marks & Spencer. Job security, variety within a strong structure, early responsibility and association with seemingly unchallengable success made for a heady combination.

The brand is devalued by poor performance and a loss of confidence that forces it to admit other brand names on to the shop floor. Even were market share to recover, it is unlikely that a graduate traineeship would have the same cachet. The recruitment market has changed the deal it now expects.

A global study of the expectations of 1,000 young high-flyers, conducted by Whiteway Research, concluded that the relationship between the talented and their employers is now one based on attraction, retention and separation. The brand relationship remains important as an attractor, and the components are both rational and emotional. Emotional in terms of the reputation the organisation has within the home country and the potential for business growth.

Emotional also in that the culture should offer inspiring role models and an environment which is open and non-hierarchical. Rational in that the offer should be one that signals challenge, the opportunity for international experience and development.

The employer relationship is no longer one of offering time and abilities in exchange for faster progress than one's peers. It is a bartering of skills in exchange for continuous waves of development. A huge learning curve which peters out once graduate training ends; a view that the organisation's business potential will reduce over time and a belief that cutting-edge assignments will not come their way are all reasons for leaving. An employer who recognises transition points between one development wave and the next, and can help the individual "surf" through it, will re-invigorate the relationship.

Underpinning the relationship is the assumption that it will come to an end. A good employer is one who enables individuals to leave feeling they are valuable alumni. There is as much to be gained from branding the existing process as the entry.

The speed with which dot.commers have risen and fallen tells a lot about the emotional susceptibility of markets. Those who committed to start-ups saw them as encapsulating the deal which high-flyers are seeking. A dot.commer who comes inside to support the e-commerce ambitions of an established player will expect that same deal.

 Carole Pemberton is managing consultant, Career Matters.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Richard Martin, chief executive of Adecco, the world's largest recruitment agency
fields.trailText: Richard Martin, chief executive of Adecco, the world's largest recruitment agency.
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

At the age of 16, when I managed a coffee bar called Under the Olive Tree in Croydon.

What has been your best moment in management?

Becoming MD of motor dealership Lex Mead. We brought a number of Austin Rover dealers under one brand and became the country's leading operation.

What was your greatest mistake?

Giving up first-class rugby to concentrate on my career.

How would you describe your management style?

Open, intuitive and trusting.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Sir John Egan's £1.5bn sale of Jaguar to Ford.

What do you find most annoying in your people?

When people abuse the trust I have placed in them.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

As 50% of my senior management team are female, I don't think that it is an issue.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

That your employees will be honest with you. You are often told what people think you want to hear.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Don't take yourself too seriously.

Which management guru do you believe in?

None of them.

Who is your management hero?

Norman Petty, who plucked Charles Holley from obscurity in Lubbock, Texas to create one of the world's greatest artists in Buddy Holly.

Who is your favourite politician?

President Mitterrand; worked hard and achieved a lot for the EU and France but never sacrificed personal life to his work.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

I would persuade people of the myopic view of short-termism.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

Chance favours the well-prepared.

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Spending time in the kitchen cooking for friends.

What annoys you most?

Surly British Airways stewardesses who do a great job of spoiling an excellent airline.

How do you relax?

Walking my collie cross and cocker spaniel with my wife.

What was your last cultural experience?

Robbie Williams at the London Arena .

What is your favourite city?

Sydney, Sydney or Sydney.

Do you have a favourite web site?

Amazon.com.

What is your greatest regret?

Not having worked abroad at a younger age than I did.

What is your biggest fear?

Running out of time before I have done everything I want to.

What would you really like to have been?

Maybe a game warden.

fields.headline: Learning to get the human factor right
fields.standfirst: The net revolution has sent manpower planning to the top of the financial services providers' agendas. Amin Rajan and Gary Storer report
fields.trailText: The net revolution has sent manpower planning to the top of the financial services providers' agendas. Amin Rajan and Gary Storer report.
fields.body:
Due to deregulation and globalisation the UK's fastest job creating industries - banking, insurance, fund management, stockbroking, accountancy, law and software services - have experienced more change in the last 10 years than in the previous 40. Customers now have almost limitless choice, as do shareholders, and both want more for less.

As a result, individual service institutions are seeking to gain an edge by revamping their business models. This has had a notable knock-on effect on the way they deal with their staff, according to a new study commissioned jointly by K Learning, KPMG's financial services learning practice, and the London Human Resource Group, a network of 17 leading financial institutions in the City of London.

"The internet has given customers an instant access to the total marketplace," says Chris Evans, human resources director of insurer Royal & Sun Alliance. "This has far-reaching implications for the way we manage, develop and deploy our people. Manpower planning is at the top of the agenda."

As an integral part of that process, the human resources organisation is being changed in two respects. Job demarcations are being redefined and HR professionals are increasingly getting involved in areas that impact on business results. These include performance management, quality orientation and executive coaching. And line managers are increasingly getting involved in activities like recruitment, training, and succession planning. A new, overarching role of HR-business partner is created to provide boardroom level business solutions.

On the coalface the range of channels used to provide services to employees is extended to include self-service tools based on corporate intranets and specialist centres providing solutions in areas such as employment law and culture change. One in five institutions has already altered demarcations and roles with many more expecting to do so over the next three years. John Matheson, head of personnel at the Bank of England, says: "We need to have an effective HR function which provides numerous self-service tools to line managers and staff alike. We are starting this mechanism by building a corporate intranet."

First and foremost, these and other changes underline the point that strategic HR is now about building the capability to cope with changing goalposts in the market place. "Our explosive growth has hugely increased the diversity of our businesses," says Mike Williams, director of HR at Cisco Sys tems. "To cater for it we're putting together the best expertise and delivery channels that help us stay ahead of the curve."

"The biggest challenge is how its HR managers become effective change agents in their new partnership role," says Geoff Morgan, HR director at insurance market Lloyd's of London.

"The question is all the more pertinent because we are seeing a growing convergence between two distinct disciplines: human resource management and organisation development," adds Norman Mitchinson, group HR director at Lloyds TSB. This convergence requires HR professionals and their line counterparts to widen and deepen their existing skills base. No longer is it sufficient to have on-the-job training backed by classroom learning. "For both groups, their understanding of the 'big picture' has so far been fairly limited, as is their ability to inspire trust and motivation for the essential change," says Michael Robinson, head of HR at fund management firm Invesco.

What is needed now are new avenues of learning like coaching, mentoring, and e-learning. To meet this need, institutions are increasingly outsourcing their training provision to providers experienced in managing projects on business transformation. This is used to raise the ability of HR professionals and line managers in managing culture change.

Financial services institutions are bringing in external experts to trigger internal learning. Their training budgets increased by nearly a quarter between 1995 and 2000, with the biggest increase occurring in banking, insurance, fund management and software services.

So overwhelming is the need to jettison the old culture that in many companies the new roles have been implemented despite long pay-back periods.This has not been easy. In many companies, HR professionals have viewed the changes as devaluing their craft and line managers see them as overloading their jobs. However, the study concludes that the opposition is the birth-pangs of a new model at the workplace which rules out a return to old ways.

 Professor Amin Rajan is chief executive of the Centre for Reserach in Employment and Technology in Europe (Create) and Gary Storer is lead consultant with K Learning (KPMG). Tomorrow's Organisation; New Mindsets, New Skills from Create, £49:50 (inc. p&p), tel: 01892 526757.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Britain's first space centre

fields.headline: Her route to the stars
fields.standfirst: A childhood passion for astronomy has led Alex Barnett to boldly take charge of Britain's first space centre, based in Leicester. Martyn Seal talked to her
fields.trailText: A childhood passion for astronomy has led Alex Barnett to boldly take charge of Britain's first space centre, based in Leicester. Martyn Seal talked to her.
fields.body:
As we're regularly reminded by Star Trek re-runs, space is the final frontier. But from this spring Leicester could be the spot to mark on your star chart as the place to boldly go as Britain's first space centre opens its doors to visitors.

Alex Barnett has been the creative director behind the building and designing of the operation. It's a job for which she had a vision ever since the idea was first put together. "I've been able to walk into the space centre in my mind from the start," she says. "I've known what it would look like, what the public will experience and so being here and actually able to deliver it is great."

She's a former student of Leicester University graduating in astrophysics, a subject she has been passionate about since childhood. "I've been keenly interested in the night sky since about the age of seven," she recalls. "I used to ask constant questions which my parents got fed up with so they bought me the Ladybird book of the Night Sky. I became totally hooked and discovered that I was very good at communicating the subject."

She swiftly proves this by explaining what astrophysics means. "It's the physics of how everything in the universe works. How stars are born, how they live and die and how galaxies are formed. It's a subject that asks how did we get here in the first place and whether there is anyone else out there."

With this passion for communicating her subject she decided that media was the right career choice after leaving university and found a job as a researcher at the BBC. It seemed the perfect area to build a career but she found not having direct contact with an audience frustrating.

"You can put your heart and soul into getting something on to the screen for your audience, but you never get to see the whites of their eyes," she explains. "You don't know if you've made a difference. When I'm giving a talk or if I'm out under the stars with a group I can see whether they understand. It makes the whole thing far more exciting and personal."

It was this realisation that turned out to be her big break. She left the BBC after she applied for a director's internship at a planetarium in Florida and got the job. "I went over there for a year. It was fabulous." When she came back she started her own business, a consultancy called Science to Go.

"I came back from the States and started bits of consultancy work for new projects, of which one was Leicester space centre. It effectively led to me into setting up my own business in science communication. I did that until it got to the stage where I was working at least five days a week for the space centre and the taxman said 'I don't think you're self-employed anymore.' " She became full-time creative director in 1998.

So what is the relevance to the UK of having a space centre? Ms Barnett explains that the UK has for too long thought that space exploration was something for the Americans or Russians. She's keen to point out British involvement.

"The UK has been actively involved in space for many years. We're particularly good at scientific satellites. Most people simply don't know about this country's involvement because we don't have a manned space programme. If we were putting people up there it would be far more prominent."

The space centre will be Britain's first visitor centre to deal comprehensively with all aspects of the universe and voyages into space. So immersed in the project is Ms Barnet she can give a detailed verbal run-through. "The building is incredible, a tower structure you tend to stare at and wonder how on earth was it built. You walk through the front doors and the first thing that greets you is a Russian Soyuz space craft. There are constant programmes in the space theatre, one of which takes you on a journey to the other side of the universe. You can also explore an area dealing with the universe and, of course the big question... is there anybody out there?"

And what is her view on whether we're being visited by little green men? "The distances involved are so vast that we don't know of a way of doing it on a reasonable time scale," she says sceptically. "It would take hundreds of thousands of years travelling as fast as we are able to reach the nearest star. So unless there is some cunning trick we don't know about, it's highly unlikely."

You walk through the front doors and the first thing that greets you is a Russian Soyuz space craft. There are constant programmes in the space theatre, one of which takes you on a journey to the other side of the universe. You can also explore an area dealing with the universe and, of course the big question... is there anybody out there?" And what is her view on whether we're being visited by little green men? "The distances involved are so vast that we don't know of a way of doing it on a reasonable time scale," she says sceptically. "It would take hundreds of thousands of years travelling as fast as we are able to reach the nearest star. So unless there is some cunning trick we don't know about, it's highly unlikely."

fields.headline: Adding to the damage done
fields.standfirst: Provident's defence of a claim brought by a boy hurt in a road accident blames his parents. Richard Colbey is sceptical
fields.trailText: Provident's defence of a claim brought by a boy hurt in a road accident blames his parents. Richard Colbey is sceptical.
fields.body:
Provident Insurance is running a novel argument in defending a claim brought by brain-damaged boy Darren Coombs against an allegedly careless driver who knocked him off his bike. Provident claims that even if its insured driver were to blame, Darren's parents and Valerie Cole, a family friend who was looking after him that day, are partly responsible, and should contribute towards the damages.

Provident says that it was negligent to allow Darren, from the Isle of Wight, who was nine at the time of the accident, to cycle alone and without a helmet. His parents, however, say that it was a quiet road, most children of that age are allowed out alone, and few cyclists actually do wear helmets.

Everybody involved in the case appears to believe that if Provident succeeds it will turn the law of personal injury "upside down". Although unprecedented in England, a similar argument has been tried - unsuccessfully - in Canada, by an insurance company.

A four-year-old Toronto girl, Diane Teno, interrupted her mother who was on the telephone, asking for money to go out and buy an ice cream from a van parked opposite her house. Having bought it, she walked back into the road and was struck by a passing car. She sued the ice cream seller and the car driver and both were held to be at fault for the accident. The Ontario supreme court rejected the argument that the mother was also liable. It accepted her claims that she had taught Diane about road safety and that she could not be blamed for her daughter's momentary lapse.

The insurance company in Diane's case might seem to have a more promising position than Provident. Far more parents would allow a nine-year-old to cycle alone than a four-year-old to cross a road.

Even if Provident does persist with the argument, it will not actually save itself any money. It will still have to pay Darren damages, which could well exceed £1m. If his parents or Ms Cole were at fault they could be required to contribute a proportion back to the insurers.

As they do not have significant amounts of money, all Provident could do is accept a small amount of money per month or bankrupt them. Either course will cost it more in administrative and legal expenses than it would gain. There would be no question of reimbursement coming out of Darren's compensation.

While Provident might be hoping to set a precedent that will benefit the insurance industry as a whole, one would have expected it to do so in a case where the facts clearly did suggest parental negligence. In practice, however, the only parents likely to be able to contribute towards massive damages are those who are insured against the risk of liability for negligence, perhaps as part of their household policies. That is of little help to the insurance industry. The only people who gain from legal actions, which effectively pit one insurer against another, are the lawyers involved.

Provident's bullish original position on the case has been watered down somewhat. It is now merely saying: "We have the option of taking an action against the parents." Its lawyers have probably pointed out the realities of the position, and that action will be quietly shelved in the next few weeks.

Of course, any argument which encourages parents to take more care for their children's safety is to be welcomed, and perhaps the publicity this case has generated so far will, in a few cases, do just that. A charitable view might be that Provident has taken this seemingly bizarre stance for that reason, rather than because it intends seriously pursuing it much further.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: NTL cuts phone rates

fields.headline: Price rise is kick in the teeth
fields.standfirst: NTL is hiking the basic cost of its phone and internet package by up to 50%. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: NTL is hiking the basic cost of its phone and internet package by up to 50%. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
NTL, the cable company best-known for its involvement with premiership football, risks scoring an own goal this week with a 50% price rise in the basic cost of its combined telephone and internet service, ntlworld.

The company was besieged by hundreds of thousands of would-be subscribers in spring and summer last year after it launched a completely free internet service. All users had to do was to switch their telephone account to NTL, where their call charges would be just 3p a minute weekdays, falling to 1p a minute at weekends.

You didn't even have to be in an NTL cable area - ntl sent small boxes to fit to BT lines, costing £10, which switched all calls through ntl instead of BT. The only catch was a £10 per month minimum spend on calls, and that non-cable users would have to continue to pay BT's line rental charges of £27.77 per month.

For many heavy net users, labouring under hefty BT net charges, the deal seemed too good to be true. More than half a million people applied for the service, resulting in long waits for the pc discs required to set up ntlworld.

But in another indicator that the era of free net access may be short-lived, ntl will this week raise the minimum monthly spend on its service by 50% from £10 to £15 for the 75,000 customers who access the service through their former BT phones.

In an email sent to users last week, the company said: "Unfortunately our costs have increased over the past year and so we will be increasing the minimum monthly spend on non-internet calls. The new minimum spend takes effect from February 1, 2001."

Were customers lured into subscribing only to see their bills jacked up once they had quit BT? NTL insists that despite the charge increase, its prices remain highly competitive, and cheaper than BT.

"The fact is that, yes, we have put charges up, but we have given proper notice and £15 a month for net and phone is still very competitive," says NTL spokeswoman Jacqueline Aldridge. How did NTL get its cost projections so wrong? "We underestimated the amount of internet usage by customers. There was no model of free, unlimited access in the UK. People used it far more than we expected, which is why we had to ration the discs," says Ms Aldridge. Many other 'free' internet service providers have since quit the market or started charging.

Last August Alta Vista, which had signed up 274,000 customers for its unmetered service, abandoned its deal, and in the same month LineOne axed its free service. Does NTL's price hike indicate that it too is about to abandon free and unmetered internet access? "We are the only provider who launched in the early part of last year which has sustained its free service... but the fact is that there are commercial pressures," says Ms Aldridge. However she adds that, for the time being at least, NTL remains committed to providing unmetered access.

NTL says the alternatives for its customers are less attractive. It points to AOL's flat-fee service, which costs £14.99 per month but does not include any non-internet calls in the price, while BT's Surf Together package at £14.99 gives free internet access at weekends and evenings only and, again, does not include non-internet calls.

But this week Freeserve launched a £12.99 a month flat rate package, £2 a month cheaper than AOL and BT, although potentially more expensive than NTL. Freeserve says that its package will suit users who are on-line at home for more than eight hours during peak time.

Hopes for cheaper net access are likely to rise next week, when communications watchdog Oftel is planning to publish the results of a consultation process on future unlimited access to the internet. It is expected that it will recommend a break-up of BT's stranglehold on internet charges. But a drawback for BT phone users considering switching to another provider is that BT recently upped the cost of its line rentals. The quarterly charge rose from £27.77 to £29.97.

So for an NTL user connected via BT, the minimum quarterly charge rises from £30 to NTL and £27.77 to BT, a total of £57.77, to £45 to NTL plus £29.97 to BT, a total of £74.97.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Gerrard Investment Funds

fields.headline: GIF plans to clean up with brand new name
fields.standfirst: CCS is hardly a star player but it is a steady performer with bags of experience to call on. Tony Levene puts it in the spotlight
fields.trailText: CCS is hardly a star player but it is a steady performer with bags of experience to call on. Tony Levene puts it in the spotlight.
fields.body:
Will it follow Andersen Consulting and the Post Office with a high-cost name conversion?
Hardly. It wants to avoid the fuss of the Post Office turning into Consignia or the £70m bill of turning Andersen into Accenture - a sum that would take up nearly five years' worth of current unit trust charges at CCS. We're talking a modest million or so -mostly on new stationery.

So what's the bright new name?
Gerrard Investment Funds, which will probably be shortened to GIF. And, in case you're thinking of asking, it has nothing to do with the kitchen cleaners that are rebranding from Jif to Cif. The name was selected because CCS is part of the Old Mutual group whose Gerrard subsidiary is the chosen vehicle for private investor money.

Enough names. What's on offer?
CCS has 17 unit trusts covering major markets, bonds, and specialities such as ethical and technology. In all, the trusts are worth a total £1.4bn. That's far from big league, but it is an increase from £800m two years ago - and they hope to reach £3bn by late 2003.

Why the optimism?
It reckons it has the formula for today's uncertain markets. It has around 100,000 wealthy stockbroking clients and it has realised that most people hate losing money more than they like making it. It reasons that by replicating that attitude into unit trusts, it could attract attention.

How has it performed so far?
Standard & Poor's have given star ratings to 11 out of 16 funds with a long enough track record. And the fund that comes nearest to replicating the risk averse private client portfolio - the Hallmark Portfolio fund - has been one of the best performing UK unit trusts over three years.

Are there any real dogs?
Not so far. Its Japanese Growth Fund is sixth in its sector over three years, although it has slipped more recently to below half way. The ethical fund is up and down, although global technology has been very much down over the past year - not much sign of risk avoidance for its investors.

Does the old economy rule?
No. They're not giving up on the wired-up world - there's always the UK Opportunities fund for those who want their technology with some sugar.

What's the fund management style?
Managers are free but far from unfettered. There is no official playlist of approved stocks, but funds have to stick generally to a set of core holdings and then justify decisionsthat stray from the guidelines. There are bi-monthly meetings to control risks.

Do they have star fund managers?
No, they don't have a massive publicity machine. But they have a wealth of experience in Leonard Klahr and Kenneth Levy who are old enough to remember the last big bear market in the mid-70s.

What's a bear market and is there a strategy?
A bear market is when stocks tumble and stay down. And the UK has not seen a serious share price rout for over 25 years. If one happens, the firm's not big enough to take big positions against the herd so it will keep its head down, listen to the news flow and try to ride out any big falls.

Do they think one will come to pass?
If they do, they're not letting on - it would see customers lining up for the exit. They see the market ending up at present levels or better this year on the back of lower interest rates due to falling inflation and moderate growth.

What could go wrong?
In the short term, there are concerns about US company profits - a few more grim warnings could turn Wall Street into a battleground. But their big concern is longer term. They've been studying their demographics and have factored 2007 into the equation.

Why?
That's when the US baby boomer generation starts to reach retirement age and turns equities into income-producing bonds. The challenge will be to find new buyers to pick up the slack.

Where will they come from?
Europe and Japan - but the numbers will have to be huge.

What's the CCS hot tip?
The managers reckon that Japan could be the best current home for their own money.

How do IFAs see CCS?
A solid, middle-of-the-road bet that's just starting to attract attention. The strong story is managed funds where CCS is a fast mover in a pedestrian world.

Is there a website?
Click on to Gerrard - it's a brochure and print a form site.

And what's the unique selling proposition?
Active management that wins in good times but protects in bad periods.

fields.headline: Dead duck or dead ringer for success?
fields.standfirst: Orange claims 1m people are savouring its shares; analysts say they may be in for a bumpy ride. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: Orange claims 1m people are savouring its shares; analysts say they may be in for a bumpy ride. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
Will mobile phone company Orange be a juicy share to buy or will it make a marmalade of your money? This week Orange claimed that around 1m people have already asked for the floatation prospectus, but analysts warn that the shares could have a bumpy ride.

The good news is that the price at which the shares will be floated is much lower than expected. France Telecom bought Orange off Vodafone in May last year for £31bn, but despite the fact that it merged France's biggest mobile company into Orange, the float price range announced this week values the company at just £35bn-£41bn. Analysts immediately suggested that France Telecom had priced the float at a big discount to ensure its success.

The bad news is that the fall in valuation reflects a steep drop in investor appetite for telecom share issues. France Telecom is selling shares in Orange partly to refinance itself; like many other telecom companies it has burdened itself with huge debts to pay for expensive "third-generation" licences and heavy investment in setting up new networks.

Many City investors have taken fright at the level of telecom debts and the sector has badly underperformed the stockmarket in recent months. Vodafone, for example, is currently trading 230-240p, down 40% on its 400p peak in March last year, while France Telecom is down even more, trading at 57% below its March peak.

The flotation, backed by a £25m advertising blitz, is one of the biggest pan-European share offers ever. It is also the first time the British public have been blitzed with an offer for a company that is not actually based in Britain. Orange is now domiciled in Paris, and the shares will have their principal listing in euros, but France Telecom has done everything to make it look and feel like a UK share offer. The shares in the UK retail offer will be quoted in sterling and dividends can be paid in sterling.

The price will not be set until after the applications for shares are in; all that Orange is saying for now is that the range will be between 733p and 860p. Retail investors will be given an extra 4% discount, worth around 32p a share, and the minimum investment is £250.

Prospects for an instant profit look slim. Although France Telecom is only selling off between 10-15% of its holding in Orange, it is setting aside a large part for small investors, making it less likely that the stock will be oversubscribed. Orange is likely to enter the CAC 40 index in Paris, but index funds which would chase after the stock are a much weaker force in France than in Britain. So is Orange worth a punt ?

The case for

 "Buy on weakness, sell on strength" is the stock market maxim. With telecom stocks out of favour and the floatation price marked down, Orange represents good value.

 Rapid growth. Orange recently overtook BT Cellnet to become the number two network in the UK behind Vodafone. Global turnover has tripled in the last three years to around £10bn in 2000.

 Strong balance sheet. Although its parent group has hefty debts, Orange floats with relatively little debt compared to other telecom companies and its cash flow is powerful. Profit margins are below Vodafone's, but as it adds more users to its network, margins are rising fast.

 WAP, internet phones, voice-activation, massive increases in data rather than voice transmission, 'wire-free' connections for devices to control all aspects of life; Orange expects to be at the forefront of such developments.

The case against

 "Don't catch a falling knife" goes the stockmarket maxim. Just because something is cheap, it doesn't mean it hasn't got further to fall. And even though Orange's price is cheaper than expected, the price already discounts a large amount of future growth.

 Market maturity. The growth of mobile phones in the UK is levelling off - it's hit around 60% in the UK already, and the switch to pre-pay means lower revenue per user.

 Over-supply. The market is awash with mobile phone company shares. Over the next few months, Deutsche Telekom, KPN of Holland, BT and NTT in Japan all plan mobile share issues.

 Brain cancer. It's not mentioned in the prospectus, but a court win against a mobile company could spell meltdown for telecom shares.

 Summing up, David Harbage of Barclays Stockbrokers says: "We are positive on the industry in the long-run, but considering the recent rollercoaster ride in telecom stocks, you are undoubtedly looking at a high-risk/high reward investment."

 Prospectuses and application forms for Orange shares can be obtained by ringing 0800 085 8888 or from Orange Share Offer.

The growth of mobile phones in the UK is levelling off - it's hit around 60% in the UK already, and the switch to pre-pay means lower revenue per user.  Over-supply. The market is awash with mobile phone company shares. Over the next few months, Deutsche Telekom, KPN of Holland, BT and NTT in Japan all plan mobile share issues.  Brain cancer. It's not mentioned in the prospectus, but a court win against a mobile company could spell meltdown for telecom shares.  Summing up, David Harbage of Barclays Stockbrokers says: "We are positive on the industry in the long-run, but considering the recent rollercoaster ride in telecom stocks, you are undoubtedly looking at a high-risk/high reward investment."  Prospectuses and application forms for Orange shares can be obtained by ringing 0800 085 8888 or from Orange Share Offer.

webTitle: MP's role in temple deal investigated

fields.headline: MP's role in temple deal investigated
fields.standfirst:
Parlimentary watchdog inquiry follows council rows

Special report: Labour in power
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Parlimentary watchdog inquiry follows council rows.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz recently declared: "I am a leading member, if not the leading member, of the Asian community in this country. All kinds of people ask me for support."

In Leicester, where he has been MP since 1987, questions around how his support is obtained have been looked at by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards.

Ms Filkin was assisted in her inquiry by Mahebub Ladha, Leicester city council's principal race relations officer, who focussed on allegations that Vaz had requested what were described as "campaign contributions" from local businessmen in return for exerting influence on planning applications.

A key allegation revolves around a controversial plan for Europe's biggest multi-faith centre, combining places of worship for three religions, on seven and a half acres of council-owned land at Manor Farm in Hamilton, within Mr Vaz's Leicester East constituency.

Three groups jointly applied to develop the land for a two-storey Hindu temple, a Sikh community centre and temple to accommodate 700 worshippers, and a marble mosque with a 17-metre high minaret.

In 1998, the land was sold to the three applicants for half of its market value of £1.5m.

A proviso was made that the developers would have to pay the cost of installing new roads and sewers, but could have the land in exchange for this if it cost more than the agreed sale price.

Prominent businessman Jaffer Kapasi, who was promoting the scheme on behalf of the Muslim group Dawoodi Bohra Jammat, was alleged to have been asked to make payments to Vaz - a claim the MP vigorously denies.

The other two groups involved were the the Swaminarayan Hindu Mission, who established the famous Neasden temple, and Sikh organisation the Ramgarhia Board.

The Sikh group has since withdrawn. Both groups say that they were not asked to make any payments. The council has not finalised the deal, or decided what to do with the site originally set aside for the Sikhs.

The city council received more than 1,000 letters of support for the scheme, but there were also nearly 700 letters of objection expressing fears that the complex could become a tourist attraction.

A spokesman confirmed that the council was approached last Spring for information by the parliamentary commissioner and "cooperated fully" with her inquiries.

Long-serving former city council leader Peter Soulsby, now Sir Peter, has given evidence directly to Ms Filkin in relation to this episode. Mr Kapasi has also given evidence.

The inquiry has been completed but its findings have not been made public. Mr Vaz denies all the charges and recent reports suggest that he is expected to be cleared of the substantial charges. Mr Vaz has also been investigated by Labour's National Executive over a complaint from senior members of the Leicester party that he masterminded a plot to remove the leaders of the city council - including Soulsby. Mr Soulsby was ousted from the council leadership in October 1993 after a row with Mr Vaz, after the MP's mother Merlyn, a city councillor, was removed from the chairmanship of a committee. Mr Soulsby was defeated in the leadership election by a compromise candidate backed by councillors regarded as close to Mr Vaz and a group of leftwingers who had a longstanding rift with Mr Soulsby after a row over the poll tax. Mr Soulsby alleged that Mr Vaz plotted against him, but the allegations were thrown out.

Stephen Leach, professor of local government at Leicester De Montfort University, catalogued Vaz's involvement in the leadership struggle in a book published last year.

There is no evidence of misconduct, but Prof Leach said yesterday he was astonished by the degree to which the MP interested himself in the council's affairs.

"It is incredibly unusual to find an MP with this level of links to his local council. I have never come across an MP who has got so involved with the details of council work."

Keith Vaz was also involved in a Hindujas-backed scheme for a "multi-cultural theme park" in the Midlands before the last general election.

He is understood to have advised the businessmen on how to promote a proposed centre in Peterborough, titled Concordia, which would be inspired by values derived from ancient Hindu scriptures and would include food from around the world, educational facilities and rides. It would not be surprising for a prominent Asian MP to be approached for such advice.

Peter Mandelson met Srichand Hinduja at the brothers' headquarters in central London, in November 1996, when the businessman tried to enlist his support in the £101m Concordia plan, a former adviser to the Hindujas claimed.

The former adviser said yesterday: "Peter Mandelson thought it was wonderful. He was ready to support it."

The ex-aide said the Hindujas were pushing for Concordia to be a landmark project to celebrate the Millennium, and applied for a grant from the Millennium Commission of £50m.

The proposal was turned down, as was a revised and more modest bid, because the commission did not feel the plans were sufficiently developed.

The Hindujas remained anxious to fund a multi-cultural project and later approached NMEC chief executive Jennie Page to discuss how their ideas for Concordia could be incorporated into the Dome.

Geoffrey Bindman, Mr Vaz's lawyer, said yesterday: "He certainly expects to be cleared of all substantial allegations [by the Filkin inquiry]."

Asked about the Manor Farm allegation, he said: "Obviously there's absolutely no truth in that whatsoever. I'm sure the inquiry will not take any different view."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Dodgy franchise operation

fields.headline: Something fishy's going on
fields.standfirst: Two years after we alerted readers about a dodgy franchise operation the DTI has shut it down. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: Two years after we alerted readers about a dodgy franchise operation the DTI has shut it down. Tony Levene reports.
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry has shut down a franchise operation more than two years after Jobs & Money warned readers that they stood scant chance of ever seeing their investment again.

The long delay makes it unlikely that hapless investors will ever see a substantial part of their payment of up to £30,000 apiece. Caring Parents, a Manchester-based franchise, has been wound up by the courts in the public interest following a DTI probe carried out by its Companies Investigation Branch. What is left of the firm's assets are now in the hands of the Official Receiver.

The franchise was launched in mid-1998 by directors Charles Hendrie, 37, and Christopher Rustage, 52. It promised wannabe entrepreneurs £160,000 a year selling a range of services to parents and claimed gave an untapped market potential of some £20m in return for a £30 a year subscription. It was marketed in national newspapers.

It claimed to have 40,000 schools on its files and links to a charity that looked after terminally ill chil dren. It also claimed that major companies such as British Airways, Cosmos Holidays and Commercial Union would sign up as partners.

But Jobs & Money questioned the earnings potential, business plan and track record of the firm. Mr Hendrie, who described Caring Parents as "the most exciting concept of my business career", had been involved with Home Choice Videos, also in the hands of the Official Receiver. He said Home Choice, a burger bar operation, and a pet foot delivery franchise had been "phenomenal" successes. But all failed.

Mr Hendrie and Rolls-Royce owner Mr Rustage were also involved in the Angling Club of Great Britain, launched in the hope of signing up three million anglers at £30 a head. Fewer than 2,000 signed up.

Hendrie promised franchisees "staggering earnings potential". But Caring Parents' owners cashed in.

Lawyers for the DTI argued:

 That Caring Parents made false and misleading representations to induce the public to become regional directors and franchisees;

 That it operated prize draws where it failed to quote rules or a closing date, potentially in breach of lotteries legislation;

 That it paid the firm's owners dividends of £105,000 when it had no profits and had not yet recruited a single £30-a-year member;

 That the business lacked any commercial basis, but continued trading using the up to £30,000 a head fees from franchisees;

 That it described its activity as a "unique proven business format", but this was not the case;

 That there were serious shortcomings in the company's accounting and financial management.

Eventually, some 30 "regional directors" signed up, netting the firm nearly £900,000. But in its first year of business, only 136 of 20m parents of school-age children joined. The winding-up order has come too late to save franchisees' cash, while the handful of parents have wasted £30 subscriptions.

Future investors in franchises should note the ease with which promoters can set up companies and lack of checks on money-making assertions in certain national newspaper "franchise" features.

The 'homework' that nets crooks a bundle

Adverts for homeworking schemes feature in many local freesheets, newsagents' notice boards and flyers. They promise large sums for "envelope stuffing" or "toy making".

Yet virtually all are bogus. Trusting people, often lone parents or the unemployed, are tricked into sending up to £100. The envelopes never materialise, while toys are rejected as "sub-standard".

Often applicants get no reply: sometimes they are told to insert similar adverts and lure others. In either case, they lose their money.

There are some 300 schemes active - one, recently shut down, netted £600,000 in nine months. A recent advert from the London-based Home Marketing Network, subject of a complaint to the Advertising Standards Authority, promised £200 a week for re-mailing 200 envelopes.

Now, the DTI is backing a new bill to outlaw the plans. It will ban upfront deposits for work or for directories allegedly detailing work;

It will allow trading standards officers to shut down bogus schemes quickly;

It will impose fines of up to £5,000 for each offence;

It will ban adverts.

"Organisers of these schemes never intend paying anything. These scams can affect the most vulnerable," says consumer affairs minister Kim Howells.

The DTI says: "Never send money in advance to companies which claim they can offer work at home and shun schemes that require you to rent equipment or pay for materials upfront."

webTitle: Defender of official secrecy chosen to head inquiry

fields.headline: Defender of official secrecy chosen to head inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: The lawyer leading the inquiry into the Hinduja passport crisis engulfing the government advised ministers to sign "gagging orders" to keep secret crucial information in the arms-to-Iraq scandal.
fields.body:
The lawyer leading the inquiry into the Hinduja passport crisis engulfing the government advised ministers to sign "gagging orders" to keep secret crucial information in the arms-to-Iraq scandal.

Sir Anthony Hammond QC drew up public interest immunity certificates to suppress evidence of government collusion in the sale of weapons-making machinery to Baghdad in breach of a UN embargo.

Unveiled by Downing Street as the man to get to the bottom of an affair that has cost Tony Blair one of his closest colleagues and threatens a second minister, Sir Anthony is a great defender of official secrecy.

Tory home secretaries Ken Baker (now Lord Baker of Dorking) and Ken Clarke signed documents prepared by Sir Anthony to withhold information that was to prove crucial to the defence of three executives in the Matrix Churchill case.

The Scott report into the arms-to-Iraq scandal recorded Sir Anthony's involvement and Lord Baker's admission that he was not told one of three executives, Paul Henderson, was an MI6 informer when he approved a ban on suppressing the involvement of the secrurity services.

A certificate prepared by Sir Anthony said: "The very nature of the work of the security and intelligence services of the crown requires secrecy if it is to be effective."

No 10 presented Sir Anthony to the public as the former treasury solicitor but he spent only three years in that post, retiring last year after an appointment in 1997.

The government has effectively picked an old Home Office hand to investigate the Home Office: Sir Anthony spent 24 years in the department up to 1992. Five years at trade and industry before becoming treasury solicitor completes his cv.

He was also involved in the earlier legal battle to shut up former MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson, seeking court orders to gag the rogue spy.

Nicknamed "Wally" after the great cricketer Wally Hammond, Sir Anthony, 60, was knighted by the Queen in May 2000.

Downing Street and the home office have said Sir Anthony will be able to call all official papers and speak to officials and ministers, though no commitment has been give that the report will be published before the election.

Now investigating the granting of a British passport to GP Hinduja as well as SP Hinduja, Sir Anthony was appointed to review whether the applications were "properly dealt with in all respects".

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP who exposed the involvement of Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz in affair, said: "It's disappointing that the prime minister has chosen someone whose record does not appear to be a full commitment to freedom of information. The government is in a mess and this inquiry has to be seen to be above board."

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Fund manager Jupiter has launched a successor to its International Green Investment Trust (IGIT) called the Global Green Investment Trust.
fields.body:
 Fund manager Jupiter has launched a successor to its International Green Investment Trust (IGIT) called the Global Green Investment Trust. The trust will be sponsored by stockbroker Collins Stewart and run by Simon Baker, who has run the existing trust since 1994. The new trust is expected to act as a rollover vehicle for investors in the IGIT, which closes its doors on March 31 after generating returns of 169% since being launched in 1993.

 As Victoria Beckham found this week, carrying around designer luggage can attract the wrong kind of attention. Charge card issuer American Express has issued a warning to travellers that they should label luggage clearly and keep a note of how many bags they are taking. It also points out that luggage lost or stolen due to negligence is not covered by travel insurance.

 Execution only stockbroker TD Waterhouse said this week that customers can view share prices in real-time on the web, or their WAP phones or through interactive digital television for the first time rather than face a 20 minute delay. Previously real-time share prices could only be viewed when executing trades.

 Rival execution only stockbroker The Share Centre has opened its Share Account and Self Select Isas for real-time internet dealing. Until now customers dealt at 9.00am, 1pm or 4pm. Share Centre boasts it offers the cheapest minimum dealing commission of its main rivals. The minimum at Charles Schwab is £12 and £9.75 at TD Waterhouse.

 Independent mortgage broker Savills Private Finance is offering a capped rate mortgage with a rate that it claims hasn't been seen since the 1950s. Homebuyers and remortgagers can apply for the 4.75% capped rate, which runs until January 2003. Then a standard variable rate of 7.74% kicks in and applies for the rest of the mortgage period. An arrangement fee of £350 applies to the loan along with a 5% redemption fee within the offer period and a maximum loan to value of 95%. Savills reckons the loan could cut the cost of a typical mortgage by almost £250 per month.

fields.headline: Can we help you solve those cash problems?
fields.standfirst: This week we launch Jobs & Money's section in which readers get the chance to have their financial difficulties aired and answered
fields.trailText: This week we launch Jobs & Money's section in which readers get the chance to have their financial difficulties aired and answered.
fields.body:
I have a maturing Tessa with Birmingham Midshires. I wanted to move it to a new account the same day so as not to lose interest, but they quoted me a £25 telegraphic transfer fee. This was not in the literature.
AY, Bristol

 You are victim of two legal banking wheezes. One is the inability to move money instantly, even when the cheque is drawn on such a creditworthy organisation as Birmingham Midshires - the usual three to four days gap is pure profit for the banks. And the other is that banks often leave out details that they think might be "too difficult" or "of interest to a few", while still imposing charges for these actions. Birmingham Midshires tells me it is monitoring customer demand to see if there should be improvements in its money transmission services, but that will stop short of instant action. This is unsatisfactory.

I have a small number of shares in Thames Water which was taken over by RWE of Germany. Now they are demanding that I sell them my shares, quoting company law. Have they the right to make this demand? What is the alternative if I don't consent?
GY, Peterborough

 They do have this right. RWE paid £12.15 a share for Thames Water last September. Under the Companies Act, once holders of more than 90% of the outstanding shares agree to a bid, the balance can be compulsorily acquired. The alternative, if you ignore their letters, is that you are left with shares which you cannot sell and which will not produce any dividend for you. But the bank acting for RWE must pay the same amount per share to you as to others and cannot charge you for acquiring your investment.

You recently quoted a financial adviser who recommended Schroder UK Growth unit trust. I am a holder and when I checked the figures, I discovered that the fund has lost money over the past six months. Has he looked at this record? Would you not have been better telling people to put their money under their bed?
MB, Liverpool

 No. Six months is not enough. Equity investments are intended for the long term and savers must accept some volatility or otherwise stick to a building society. The past is no indicator of the future and our advice was aimed at those buying now. Most investors make the mistake of buying after unit trusts have increased instead of considering those which have fallen back.

I'm currently working in the Republic of Ireland, and am struggling to pay back loans I took out during university. I'm looking for help and advice on how to manage these repayments and stop being served with Default Notices.
HA, Dublin

 Living in Ireland does not absolve you from debt repayment, but it does offer some protection against court action. You should list your creditors and how much you owe them and work out how much you can afford to pay each month from your salary. Then offer each a monthly payment. Most would rather have a small sum on a regular basis than risk chasing you through a foreign court system they are unaccustomed to dealing with.

I have a £30-a-month Norwich Union endowment policy due to mature shortly, producing about £30,000. As I don't miss the money I want to start a new policy. But Norwich Union refuse to sell me one - they say they no longer provide them. But they sent a rep to my home to talk about Isas. What should I do?
DR, Leicester

 Be thankful. The return on your 20-year policy has been acceptable. Endowments have been an expensive way to save - besides concealed high commissions and other hidden costs, you are also paying for life cover which you may not want and could certainly buy cheaper elsewhere. You now need to find a home for your lump sum. There are a number of protected funds, if you want a similar security to your endowment. Don't just talk to Norwich Union - discuss your needs with at least two independent financial advisers.

webTitle: Scotland creates a new north-south divide

fields.headline: Scotland creates a new north-south divide
fields.standfirst:
Free care for pensioners and a 21% rise for teachers pose a big challenge to Westminster
Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Free care for pensioners and a 21% rise for teachers pose a big challenge to Westminster.
fields.body:
Devolution is drawing an indelible line across the UK. On one side students pay tuition fees, the teaching profession is in crisis, and many of the frail and elderly must pay to help meet the costs of their care. On the other there are no tuition fees, teachers have won a 21.5% pay deal, and now it looks as though all pensioners will enjoy free long-term care.

Scottish executive proposals to fund long-term care for all pensioners has opened up the biggest policy divide yet between Holyrood and Westminster, and raised the spectre of a two-tier UK society split along the Scotland-England border.

Yesterday, as pressure grew on the UK government to follow Scotland's lead, there were warnings that Labour risked losing the grey vote over the issue, and predictions that Scotland could become a giant nursing home as pensioners rushed north to take advantage of any better deal.

Sir Stewart Sutherland, who chaired the royal commission which recommended free personal care for the elderly, said he believed its introduction in England and Wales was now inevitable. But the health minister, John Hutton, ruled out any policy reversal in England and Wales, where nursing care is free but personal care is means-tested.

"Devolution means that it is for the Scottish parliament to make decisions on its response to the royal commission on long-term care," he said. "Both the government and the Scottish executive are committed to improving health and social care services for older people, but we are doing this in different ways."

Analysts say the government and the public have to accept that Scotland can follow a different path, however awkward it might prove. "This is exactly what the Scottish parliament was designed to do," said Malcolm Dickson, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "It was designed to take decisions that reflected the broadest strand of public opinion.

"But it is an embarrassment for Labour in the run-up to a general election and following on from tuition fees and the teachers' deal. What the Scottish parliament has done is provide a stick with which to beat the party. People will say if it's good for Scotland why is it not good for the rest of the UK? But this is something the political parties need to get used to in a post-devolution situation."

Downing Street may have been spared some difficulty by the fact that the Scottish executive will not reveal the detail of its proposals or take a final decision until August.

Yesterday, the Scottish National party and the Conservatives demanded clarification of the executive's apparent commitment on free long-term care, but the first minister Henry McLeish would not comment further. However, the Liberal Democrats, whose rebellion forced Mr McLeish to rethink his earlier refusal to fund all long-term care, said the executive's position was unequivocal.

Enormous impact

Public policy experts say this will have an enormous social impact across the UK. "This is absolutely huge," said Allyson Pollock, chair of the school of public policy at University College London. "It is really a triumph for Scotland if they really do go down this road. Over the last 20 to 30 years a lot of care has been shifted to being a personal responsilbity and what the Scottish parliament is saying is that care is now a universal collective responsiblity."

Professor Pollok said the issue would shine a light on the "covert privatisation" of the health service in England and Wales. "You have to ask why in England we are shunting more and more care into the unregulated private sector," she said.

Teachers leaders have already warned that a recent 21.5% three-year pay deal for Scottish teachers will cause deep discontent south of the border.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, has said schools in England could find it even harder to attract teachers. "I think morale of teachers in England and Wales will be severely depressed if they do not get at least equal treatment." Pensioners' groups in England have also warned that there will be great anger and bitterness if Scotland's elderly get a substantially better deal, but warnings that Scotland wll be colonised by middle class English pensioners have been dismissed.

John Curtice, a political analyst at Strathlclyde University, whose elderly mother lives in Cornwall, said: "At the point which people need that kind of care the last thing they are going to be capable of doing is making a long-distance, long-term move."

Others say the biggest question raised by the care issue is how Scotland can afford to be so generous. The country has traditionally enjoyed a favourable slice of public funds in its £17bn budget, some 25% higher per head than the rest of the UK.

Some analysts say the care issue will increase pressure for a complete review of funding, but economist Arthur Midwinter says Scotland has an appropriate share for its level of need and can afford the £110m cost of universal free care.

"If it's a priority they can find the money," he said. "I don't see any difficulty in funding it. They might have to adjust some of their other programmes, but they won't need to put up the tartan tax to do this."

Mr Curtice, however, said much of the unease at this latest policy departure comes not from Scotland's ability to pay for it but the process that allowed it to happen.

"It illustrates the impact of PR and the different power balance from Westminster," he said. "What is shows is that, boy, oh boy, haven't we got a different parliament up here."

fields.headline: US spectrum sale raises £11bn
fields.trailText: Telecom companies yesterday paid the price of mobile communication after the US auction of wireless spectrum closed raising an estimated $16.9bn(£11.6bn).
fields.body:
Telecom companies yesterday paid the price of mobile communication after the US auction of wireless spectrum closed raising an estimated $16.9bn(£11.6bn).

Two companies, one of them Vodafone's 45%-owned subsidiary Verizon Wireless, paid a combined $5.5bn(£3.7bn) for three licenses in New York alone.

Like the winners of the record-breaking next generation mobile auctions in Europe last summer, Verizon and the other new licence holders will be under pressure to justify the expenditure.

They may have paid heavily, but they stand to gain just as much. "New York has the highest population density in the country," said Boston-based telecoms analyst Dave Bishop of the Yankee Group.

"It has one of the most affluent populations, and the second longest commute time - 70% of (mobile phone) use is during the commute."

The companies bidding for the licences said they had to seize the opportunity, whatever the cost. "Spectrum is in scarce supply," said a source from one bidding company. It may not be available for three or four more years."

The FCC ran the auction cautiously after the staggering prices reached in the German and UK sales of next generation mobile licences last summer. The commission was equally determined to avoid the fate of the French auction.

fields.headline: Floods water down beer sales
fields.trailText: December's floods added to the woes of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, the embattled producer of Bank's and Marston's ale which has been at the centre of takeover speculation for more than six months.
fields.body:
December's floods added to the woes of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, the embattled producer of Bank's and Marston's ale which has been at the centre of takeover speculation for more than six months.

The company yesterday disclosed its like-for-like sales were down 0.5% in the six weeks to January 6. It blamed the fall on the closure of 65 flooded pubs in Yorkshire and the Midlands.

Managing director David Thompson said: "The weather had a serious effect on our pubs in the basins of the Ouse, the Trent and the Severn."

He insisted that the company's seasonal update could not be compared to positive figures from rivals such as Greene King, because Wolves & Dudley was measuring its performance over a six week, rather than three-week period.

Addressing Wolves & Dudley's annual general meeting at Wolverhampton Wanderers Football Club, chairman David Miller confirmed that a strategic review was considering closing at least one of the firm's four breweries.

Wolves is being stalked by leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare, while Mr Thompson is trying to put together a management buyout. The shares fell 7.5p to 472p.

webTitle: Brown to signal tax cuts for poor

fields.headline: Brown to signal tax cuts for poor
fields.standfirst:
Labour's heartland to get help in pre-election budget as confident chancellor aims for second term

New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour's heartland to get help in pre-election budget as confident chancellor aims for second term.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today hold out the prospect of a series of pre-election tax cuts targeted at Labour's heartland supporters as he lays the basis for a record second full term.

Abandoning the traditional pre-budget "purdah", the chancellor makes clear that he is determined to bring down taxes to help families struggling with children and to boost investment in Britain's inner cities.

In a speech to a Fabian Society conference in London, sponsored by the Guardian, Mr Brown will reassure grassroots supporters by saying that he is determined to spend more and never to embark on the sort of "indiscriminate" Tory tax cuts of the late 1980s which led to boom and bust.

"We need both targeted tax cuts and spending increases as engines of opportunity for families," the chancellor will say. "We need tax cuts or credits and public investment together as the engine of opportunity and prosperity."

The chancellor will then list the previous tax cuts he has aimed at the less well off. These include the working families tax credit and the new 10p tax rate.

The chancellor's speech, which was billed last night by his aides as an ambitious attempt to set out his vision for a second term, demonstrates Mr Brown's confidence after his success in restoring Labour's reputation for economic prudence. During the last election Labour was paranoid about talking of spending increases, insisting that the party would stick to Tory spending limits for its first two years in office.

With the economy in a buoyant state, Mr Brown indicates today that he has no qualms about talking of spending rises and an important role for what he calls the "enabling state".

Mr Brown will say: "For us, equality of opportunity cannot be achieved by markets alone, however dynamic; by individuals alone, however enterprising; or by voluntary organisations alone, however close to the community. But nor can it be achieved by government alone. It is the duty of the state to provide the framework and the finance to make opportunity possible. It is the role of the private and voluntary sector and not just government to deliver these opportunities."

Mr Brown's speech comes as his position has been strengthened as never before after the resignation of his foe, Peter Mandelson. However, both Mr Brown's aides and his detractors denied reports yesterday that the chancellor is using the departure of the arch pro-European Mr Mandelson to stiffen a series tests Britain will have to meet before the government holds a referendum on the euro.

At the same conference, education secretary David Blunkett will call on Labour to lift its vision beyond arguments over income inequality towards creating a "civil society" for all.

He will argue that parties in office had to review and refresh their thinking continually, and recognise that ideas matter profoundly.

Mr Blunkett will emphasise the importance of equipping people with skills and education to create thriving, moral communities. The party's "key challenges" were to "ensure that all have good skills and jobs, that opportunities through lifelong learning and quality of life are shared across the society, and that people are equipped and engaged as citizens shaping their future".

Mr Blunkett will argue: "Too often the centre left has focused on income distribution as the measure of its success or failure without looking behind the statistics as to the real cause of inequality - inequality of skills, education, jobs and assets that people hold.

"We need to look beyond income to determine how more just our society has and can become."

Rewriting the old clause 4 of Labour's constitution, which emphasised common ownership, had helped it to address quality of life issues. Labour had to help people build "reservoirs of social capital".

"In the past the centre left allowed its concern with physical and social conditions to obscure a commitment to social morality and the importance of civil virtues and civil society." But that was changing. The party was addressing people's concerns as individuals and citizens, whether in talking about crime, anti-social behaviour, welfare or education.

fields.headline: Timely inquiry into CD pricing
fields.standfirst: Spotlight on the music business
fields.trailText: The European commission's decision to carry out a full inquiry into the music industry biggest names - Bertelsmann, EMI, Warner Music, Sony and Universal - with regard to the pricing of CDs is not before time.
fields.body:
The European commission's decision to carry out a full inquiry into the music industry biggest names - Bertelsmann, EMI, Warner Music, Sony and Universal - with regard to the pricing of CDs is not before time.

The investigation may uncover nothing illegal, or it may decide, as the competition commission did on car prices, that customers are being overcharged.

But the very process of launching a new investigation will force the big record industry corporations to re-examine how they go about their business - and that cannot be a bad thing. The music industry is in a mess, not least because its traditional structure is being undermined by the internet.

The retail end of the business is under multiple attack. Online stores such as Amazon.com make tracking down a particular CD quick and easy - and often cheaper than via traditional routes.

At an even more fundamental level, bands are setting up websites and selling direct to the public.

Then there are all the websites in which copyright music is available for illegal downloads. These can then be burned into a CD for 50p or so.

This illegal practice has mushroomed, not least because many people perceive that they are being ripped off when they buy a CD in Britain - or, indeed, throughout Europe.

The relatively low price of CDs in the US just adds to the general sense of being ripped off.

It is not the first time that the CD market has been pored over by competition watchdogs. Like supermarket profits and beer prices, it is a perennial favourite of regulators.

The price of CDs was one example used time and again when the government launched its "rip-off Britain" campaign - which soon fizzled out. The competition authorities had a look too - and found no sign of any overcharging funny business.

But last year the Federal Trade Commission in the US had a little look at its domestic CD market - which is always held up by European buyers as an example of how cheap CDs could be - and found against the same companies now being investigated by the EU.

That alone would suggest that European consumers are being ripped off on a biblical scale. The times and technologies are changing, and the industry must change too.

Storybook store

Tim Waterstone's association with the bookshop he founded has been an extraordinary tale. Mr Waterstone, readers will recall, left WH Smith under a cloud in 1981 and set up his first bookstore with just £6,000 in his pocket. Eight years later, WH Smith bought what by then had become a 30-strong chain, making £8m for an executive the company had once sacked.

He was reunited with the chain after a management buyout which formed HMV Media in 1998.

But it has not been a happy reunion. Mr Waterstone, who became chairman of HMV, has had a fractious relationship with his colleagues and is deeply critical of what he views as HMV's "dumbing down" of Waterstone's. "Bland popularism" was the phrase used by one "close" insider.

For over a year now, Mr Waterstone has been keen to go back to square one and buy back the chain he founded. HMV has publically stated that it is not for sale, but in recent weeks Mr Waterstone has been encouraged that a final bid might be worthwhile.

Mr Waterstone is understood to have seized upon a research note from Deutsche Bank which suggested HMV would do well to accept the rumoured offer of £200m the entrepreneur has previously made.

HMV is under pressure for cash, and a disposal would help a restructuring of its debt repayment schedule. Given present market conditions, a flotation of the business is out of the question.

HMV's Christmas trading statement showed a long-awaited improvement in sales at Waterstone's, which could be seen as reason for the group to keep the chain. Equally, however, it may play into Mr Waterstone's hands by encouraging his nervous backers at PPM Ventures to show him the money in the present unforgiving climate.

Humble pie off

Humble pie was off the menu for Interbrew's chief, Hugo Powell, who broke his silence yesterday to mount a breathtakingly brazen defence of his firm's misjudged purchase of Bass Brewers. Mr Powell still says Stephen Byers' order to reverse the deal was unreasonable and unpredictable. But his chances of overturning it are slim: the best he can hope for is more time to sell Bass, and more choice of potential buyers.

Interbrew's options are narrowing. It seems the office of fair trading is refusing to countenance most finance houses, which leaves a short list of suitable industrial candidates. Interbrew is in a tight corner of its own making.
fields.bodyText: The European commission's decision to carry out a full inquiry into the music industry biggest names - Bertelsmann, EMI, Warner Music, Sony and Universal - with regard to the pricing of CDs is not before time. The investigation may uncover nothing illegal, or it may decide, as the competition commission did on car prices, that customers are being overcharged. But the very process of launching a new investigation will force the big record industry corporations to re-examine how they go about their business - and that cannot be a bad thing. The music industry is in a mess, not least because its traditional structure is being undermined by the internet. The retail end of the business is under multiple attack. Online stores such as Amazon.com make tracking down a particular CD quick and easy - and often cheaper than via traditional routes. At an even more fundamental level, bands are setting up websites and selling direct to the public. Then there are all the websites in which copyright music is available for illegal downloads. These can then be burned into a CD for 50p or so. This illegal practice has mushroomed, not least because many people perceive that they are being ripped off when they buy a CD in Britain - or, indeed, throughout Europe. The relatively low price of CDs in the US just adds to the general sense of being ripped off. It is not the first time that the CD market has been pored over by competition watchdogs. Like supermarket profits and beer prices, it is a perennial favourite of regulators. The price of CDs was one example used time and again when the government launched its "rip-off Britain" campaign - which soon fizzled out. The competition authorities had a look too - and found no sign of any overcharging funny business. But last year the Federal Trade Commission in the US had a little look at its domestic CD market - which is always held up by European buyers as an example of how cheap CDs could be - and found against the same companies now being investigated by the EU. That alone would suggest that European consumers are being ripped off on a biblical scale. The times and technologies are changing, and the industry must change too. Storybook store Tim Waterstone's association with the bookshop he founded has been an extraordinary tale. Mr Waterstone, readers will recall, left WH Smith under a cloud in 1981 and set up his first bookstore with just £6,000 in his pocket. Eight years later, WH Smith bought what by then had become a 30-strong chain, making £8m for an executive the company had once sacked. He was reunited with the chain after a management buyout which formed HMV Media in 1998. But it has not been a happy reunion. Mr Waterstone, who became chairman of HMV, has had a fractious relationship with his colleagues and is deeply critical of what he views as HMV's "dumbing down" of Waterstone's. "Bland popularism" was the phrase used by one "close" insider. For over a year now, Mr Waterstone has been keen to go back to square one and buy back the chain he founded. HMV has publically stated that it is not for sale, but in recent weeks Mr Waterstone has been encouraged that a final bid might be worthwhile. Mr Waterstone is understood to have seized upon a research note from Deutsche Bank which suggested HMV would do well to accept the rumoured offer of £200m the entrepreneur has previously made.
