fields.headline: Bookham bruised after warning
fields.trailText: Former high flyer Bookham Technology saw its stock market value shrink further yesterday after the company said it had underestimated fourth-quarter losses by 40%.
fields.body:
Former high flyer Bookham Technology saw its stock market value shrink further yesterday after the company said it had underestimated fourth-quarter losses by 40%.

Bookham, which manufacturers fibre-optic components, blamed its problems on a reduction in orders from its biggest customer and write-offs related to a recent acquisition in north America.

It now expects operating losses in the three months to December 31 to be between £15 and £15.5m. It had previously estimated losses of £11m.

Investors reacted badly to the news, marking Bookham's shares down 207p to £11 - a level not far off last April's £10 flotation price.

Analysts said they were becoming concerned about Bookham's inability to meets its financial targets. "This is becoming a bit of a habit," one analyst said, referring to widening third-quarter losses.

Bookham said revenues for the fourth quarter would be in line with expectations, but that it had sold fewer of its lower margin mini-DIL products because of a decrease in orders from Nortel.

Although this had been offset by increased shipments of next generation Dense Wavelength Division Multiplexing (DWDM) products, Bookham said it had incurred addition costs in meeting the demand.

Chief executive Andrew Rickman accepted Bookham could have coped with the demand had it been better prepared, but said he was pleased to be gaining market share in higher margin areas.

"From the market's point of view it was very important for us to grow in this area," he said. "We are performing very well in what is the highest value area of our industry".

The company also had to write off up to £2m because its purchase of a manufacturing facility in the US had made some investments redundant.

fields.headline: Interbrew heads for High Court
fields.standfirst: Belgian brewer hopes to overturn a competition ruling
fields.trailText: Interbrew, the Belgian producer of Stella Artois, is heading for the High Court to challenge trade secretary Stephen Byers' order to unwind its £2.3bn purchase of Bass's brewing division.
fields.body:
Interbrew, the Belgian producer of Stella Artois, is heading for the High Court to challenge trade secretary Stephen Byers' order to unwind its £2.3bn purchase of Bass's brewing division.

The firm is to seek a judicial review of the decision, although a successful outcome would be unprecedented - seven previous attempts to overturn competition rulings have failed.

As it announced the challenge, Interbrew revealed it was taking an €1.2bn (£750m) charge to cover potential losses on the resale of Bass Brewers, which makes beers such as Carling, Tennent's and Worthington.

Chief executive Hugo Powell admitted there was little hope of entirely overturning Mr Byers' ruling. He hopes that the courts will allow Interbrew to keep part of Bass Brewers and permit more flexibility in selling the rest.

"We're not so much trying to overturn the decision as change the parameters."

Interbrew is particularly concerned about a requirement for the office of fair trading to approve any buyer of Bass Brewers. After informal talks with the OFT, Mr Powell said: "I am expecting the list of approved possible buyers to be very short."

Insiders say the OFT has indicated it will rule out many venture capital buyers on the grounds that the highly leveraged structure of such a deal would leave Bass Brewers at risk of financial meltdown.

There are competition concerns over European firms such as Carlsberg-Tetley and Heineken. This leaves only a handful of international buyers including South African Breweries, Anheuser Busch of the US and Kirin or Asahi of Japan.

Mr Powell also wants at least a year to complete a sale. Previous attempts to overturn competition rulings have floundered on a requirement to prove that government decisions are irrational.

Interbrew's advisers believe, however, that because it was initially scrutinised in Brussels, the Bass deal falls under the auspices of European law, which says government decisions must be "proportionate".

A spokesman for the department of trade said: "If Interbrew wish to seek judicial review of the decision that is, of course, a matter for them and it would be inappropriate to comment further."

webTitle: 11,000 jobs go as Ericsson stops making phones

fields.headline: 11,000 jobs go as Ericsson stops making phones
fields.trailText: The world's third-largest mobile phone company is to halt production of handsets, eliminating 11,000 manufacuring jobs in the process.
fields.body:
The world's third-largest mobile phone company is to halt production of handsets, eliminating 11,000 manufacuring jobs in the process.

Ericsson, based in Sweden, is to hand over all phone manufacturing to Singapore-based Flextronic. Kurt Hellstrom, Ericsson's chief executive, said yesterday that the mobile phone division lost £1.1 bn in 2000. At least 1,700 of the jobs at risk are at the Basingstoke plant in Hampshire, where 90 redundancies are planned.

Mr Hellstrom said the move out of manufacturing was one of a series of measures designed to make the mobile phone division profitable by the second half of this year. The company's overall profits fell from £603m to £326m in the last three months of 2000, he said.

The results drove Ericsson's share price down nearly 12% to 747p.

Ericsson has lost market share to Nokia and Motorola, which have been focusing on the lower end of the market. The company has also had production halted by a fire at a supplier's factory, resulting in a shortage of parts .

"I'm definitely not satisified with the results," Mr Hellstrom told a press conference in Stockholm.

"There has been a mismatch between our product line and market demand because of the emphasis [in the market] on entry-level phones."

Ericsson will cut the staff in its mobile division from 16,800 to 7,000, with 4,200 people moving over to Flextronic.

Remaining staff will concentrate on research and development, design, and sales and marketing. Some factories will also transfer to Flextronics.

Phone makers are facing intense price competition.

"The handset market is becoming more of a high volume, low margin commodity market," said James Eibisch, telecoms research manager at IDC. "In such a market environment, companies of all types are decapitalising and moving manufacturing out to external companies." Mr Hellstrom predicted that 500m handsets would be bought this year globally, with the number of mobile subscribers rising to nearly a billion.

In a restructuring move, US telecoms firm WorldCom is expected to cut more than 11,000 jobs, or about 14% of its staff.

webTitle: Army to train women for front line combat

fields.headline: Army to train women for front line combat
fields.trailText: The army is preparing to train women for front line combat roles, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The army is preparing to train women for front line combat roles, it emerged yesterday.

Women officers are expected to join a platoon commanders' course at Warminster, Wiltshire, where they will train female recruits in warfare including hand-to-hand combat with bayonets.

Senior army officers who were hostile to the move now appear reconciled to it. The training will go ahead if Labour wins the election.

In an interview earlier this month, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said he believed that a woman could be appointed chief of the defence staff for the first time.

However, he said he realised that a woman would only become head of the armed forces if the number of front line combat roles open to them increased.

General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, who retires next month, referred in a speech in December to a Ministry of Defence study, on the "suitability for close combat roles" for women.

The study is due to be completed by the end of March.

He said: "I am not sure that the nation is ready for such a step yet, but from my perspective we must ensure that nothing, I repeat nothing, damages the combat effectiveness of the British armed forces."

He said that the chiefs of staff were not in the business of designing armed forces "for the good times". However, Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, who will take over from Sir Charles, is believed to be less hostile to the idea.

An MoD spokesman denied yesterday that there were plans to train women for combat roles. Any decision would have to await the internal study, he said.

Women already serve in artillery regiments, serve on ships, and have been trained as helicopter and jet pilots. They are barred from fighting in frontline infantry or armoured units.

But women served on the front line with the Royal Artillery in Kosovo

At present, 70% of posts in the army are open to women, 73% in the Royal Navy, and 96% in the RAF.

webTitle: Alarm at modern art's atrocity exhibition

fields.headline: Alarm at modern art's atrocity exhibition
fields.standfirst: Questions raised about the moral basis of carnal art and whether practitioners like Tracey Emin can carry on
fields.trailText: Questions raised about the moral basis of carnal art and whether practitioners like Tracey Emin can carry on.
fields.body:
A cry of disquiet went up yesterday about the rising number of modern artists who exploit, plunder or injure their own bodies "to seduce the contemporary art market".

A senior art academic and psychoanalyst warned that they had entered a realm "where the body becomes the medium, where pain becomes a product and the stability of intimacy is forfeited".

She said artists like Britain's Tracey Emin and Orlan, who specialises in carnal art in France, were in danger of running out of their own product. Of Emin, she said : "Soon, bartering the bodily intimacies of her youth and beauty will become a hard act to follow."

Tessa Adams, senior lecturer at Goldsmiths College, London, raised the issue at a high-level London seminar convened to spot trends in modern art, public leisure tastes and technology.

She was speaking to an audience of artists, market researchers, advertisers, arts bureaucrats and business people.

After her talk, titled Stolen Bodies, she stressed that she was raising questions - but not making moral judgments - about a trend which had grown since the 1990s.

"It has a horror side but I am not talking about it with horror".

She thought the artists might be reacting to the human genome project or to developments in imaging technology which had left the human body no hiding place.

In her talk, she said: "We can ask what will happen next in a climate of exchange that calls the artist to offer the testimony of their flesh to seduce the contemporary art trade.

"What of the artist who plunders their own body? Who steals their substance for some sort of exchange? ... In this business, the viewer, the critic and the curator claim the body in a sinister way.

"And these artists cannot just wash their mouths out and walk away intact. What happens when the distinction between the body of art and the art of the body is eroded - and where are we going?"

Among individual artists, she cited:

 Tracy Emin, "of unmade bed fame, is certainly a seasoned player in this game. Since she has art-marketed her nakedness in a narrative of sensual obligation - where the boundaries of abuse, submission, promiscuity and love blur - her body will never be reinstated.

 Orlan "is also running out of her product. 'My work and ideas', she tells us, 'are incarnated in my flesh'. And for this she employs surgeons to act out her startling quest for a series of facial transformations.

"Orlan refuses a full anaesthetic and insists on speaking to us as the knife plunges into her flesh ... luckily the epidural works, while the video records her transgressive witness.

"But carnal art has its limitations. The fragile face cannot continually be redesigned. As a solution to this diminishing return, Orlan's last operation was one of adding unnecessary implants".

 British sculptor Marc Quinn, who tapped eight pints of his blood over five months to make a frozen cast of his head. "Now preserved through refrigeration, the precious substance stands as a monument of useless incarceration".

 US cystic fibrosis sufferer Bob Flanagan, who "acted out a sequence of self-imposed pain" in his sickbed. "Should the public have stopped him there and then?" Dr Adams asked.

Afterwards she said: "The question I am asking is whether we can bear the responsibility of these artists bringing us into their bodies.

"I am not suggesting stopping them through censorship or by law because I am an artist myself. There is a lot of beauty in the way in which these artists have constructed their pieces."

She went on: "I think the moral question is about the use of new forms. It is the same issue as stem cell cloning. It is a question which we are still absorbing."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Stepstone losses at £91m
fields.body:
Stepstone losses at £91m

Norwegian online recruitment firm Stepstone saw losses jump last year to €133.6m (£91m), but said plans to break even by the end of the year were still on track.

Chief executive Giles Clarke yesterday said a booming jobs market in Europe and access to digital TV customers via its recruitment channel would produce strong growth.

He blamed the losses on a rapid expansion that was now complete - adding that the costs of running the business in the last three months had declined significantly.

Revenues rose to €19.8m in the fourth quarter from €14.1m in the third and from €3.8m in the fourth quarter of 1999.

BT rates badly for charges

BT's high-speed internet charges are among the highest in the world, Oftel said yesterday. Its £40 monthly charge for a residential ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) service compares with £37 in France, £31 in Germany and £32 in the US.

Meanwhile, BT yesterday stepped up the battle for internet customers by announcing a package of unlimited online access on its regular phone lines for a monthly fee of £14.99.

The move comes ahead of an Oftel report into unmetered internet access due out next week.

DC Thomson ups radio stake

DC Thomson, the Scotland-based publisher of the Beano and Dandy comics, said yesterday it had raised its stake in Scottish Radio Holdings to almost 9.6%.

The privately owned Dundee publisher, whose titles also include the Sunday Post and People's Friend, picked up 431,000 shares in Scottish Radio at 1,725p a share on Thursday, taking its holding to almost 3.16m.

Friends' ethical trust closes

A poorly performing £40m Friends Provident ethical investment trust was wound up yesterday, and is being rolled over into a new investment trust that will not be focusing on ethical issues.

The move means 17,000 investors in the Friends Provident Ethical Investment Trust will have to decide whether to transfer into the newly created Geared Opportunities Income Trust, have their holdings switched into units in the firm's £635m Stewardship ethical unit trust, or take the cash.

The trust, launched in 1993, was due to wind up at the end of this year but the board decided to bring this forward. It was liquidated yesterday following an extraordinary general meeting of the board.

OFT postpones Abbey decision

The competition watchdog yesterday delayed a decision on Lloyds TSB's bid for Abbey National until late February.

The office of fair trading said it would extend the period for considering the proposed deal by 15 working days to February 23. A decision on the merger was due by February 2.

webTitle: Branson's airships to transform task of locating lethal landmines

fields.headline: Branson's airships to transform task of locating lethal landmines
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson is to spearhead a drive to clear the world's former battle zones of 60m landmines, using advanced radar technology.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson is to spearhead a drive to clear the world's former battle zones of 60m landmines, using advanced radar technology.

The system was developed by a Ministry of Defence agency and the low-flying expertise of Sir Richard's Virgin group's airship division.

He has enlisted Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, as a patron of the Mineseeker Foundation.

It is being launched today in an attempt to map the minefields which kill or maim 25,000 civilians every year.

The low-flying airships, usually used to provide aerial camera platforms above sports stadiums, will sweep former war zones to precisely locate unexploded mines. Five airships will be fitted with the systems developed by the defence evaluation and research agency in Farnborough, Hampshire.

Preliminary results from a trial in Kosovo showed that an airship could identify mines at a depth of up to 4 metres while sweeping terrain at a rate of 100 square metres a second. This compares with 40 square metres a day, using conventional probes by explosives experts crawling through minefields on their stomachs.

Anti-personnel mines are spread over 800,000 sq km of former war zones in four continents - an area the size of France and Germany.

The issue was taken up by the late Princess of Wales but its international profile has declined since her death.

Under the scheme, airships would be provided on a not-for-profit basis by the Lightship Group, part of Sir Richard's Virgin Airship and Balloon Company.

Mike Kendrick, its chief executive, said 80% of land currently designated as mined was safe. By pinpointing minefields accurately, this land could be returned to productive use and civilian casualties reduced in countries such as Afghanistan, Bosnia Herzegovina, Cambodia, Chechnya, Iraq, Mozambique, Nicaragua and Kosovo.

Airships were more suitable for the work than aircraft that travel too fast for accurate mapping, or helicopters that can detonate mines accidentally with their propellers.

The Mineseeker Foundation will try to raise £10m from commercial sponsors to develop the system and equip five airships over the next two years.

Patrons include Mr Mandela and Queen Noor of Jordan. Mr Mandela said: "I wholeheartedly support the Mineseeker Foundation, which... will make a substantial impact in de-mining efforts in communities that have been deprived of economic stability and experience terrible human suffering."

John Flanagan, programme manager for the Mine Action Coordination Centre in Pristina, Kosovo, said: "If there was an end to laying mines today, it would still take 1,000 years to get rid of them using conventional methods of detection. Using this technology we could solve the problem in 25 years."

fields.headline: Brother Jack McDuff
fields.standfirst: The Illinois-born jazz musician who played the Hammond organ with subtlety and distinction
fields.trailText: The Illinois-born jazz musician who played the Hammond organ with subtlety and distinction.
fields.body:
The new release by the electric keyboard veteran Jimmy Smith and a packed Barbican show by downtown New York left-fusion trio Medeski, Martin and Wood confirm that the Hammond organ is still alive and noisily well in contemporary music. It was probably a source of satisfaction in the last years of the organist Brother Jack McDuff that his chosen instrument should have enjoyed such a popular and creative renaissance at the close of the 20th century.

McDuff has died, aged 74, after a long career which found him still changing his line-ups and his musical style into his late 60s, and which gained him a reputation as a distinctive and impressively subtle practitioner on an instrument normally cramped by an overpoweringly tempting standardised style, and a new audience, in the mid-80s, on the club circuit.

The Hammond was invented in the 1930s, and brought portability to the jazz organ for the first time - Fats Waller took one on the road as early as 1939. But it was the early years of the 1950s that saw a profusion of its use, from soul and gospel-inclined jazz groups to black church services all over the United States. The small, self-contained instrument had immense appeal because of its ability to mimic the dramatic sonorities of church pipe organs at the same time as offering jazz players a bebopper's speed of execution and the potential for a complex pedalled bassline, if you could shift your feet fast enough.

First Fats Waller and Count Basie, then Wild Bill Davis and Milt Buckner explored swing-based repertoires for jazz organ in the 1940s and early 50s, but it was Philadelphia's Jimmy Smith (initially, and tellingly, a student of both bass and piano) who revolutionised the use of the instrument and adapted it to the complex melodies of bop. Smith's early organ-trio records in the mid-50s were big hits from the start, and not only made him a jazz star, but created a hard-driving, bluesy sound using Hammond, drums and guitar that virtually wrote the book for half-a-century of organ jazz to come.

McDuff was initially devoted to Smith's methods as were all his Hammond-playing contemporaries. Born in Champaign, Illinois, he taught himself piano (like Smith, he was also a bassist), shifted to the Hammond, and from the mid-50s began playing regularly around Chicago in groups that sometimes included the saxophonist Johnny Griffin.

McDuff worked with tenor saxophonist Willis "Gator" Jackson until 1959, and then formed a trio on the classic Smith model. The key guitar roles in McDuff's groups were the best in the business, including Kenny Burrell and two shrewdly-spotted young newcomers in the gifted and subsequently hugely popular pair, Grant Green (1960-61) and George Benson (1962-65). Benson complained he was too inexperienced to take solos when he first went on the road with McDuff, but the experience eventually turned him into a jazz legend.

Early McDuff recordings like Brother Jack (for Prestige) were to have a second coming in the 80s as anthems of the club-world of acid jazz, and their powerful swing and bluesiness, allied to an unusual delicacy and pianistic intricacy of line, quickly built McDuff's reputation as something different in a crowded field. Less abrasive and raunchy than Jimmy Smith, his take on the familiar phraseology of the blues suggested an inventive and independent musical mind.

McDuff's career was subdued in the 70s, but revived in the latter part of the following decade. He used vocals more, played electric piano as well as Hammond, and became more soul-oriented, at one stage renaming his band The Heating System in deference to a younger and non-specialist audience.

His continuing prowess was revealed in a succession of sparky albums from 1988, which included such soulful performers as saxophonist Houston Person and guitarist Phil Upchurch, a good deal of soul singing, and occasional guest appearances from the superstar Benson.

Bringin' It Home, recorded as late as 1998, is an ebullient reunion of old McDuff partners - including Benson and saxophonist Red Holloway - and the familiar blues-groove Hammond repertoire gets some of its freshest treatment.

McDuff leaves his wife Kathy and her two children.

fields.headline: Peter Haigh
fields.standfirst: BBC television announcer known for Come Dancing
fields.trailText: BBC television announcer known for Come Dancing.
fields.body:
Peter Haigh, who has died aged 75, was one of the slightly raffish familiars who gave BBC Television its particular stamp when it was relaunched after the second world war. It is fashionable today to assume that its dinner-jacketed announcers and "comperes" then were all stuffy Oxbridge snobs. On the contrary, several of them imparted a distinct whiff of the second-hand car forecourt or the cashiered officer-class.

Haigh, brought up in North London and sent to a minor public school but not to university, had in fact been a subaltern in the Welsh Guards from 1944 to demobilisation in 1947, serving for a while in terrorist-torn Palestine. It was being seconded to Forces' Broadcasting units a couple of times which imbued him with an ambition to enter real broadcasting. He bombarded BBC Radio with requests for an audition, then the renascent television service, and finally, in 1952, after working as a commercial artist, a postman and a tea-planter, was given a trial as a continuity announcer along with the then established crew of Sylvia Peters, Mary Malcolm and McDonald Hobley.

The job was to nurse the audience from programme to programme, especially when there was any hiccup or abrupt change of mood. Women viewers, it was averred, immediately took to Haigh's immaculate diction and neat moustache. Their favourite newspaper columnists referred to him as "television's most eligible bachelor". He was offered the post of senior announcer when Hobley moved on in 1956. But by then Haigh could see that the announcers' days were numbered. Since the advent of ITV the year before, viewers had clearly shown a preference for the zippy on-screen punctuation of commercials or trailers. They didn't need a helping hand any more.

So Haigh turned down the offer to concentrate on the freelance opportunities which had come his way - Come Dancing, Picture Parade and miscellaneous celebrity occasions.

Come Dancing was a weirdly popular outside broadcast from ballroom dancing venues, masterminded by Mecca's Eric Morley, who was also responsible for the Miss World contest. In common with his fellow presenters, Haigh would be expected to take the floor with sequinned charmers from Pinner or Port Sunlight.

Picture Parade was the first sustained attempt to review new cinema releases. Teamed with the British film star Derek Bond, Haigh worked hard to make it popular, incorporating interviews with the likes of John Wayne, Anna Neagle and Joan Crawford.

But writing in Contrast, the austere British Film Institute quarterly, in 1962, the film critic Boleslaw Sulik condemned it as dull, depressing and predictable. Robert Robinson took over the programme, and Haigh's career declined. He went to live in Portugal, where he opened a waterside restaurant.

In 1957, he had married the Rank starlet Jill Adams. They had a daughter before they separated. In Portugal, he met his second wife, the German-born Inge, who survives him.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: Live with keys
fields.trailText: Live with keys
fields.body:
When you were 18, you used to be given the keys to the house. Nowadays, this is the age when your parents are most likely to change the locks while you're out.

In that drawer full of rubbish in your kitchen, you will usually find a selection of mystery, unlabelled keys. If you really want to know what they unlock, throw them away and, in a matter of hours, you will find out.

Carrying a bunch of keys has always been a bit of nightmare, unless you carry a handbag, or you're a Beefeater, or both. That's why people with expensive suits like to holster up their keys in a little leather pouchette. However, the best way of signalling to your partner that it's time to leave a dull party is to jangle your keys in an imminent departure kind of way - and you can't jangle a little leather pouchette.

The greatest fear of people who live by themselves is that they will leave home without their keys. That's why the first thing they do when they've closed the door behind them is to check for their keys. Alternatively, they leave them with a neighbour who can be trusted. The golden rule here is that if your neighbour doesn't then immediately entrust you with their own keys, they are not to be trusted.

This helps explain why so many people hide their keys instead. The favourite places are under the mat, under the dustbin or in a place so secure that you completely wipe it from your memory. Others prefer to carry their bunch of keys on their belt loop. The reason for this is that the one thing you're most unlikely to forget when you walk out of the house is your trousers.

Everyone has a few big old shed keys with one tooth, all of which look interchangeable but aren't. The reason why the key that looks remarkably like your shed key doesn't unlock the shed is because the key that is your shed key doesn't open the shed, either. The whole point of keys is that no two keys are the same - that's why it's foolish of you to expect that the key you got copied from your front door key will actually open your front door.

One day, keys may be replaced by smart cards, but not until the cards are smart enough to get into your back pocket when you've walked out of the house without them.

Biometrics will mean the end of all keys, smart or stupid. You'll simply roll up to your house, shout out it 'It's me', and the lock will completely ignore you, much like your girlfriend would in a similar situation.

fields.headline: Eye swear
fields.standfirst: 'Soon, I'll buy a cardie from Oxfam and my transformation will be complete'
fields.trailText: Dulcie Domum : 'Soon, I'll buy a cardie from Oxfam and my transformation will be complete'
fields.body:
'Diana was the best thing that ever happened to the royal family, and Wills has got her star quality! Just give the guy a chance, and he can bring back that glamour!"

"When I hear the word glamour, I reach for my machine gun."

Gordon and Elaine are arguing about the monarchy. Could this pave the way for renewed passion? An elopement, leaving the house divinely half-empty?

"Dulcie! What do you think?"

"You'll never agree," I say. "It's Marx versus Spencer."

Elaine solicits opinion of dozing Great Aunt. "Och, I swearrr by House of Fraserrr , dearrr ."

Wait! Has Great Aunt Elspeth stumbled upon the solution to our constitutional dilemma? The House of Frasier! Why not? They have a dog. Niles even looks a bit like Edward VIII. Not sure about that Daphne, though. Where did she go to school?

Though Elspeth may swear by House of Fraser, I am attempting new family rules: no swearing. Elaine regularly rings Italy to abuse Tom. BT should offer a new package: Friends, Family and F-words. Cuss your ex free after 6pm. Aunt dislikes strong language, so I am becoming demure. I have also decided to give in and embrace my decline. It's no use trying to compete with Elaine, the Diana of this household. Instead, I offer Aunt solidarity in antiquity.

Frugality prevails. I roast root vegetables, with terrible consequences. I ostentatiously darn socks. Aunt peers at me dubiously. "Dulcie, arrre you surrre you can see to worrrk in that poorrr light? How long is it since you had an eye test?"

Harriet bounds in. "Mum?" she whispers, "Can I say fecking and fupping, like they do in Father Ted?"

"No!" Harriet scowls. She needs expletives. She has bombed in her GCSE mocks, especially Spanish, and is having to wean herself from satellite TV and venture into the alien concept of work. "Oh, bother!" she snaps, marches out and slams the door.

"Is Harrrrrriet all rrright ?" enquires the aunt.

"Oh, yes," I assure her. "She was just asking me about a couple of words in Spanish."

"Spanish!" exclaims aunt with disapproval. "I had a drrreeadful attack of verrrtigo once in Santiago de Compostella. I was watching the incense- burrrnerrr swing to and fro." Make mental note never to refer to Iberian peninsula again.

Submit to eye test to placate aunt. Young male ophthalmologist is formal in manner, dark-suited and reserved, rather like a priest in a 19th-century novel. He shines lights into my eyes. Horrid. Feel I am hiding in an attic in my own skull. My blood vessels are briefly projected on to the opposite wall, like a map of the Amazon and just as endangered. It is strange having a stranger staring deep into your eyes. Though he may be a young puritan looking for adultery, my ovaries are too old for me to play Madame Bovary. Next, there's the glaucoma test: being shot in the eyeball with a blast of air. Oh yes, we old people know how to enjoy ourselves. Choose cheap unglamorous frames, then potter home quaintly, a bit like Miss Marple without the intellect. How leisurely life is when you've given up shaving legs. Soon, I shall buy a beige cardie from the Oxfam shop and my transformation will be complete.

We are just settling down to a cup of cocoa before our mid-afternoon zizz when the phone rings. "Mum!" shouts Harriet. "It's Fred!" Oh crumbs, oh heck. A demon lover, just as I was settling into decrepitude. Had assumed Fred's perverted partiality for me had worn off since I refused to go to Bala over New Year.

"Hi!" breezes Fred, refreshed, perhaps, by a life of solitude, landscape painting and the occasional compliant youth. "I'm staying with Jonathan and Roy. Would you like to come to dinner on Saturday? I've got a proposal for you."

Am for a moment speechless, caught in no man's land between Miss Marple and Madame Bovary. Can I resurrect myself by Saturday? I know Jonathan, Roy and Fred are mostly gay, but if I am to be their ageing diva, restoration work must commence at once. And a proposal? Are we talking marriage, or does he just want to borrow money? Ring off and glance into hall mirror. Hair or hedgerow? Too close to call. Hope the hairdresser has sharpened his machete.

fields.headline: The sweet smell of success
fields.standfirst: Every season brings fragrant delights, and winter is no exception, says Christopher Lloyd. Outdoors, you can create a scented wonderland, and the right plants cut for the house will brighten the darkest of months.
fields.trailText: Every season brings fragrant delights, and winter is no exception, says Christopher Lloyd. Outdoors, you can create a scented wonderland, and the right plants cut for the house will brighten the darkest of months.
fields.body:
There is no closed season for garden scents, and many of them can strike us quite forcibly, even in the depths of winter. Especially, of course, when frost relents. Many of these scents can be transferred to the house and enjoyed there in comfort but, in a warm room, they may not last that long. There are others that must be savoured in the garden or not at all.

The most compelling of these in my own garden is Olearia solandri . The whole bush gives off the fragrance of heliotrope. But, it is not a scent that can be captured and pinned down. It has to reach you as you pass nearby and will then suddenly detain you when your thoughts were miles away. That can happen at any time of the year. This is a big shrub with tiny leaves and ochre-coloured stems. It has little white flowers for a week or so in August and they double up on the scent. It is not entirely hardy, so give it shelter from cold winds. Strong off-shore winds will not deter it in the least.

Many cistuses have a gummy, airborne fragrance. You associate it with hot summer conditions, but it is not infrequently to be caught in winter. Cistus * cyprius is the natural hybrid that gives me greatest pleasure in this respect. In cold weather, its foliage changes to the colour of oxidised lead. In June, for rather longer than a month, it is covered every morning with a new crop of large white saucer-blooms, each petal having a maroon blotch at its base.

Strongest flower scent on the air in January-February is the lily-of-the-valley fragrance of Mahonia japonica . This has clustered strands of pale yellow flowers surrounded by a ruff of prickle-edged, pinnate leaves. None of the hybrids derived from it share its wonderful scent to any degree. The size of the shrub is easily controlled by a heavy pruning in early spring. This will not in any way prejudice its flowering potential in the following winter, even if the cutting-back operation removes practically every leaf on the shrub.

The spicy scent of winter sweet, Chimonanthus praecox , can also be strong on the air if the weather is mild. This is another large shrub and its foliage is spitefully uncooperative all summer, so that its being deciduous comes as a release. It is commonly raised from seed and a seedling may take six or seven years of growing and cogitating before flowering starts. Also, the quality of the flowers is variable and may be disappointing. But you have to start somewhere. Tuck the shrub away in a warm corner. I should add that it is unlikely to ripen sufficiently to flower at all, ever, in the north of Britain. There are named clones and if these are vegetatively propagated, as they should be, onset of flowering will be much earlier. Some flower earlier than others, and if a range of cultivars is grown this can spread their season from late November to February. I don't want to sound discouraging, but winter sweet is a shrub for the dedicated and sedentary gardener.

Not so the shrub honeysuckle, Lonicera * purpusii , which will flower from early youth, but is no more comely a feature in the summer than winter sweet. Winter- flowering shrubs should be scattered discreetly through the garden so as to cause minimum distress in their off-season, which is at a time of year when we most want to enjoy our gardens by actually being in them. This honeysuckle has a long flowering season, which reaches its peak in late winter. It wafts generously. The flowers themselves are borne in pairs and are off-white in colour. Pruning consists of removing whole branches of old, twiggy growth, so as to encourage the shrub to renew itself. Do this in March, immediately flowering has more or less petered out. Young foliage unfolds early so some of this may have to be sacrificed.

The Chinese witch hazel, Hamamelis mollis (as dull a shrub in summer as any) has a wonderfully individual fragrance. It needs no pruning, but you will want to cut it for the house as soon as it is large enough to be plundered. The light yellow H. * intermedia 'Pallida' is the showiest in a garden setting, with longer petals than most. Brown-flowered kinds are beautiful in the hand, but do not show up well outside. Viburnum farreri and the stiff V. * bodnantense are heavily almond-scented and flower any time from autumn to early spring, though sometimes annoyingly before they have shed their leaves in autumn. The flowers are frost-tender. Pale, slightly grubby pink is the normal colouring (a stronger pink in spring), but I prefer the pure white V. farreri 'Candidissimum', whose young foliage has the additional merit of being a very fresh light green.

The common snowdrop smells of honey and it is a treat to have a big bunch of it by your side in the house. Some crocuses are honey-scented, notably Crocus chrysanthus 'Snow Bunting', which is also one of the earliest of the winter-flowering kinds. My first, this year, opened wide to the sun on January 6 and that is not unusual. But it is often sold untrue to name, whiter but later-flowering and unscented. Very heavily fragrant among the earliest-flowering narcissi is Narcissus tazetta , which gives its name to a whole range of cluster-headed cultivars. My stock came to me from Kew (Wakehurst Place), but it is a variable species, having a wide geographical range. First blooms may open in January but a succession continues into April. The flowers are white (with a cream cup) and the leaves dark green. It is liable to frost damage, so a position against a warm wall is worth sparing.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Paul Kaye
fields.trailText: Paul Kaye
fields.body:
Paul Kaye, 36, is the son of a shopkeeper. Brought up in Wembley, he studied theatre design at Nottingham University and went on to become a graphic designer. In 1996, he transformed himself into Dennis Pennis, the spoof TV reporter who informed Hugh Grant that his acting was wooden and Naomi Campbell that she resembled a duck. After a year, he killed off his alter ego to concentrate on acting. After appearing in two sitcoms, he recently made his drama debut in BBC1's Two Thousand Acres Of Sky. He is separated from his wife, has one son and divides his time between Israel and London.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

Lying in a hammock with my son asleep on my belly.

What is your greatest fear?

Israel going to war.

Which living person do you most admire?

Patrick Vieira. He's the most graceful and fearless football player I think I've ever seen. And he gobbed at Ruddock.

What vehicles do you own?

Drunkenly cycling through Camden recently, I spotted Mark E Smith in a bar, parked up the bike and went in to bother him. I forgot to lock up and some bastard nicked it. So, the answer to your question is none.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?

For my sins, I used to be in-house graphic designer for Spurs back in the late 80s. I figured that sticking the odd subliminal cannon into their merchandising catalogues would keep the evil spirits from my door, but I was wrong. The day before I left, I lit a fag on top of a crowded bus on my way home. The discarded match got stuck in the turn-up of my trousers and I became a human inferno in seconds. I ran screaming off the bus still on fire, and a bloke from a carpet shop put me out with one of his rugs. I got home on the tube in a pair of singed Y-fronts, and bear the scars to this day.

What is your greatest extravagance?

I have a £150-a-week sushi habit.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

No eyelashes, and no real eyelids to speak of, either.

What is your favourite building?

Karnak's Temple, Luxor. Maybe it was the heat, but when I went there I found myself in this little antechamber and was overcome with visions of Egyptian orgies. I masturbated swiftly wearing a Hawaiian shirt and a camera around my neck - which just goes to prove that all tourists are wankers.

Which living person do you most despise and why?

Yigal Amir, Rabin's assassin.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

Don't see the film Don't Look Now when you're 10 years old.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Grate expectations
fields.trailText: Grate expectations
fields.body:
The subject Shredders of raw veg, chocolate, cheese, ginger, fingertips, knuckles.
The basics To grate food is to rub it on a surface with raised cutting edges. Aim: fine particles or shreds. Realisation of aim: variable.
The details Bad news: no one's invented the perfect grater. Good news: there are three basic designs to choose from, all with strong points, as well as weaknesses. Design one: the box grater, a hollow obelisk with a handle on top. Advantages: grates coarse or fine (but ignore the feeble 'slicing' blades); cheap and stable, unlikely to skate across the table. Disadvantages: blades not always the sharpest. Design two: a drum, turned by a handle, with the grateables pressed against it by a hinged clamp. Put stuff in the clamp, press, turn handle. Advantages: knuckle-friendly, works like a dream. Disadvantage: you can only grate little hunks. There are variations on the theme, but the original design beats all. Zyliss makes a good one. Design three: a flat sheet of metal, operated either in midair or with a 'foot' resting on the work surface. Advantages: simplicity and ease of storage. Disadvantages, apart from flaying: the hand-held type takes careful handling, while the footed creatures can shoot across your work surface. In both cases, however, human ingenuity has wrought grate wonders. Footed graters: Good Grips makes one with two plates (and feet) attached by a hinged handle. Stable, versatile and requiring little strength or co-ordination. Hand-held: the miraculous Microplane, a work of genius. Metal chemically etched to make razor-sharp blades that can cut through anything . Expensive, but the gratest.
Where to buy Ordinary graters: anywhere. Good Grips: better kitchenware shops and departments. Microplane: various stockists, including Lakeland (015394 88100).
The easy way out Many food processors have a grater disc. Fast, but hard to control. Grating is manual labour.

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Harvest ale
fields.trailText: Harvest ale
fields.body:
If you've ever wondered why some English beers are called barley wines, JW Lees Harvest Ale will supply the answer. For a start, it's 11.5% alcohol, so it's in the big-hitting red wine league. And, with its rich, sultana fruitiness, you could be forgiven for thinking you were drinking sherry with the addition of hops. The beer is an annual vintage, made from the first Maris Otter barley malt and East Kent Goldings hops of the harvest, then matured in the Manchester brewery until its release in December. The beer will improve with age.

Head brewer Giles Dennis explains that, even though the beer is filtered and pasteurised in the brewery, the alcohol will continue to work with residual sugars to deepen and improve the flavours, something I can confirm from a 'horizontal' tasting of several vintages. The 2000 vintage costs £2.29 a bottle, and is only sold in the north, through Booths and selected wine and beer shops; Guardian readers from elsewhere in the country can, however, order this fantastic brew by calling 0161-834 6850.

webTitle: Superplonk: Malcolm Gluck searches for Valentine's Day bargains

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Gluck searches for Valentine's Day bargains
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck searches for Valentine's Day bargains
fields.body:
Anyone looking to celebrate Valentine's Day with something a little out of the ordinary might care to visit Waitrose and outlay the vast sum of £4.99 on a magnum - yes, that's right, a magnum, or 1.5 litres, two bottles - on a non-vintage Spanish red called Totally Two Thousand Tempranillo. A magnum is a splendid shape to find wine in and, at that price, you can afford to be generous with it. It is a superbly adult brew of warmth and wit, offering plummy fruit allied to great tannins. It is fresh-edged and full of fun, and you can pick it up at £4.99 only until February 4, when it reverts to its usual price of £5.99. It rates 15.5 points out of 20.

Waitrose has several interesting wines also on offer until February 4. Abbotts Ammonite Cte du Roussillon 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99) has superb tannins and texture for the money. There is great elegance and class here, as the wine has something to say for itself. James Herrick Chardonnay Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (16 points, £3.99) is subtle, gently fruity, stylish and well- tailored. It shows a lovely lemon edge as it finishes. Zagara Catarratto Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £3.49), from Sicily, is absurdly underpriced. It is a gooseberry, lemon and melon-fruited wine, classily assembled and so stylish for the money it almost defies belief. It goes well with spicy fish, or, indeed, with the spicy mishmash that characterises ribald conversation at dinner parties these days.

At Tesco, Somerfield and Kwik Save there is Banrock Station Chardonnay 1999. The previous vintage of this wine, indeed the whole Banrock range, seemed to be imitating sticky-toffee pudding, so chewy and blatant was it, but the 1999s redeem themselves somewhat. This chardonnay offers firm, melon fruit with crisp, citric acids, and at £3.99 represents great value for such engaging Aussie style. It rates 15.5 points.

At Tesco, Unwins, Oddbins and Safeway there is Cono Sur Pinot Noir Reserve 1999 (16 points, £6.99). This is chewy, ripe, thick, aromatic, tannic and charmingly lingering. It has a certain richness that recalls Volnay, though this once-wonderful burgundy has no examples nowadays that parade Cono Sur's singular charms for the same money.

The rest of what follows is all to be found at Tesco. Santorini Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £4.99), from the Greek island that some believe was once Atlantis, exhibits delightful richness and acidic freshness combined in a very striking way, accomplishing subtlety with weight. Tre Uve Ultima 1998 (16 points, £5.99) is an Italian red offering a superbly rolling tannic richness geared to run smoothly alongside plum/blackberry fruit. Splendid glugging here. Thandi Elgin Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £6.99), from South Africa, has marvellous dash and richness: creamy, gently spicy, textured, very deep. A food wine, a conversation wine, a bottle to acquire when you wish to demonstrate your versatility and acumen. Camelot 1999 (16 points, £9.99) is a red wine from Sicily, no proceeds from which, as far as I know, go to the lottery operators of this name. You may well expostulate at a tenner for a Sicilian red (I did), but this is a wine of compelling character, made in limited quantities and thus available only at selected branches where the car parks show a preponderance of Volvo estates and the like (call 0800 505555 for details). It shows stunning, earthy fruit of hedgerow complexity and great concentration. The fruit is beautifully orchestrated with the tannins. Kumala Semillon Chardonnay 2000 (15.5 points, £3.99) has deliciously rich, gooseberry fruit, ripe yet balanced. This wine can also be found at Thresher.

And last at Tesco, a syrah from Chile. Caliterra Syrah 1999 (16 points, £5.49) is a very leathery, savoury, pliant wine that oozes charm without being OTT. It is unashamedly modern, yet not brash or too full of itself. It is one of those wines I wish I encountered more when I went out to eat, at restaurants or friends' homes, for it is deliciously inexpensive when compared with many a shiraz, and it is a wine you can toy with as you talk between mouthfuls.

For the latest wine news, or to email Malcolm Gluck, visit www.superplonk.com.

fields.headline: Super Bowls
fields.standfirst: There's something about a hot, home-made soup that warms both body and soul in winter, says Jeremy Lee. It is comfort food of the highest order - and all the better for being so relatively simple to prepare
fields.trailText: There's something about a hot, home-made soup that warms both body and soul in winter, says Jeremy Lee. It is comfort food of the highest order - and all the better for being so relatively simple to prepare
fields.body:
Don't get me wrong - any visit home is a grand treat: the folks, the house, and great grub, too. However, there is an oddity to the heating in my parents' home. When the fire in the big room is lit, it tells the thermostat how warm the room is. The heating then promptly turns itself off - throughout the house. As if that weren't bad enough, Ma and Pa are now so used to it that they often just forget to put the heating on at all, leaving us to wander the house in shivering disbelief.

It so happens, however, that I think a proper winter is a good thing - just so long as the freezing cold stays where it is meant to: outside. I love the real changes of real seasons, and the winter has real food to go with it. Food that cooks gently and slowly, all the while filling the house with rich smells that tickle the nostril and give off a general feeling of well-being.

All recipes serve six.

PASTA E CECI It is well worth searching out Spanish chickpeas, garbanzo, for this recipe, as they are immeasurably superior to any others that I can think of. 150g dried chickpeas, soaked for 24 hours
200g unsmoked bacon (or pancetta)
4 cloves garlic, peeled
6 tbsp olive oil
1 small sprig fresh rosemary, leaves picked
150g tinned whole tomatoes, roughly chopped
220g dried pasta such as rigatoni or penne
3-4 tbsp fresh Parmesan, grated
Sea salt and black pepper

Discard the water in which the chickpeas have been soaking, and give the drained pulses a thorough rinse under cold running water. Put the prepared pulses in a heavy- bottomed pot, along with the bacon, add enough water to cover and bring to a boil. Turn down the flame, and simmer the chickpea mixture over a gentle heat for an hour and a half to two hours, until the chickpeas have softened.

In a separate pan, fry the garlic in the olive oil, then remove and discard it once it has browned. Add the picked rosemary leaves and the chopped tomatoes to the pan, then reduce the heat and cook at a steady bubble until the oil splits from the tomatoes.

Drain the chickpeas and bacon, and add these to the tomato mixture, along with a further 100-200ml of water. Stir together, bring up to a boil, then cook over a gentle heat for another 15 minutes.

Now tip in the pasta, season and cook for another 12-15 minutes, until the pasta is just cooked. Remove one third of the soup mix from the pan, and liquidise in a blender. Return the whizzed-up soup to the pot, and cook at a simmer, stirring every now and then, for another 10 minutes. Add the Parmesan and serve.

YELLOW SPLIT-PEA SOUP

2 onions
1 medium carrot
1 stick celery
180g yellow split peas
1 green ham hock
1 bayleaf
Sea salt and black pepper

To serve

Soft, white, sliced bread
1 small handful flat-leaf parsley, washed and picked

Peel all the vegetables and chop them into small pieces. Heat a large, heavy-bottomed pan, add a little oil, and in it fry the vegetables for a few minutes. Add the split peas and fry for a few minutes more, stirring to ensure that they are all coated in the oil.

Pour in 1.5 litres of cold water, add the ham hock and bayleaf, then season generously. Bring up to a very gentle simmer, and spoon off any scum that rises to the surface. Leave the soup to tick over at a gentle simmer for two hours or so, then remove the hock and, once it is cool enough to handle, cut off the meat, chop it into small pieces and set to one side.

There are two schools of thought as to how to serve such a soup - that is, smooth or not - but I don't really have a preference: I like it either way, depending on my mood. Blend the finished soup, by all means, or serve it rough and ready as it is. The spilt peas will have all but disintegrated by the end of the cooking process, anyway.

Just before spooning the soup into bowls, cut up the bread into cubes and fry in light oil and butter until crisp. Finely chop the parsley, and stir this into the soup, along with the meat and the croutons.

JERUSALEM ARTICHOKE AND CEPES SOUP Deeply satisfying.

20g dried cepes (or porcini)
1 small floury potato
1kg Jerusalem artichokes
3 shallots, finely chopped
500ml light chicken stock (or water)
10 hazelnuts, roasted and skinned
150ml whole milk
Sea salt and milled white pepper
1 small handful parsley, chopped

Soak the mushrooms in warm water or stock for 20 minutes. Peel the potato and artichokes, and rinse them under cold running water. Fry the shallots in a little butter. Squeeze dry the porcini, chop them small, add to the shallots and stew gently for 10 minutes or so without colouring.

Roughly chop the artichokes and potato, and add these to the pot. Pour in the stock and the nuts, and simmer for 30 minutes or so, until the vegetables are cooked. Liquidise the mixture, then return it to the pot and add the milk. Bring up to a simmer and adjust the seasoning. If the soup is too thick, add a little more milk and water. Just before serving, stir in the parsley.

MULLIGATAWNY I am immensely fond of this curious soup that once featured so regularly on many a menu.

2 onions
60g unsalted butter
1 tbsp tomato purée
1 tbsp mild curry powder
250g tinned tomatoes
4 cloves
3 green chillies
1 red pepper
3 cloves garlic
250g lentils (Puy work very well)
40g seedless raisins
1 tsp brown sugar
1.4 litres chicken stock
Sea salt and black pepper

Peel and finely chop the onions, then fry them very gently in the butter until just golden. Add the tomato purée and curry powder, and continue frying gently for 15 minutes, stirring often. Put the tinned tomatoes, cloves, chillies, red pepper and garlic into a liquidiser, and render to a pulp. Pour this into the cooking pan, and simmer until the contents have thickened to a paste-like consistency and taken on a slightly darker hue.

Put the lentils in a sieve and rinse them thoroughly under cold running water. Tip the cleaned lentils into the pot, along with the raisins and sugar, then pour in the stock and bring the soup up to a boil. Skim off any foam that appears on the surface, then reduce the heat to a simmer. Season generously, cover the pot, and leave to cook gently for an hour and a half.

You may be tempted to liquidise the cooked soup, so making it smooth, but it is really not necessary. Serve with a swirl of yoghurt into which you have mixed some chopped fresh mint.

Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: Not just a pretty place...
fields.standfirst: Behind many fashion shoots with supermodels such as Kate Moss, there is a glamorous location - and sometimes this just happens to be where someone lives. So what does it take to make a home a hot property? Lesley Gillilan reports
fields.trailText: Behind many fashion shoots with supermodels such as Kate Moss, there is a glamorous location - and sometimes this just happens to be where someone lives. So what does it take to make a home a hot property? Lesley Gillilan reports
fields.body:
There was a spell, in the early 90s, when Naomi Tate's apartment, a faux Villa Medici in mid-Kensington, was the in place with fashion photographers. "Everyone, but everyone, wanted it, darling," says her agent, Anna Darby, of Lavish Locations. But a flurry of high-profile shoots was followed by a long, long silence. When everyone, but everyone, wanted pristine minimalism, Tate's "faded palazzo", with its raw, variegated plaster walls and rich mélange of antique textiles, dropped off the hot list like a stone.

"There were clients who still wanted to use it, but only if Tate could be persuaded to paint her walls white," says Darby. "Of course, she told me to go forth and multiply. So, as a fashion-location, the place died a death." Poor Naomi. Well, yes. And no. The fashion location market, like fashion itself, is a whimsical trade, subject to a constant, shifting cycle of prevailing trends. A few seasons later, and not only has minimalism been "shagged to death, darling", but Tate's flat is back in vogue (indeed, in Vogue). "Suddenly, it took off again," squeals Darby. "Now it's gone completely mad."

Tate's recent clients include Tatler, Harpers & Queen, German Elle, various fashion advertising agencies ("I don't always pay much attention to who they are," she admits) and the photographer Corinne Day, who spent a day in her living room with Kate Moss shooting fashion stills for Vogue's Gold issue, published last December.

For this, Day shot Moss lying on a bed of old gold brocade in a Sportmax tinsel mini; and, in another photograph, her legs, clad in Paco Rabanne's slashed chain-mail hipsters, sprawled across frayed damask upholstery. Moss also squatted on the original parquet flooring in £2,000-worth of sequinned "heirloom material"; perched on the edge of a stool, eating what looks like an M&S sandwich, in nothing but Roberto Cavalli lingerie, an "amazing" diamanté suspender belt and vintage Vivienne Westwood boots. Behind her, a pair of disintegrating red silk curtains (circa 1800) fall into crumpled folds on to an antique Persian rug; there's a glimpse of genuine Victorian plaster; a hint of radiator piping - all lit by a pale wash of what looks like natural sunlight (though photographic lighting can fake it where necessary).

Tate, a ballet dancer, did not set out to turn her apartment into a photography location. The Villa Medici number in her house was, after all, her own personal expression of home. But later, when a magazine article inspired her to try letting it out to photographers and film production companies, the place turned out to have everything they needed: big open spaces, lots of light, atmosphere and interesting photogenic features (period fireplaces, garden statuary, and pale but interesting walls are popular with fashion clients).

Film companies tend to pay more, but, says Tate, they are "extremely demanding - they just take over". Fashion stills and other product photography is far less obtrusive(shorter hours, fewer people). And though it costs nothing to register with a location agency such as Lavish, a hot property on their books can net two or three shoots a week, at anything between £500 and £1,000 a day.

So what, in the current scheme of things, constitutes a hot property? According to Anna Darby (who has thousands of registered locations, including numerous private houses suited to film and fashion), Tate's improved fortunes are down to a recent rush on "shabby chic", which, she explains, is "totally, utterly, faded grandeur" - Decadence with attitude, in other words.

"If there are ripped curtains, they must be expensive ripped curtains," says Darby. If the walls are pocked and the paintwork peeling, all the better - especially if they are authentic Georgian or Victorian. Cobwebs and cracked windows? Lovely. "Dereliction looks so good with luxury clothes," she explains.

Within the shabby chic class, there are other sub-categories, such as "stately" - decaying mansion, with distressed historic paintwork - and "grunge" - rat-infested blocks, 50s housing estates, scabby industrial spaces, damp basements, etc.

According to Tiffany Parish of rival agency Amazing Space, grunge is very big right now, as is anything that looks vaguely American (to give a shoot that Chicago feel, say, you might get a high-rise apartment in, er, Croydon. New England? A clapboard cottage in Essex). But one of the biggest fashion location stories for this season is retro - "completely, utterly authentic" properties from the 50s, 60s or 70s. And if you were under the illusion that fashion models were always jetting off to exotic places (you know the sort of thing: the Ice Hotel in Jukkasjarvi or a desert hut in Ngamiland), then think again - one of Parish's hot spaces right now is a 70s house in the south London suburb of Streatham.

Home to artist Celeste Braithwaite, it doesn't look much from the outside (architecturally, it is akin to a postwar municipal office in the public utilities sector). The inside is not very pretty, either - unless you happen to like Artex and varnished pine. But the property's untouched 70s features (indoor pool with poolside cocktail area, original kitchen units, tan leatherette seduction sofa with built-in drinks cabinet and sound-system) make it the ultimate retro fashion location.

Like Naomi Tate, Braithwaite did not set out to attract photographers, and those alluring fees, to her home. She got into location work through a friend in television, who instantly spotted the house's potential. And though the sideline has taken a while to get going, her home provides an irregular but solid income.

Her first booking was for an American magazine, Mademoiselle, involving "a whole load of people from LA". She's since had German Cosmopolitan and Harvey Nichols (which shot a surreal magazine advertisement there that consisted of unpopulated interiors on to which knitted bears were later superimposed). The most recent job is a forthcoming Gap fashion advertisement for Wallpaper* magazine, in which a group of nine models frolic around the swimming pool. As always, popular areas were the kitchen, the hallway and the naff-but-groovy bathroom with its yellow circular bath (roughly the colour of egg yolk) and brown carpet.

By fashion-shoot standards, the Gap job involved an unusually large crowd ("loads of hairdressers, make-up artists, a catering truck"). But that's nothing when compared with a film crew. A television ad filmed in the house for a Polish internet bank involved at least 30 people, miles of wires and cables, a dog, a cockatiel, and some redecoration. "It was the Polish crew that painted the kitchen," says Braithwaite, indicating an area of pond-weed green that used to be knotty pine. They also papered the hall - in 70s-style vinyl (she loves it). And there are other perks: "The majority of clients leave the place tidier than it was before," says Braithwaite.

Though the house is popular now, Braithwaite is the first to recognise that the passing of fashion's recent 70s phase will mean it will bring in less location work. And, anyway, she doesn't get anywhere near the conveyor belts of clients who go in and out of Trevyn McDowell's vast converted warehouse in Clerkenwell, east London. It is a minimalist space, says Anna Darby, who represents this property, too, but it is, she insists, "feminine minimalist - minimalism with warmth". Even so, no photographer worth their salt would be able to resist a couple of thousand square foot of light, white modernism.In fact, McDowell's apartment, and others like it, are the 21st-century equivalent of castles and stately homes - properties with a shelf life, even in fashion.

McDowell, an actress (she played Doctor Lydgate's wife in the BBC's adaptation of Middlemarch) turned designer, runs Site Specific, a company that specialises in "fit-outs" for warehouse conversions. She registered her property with a location agency as a way of dealing with all the space-seeking photographers who kept ringing on her doorbell ("Agencies take care of all the contracts and insurance"). Her home has since been hired out for "catalogue work, pop videos, celebrity interviews, loads of fashion shoots" (Marie Claire, Debenhams, Next, M&S, etc).

When shoots are in progress, McDowell tends to hide away in an office below the living space: "If I pop upstairs to get a jumper or something, I'll often find a male model in the bath or someone in the bed. It's quite invasive. Basically, you've got a big bunch of strangers in your home doing their own thing - you have to be able to cope with the disruption, and the wear and tear." There is nothing predictable about the disruption, either. "I might have three shoots in one week and then nothing for two months."

There are some properties, however, that will never get used. What puts Anna Darby off?

"Double yellow lines outside the house. Tiny rooms - rooms full of Damien Hirsts [familiar artworks present copyright problems]. People who ask, 'Will there be much damage to my lovely cream carpet?' The Outer Hebrides. Photographers will travel outside London, but there are limits."

Even if none of these turn-offs applies, the fashion-location market is not an easy one to satisfy. Can you, for example, meet the enduring demand for concrete Brutalism ("slightly sinister - very Russian looking")? Or the new "Dallas look with a touch of the 2000s" (as seen in recent Versace ads, it's vaguely Italian-Baroque, all marble, chandeliers, real fur and big, expensive dogs)? And has anyone out there got a 30s house, panelled in light oak, slightly reminiscent of Citizen Kane or a Philip Marlowe movie; could be America, but preferably Hertfordshire? "Everyone, but everyone, is asking for Deco Retro."

"It was the Polish crew that painted the kitchen," says Braithwaite, indicating an area of pond-weed green that used to be knotty pine. They also papered the hall - in 70s-style vinyl (she loves it). And there are other perks: "The majority of clients leave the place tidier than it was before," says Braithwaite. Though the house is popular now, Braithwaite is the first to recognise that the passing of fashion's recent 70s phase will mean it will bring in less location work. And, anyway, she doesn't get anywhere near the conveyor belts of clients who go in and out of Trevyn McDowell's vast converted warehouse in Clerkenwell, east London. It is a minimalist space, says Anna Darby, who represents this property, too, but it is, she insists, "feminine minimalist - minimalism with warmth". Even so, no photographer worth their salt would be able to resist a couple of thousand square foot of light, white modernism.In fact, McDowell's apartment, and others like it, are the 21st-century equivalent of castles and stately homes - properties with a shelf life, even in fashion. McDowell, an actress (she played Doctor Lydgate's wife in the BBC's adaptation of Middlemarch) turned designer, runs Site Specific, a company that specialises in "fit-outs" for warehouse conversions. She registered her property with a location agency as a way of dealing with all the space-seeking photographers who kept ringing on her doorbell ("Agencies take care of all the contracts and insurance"). Her home has since been hired out for "catalogue work, pop videos, celebrity interviews, loads of fashion shoots" (Marie Claire, Debenhams, Next, M&S, etc). When shoots are in progress, McDowell tends to hide away in an office below the living space: "If I pop upstairs to get a jumper or something, I'll often find a male model in the bath or someone in the bed. It's quite invasive. Basically, you've got a big bunch of strangers in your home doing their own thing - you have to be able to cope with the disruption, and the wear and tear." There is nothing predictable about the disruption, either. "I might have three shoots in one week and then nothing for two months." There are some properties, however, that will never get used. What puts Anna Darby off? "Double yellow lines outside the house. Tiny rooms - rooms full of Damien Hirsts [familiar artworks present copyright problems]. People who ask, 'Will there be much damage to my lovely cream carpet?' The Outer Hebrides. Photographers will travel outside London, but there are limits." Even if none of these turn-offs applies, the fashion-location market is not an easy one to satisfy. Can you, for example, meet the enduring demand for concrete Brutalism ("slightly sinister - very Russian looking")? Or the new "Dallas look with a touch of the 2000s" (as seen in recent Versace ads, it's vaguely Italian-Baroque, all marble, chandeliers, real fur and big, expensive dogs)? And has anyone out there got a 30s house, panelled in light oak, slightly reminiscent of Citizen Kane or a Philip Marlowe movie; could be America, but preferably Hertfordshire? "Everyone, but everyone, is asking for Deco Retro."

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Some letters
fields.body:
I particularly enjoyed Dave Eggers's assault on the over and inappropriate use of the word irony (On Second Thoughts, January 20). Unfortunately, he failed to give an example of its correct usage. Now, isn't that ironic?

Stephen Firn

London SW20

Julie Burchill is, as ever, heavy-handed and lacking in compassion (January 20). But, having had one or two male-to-female transsexuals as friends and longing to be thought of as fair-minded, their apparent narrow, male view of what constitutes femininity bewilders me. I have come to the conclusion that we and they have made a big mistake, and that our descendants will shake their heads in disbelief when they consider that all we had to offer was mutilation.

Paul Thompson

Scone, Scotland

Perhaps, Julie, the NHS should deal only with broken legs or the odd heart transplant. I write not as a transsexual but as a wife to one. Yes, I have been through all the pain, anger and disgust at being told that my man could no longer be a man. Although we are separated, she is still my best friend. I said 'she', for that is what she is. Yes, she has put me and others through a fair bit of trauma, but it takes guts to do what she has done - and she is a better person for it. I don't expect you to understand, but this is real; the NHS does not give out gender reassignment operations like Smarties.

I've heard that the NHS now helps people with narrow minds. Don't worry, Julie, the waiting list is only five years.

Miss Pat Fraser

Syston, Leicester

As a transsexual woman, I felt left out. Julie Burchill had insulted nearly everyone, yet never even sneered in my direction - until last week. Her tirade was a real let-down. The majority of us are not middle-aged, not married and don't wear silly blouses, and she missed out all the transsexual men (who don't wear blouses at all). Her entertaining rants are rarely disrupted by facts, so I didn't expect her to recognise that gender reassignment surgery saves money for the public purse, but I am devastated by her claim that there are 7,000 operations a year, when the real figure is about 100.

At her hyperbolic best, she'd have multiplied our numbers by thousands or millions, rather than a measly 70. Instead, we're stuck being 1 in 10,000 of the population, rare enough still to have some shock value to those like Julie Burchill who've apparently never met us.

Claire McNab, vice-president, Press For Change

Bradford, West Yorkshire

If Alexander Chancellor groups single mothers together with drug addicts and criminals (January 20), why does anyone have time to complain about Julie Burchill?

Dave Scrubber

kyliesaidtojason@excite.co.uk

Three pans to make mashed potatoes (Food, January 20)? What planet is Jeremy Lee inhabiting? But then, I have no assistants and save time using a microwave. He should try it some time.

Betty Bezant

Bournville, Birmingham

How wonderful that there is wheelchair access at Tabla (Eating Out, January 20). Shame that the toilet is inaccessible. Are able-bodied diners also denied toilet access, or do they possess unusually large bladders?

Mrs Dianne Watterton

Greasby, Wirral

Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
