As darkness fell, the men in C team reported for the night shift at the main station just off the Grand Canal and began settling down to play cards, watch TV, read the sports pages or doze on their bunkbeds. With the Christmas and New Year festivities long over and the carnival several weeks off, the old town centre was relatively empty. This inactivity, with the cold, damp, still air, made the risk of fire thankfully low. At 9pm the phone rang. A policeman patrolling the canals near Venice's 18th-century opera house, La Fenice, had seen smoke coming from somewhere near the theatre. As the alarm went off, the men ran down to their fire boats. "We knew that if a fire had started anywhere near or in the theatre, we had to act fast," says Commandante Alfio Pini, head of the Vigili del Fuoco. "The square where the theatre stands, in one of the oldest parts of Venice, is very small and crowded with old, mainly wooden buildings, restaurants, bars, hotels and homes all very close together, and the risk of a fire spreading fast is enormous." The canals and a small lagoon surrounding a major part of the theatre had recently been drained for the first time in 40 years for dredging and restoration work, and this would hinder access to the area and eliminate the nearest supply of canal water. When the team arrived at Campo San Fantin less than three minutes after 9pm, flames were shooting from an upstairs window at the side of La Fenice. By 9.10pm, the whole upper floor was a fireball. Here was every Venetian's nightmare come true. Most visitors to Venice remain unaware that, although the city is built on water and regularly flooded by high tides, fire is the most dreaded of all disasters. There were, until very recently, no fire hydrants in the streets. Without space on firm ground to erect a 100ft hydraulic ladder, firefighters here still rely on old-fashioned extending wooden ladders, which usually reach low levels only; the amount of equipment that can be transported on their fire boats is limited; and when high tides swell, the canals boats often have difficulty passing under many of the bridges. That night, outside La Fenice, the firefighters were forced to run their hoses from more distant canals, only to have insufficient pressure to tackle the spreading blaze. One bystander likened it to "trying to put out the fires of hell with a garden hose". At 9.20pm, the men watched helplessly as the floors and supporting structures of the sumptuous rococo salons and ornately gilded multi-tiered auditorium crashed in, and the stage collapsed in a roar of flames, showering the neighbourhood with embers."We only just managed to get clear when the floor and stage caved in - we saved ourselves by a hair," recalls one fireman. Pini and his men knew almost from the outset that there was no choice but to let La Fenice burn to the ground. They evacuated the surrounding buildings and then turned their hoses on them to prevent the fire from spreading. "We had to choose between the theatre and the town: it was either save La Fenice or save Venice. So we switched from attack to control tactics. We got back-up from the mainland fire services, including a helicopter to collect water from the lagoon and spray the area from above. Luckily, there was no wind that night, which prevented a disaster. It was the worst fire the Vigili has ever worked on." He told his cellmate that the destruction of the theatre "was a question of contracts" and that he carried out the arson because he needed the money. He also named the people who had paid him. At this point the prosecutor barred the cellmate from giving further evidence on the grounds that the matter was under investigation, leaving yet another loose end to be tied up in the trial, which is set to continue until Easter, if not autumn. Although his photographs have been used as forensic evidence, Arici - like many of those familiar with the case - dismisses both the "mafia connection" and the arson theory as speculative rubbish. At a computer in his studio, he clicks through his reportage of the blaze. Although the rapid spread of the flames becomes more evident with each close-up, he claims the pictures do not prove anything. "Some experts say the only way a fire could travel so fast from one side of the theatre to the other, with a wall in between, is if there were two, maybe three separate fires. Well, it may appear so, but with the inflammable material stored there, the dry, honeycombed wood throughout, and the draught from the open doors, the fast crossover makes complete sense." Arici believes that the prosecutor is misguided in charging the two electricians with arson, and is convinced that the fire was nothing more sinister than a tragic combination of circumstances. "The danger involved in setting fire to a theatre, especially one with such a confusing layout as La Fenice, would put off anybody. I've known it for 20 years and was always getting lost. It was a rabbit warren. They couldn't have started a fire in that area and been sure of escaping in time through the labyrinth of staircases, corridors, steps, doors, turnings, dead ends. Being late with the renovation, they tried to speed things up a bit, were perhaps using something like a blowtorch, and some sparks fell somewhere. Or maybe they did want to do a little damage, an excuse to extend the deadline, and got scared when things went out of control. To destroy a whole theatre and risk your life just to avoid paying a fine of a few million lire would be unbelievable. The more important issue is that lack of security remains a fact, whether this was an accident or not." And there, Arici has put his finger on far more shameful aspects of the case. No one knows more about the scandalously lax administrative standards and wanton disregard for the theatre's security than the stage door-keeper and "concierge", Gilberto Paggiaro. To his dismay, Paggiaro, who has worked at La Fenice since 1984, has been charged with "culpable negligence", along with the theatre's former general manager, its chief administrative supremo, the former mayor Massimo Cacciari (in his capacity at the time as representing the building's owners, the city council) and five surveyors and engineers, who are accused of failing to implement adequate safety measures during the theatre's refurbishment. As far as Paggiaro is concerned, the administrative rot was all-pervasive and nothing new. "There has always been a problem with staffing La Fenice," he says. "For years I'd been telling the management that I'm often alone on duty. Although there are three other caretakers, for many reasons they may not be there, and one man cannot properly supervise the theatre's safety. Their answer was always, 'It's too expensive to hire more staff.'" Between August 1995 and January 1996, Paggiaro was under added pressure, having to monitor the comings and goings of the 50 staff members who had continued working in the theatre's offices for the duration of the refurbishment, while also keeping an eye on a daily influx of another 50 or more strangers - builders on varying shifts from different firms and casual shift workers whom he didn't recognise, as well as tourists who would wander in to look around and take photographs. "The smoke alarm, which was installed in front of my office, used to go off with fumes from building works, so they had unplugged it weeks earlier. But no one thought it important to have a fireman on duty through the night, or to arrange for a hose to be connected to a central water supply since the surrounding canals were empty, just in case something happened." Paggiaro's claims are backed up by recent evidence given by an engineer who was in charge of managing the site until the builders moved in. The engineer, who had tested the theatre's old firefighting equipment shortly before it was disconnected and found it in perfect working order, had at the time suggested that some empty cisterns, buried for years under the building but still watertight, could be used now to provide 200,000 litres of water in case of emergency. His proposal was not taken seriously, not even when, on January 12, a fire broke out following the overheating of metal on a piece of equipment that had been placed too close to a wooden beam. On that occasion, the fire had been put out quickly, because workmen were still on the site. Only a month previously, says Paggiaro, a surveyor from the Prefect's office began drawing up revised safety regulations. "Even then, the administrators put off any decision about implementing those rules. They said it wasn't urgent, and that the various building firms should take responsibility for safety. The builders said it was the theatre's responsibility. Each one passed the buck to the other." On the night of January 29, Paggiaro began making his safety rounds at about 8.30pm when he smelled smoke."I thought it was outside, perhaps from one of the restaurants next door. I looked into the street but saw nothing. It was strong enough for me to put a handkerchief to my mouth, but I carried on with my rounds. All at once, I saw flames and lots of smoke reflected in a mirror on an upstairs landing outside the Salle Apollinée." Running downstairs to his office, he phoned the Vigili del Fuoco, which told him that the incident had already been reported. By then, the smoke was getting thicker and sparks were flying. "I waited a few minutes for the firemen, and when they didn't come I got frightened and went out into the square - and ran into Graziano Arici taking pictures of the blaze." What upsets him most, as an experienced veteran employee of the theatre, is the suggestion that he was negligent in reporting the blaze early enough because he was asleep, drunk or watching TV when it began."Had the smoke detector not been disconnected, I obviously would have known something was wrong and raised the alarm far earlier." The majority of Venetians regard the Fenice affair with weary resignation. Shock and sadness over the disaster, followed by a collective determination to triumph over adversity, has been superseded either by embarrassment or a near cynical indifference. Even the whodunnit element has lost its grip, as the trial drags into its fourth year, and all 10 defendants, apart from the two electricians, have moved on to other jobs. Besides, they now have a new focus for their anger: the five-year debacle over the rebuilding of La Fenice. Today, the site is little more than a vast, spectral ruin, desolate as a war zone, open to the sky, its facade and outer walls clad in scaffolding, plastic sheeting, and boarded up outside. Inside, large cranes, transported, like all materials and machinery in Venice, piecemeal by boat along the canals and assembled on site, stand idle in the swirling winter fog. Underfoot, the ground, mostly rubble, remains soggy after recent weeks of unusually severe "aqua alta" - the annual high tides that are steadily eating away at Venice's fragile and diseased substructure. Here a fragment of marble, there an isolated neo-classical column propped up by wooden posts, elsewhere a ragged section of dusty-pink fresco are poignant reminders of what was lost and how much has yet to be rebuilt. With few builders on the site and no work apparently in progress due to a new, acrimonious dispute over costs and scheduling between the German-Italian construction firm, Holzmann-Romagnoli, and the town council, the sense of doom is as crushing as an operatic tragedy.  Read the rest of this article here

webTitle: David McKie on cleaning up cliches

fields.headline: Festering saws
fields.standfirst: David McKie on... the need to clean up the cliches
fields.trailText: We need to clean up the journalistic cliches.
fields.body:
I have a confession to make. Call me an old curmudgeon, but I sometimes think that 18th-century doctors had the right idea when they treated patients with leeches. Not, as I understand it, with any old leeches, but with a particular brand called hirudo medicinalis, the European medicinal leech (the Encyclopaedia Britannica has a picture of it looking very unpleasant indeed). The leech is a species of worm - we know of around 300 subspecies - with small suckers at the anterior end and large suckers at the posterior. There is nothing very endearing about them. But for much of the 19th century many doctors believed you could not beat leeches for sucking all kinds of infection out of the system. Mention skin disease, tumours, whooping cough, gout, even mental illness, and a leech would swiftly be sent for.

Am I alone in thinking that we sometimes need some kind of leech equivalent to get to work on the words and phrases journalists use, sucking infections out of the system? Don't get me wrong, but trawling every day through the newspapers, I am increasingly inclined to think that what once were fresh new catchphrases have become a kind of infectious disease. Even otherwise lively and original writers apparently cannot stop using them. Yes, since you ask: all newspapers, this one included. One of our three or four most accomplished writers used "since you ask" in a column this week.

For instance: "Call me an old fogey/Tractarian/Luton Town supporter, but..." This suggests an essentially matey approach, cushioning the blow to which a reader might otherwise be provoked by a controversial assertion - though in practice, like "Am I alone in believing... ?" it is nowadays mostly used to preface a statement for which the writer expects near-consensual agreement. A letter to the Daily Telegraph, for instance, might start: "Am I alone in thinking Mr Blair's decision to recall Peter Mandelson to the cabinet after his first misadventure demonstrates his essential weakness?" A letter to the Guardian might say: "Call me hard-hearted, but I think Peter Mandelson deserves all he gets."

The most extreme example of this warding-off practice, and the most hypocritical, is that made famous by Denis Healey, who used the words "with the greatest respect" or, even more menacingly, "with the very greatest respect", to preface some mighty insult. Another recent infection of the warding-off kind is "I have a confession to make". The words that follow are sometimes properly penitent. But quite as often what is confessed is something the writer is eager to boast about ("I have to confess I never expected such a bulging postbag as followed my piece on warts"). There may be times when it is appropriate for a writer to ward off expected criticism. But "call me a... " and "am I alone...?" are well past their sell-by dates.

As, indeed, is "well past its sell-by date". When it was first applied to subjects other than groceries, it had a tang of freshness about it. "That," a good few columnists must have thought to themselves when they first saw it, "is a phrase to kill for." (Or to die for. These two wizened cliches mean much the same.)

The same, I'm afraid, now goes for the practice of inserting into an otherwise orthodox sentence the interjection "hey", as in: "Yes, Vladimir Putin is doing odious things in Chechnya - but hey, who cares when Puff Daddy's in town!"

The persistence of these infections must surprise even literary epidemiologists. Optimists might have supposed that Harold Wilson's incurable habit of opening sentences with "at the end of the day" would have put that usage to sleep, but still it crops up even in literate newspapers. It seems odd that the expression "don't get me wrong" should ever get past a sub-editor. When I first started in newspapers I was sharply rebuked for writing of "a scene of indescribable chaos". "If you can't describe it, laddie," said the gnarled old sub (when, I think of it now, he must have been all of 37) "you shouldn't be working here." If you have to ask readers not to get you wrong, it means you have failed to make yourself plain in the first place.

To be fair - there's another one - even the most brilliant of coinages can become infected in time. One treasures those that survive because nobody copied them. I have a confession to make: I have twice pinched a formula from Bernard Levin when he used to write columns to die for. "Wild horses," he wrote, "would not drag from me the name of my informant, who was... " Then he named him. There's another once clever but nowadays played-out device which holds out the hope of some really juicy morsel of gossip, and then at the very last moment withholds it. To wit: "I have just discovered the most extraordinary secret about Michael Portillo. It seems that he tells his friends... but alas, I seem to have run out of space."

In my view, those who use this device after so much previous employment deserve not just to have leeches stuck to them, but to undergo ancient torments such as the one where... but alas, I seem to have run out of space.

 Ian Mayes is away.

webTitle: Planting a rainbow: the beautiful deception

fields.headline: Planting a rainbow: the beautiful deception
fields.standfirst: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
Flowers and their Colours

First and foremost, flowers attract us by their colours. But of course it is not us they are trying so hard to attract: it is the birds, the butterflies, the insects, and those legendary night-pollinating moths. If a flower garden gives me the impression that it is flowering there for my pleasure and benefit, it is engaged in a deception. And if I fall for that deception, I am like someone who, entering a crowded room, believes that all eyes are upon him, when in fact all eyes are upon the swarm of bees visible just over his shoulder.

"How beautiful are the retired flowers!" wrote Keats in a famous passage; "how they would lose their beauty were they to throng into the highway crying out, 'Admire me, I am a violet! Dote upon me, I am a primrose!' " In fact that is exactly what the flowers, even the retired flowers, are saying to their pollinators. Or if not that, then they are saying something coarser.

And their colours, which provoke in us such a profound and complex response, were once their exclusive property. No one saw such colours, unless it was in a flower, or a gemstone, or some extraordinary artifice such as purple-dyed cloth. Some flowers may have disturbed or repelled by their mysterious or obscene shapes, but none, surely, was thought ugly for its colour. Sad, perhaps. But never ugly.

Today some makers of gardens are so browbeaten by colour snobbery that they settle for a garden in which all flowers are excluded, or they take nervous care to check which flowers, which colours, are okay. Gardening writers, in the hope of giving the weight of science to their reflections, talk about combinations of complementary colours, and sometimes even refer to the colour wheel. But this is uncandid taste masquerading as high theory.

There is no point in asking, in the abstract, whether burnt orange will look well alongside vermilion. A garden is not a canvas, and even with a canvas the question has no answer. How large a patch of burnt orange, in relation to how large a patch of vermilion - and what else is going on within the proposed colour field? Is the gardener who thinks of placing a burnt orange flower beside a vermilion one taking into account the colour and relative importance of the leaves? Or is it assumed that all greens are somehow factored out by the retina?

Gardening is quite unlike painting, but there are things one can learn from the painter nevertheless. John Gage, the great historian of colour theory, tells a story of Turner and Constable exhibiting their paintings side by side in 1832 in the crowded conditions of Somerset House. Painters in these exhibitions specialised in last-minute tricks to ensure that their works looked well. On this occasion Constable found "the red robes of the dignitaries in his picture of the Opening of Waterloo Bridge (London, National Gallery) cast into obscurity by the wafer of red sealing wax which Turner applied to the water of his cool green sea piece next to it, Helvoetsluys, and later painted into the form of a buoy. 'He has been here,' said Constable when he saw it, 'and fired a gun.' "

Some small flowers possess this ability to "fire a gun": (no 1) Pheasant's Eye, the hardy annual Adonis aestivalis , is a flower with the force of a concentrated blood-red anemone - a small ranunculus, in other words. The kind of flower you would expect to find in a Mughal miniature, or in the border of a Book of Hours. You give it a place to grow. It comes back year after year, an unerring shot.

And in such company who could object to the classic (no 2) Cornflower, Centaurea cyanus , a flower more often seen in the shops these days than ever before. The gardener should not be too proud to learn from the florist, or to plant what is so obviously beautiful people forget to recommend it; in this case, the flower which defined a certain range of blue. I intend this year (taking a tip from the florist's bucket) to try out (no 3) the Safflower, Carthamus tinctorius , whose other name, Saffron Thistle, reminds us what it is, that orange thistle which sometimes, on reaching London, seems to have had too crushing a ride.

It is the full orange I want, no lame excuse for a hue. People are sometimes under the illusion that the flowers they find ugly, or over-assertive, are the ones that have been genetically modified. In point of fact the flowers they find ugly are very often orange, like the incomparable (no 4) California Poppy, Eschscholzia californica . When I first invited visitors to my garden, they turned the corner and very loudly and flatly declared, "I don't like that." Perhaps I had let it seed itself too promiscuously, but I have charted its favour in the last decade. Today I think people would say more tactfully: "Orange can sometimes be so difficult to place."

It means the same thing. It means I don't like orange: it "fires a gun". But I remember one summer, in the august Venetian courtyard of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, all the windowboxes had been filled with trailing (no 5) Nasturtiums, Tropaeolum minus , the seed we are given to plant as children because it is large enough to handle individually: it is childproof. For this list I choose the admirable "Alaska" with its variegated leaves, but in my garden we try to accommodate any variety we can find.

Nor do I like a year to pass without the orange ice-lolly flowers of the tall (no 6) Mexican Sunflower, Tithonia rotundifolia ("Torch" is the full-size variety). You see how obvious my taste is. I like a flower the colour of blue poster paint, (no 7) Phacelia campanularia , the Californian Bluebell, of the purest lemon-yellow like (no 8) Oenothera biennis , the Evening Primrose. I like the plants of childhood, like (no 9) Love-in-a-Mist, Nigella Damascena and (no 10) Forget-Me-Not, Myosotis sylvatica . This leaves us notably short on reds and pinks, but not chronically short with 90 more to go.

 The seeds listed are available from Chiltern Seeds, Bortree Stile, Ulverston, Cumbria LA12 7PB (tel 01229-581137, fax 01229-584549).

fields.headline: The last word on   Victoriana
fields.standfirst: There is no one depressed in this house -  Queen Victoria
fields.trailText: There is no one depressed in this house - Queen Victoria
fields.body:
Predictably enough, the centenary of Queen Victoria's death this week is marked not only by sentimental effusions about how jolly the queen herself was, but also by a positive reappraisal of all things Victorian. Some of it is justified: much architecture, literature, science and engineering of the Victorian period is splendid, and one day people will recognise the virtues of some of its painting as they already recognise those of its music.

But there is one thing Victorian we can well continue to do without, despite insistent calls from certain quarters for its return: and that is "Victorian values".

The existence of temperance societies, Christian evangelism, with its missions to the slums of big cities (and the "savages" of the colonies), extreme prudery, brides sexually ignorant on their wedding nights, Samuel Smiles's best-selling "Self-Help", and the rest of the familiar marks of the Victorian age, tells us an important truth: that Victorian society was in fact the opposite of what these marks imply. The reason is simple: there would have been no need for the mobilisation of such moralising forces if Victorian society were not riddled with the sins they oppose. The Victorian age, in fact, was very far from embodying Victorian values in practice.

We think of those times as prim and proper because the 19th-century moral minority (which in our own times has come to be called, by wishful thinking, "the moral majority") was literate and well-off, and could therefore make a noise in society out of proportion to its numbers. The moralisers went to war against drunkenness, vice, unemployment (then called "laziness") - in short, all the symptoms of a society many of whose members were poor and hard pressed.

Their plight reveals the real values of the Victorian age, whose true marks are sweatshops, slave wages, child prostitution, long working hours, exploitation, dreadful living conditions, absence of medical care and schooling, street violence and crime - all at extremely high levels. It was the Artful Dodger's world, not the saccharine world of sentimental respectability. The former was reality for the majority, the latter was a moralisers' dream.

Alcohol was one of the age's endemic problems. Drunkenness was one of the few escapes available to the poor. They drank cheap liquors, which further damaged health already compromised by poor nutrition and harsh working conditions. Moralisers sought to stamp out drinking, but not the causes of drinking - and that was how the rest of their endeavours worked: by tackling the symptoms, not the disease. Mainly they tried to persuade, bully or punish the poor into accepting their lot and behaving themselves.

Proponents of Victorian values claim that if only we could return to them we would overcome contemporary problems. Victorian virtue is exemplified for them by Mrs Nubbles, Dickens's widowed washerwoman, who cared for her children in a home that was poor but had "the air of comfort that comes with cleanliness and order". It is symbolised by the Cratchits eating their poignantly limited Christmas dinner. Let us applaud and emulate the Nubbles and Cratchit spirit, admirers of Victorian values say, and all will be well.

Lytton Strachey was right, so were Dickens and Gissing: if we read them we will not be lulled by soft-focus historical sentiment, and the rich patina of accumulated time, into thinking that because Queen Victoria laughed at jokes, Victorian values are a good thing after all.
fields.bodyText: Predictably enough, the centenary of Queen Victoria's death this week is marked not only by sentimental effusions about how jolly the queen herself was, but also by a positive reappraisal of all things Victorian. But there is one thing Victorian we can well continue to do without, despite insistent calls from certain quarters for its return: and that is "Victorian values". The existence of temperance societies, Christian evangelism, with its missions to the slums of big cities (and the "savages" of the colonies), extreme prudery, brides sexually ignorant on their wedding nights, Samuel Smiles's best-selling "Self-Help", and the rest of the familiar marks of the Victorian age, tells us an important truth: that Victorian society was in fact the opposite of what these marks imply. The reason is simple: there would have been no need for the mobilisation of such moralising forces if Victorian society were not riddled with the sins they oppose. The Victorian age, in fact, was very far from embodying Victorian values in practice. fields.headline: Bonfire of the zealots
fields.standfirst: Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Hold the front page! OK then, hold page seven! Timewatch (BBC2) made the shocking revelation last night that Sir Thomas More wasn't the nice, kind-to-small- animals-and-children figure he was made out to be in A Man for All Seasons. He wasn't decent or fair, or driven by anything other than ambition and fanaticism. And he probably didn't even give money to ye olde Comical Reliefe.

A Man for All Seasons was, according to the historian who presented The King's Servant, "a whitewash. Hollywood under the Tudors". More, whose charm hid a steely ruthlessness, was actually a zealot whose hatred of heretics - that is, people who didn't believe what he did - led him to imprison, torture and burn them. He dexterously rose through the ranks at Henry VIII's court until Fat Henry's divorce from Catherine of Aragon and subsequent marriage to Anne Boleyn meant he could no longer do the King's wishes, conflicting as they did with his Catholic views. And Fat Henry had been so nice and reasonable up until then. Well, you could have blown me down with a hurricane. A nasty, conniving, rabidly toxic politician? Working in the court of Fat Henry? Shurely shome mishtake.

Even once this statement of the completely obvious was out of the way the programme still failed to engage. This was entirely down to the decision to dramatise the events surrounding More's fall from grace. True, dramatisations of what (might have) happened are more interesting than cameras panning over old documents and castle walls but, in this case, only just. With everyone overacting for England, it was all too easy to imagine the actors getting a call from their agents: "Listen, I got you a great job - Sir Thomas More. No, not in A Man for All Seasons. In a reconstruction in a BBC2 documentary. Hello? Hello?"

Timewatch's finest moment came in a t te-à-t te between More and Thomas Cromwell. "How will you control the king when you hand him the earth?" More asked Cromwell, who brought about the submission of the clergy to Henry. "And if you can't control him, what will be the end for you?" Is that a line from Invasion of the Giant Ants or what? The beanpole historian told us these events were pivotal in English history. So why did it sound like an insurance salesman talking about a boring policy document? Tripe.

Now they've all hit 35 and survived the storm in last week's episode, the gang in Dawson's Creek (Channel 4) are taking time to evaluate what they want to do with their lives once they stop pretending they're schoolchildren. Bizarrely, none of them mentions going to Hollywood, perhaps to star in a movie about sex or drugs to shake off their squeaky-clean images. How strange. Of course, it would be hard to go to Hollywood when your head is so firmly stuck up your bottom that you ruminate endlessly in a postmodern style about how teen shows run into trouble when the stars get too old for high school and have to go to a nearby, heretofore unheard-of college or stay in a town where their brains and qualifications make continued residence unrealistic. God, how utterly uninteresting.

Is it wrong to boycott Frasier (Channel 4) because Kelsey Grammer is a chum of George Bush? It's either that or stop buying Ricky Martin records. And seeing as not even deaf, stupid people buy Ricky Martin records, not watching Frasier is the only thing I can do to register my disapproval of Bush. Such a decision is all the harder because - at last - Daphne's cor blimey bruvver 'as naffed off, and it's fun counting the ways they are trying to hide her bump. Still, you can't win 'em all. As Al Gore recently found out.

fields.headline: Let the people in!
fields.standfirst: The government wants entry to national museums to be free, just like everyone else. So, asks  David Barrie, what on earth is the problem?
fields.trailText: The government wants entry to national museums to be free, just like everyone else. So, asks David Barrie, what on earth is the problem?
fields.body:
This week, the BBC confidently announced that culture secretary Chris Smith had done a deal with the Treasury and that admission to all national museums would soon be free. The story was quickly denied by government spokesmen, but the headlines it provoked are a reminder of how central the promise of "free admission for all" is to the success of the government's cultural policy. After all, Tony Blair pledged to write the arts into the government's "core script".

In the 1980s, when museum charges were encouraged by the government of the day as part of a market-driven economy, museums and their collections were regarded as commodities. And the result? Those institutions that went down the charging route saw their visitor numbers plummet on average by a third - and these numbers have never fully recovered.

This approach failed to take account of the unique importance of museums: the treasures they display are the common threads that link us to each other, to our past, to other cultures. They are a crucial part of the fabric of the individual and of society, and everyone should have free access to them. They have been built up with public money or through generous private donations - they belong to us all.

This government has gone a long way to making these collections freely accessible to everyone. Dropping charges for children in April 1999 resulted in a 20% increase in child visitors. The next phase saw pensioners getting in free from April 2000 and resulted in a 40% increase in visits by senior citizens.

But the government's policy has stalled at the final stage due to absurd VAT regulations that mean national museums that currently charge will lose millions of pounds if they go completely free. This is because they are treated as businesses, and can recover their VAT. As a result, the government has come up with a precarious compromise, asking these museums to drop their charges for adults to £1 from September, rather than scrap them altogether.

Yet charging is, in itself, a barrier - the amount is almost immaterial. One museum which recently introduced a charge of £1 saw its visitors fall by 50%.

The government has unwittingly provided an incentive to non-charging national museums to introduce entry fees in order that they too can reclaim their VAT - for the British Museum that amounts to £2-3m a year. VAT recovery is fast becoming the driving objective of our national museums and galleries.

So where do we go from here? The National Art Collections Fund has proposed a solution that would enable all national museums and galleries to go free without having to worry about their VAT bill. Through a simple amendment to the 1994 VAT Act, they could be added to the list of existing bodies (such as the BBC) that can reclaim VAT, even though they are not, strictly speaking, "businesses".

If a museum is free, people drop in casually. It can be for a few minutes or a few hours - they don't feel they have to spend a day there to get their money's worth: free admission is the gateway to an experience that can literally change lives.

 David Barrie is director of the National Art Collections Fund.

webTitle: That was the age of the train

fields.headline: That was the age of the train
fields.standfirst: The post-war years saw an explosion of films glorifying Britain's railways.  Geoffrey Macnab  finds them playful - and poignant
fields.trailText: The post-war years saw an explosion of films glorifying Britain's railways. Geoffrey Macnab finds them playful - and poignant
fields.body:
By common consent, the 1930s and 1940s were a golden age for British documentary. Under their fiery Scottish boss John Grierson at the General Post Office Film Unit, young directors like Harry Watt, Edgar Anstey and Basil Wright began to flourish. Such films as Song Of Ceylon (1935) and Night Mail (1936) hinted at how documentary could be at once playful, lyrical and provocative, educational and formally adventurous. The war provided young directors with perfect subject matter. The work done by the Crown Film Unit and the Ministry of Information, notably Humphrey Jennings's Fires Were Started, Pat Jackson's Western Approaches, and Harry Watt's Targets For Tonight had an urgency that peace-time films could not match.

It was inevitable that British documentary's profile would fall once the war was over. "Everything afterward seemed an anti-climax," acknowledges John Legard, an editor and producer who began his career at the Crown Film Unit in 1943. Many of the best-known film-makers now made the transition to feature films. Those who stayed behind fell out of the public gaze, and had to find new subject matter. They made films about housing, the coal industry and agriculture. One prodigious but unsung outfit, British Transport Films, produced hundreds of documentaries about every aspect of travel in post-war Britain. The best of their work is now being released on video by the British Film Institute in the series British Transport Classics.

The glib assumption that only the most inveterate trainspotters could find any interest in movies about steam engines, trains caught in snowdrifts, electrification, timetables and branch lines doesn't hold quite true. With the British railway system currently in a state of crisis, these films have a special poignance. They present an extraordinarily rosy image of rail travel in post-war Britain.

They show trains driving through snowdrifts to help farmers rescue their livestock or taking trippers to seaside towns. They portray stationmasters and railway workers in an idealised light that makes even Soviet documentaries about heroic workers seem understated. They reveal how local lines opened up remote areas of the UK to travellers and holiday-makers. One guesses that railways never did operate quite as smoothly as the documentaries suggest, but there is something oddly consoling in their evocation of an era when the transport system served the British public rather than simply inflicting pain on it.

British Transport Films came into being in the summer of 1949, in the Pillars of Hercules, a pub in London's Soho. It was here that Grierson's old protege, Edgar Anstey, summoned young cameraman Ronald Craigen for a meeting. "He told me that the British Transport Commission had decided to make up a film unit and he wanted me as the cameraman," Craigen, now 86, recalls. "We were to deal with waterways, railways, buses - anything that was part of the nationalised travel system."

The goal of the new film unit, Anstey declared, was "to create an appetite for travel". The documen taries were intended to open up Britain to all its inhabitants. "In those days, a large percentage of the country didn't own a car - they went by train or bus," remembers Legard, who joined the unit in 1951. "We worked on the basis that if you get people interested, they will travel," Craigen says. "And if they travel, they'll probably go by British Rail or on the nationalised buses. We were showing them the things they could see. It was quiet promotion, not blatant advertising but subtle work.

These are propaganda films for sure. Their upbeat optimism often begins to grate. The commentaries are written in sub-John Betjeman doggerel. ("The guard is laconic/ His obsession with time is quite chronic," runs one typical rhyming couplet.) Some of the films hardly touch on travel at all, and instead show the joys awaiting trippers at the end of their journeys. My Heart Is Highland (1952) is mainly about heather, lochs and hillsides, but with several sycophantic asides about the glories of hydroelectric power and the good works of the Forestry Commission. The Land of Robert Burns (1956) is a none too convincing hymn of praise to rural Ayrshire. Some of the more specialist documentaries, for instance the mini-epic about the electrification of the London Midland Region Main Lines or the film extolling the blue pullman, are hard to watch with eyelids open.

Anstey and his team spent months polishing each new film. In the process, such matters as overcrowding, the problems resulting from nationalisation and the consequences of the Beeching cuts are not even touched upon. We are offered a Trumpton-style vision of Britain in which all social tensions are miraculously rubbed out.

The artistry that characterised the work of Basil Wright, Humphrey Jennings at al has also gone into these films. The British Transport Films team shared the same political drive as their predecessors. They were left-wing idealists, proseltyising on behalf of a travel system accessible to all. They refused to fraternise with the enemy. "We were once shooting at Alnwick Castle with the Duke of Northumberland in a rather splendid banqueting hall," Legard recalls. "The crew were invited to have a drink with the Duke, and they said certainly not, they were not going to drink with the aristocracy."

Legard admits the unit was never critical of its main paymaster, British Rail. "You could argue that that was a weakness. There were terrible problems in the railways at that time, but we were making films in the service of a particular industry and championing the craftsmen. That was fair enough."

The documentaries were shot silently, with a commentary and a score conducted by Muir Mathieson (the maestro of British film music) added on. Anstey and his colleagues were able to conjure drama out of the most unprepossessing situations. The pivotal moment in Elizabethan Express, a record of a journey aboard a steam train from King's Cross to Edinburgh Waverley, comes somewhere near Newcastle, where signalling failure delays the train by four and a half minutes. Clawing those missing minutes back becomes a matter of life and death for all concerned. "Nothing must stop her. That is official. Lateness causes pain," runs the commentary as extra coal is heaped into the engine and Macleod, the heroic driver, settles down to his task.

Anstey was a milder personality than his old boss, Grierson. "He was a fierce, rather volatile figure," Legard remembers. Anstey remained respectful toward his old boss, but Grierson was not always flattering about Anstey's efforts. When the unit made a film about the post office, 30 Million Letters, which featured a playful pastiche of Night Mail, the Scot let everyone know he was not impressed. "It was shown at the Venice festival. Grierson, who was on the jury, didn't think much of it. I mentioned it and he said, 'Och, it's been doon better.'"

The films were seen by millions. They were shown in cinemas as supporting programmes, but there was also a team of travelling projectionists. "The non-theatrical circuit was colossal at that stage," Legard recalls. He and his colleagues became experts on the railway by default. "We didn't really have a passion for trains," says Craigen. "The passion was for making films. That was our main driving force." As a cameraman, he was often perched on top of trains, or hanging out of them, or squatting down by the side of the track to get the best possible shot. He talks in rapturous terms of how handsome the old steam engines looked. "The beautiful sun on glistening snow, the train coming up the incline, billowing white smoke..."

Legard believes that the films have aged remarkably well: "Many of the feature films of that time seem terribly dated, but some of the modest little documentaries we were making about the railways seem as fresh as daisies."

The unit closed in 1982 mainly, it seems, because British Rail could no longer afford it. By then, Anstey was retired, and the old-style Grierson-approach to documentary was out of favour. The idea of taking months to shoot and edit a 35mm film with an orchestral score about an engine caught in a snowdrift (as in Snow Drift at Bleath Gill) didn't make sense when a TV crew could cover it in an afternoon. Still, there are several organisations around today who would benefit from resurrecting a British Transport Film unit to extol their virtues. Virgin, GNER and Railtrack spring to mind.

 British Transport Films Collection Volumes IV and V are released by the BFI.

Anstey was a milder personality than his old boss, Grierson. "He was a fierce, rather volatile figure," Legard remembers. Anstey remained respectful toward his old boss, but Grierson was not always flattering about Anstey's efforts. When the unit made a film about the post office, 30 Million Letters, which featured a playful pastiche of Night Mail, the Scot let everyone know he was not impressed. "It was shown at the Venice festival. Grierson, who was on the jury, didn't think much of it. I mentioned it and he said, 'Och, it's been doon better.'" The films were seen by millions. They were shown in cinemas as supporting programmes, but there was also a team of travelling projectionists. "The non-theatrical circuit was colossal at that stage," Legard recalls. He and his colleagues became experts on the railway by default. "We didn't really have a passion for trains," says Craigen. "The passion was for making films. That was our main driving force." As a cameraman, he was often perched on top of trains, or hanging out of them, or squatting down by the side of the track to get the best possible shot. He talks in rapturous terms of how handsome the old steam engines looked. "The beautiful sun on glistening snow, the train coming up the incline, billowing white smoke..." Legard believes that the films have aged remarkably well: "Many of the feature films of that time seem terribly dated, but some of the modest little documentaries we were making about the railways seem as fresh as daisies." The unit closed in 1982 mainly, it seems, because British Rail could no longer afford it. By then, Anstey was retired, and the old-style Grierson-approach to documentary was out of favour. The idea of taking months to shoot and edit a 35mm film with an orchestral score about an engine caught in a snowdrift (as in Snow Drift at Bleath Gill) didn't make sense when a TV crew could cover it in an afternoon. Still, there are several organisations around today who would benefit from resurrecting a British Transport Film unit to extol their virtues. Virgin, GNER and Railtrack spring to mind.  British Transport Films Collection Volumes IV and V are released by the BFI.

fields.headline: Anyone for metaphysics?
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
Next time you find yourself getting pavement rage at all those clipboard-wielding do-gooders in netball bibs on the high street, spare a thought for Victorian gentlemen. Apparently, they couldn't walk down Oxford Street without being accosted by frisky prostitutes or leafleted about the pernicious evil of masturbation. I learned this, and much else besides, in Radio 4's Victoria Season, which began this week. Quite the giddiest moments came during that ordinarily well-behaved slot, the afternoon play.

Victorian Marriage Beds, a three-part series about disastrous Victorian wedding nights, kicked off with an eye-wateringly frank look at George Eliot's sexual relationship with her second partner, John Cross, who was 21 years her junior. It began quite innocently, with Eliot teaching Cross the history of metaphysics and him teaching her the rules of lawn tennis. If only they had stuck to such simple pleasures.

Six weeks into their marriage, Cross and Eliot had yet to consummate it. The more Eliot dragged him round Venice's art galleries, looking at paintings of nude folk, the more, well, hot and bothered young Cross became. Sensing a problem, Eliot tried a couple of cold-shower comments - "Shall I read you some more Dante? I was thinking I should stitch my bonnet" - but, by this point, Cross was lost to us and in sore need of some of those leaflets. When Eliot finally put her bonnet and poetry aside, loosening her corset and ordering champagne ("Touch me! let me touch thee!"), Cross promptly threw himself out of the window, into the Grand Canal.

It was all horribly real, despite acres of sober and sensible commentary by medical historian Leslie Hall interspersed with the action. You soon forgot it. With the intimacy of good radio, Cross's predicament was almost too intense to bear - you could feel his sexual frustration as he wandered the streets of Venice. This isn't as bad as feeling it on a busy water taxi full of strangers, but it still left me wanting less of such historical insights into the doomed marriage bed.

More ardour-cooling material was brought to us by Ian Hislop, who fronted the Victorian season, and quite rightly. I've always thought there was something positively Dickensian about him, and he has the right voice for programmes that call for business-like incredulity. A Revolution in Five Acts, a look at world-changing pieces of Victorian legislation, demanded just that, especially the one dealing with the Contagious Diseases Act of 1864. Passed, said Hislop, "to provide clean whores for our boys" after infectious disease had killed more servicemen in the Crimea than combat, the Act is yet more evidence that Victorian values, especially those surrounding sexual conduct, were not as simple as we think. I'm not sure there is anyone left out there who really believes it was all no more complicated than covering up saucy table legs, but if they do exist, let's hope they were listening.

Queen Victoria was told the Act was to do with cattle, which it was, to some extent, and it was passed without debate at a late-night sitting. Any woman suspected of being a prostitute could be forcibly examined for infection using "a giant metal speculum and leg clamps". It's the old is-she-a-witch?-ducking-stool conundrum - if you float you're a witch; if you drown, you're not a witch but you're dead. Innocent women wrongly accused of prostitution were irrevocably stigmatised; women who were guilty were treated severely and often with unsterilised implements that spread rather than limited infection. Hislop couldn't help snorting at the ludicrousness of this and the hypocrisy of sexual double standards his programme uncovered.

That's the problem with too much looking back Victorian-wards, this week as always: we may know that things were more complicated than the stereotypes suggest, but we also kid ourselves that we have significantly moved on. The truest words in the entire week were to be found in a snippet from that old music hall song, It's the Same the Whole World Over. "It's the poor what gets the blame/It's the rich what gets the pleasure/Ain't it all a bleeding shame?" Ain't it just.

fields.headline: McGuggenheim?
fields.standfirst: Motorbikes and Armani - is this any way to run a great gallery?  Mark Honigsbaum on the Guggenheim, a museum brand spreading from Las Vegas to Venice, thanks to the aggressive marketing of Thomas Krens, its talented and controversial director
fields.trailText: Motorbikes and Armani - is this any way to run a great gallery? Mark Honigsbaum on the Guggenheim, a museum brand spreading from Las Vegas to Venice, thanks to the aggressive marketing of Thomas Krens, its talented and controversial director
fields.body:
Ever since Lorenzo de Medici first sponsored Michelangelo, the commercialisation of art has been gathering pace. But what happens when museums - the gatekeepers and guardians of art - start behaving like corporations?

The New York-based Guggenheim museum has announced a three-way collaboration with the Kunsthistorisches museum in Vienna and the Hermitage in St Petersburg. Under the new arrangement - which builds on a prior agreement between the Guggenheim and the Hermitage - the museums will exchange paintings and curating staff in an effort to boost what Nicholas Iljine, European representative of the Guggenheim Foundation, calls their collective "marketing and picture power".

The response of the guardians of the American museum world is to cry "McGuggenheim!", and claim that Thomas Krens, the management-trained director of the New York Guggenheim, is rolling out the brand. The tie-up with the Hermitage and Kunsthistorisches are just part of a wider strategy for what looks increasingly like a bid by Krens for world domination. Following the critical success of Frank Gehry's titanium-clad Bilbao museum, Krens is already planning new Guggenheims in Las Vegas, Rio de Janeiro, Venice and St Petersburg, as well as a massive new "son-of-Bilbao" on the East River at Wall Street.

But it is not so much Krens's franchise approach to the memory of Solomon Guggenheim (1861-1949) - the mining magnate whose endowment gave birth to the original Frank Lloyd Wright museum 63 years ago - that affronts his critics so much as his commercialisation of the space inside the present 88th Street ziggurat. Three years ago, for instance, Krens, 54 - who wears black and rides a BMW to work - controversially curated The Art of the Motorcycle, an ode to bike design that was sponsored by BMW. This month marks the end of another crowd-pleaser, Giorgio Armani, an exhibition of sketches and frocks sponsored by Time Warner fashion magazine In Style, and reportedly accompanied by a gift of $5m (£7m) to the museum by the Italian designer.

Both shows were wildly popular, attracting visitors who had never seen the Guggenheim's holdings of Kandinskys and Klees to the museum for the first time, but Philippe de Montebello, director of the rival Metropolitan Museum of Art complained: "It's a betrayal of public trust," in an interview in Forbes magazine. "A compromising sponsorship to clean up the bottom line," is how Maxwell Anderson, director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, described it.

Krens retorts: "Culture can be educational and entertaining. Our success is a function of our authenticity. We are not for sale." Well, there may have been only six BMWs in the motorcycle exhibit, but what was authentic about also putting a BMW on the cover of the catalogue?

Krens's supporters on this side of the Atlantic have come to his defence. "I personally wouldn't do an Armani exhibition," says the Royal Academy's Norman Rosenthal, who considers himself both a "friend and admirer" of Krens, "but I might do a motorcyle exhibition. There have been shows about motor cars, why can't there be shows about motorcycles?"

In many ways Krens's courting of commerce echoes the row over Rosenthal's courting of Saatchi and the even more controversial decision by the Brooklyn Museum last year to allow Saatchi to curate his Sensation exhibition after the museum accepted a $168,000 donation from the advertising executive-turned-collector and $50,000 from Christie's, which auctions many of Saatchi's works.

Rosenthal argues that such concerns are overblown. "The art world is full of contradictions. You can never resolve them all. What you've got to do is judge every individual case and every event on its merits."

He maintains that Krens's ambition is good for the Guggenheim and good for worldwide art audiences. Compared to the Met, the Guggenheim's endowment is relatively modest - just $37m, or the equivalent of one year's operating expenses (the Met's endowment by comparison funds it for 11 years). Unlike most British art institutions, it cannot rely on public funds to bail it out when gifts, contributions and attendances dry up. The only way it can survive is through growth, hence the new Guggenheims in New York and elsewhere and the partnership with the Hermitage. "Krens's view is that the world is full of art, but huge parts of it are not on view. He's trying to make space for all of it," says Rosenthal. This interconnection between the market, growth and survival is perfectly encapsulated in Gehry's model for a new megamuseum in South Street, overlooking the East river. Nicholas Serota was able to fund Tate Modern with £50m from the Millennium Commission and £6m from the Arts Council's Lottery Fund, Krens will have to raise nearly all the money for his proposed new Manhattan museum privately.

As presently envisaged, the new museum -a swirling wave of titanium and glass stretching four blocks along the piers at South Street which Gehry describes as "two holey donuts on stilts" - would have 200,000 square feet of permanent exhibition space, as well as a 40-storey office tower, arts and education centre, theatre and a massive park and outdoor sculpture garden. In an echo of Serota's explanation for the Tate needing Bankside, Krens argues that the new building will take the pressure off Wright's ziggurat, freeing up space at the Fifth Avenue building for more of the prewar permament collection, while allowing postwar and new experimental installations, like video, to migrate to the new building. Without that space, the Guggenheim may not be able to attract donations of important private art collections on which the museum's future survival depends. "This space will allow the institution to grow into new areas and support the long-term viability of the Guggenheim," he says. All of which is a good argument for New York but not necessarily for the new Guggenheims Krens is also planning in Las Vegas and beyond. The new resort hotel-casino in Vegas - a joint venture between the Guggenheim and the Hermitage scheduled to open this spring - is expected to bring art to a whole new audience, the 35m or so punters who patronise the desert casinos each year.

Gamblers and philistines, Krens's critics resort sniffily. The Guggenheim management board are simply after the money, the Met's de Montbello, claims sceptically. "It's certainly not the same thing as if they were to send their collection to the St Louis art museum where they would get zero, but they would reach a very large public."

The hotel museum in Las Vegas (which is rumoured to be considering a reproduction of the Sistine chapel on the roof) is only one of a series of joint ventures that Krens is pursuing in an alliance with the Hermitage that is aimed at forging a whole new paradigm, what Krens calls an "international museum".

In return for the Guggenheim helping the Hermitage renovate the General Staff building in St Petersburg adjacent to its present state appartments in the Winter Palace, for instance, the Hermitage will make its unique collection of old masters and French impressionists available to the new Guggenheims in Las Vegas and New York, and vice versa. This treasure-sharing arrangement will also encompass Bilbao, the Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin and a second Venice Guggenheim. The tie-up with the Kunsthistorisches museum in Vienna - renowned for its collection of Brueghels and other European masters - converts this "marriage of opposites" into into a menage a trois.

"It worries me that too many adventures by museums who adopt a for-profit mentality may end up jeopardising the tax-exempt status for all of us," says Max Anderson of the Whitney. "Institutional jealousy," Rosenthal responds. "He's not a stupid man, he's a Dostoyevskian figure, a gambler much more than he is Mr Management." The Guggenheim used to be the 'poor relation'; now under Krens it attracts many of the sponsors rival museums would like to have for themselves. Moreover, says Rosenthal, Bilbao was "an astonishing achievement". If this is what Krens means by "leveraging our expertise" the more the better.

Not everyone,however, is quite so enamoured by Krens's undoubted achievements. "Krens is a dynamic character who likes to go his own way. You either love him or hate him," says one prominent British museum curator, who asked not to be named. "His philosophy is that you rush around the world proposing 10 schemes in the hope that one of them works out. What you have to weigh up is whether it's of benefit or not."

Krens was unavailable for comment, presumably too busy scouring the globe in search of new "alliances" and "migratable cultural resources". It is perhaps an indication of his iron management style that the Guggenheim failed to put up anyone else to speak in his place.

Some find him intimidating - he is at least 6ft 6in and with a personality to match. When Hila Rebay, the art adviser to Solomon Guggenheim, commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to design a new building in Manhattan to house Guggenheim's four-year-old Museum of Non-Objective Painting, she wrote, in 1943: "I need a fighter, a lover of space, an agitator, a tester and a wise man." Krens would seem to fit at least the first three of Rebay's requirements.

"He's incredibly energetic," says a senior museum staffer. "I've worked with a number of corporate high-flyers but this man travels more than anyone I've ever met, and he knows how to get things done." One of Krens's first acts as director was to restore Wright's rotunda and monitor building to its original splendour and add a new tower, thus extending the overall exhibition space at the Fifth Avenue building. Next came a new downtown space, the Guggenheim Museum Soho, followed, in 1997, by Berlin and Bilbao.

The South Street building, however, is a far more daunting proposition. Bilbao was susbsidised by the Basque government, who even chipped in a $20m gift to the Guggenheim endowment. Although New York's mayor, Rudolph Guiliani green-lighted the Manhattan project and the city will provide the land and $67m towards the building, Krens will have to raise the rest of the capital himself. Fortunately, he has the backing of a number of wealthy trustees, including Peter Lewis, the billionaire chairman of the Guggenheim board, who made his fortune selling high-risk insurance and is apparently talking of donating as much $100m towards the project (Lewis is a big fan of Gehry's - the architect has not only built a house for Lewis in Cleveland but is also designing him a business school).

Judging by the crowds flocking to view Gehry's model of the new museum, currently on display at the Fifth Avenue premises, the South Street building would be at least as big a draw as Bilbao. Management consultants McKinsey & Co estimate it would create around 5,000 new jobs and attract 2.5-3.5m visitors a year. However, some critics remain singularly unimpressed - calling Gehry's design more Disney World than art world -while a proposal to build "sky boxes" to entice corporate sponsors appals those who believe museums should subscribe to more democratic principals.

There is just one problem with this line of argument and that is, for all Krens's supposed commercial "debasement", his exhibitions are hugely popular. When Dennis Hopper launched Art of the Motorcyle in Bilbao, for instance. it attracted an astounding 1m visitors (the exhibit will open the new Las Vegas Guggenheim in the spring). The figures aren't in for the Armani exhibit yet, but judging by the crowds packing the ramps this month, it has done very well and should be a similar hit when it transfers to Bilbao in April.

Indeed, Krens points out that worldwide attendance at the four Guggenheims is now 2.5m, compared to 350,000 in 1989, the year after he took over. And he predicts that once the Las Vegas museum is up and running, attendances could be closer to 6m, surpassing both the Met's 5m and the Museum of Modern Art's 2m.

Whatever the views of his detractors, there's no getting away from the fact that - as Newsweek puts it -Krens's "aggressive, global approach may be what high culture needs to survive in our world".

However, some critics remain singularly unimpressed - calling Gehry's design more Disney World than art world -while a proposal to build "sky boxes" to entice corporate sponsors appals those who believe museums should subscribe to more democratic principals. There is just one problem with this line of argument and that is, for all Krens's supposed commercial "debasement", his exhibitions are hugely popular. When Dennis Hopper launched Art of the Motorcyle in Bilbao, for instance. it attracted an astounding 1m visitors (the exhibit will open the new Las Vegas Guggenheim in the spring). The figures aren't in for the Armani exhibit yet, but judging by the crowds packing the ramps this month, it has done very well and should be a similar hit when it transfers to Bilbao in April. Indeed, Krens points out that worldwide attendance at the four Guggenheims is now 2.5m, compared to 350,000 in 1989, the year after he took over. And he predicts that once the Las Vegas museum is up and running, attendances could be closer to 6m, surpassing both the Met's 5m and the Museum of Modern Art's 2m. Whatever the views of his detractors, there's no getting away from the fact that - as Newsweek puts it -Krens's "aggressive, global approach may be what high culture needs to survive in our world".

fields.headline: The devil in the dance
fields.standfirst: As The Red Shoes is given a modern reworking,  Lyn Gardner  explores how authority has always felt threatened by the mania for dance
fields.trailText: As The Red Shoes is given a modern reworking, Lyn Gardner explores how authority has always felt threatened by the mania for dance
fields.body:
Red is the colour of blood, the colour of danger and the colour of temptation. In Snow White, the heroine is tempted to bite into the red part of the apple and is poisoned. In Little Red Riding Hood, a girl puts on a red cloak and goes into the forest, where her visibility makes her fall prey to the wolf. Hans Christian Andersen took the symbolism to a new extreme of cruelty in The Red Shoes - an age-old folk tale given a modern reworking this week by the Kneehigh Theatre Company. In Andersen's deeply unpleasant version, the little orphan girl Karen is punished for her vanity in coveting red shoes and daring to wear them to church.

Like the wicked queen in Snow White, who, in some versions of the story, is punished for her sexual jealousy of her stepdaughter by being forced to dance herself to death in red-hot shoes at the happy couple's wedding reception, Karen is condemned to dance in her shoes until "she turns raw and red and her skin clings to her bones as if she were a skeleton". It seems certain she would have danced herself to death but for the fact that her wild, abandoned steps lead her to the town executioner, who chops off her feet.

The idea of uncontrolled, wild dancing as something dangerous stays with us: the club must be licensed for entertainment; the rave strictly policed. The idea of people enjoying themselves, whirling like banshees out of control is deeply unsettling to authority. Uncontrolled passion must be restrained.

Yet in the not-so-distant past, hundreds of thousands of people took part in frenzied outdoor orgies and wild displays of dancing that lasted for weeks. People would dance themselves into a state of elation, tearing off their clothes, laughing, weeping and having sex with strangers. Some participants died of heat stroke and exhaustion, others just had a jolly good time, found release, and then returned to their old lives. A bit like weekend clubbers.

From as early as the eighth century and as late as the 17th, these dance manias spread across Europe. In the late 13th century, several hundred people danced so furiously on a bridge over Germany's Maas river that it collapsed, killing most of the revellers. The survivors were treated in the nearby chapel of St Vitus, giving rise to the name St Vitus's dance for these manias and associated neurological conditions in which the patient's limbs twitch and jerk uncontrollably. In Italy, cases of tarantism - in which the victims believe they have been bitten by a tarantula and will only survive through incessant and frenzied dancing - have been reported well into the second half of the 20th century.

Individual and mass hysteria is the commonest explanation for these outbreaks of dancing manias and, in most cases, it has been suggested women were most commonly affected. Dancing yourself to death seems to be a peculiarly female affliction - perhaps a desperate attempt at escape and release for women whose lives were strictly controlled by behavioural and social conventions.

But in combining the sexual symbolism of the shoe, common in so much mythology and folk tale, with the potency of the colour red, the misogynistic Andersen created a new version of an old myth in which the anti-heroine Karen is offered no release, but merely punishment, mutilation and death. At the end of the story, this original scarlet woman hobbles to the church on crutches, where she repents, her heart breaks and her soul flies up to God.

Quite how vindictive this tale is can be deduced from the fact that Andersen named his heroine after his half-sister, Karen, whom he loathed because she was the illegitimate offspring of a liaison between his mother and a married man. For the socially ambitious, upwardly mobile Andersen, Karen was a reminder of his humble beginnings and his mother's promiscuity. He punished her the only way he knew how: in print.

But the punishments for women who dare to dance to their own tune have gone on being meted out. In Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger's 1948 film version of The Red Shoes, Karen becomes Vicky, a young ballerina singled out by ruthless, exacting ballet impresario Lermontov for stardom. Lermontov employs Julian, a composer, to create a ballet version of the Andersen story for Vicky, and ballerina and composer fall in love. Forced to choose between the demands of Lermontov and Julian, ballet and love, Vicky succumbs to the pressure and dances herself to death. With its ravishing, expressionistic use of colour and lush romanticism, The Red Shoes has rightly become a movie classic but, in daring to want both love and art, Vicky served as a gruesome lesson to millions of post-war British women, who, after the freedoms of the war and a taste of work outside the home, might have been tempted to imagine that, in peace time, they could have it all: marriage and career, love and creativity.

Fifty years on, we still struggle to reconcile our desires with reality. The Red Shoes remains as potent, bitter and scary for women today because, like the stepsisters in Cinderella who mutilate themselves to make the shoe fit, or Karen and Vicky, whose feet are severed from their bodies, we all sacrifice bits of ourselves in a maddened attempt to conform and survive. And, like poor Karen, when we realise what we have lost, we often replace the loss with pain, addiction and obsession. The Red Shoes is not about the temptation of red, but the stain it leaves behind long after the whirligig dance is over.

 Kneehigh Theatre Company's production of The Red Shoes is at BAC, London SW11, from Tuesday. Box office: 020-7223 2223.

fields.headline: Hiring John Malkovich
fields.standfirst: Whatever the accent, the old school ham is never dull.  Jonathan Romney  likes to think he helped the US actor's career
fields.trailText: Whatever the accent, the old school ham is never dull. Jonathan Romney likes to think he helped the US actor's career
fields.body:
I think I once gave umbrage to John Malkovich. I asked him why he was always recognisably himself in his films - why he tended not to disguise himself, or do funny voices. He replied that mine was a superficial appraisal, and more or less suggested I go back and look at his films properly. Shortly afterwards, he did exactly what I thought he never would - put on a funny voice. The film was Rounders, a stolid gambling thriller in which he played a Russian card sharp. The house erupted as Malkovich spat in an accent thick with borscht: "Geev the myen hees money!"

Whether he is way over the top, or in camp somnambulist mode, Malkovich often resembles an old-school ham. Extraordinary Malko moments tend to be conventional bad acting or very idiosyncratic performances that overshadow everything else. In the first category is his wan Mr Kurtz in Nicolas Roeg's Heart of Darkness: as he reclines, languorously gasping, "The horror! The horror!", you're reminded of Oscar Wilde getting in a last barb at the wallpaper before he pegs out. In the latter category is his Dauphin in Luc Besson's Joan of Arc. About to become King of France, he whines, "You call this a crown? Don't we have anything more regal?" like Isaac Mizrahi putting the finishing touches to his Siege of Orleans winter collection.

Malkovich can be extremely compelling playing heavies in thrillers In the Line of Fire and Con Air. But his real forte is those performances that go beyond good and bad and become the one thing you remember about certain films. I've retained practically nothing about The Portrait of a Lady except the way Malkovich grinds his forehead into Nicole Kidman's face.

The inspired conceit of Being John Malkovich allowed him to suggest that what we had taken for superciliousness was really a keen sense of the ridiculous. Playing "John Horatio Malkovich" he portrayed himself as a man who spent his time idly choosing bath towels, who was piqued because no one could remember his films, and who eventually went "up his own portal", just as he'd been accused of doing on screen for years. The question then was: how could he carry on being John Malkovich after that?

One answer comes with E Elias Merhige's new film, Shadow of the Vampire, about the making of FW Murnau's horror classic Nosferatu. Malkovich's Murnau is another of his shady aesthetes, and he again uses his familiar mutter, this time with faint German inflections. But Merhige's film is really about the way a strong-willed star can subvert the plans of even the strongest-willed directors - something Malkovich's directors know to their cost, or benefit. Shadow of the Vampire looks like an allegory of the Malkovich acting style - an essay on the pros and cons of Hiring John Malkovich. But it's a risk directors continue to take, and, God knows, the result is never dull. Geev the myen hees money, I say.

fields.headline: Peer pressure
fields.trailText: Smallweed's rather fond of Gerard Houllier (and Croydon)
fields.body:
If I were Lord Alli, formerly Waheed Alli, TV tycoon, I would be feeling pretty miffed about Lord Alton of Liverpool, leader of the Lords opposition to the sanctioning of therapeutic cloning of human embryos. Not because of his views, but because Lord Alton - once David Alton, Liberal MP - has had his name married to Liverpool, yet the same authorities would not let Alli have Croydon.

When made a peer, he asked the Garter Principal King of Arms to let him be Lord Alli of Greenwich or Lord Alli of Croydon. No, he was told: you can't have Greenwich, since that belongs to the Duke of Edinburgh, and you can't have Croydon because it's a London borough and I keep those for dukes, earls and marquises. How typical of this shockingly London-centred country to give away the title of Liverpool while declining to dish out mere Croydon. Fond as I am of Croydon (yes, really), it is hardly in the same class as the city of maritime history, the Liver building and Gérard Houllier.

Yes, Gérard Houllier, who, now that his team has reached the Worthington Cup final, has moved to the very top of the coveted Smallweed Rankings, just ahead of PY Gerbeau. For those who have never heard of the Smallweed rankings (which is everybody but Smallweed, since I only invented them five minutes ago), this celebrated system rates in order of recent success all those bosses of big British institutions who are imports from abroad and have utterly charming accents. At present it stands as follows: 1. Houllier of Liverpool. 2. Gerbeau of the Dome. 3. Wenger of Arsenal (not doing so well now, are they?). 4-24. Various other people. 25. Luc Vandevelde of M&S. Watch out for further adjustments.

Which brings me to another exciting innovation: Smallweed's Resort of the Year. To whet your appetites for a sun-kissed summer, I hope to suggest over the next few months fun places to spend your holidays. A winner will be announced in due course. Here we go:

Smallweed's Resorts of the Year, number 1: Uttoxeter, Staffs. Uttoxeter has a pretty marketplace (or so its website suggests) and a memorial to Dr Johnson in the form of a kiosk which is now a very small shop. Dr Johnson once refused to show up as instructed at his father's stall in Uttoxeter market. Many years later he came back to the town and stood in the rain, bare-headed, as a form of penance.

What's more, Uttoxeter (or so its web site suggests) is where the civil war effectively ended, when Royalist forces expected to do bloody battle with the Parliamentarian army of General Lambert surrendered instead. Uttoxeter has a racecourse and is not all that far away from Alton Towers. There is also a railway station. Uttoxeter's so-called rivals, I suggest, have a great deal to beat in coming months.

A question that has troubled me for some time reared up again at the Wigmore Hall on Wednesday at a concert given by the sublime American soprano Barbara Bonney. The audience, as you'd expect, was ecstatic. But how can one express adulation in today's concert halls? The old practice of shouting "Bravo!" sounds so heyday-of-empire. Instead, my fellow-adulators mostly made do with cries of "hoo" and "hoy" which convey no particular message but just make a noise.

Maybe the concert hall will one day become like the football ground, with audiences shouting: "Two, four, six, eight, who do we appreciate? D-I-M-I-T-R-I-S-I-T-K-O-V-E-T-S-K-Y - Dimitri Sitkovetsky!"; or even, "One John Eliot Gardiner and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment - there' s only one John Eliot_ etc, etc." But I hope not. The chanting of names even as brief as Bonney's would delay her luscious encores. The accompanist, by the way, was Malcolm Martineau, who deserves to have his name chanted too. People sometimes forget that bit.

In pieces about what Hartlepool thinks about Peter Mandelson, I noticed that interviewees were sometimes described as Hartlepudlians. I thought this was a joky derivation from the Liverpudlians of Liverpool, but the borough council tells me that it is correct. I then phoned Blackpool to ask if its people were known as Blackpudlians, but that appears to be frowned on. "We are known as 'sand grown 'uns'," my informant proudly confessed. "Blackpudlians", I suppose, too easily summons up black puddings. These matters are very sensitive.

"My heart leaps up when I behold a rainbow in the sky," wrote Lord Rees-Mogg in the Times on Monday. "That is nothing to the way it leaps up to see Bill Clinton leaving the White House." The first thought, of course, is Wordsworth's; the second is merely Smog's. But I know how he feels. My heart leapt up when I read this week that Sean Connery had been cast as Socrates in a bumper new movie. I predict this film will have huge successes with audiences, right from the opening scene ("The name is Socrates... James Socrates") to the climax when the apparently dead philosopher springs back to life, revealing that before he swallowed the hemlock, he had gulped down an antidote supplied by his secret service boss. The rest of the cast has not yet been revealed, but I understand it is likely to be as follows: Aristotle, Roger Moore; Plato, Robert de Niro; Alcibiades, Vinny Jones; Persephone, a nubile maiden with whom Socrates is conducting a secret affair, Catherine Zeta-Jones; Xanthippe, Judith Kilshaw. The hemlock, cold tea.

And finally, Smallweed's poem of the week, dedicated this week to Lord Rees-Mogg:

My heart leaps up when I behold

A dustbin in the sky.

They have them emptied, I am told

By dustmen who can fly.

- Keats.

A pedant writes: I am a keen student of the works of John Keats, and do not recognise the stanza you have quoted.

Smallweed engagingly snarls: I said nothing about John Keats. These words are the work of a man called Rog Keats, who works in my local butcher's.
