fields.headline: Blood, ballads and bullets
fields.standfirst: Glasgow opens the first centre for political song this week. But, as  Gerard Seenan learns, dissident inspiration can take strange forms
fields.trailText: Glasgow opens the first centre for political song this week. But, as Gerard Seenan learns, dissident inspiration can take strange forms
fields.body:
On February 11 last year, a group of Chinese prisoners was paraded through the streets of Beijing. In the freezing cold, they stood on the back of an open-top truck preparing for their death. The sight was intended as an example to all, an illustration of the consequence of betraying the communist regime. But something strange was happening. Over the noise of the truck's engine, a faint tune could be heard. As bystanders listened harder, it became clear that the prisoners were singing. But this was no political protest song. Against the shadow of the imperial city, the prisoners were belting out the 1998 World Cup anthem by Latin love god Ricky Martin: The Cup of Life.

"It does seem a strange choice and I don't know why they chose it, but it was their way of saying to the regime that they were not afraid of dying," says Rosemary Burnett of Amnesty International. "Across the world, song is used by the oppressed as a way of illustrating defiance. Sometimes they are overtly political songs, but in other times it can be Ricky Martin or, for instance, the Kosovar refugees sang George Michael songs."

Such pieces of apparent ephemera on the edges of political struggle are exactly the sort of information which has been largely overlooked by political and cultural historians. While the great sweeps of history have been recorded for posterity, the tunes which accompanied - and occasionally instituted - change, have often been lost or ignored.

A new centre launched in Glasgow this week aims to begin to reverse that trend. The centre for political song at Glasgow Caledon ian University marks the first attempt to collate the song and music that has accompanied politics the world over.

Although still in an embryonic stage, the centre already has material covering everything from sardonic swipes at New Labour's last election campaign to the music which accompanied the rise of the Third Reich and that which helped bring civil rights to America. The basis for the initial collection is the records, scores, books and amateur pamphlets gathered over a lifetime by the former Labour MEP Janey Buchan and her late husband Norman. That's why I thought I'd try and get this centre off the ground."

Getting the centre off the ground has been a long process, but knowing where to stop and where to begin may be the hardest. "I wouldn't bother trying to define what a political song is - it'd be impossible," says Buchan. "Defining where political songs and songs of social comment start and end may be our most difficult task," adds John Powles, collections manager at the university.

The centre contains much overt protest material from the American civil rights movement - from the "Songs of the Freedom Movement", which records the songs of the project for freedom schools in Mississippi, to Nina Simone's Mississippi Goddam. A standard refrain of America's white racists to the more progressive whites was the question: "How would you like it if they married your sister?" It's a comment addressed in an apparently apolitical torch song. In the Yip Harburg-penned Now, Lena Horne croons the line: "And listen mister, we don't want to wed your sister": an artful retort sneaked out in a mainstream song.

Throughout the Vietnam protests of the 60s, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez and many more gave the protest generation a focus for their condemnation. But when, in the UK, the attacks became universal and without focus, there was a backlash. "For about six months after the Sex Pistols TV interview with Bill Grundy in December 1976, a lot of councils and some of the commercial chains refused to put on or cancelled punk gigs," says Martin Cloonan, an author on censorship in pop. The most political punks were anti-establishment, but what that led to were political movements like Rock Against Racism," he says.

"In the UK, punk's nihilistic politics was followed by targeted political songs such as Tom Robinson's 1979 standard Glad to Be Gay and, in the 80s, by Billy Bragg and his mates in the Labour-supporting Red Wedge, and the Special AKA's Free Nelson Mandela". The largest part of the collection was gifted by Buchan, much of it covering Scottish protest and the women's movement: tunes from the Faslane peace camp's Ding Dong Dollar to the Lament of the Working Class Hero's Wife. "

"We are seeking donations to widen the scope and already we know the centre's going to be huge," she says. And already political song is filtering through from the most oppressive regimes. The centre has received a cassette and translation of protests songs by imprisoned nuns, smuggled out of Tibet. The nuns sing: " I sing a song of torment From Drapchi prison of Tibet /I sing in my song our land of the Dharma has now become a prison camp."

fields.headline: South Shropshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Here at the beginning of the year we looked out to the south over a green-grey landscape hung about with damp cloud where half a dozen little streams wander down from the southern flank of Titterstone Clee Hill to join the River Teme near Tenbury Wells.

There wasn't a glimpse of the sun as we looked down to the sentinel trees skirting Whitton Court. This pile has 14th century origins, its massive brick chimney stacks poking now from the misty garden that overhangs the secretive Colly Brook. A single ewe cried out from the soggy swede field where her flock was foddering, otherwise the dank world was silent as we went along. The creamy red clay of the farm track that took us towards Hope Court spoke volumes about the early winter rains. The little church up the lane at Hope Bagot assumed the quality of a wraith, all wrapped around by the chill vapours as we drew close. There beside the lych gate is the gargantuan churchyard yew thought to be more than 1,600 years old, with its "holly" well issuing from the root system, its waters supposed to alleviate sore eyes. Not far away, visible at the base of the west tower, we could make out the pair of sinister millstones used as cornerstones when the tower was erected at the end of the 13th century. In 1292 Valentine the miller was "dragged down" and killed by the inner wheel at Hope Mill. The Assize Roll for that year records that a deodand of seven shillings was charged - a deodand is a chattel which causes death and is forfeited to the Crown to be used "for pious purposes". So the two millstones were probably given to the church authorities and used in the base of the wet tower then being built.

A long climb follows, through steep pastures above Hope Bagot. A stone tower marks the line of the pipeline that brings Birmingham's main water supply from the Elan Valley beyond the Welsh border. Then we came out on Clee Hill Common where the dark mist wrapped around us, ever closer. The dismal rushy moor was running with water, a handful of disconsolate ewes were foraging and cast glances our way before we vanished in the cloud.

Sometimes a day such as this metamorphoses to astonishing brilliance; we've paid our penance and the sky clears to open vistas as the sun goes down in glory. There was no such reward today. Our descent from Titterstone Clee's summit was into uniform greyness.

fields.headline: High blood count
fields.standfirst: Imagine if Max Schreck, star of the horror classic Nosferatu, had really been a vampire. It's   this idea that gives Shadow of the Vampire its bite.  Joe Queenan gets out the garlic
fields.trailText: Imagine if Max Schreck, star of the horror classic Nosferatu, had really been a vampire. It's this idea that gives Shadow of the Vampire its bite. Joe Queenan gets out the garlic
fields.body:
Shadow Of The Vampire is a one-joke movie, but the joke is a very good one. The premise is this: in 1921, the great German director FW Murnau set out to film Bram Stoker's Dracula, one of the most popular novels ever. Denied permission by Stoker's estate, Murnau concocted his own version of the Romanian Count Dracula, his being a skeletal figure with extremely long fingernails who lived in the mountains of Czechoslovakia. The character was named Nosferatu, and the black-and-white silent film bearing his name is widely thought to be one of the greatest horror movies of all time: frightening where Bela Lugosi's Dracula was merely camp, philosophical where films like Frankenstein were merely maudlin.

Murnau, as portrayed by the peerlessly strange John Malkovich, is clearly a bit touched in the head. A typical product of the Weimar Republic, Murnau is a denizen of that brooding Teutonic demi-monde where everyone is androgynous, everyone is addicted to at least one dangerous drug, and everyone seems to be waiting for either the Gestapo or Liza Minnelli to turn up. Mercifully, Shadow spares us any ruminations on the role of decadent, disenfranchised vampires in the rise of the Third Reich; it proceeds from the reassuring assumption that all Germans of that era were weird.

To make his vampire movie extra-special, Murnau has arranged for the lead role to be played by an ageing thespian named Max Schreck, an unbelievably hideous man. No one has ever heard of him. Enter Willem Dafoe, another reliably idiosyncratic actor of Malkovichian pedigree, whose distinctive teeth make him the perfect choice for the part. Though Schreck is identified as an alumnus of Stanislavsky's actor's school, it soon becomes apparent that the actor is a real-life vampire. Well, it does to the audience.

Tragically, the other characters in this movie-about-the-making-of-a-movie are less quick on the uptake, and even after a number of mysterious disappearances, several vicious attacks on the cast and crew, and one unnerving incident where Dafoe plucks a bat out of the air and eats it raw, they still do not put all the pieces together. Oh, they definitely have him pegged as an oddball and a bit of a ham, but it does not seem to occur to them that he may be the spawn of Satan. Their failure to process this information results in many more deaths, massive budget over-runs, and lots of drug abuse. But in the end, they get the footage they came for.

Because he is a vampire, with unconventional dining habits and unusual sleep patterns, Schreck creates many problems on the set - quite apart from his tendency to rip the lungs out of passing gofers and assistant producers. Indeed, after his "find" has feasted upon the original cameraman, Murnau is forced to shut down the production and go back to Berlin to obtain a replacement (Carey Elwes). But, in due course, the film is finally shot, and lasting fame for all involved parties is assured.

Shadow of the Vampire is partially a half-hearted meditation on the search for immortality and partially a coy meditation on the ordinary hardships encountered in making a film. While it is true that Schreck's depredations massively reduce the cast (one producer, two cameramen, one actress, one script girl, countless hangers-on), Murnau seems content to work around these problems because the actor delivers such a realistic performance, and because he usually manages to get everything in one take. The film seems to be saying that making a movie with a bloodthirsty vampire isn't that much harder than making a movie with Kevin Costner.

In the past century, the movie industry has made many valiant attempts to satirise itself (Sullivan's Travels, Day for Night, Contempt, Scream III), but Shadow Of The Vampire may be the cleverest effort yet. By portraying Murnau as a director who is willing to sacrifice the lives of a dozen colleagues if it will ensure his own immortality, director E Elias Merhige delivers a refreshingly honest look at the craft he practises. That is: career is everything. Had Alfred Hitchcock crossed paths with a real-life vampire before making Psycho, he would have hired him in a heartbeat. So to speak. Malkovich, who has played so many weirdos that it is hard to imagine him in any other kind of role, is perfectly cast as the deranged director.

Achieving the almost unimaginable feat of being both under the top and over the top - often in the same frame - Malkovich radiates a functional insanity that the unlettered could easily confuse with classic Type-A Prussian workaholism. Those dreary cadences, his famously low affect, that almost phonetic delivery that make Malkovich's performances so jarring elsewhere work wonders in this droll, tongue-in-cheek affair. When he tells Schreck (who has just polished off his lovely co-star): "Frankly, Count, I find that this composition is unworkable. Please return to your original mark," we are torn between revulsion and laughter. This is as it should be.

Dafoe delivers an equally solid performance as the tormented, emaciated, profoundly untrustworthy vampire. Having signed on to the project not because he wants to see his name in lights, but because he has been promised an opportunity to eat the female lead, Dafoe's performance mercilessly satirises prima donna leading men everywhere. Unlike them, whiners who are always demanding a bigger bedroom or a more flattering camera angle, Dafoe merely demands an opportunity to eat the script girl. At which point, Malkovich warns him that if he carries out this threat, he will get no close-up. Like I said, it's a one-joke movie. But it's a good joke.

 Shadow of the Vampire is out on Friday

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Children's Tax Credit

fields.headline: Giving yourself a break
fields.standfirst: Confusion over who qualifies has discouraged many people from claiming the Children's Tax Credit from last April. Jill Papworth reports
fields.trailText: Confusion over who qualifies has discouraged many people from claiming the Children's Tax Credit from last April. Jill Papworth reports.
fields.body:
More than 2m families who could benefit from the new Children's Tax Credit, potentially worth up to £520 a year, have so far failed to put in a claim.

The tax break replaces the Married Persons Allowance which was abolished by the government last April. Ministers wanted the cash to be targeted at children rather than just used as a support for marriage despite objections from church groups and opposition parties. But the switch to a means-tested tax relief for people with children will mean that couples need to fill in an Inland Revenue form. Confusion over who qualifies for the credit under the new rules has discouraged many people from making a claim.

Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said the credit would benefit 5m families, but only 2.8m claim forms sent out last summer by the Inland Revenue to potential claimants have so far been returned.

The Treasury points out that of the 5m families who stand to benefit from the new, "family tax cut", a million are self-employed and will therefore be claiming the credit in arrears. So they don't count, at least not yet.

Nevertheless, there are still at least 1.3m eligible families out there who, if they get their acts together and their claim forms in by the end of February, could start receiving the tax credit, worth up to £10 a week, in their pay packets from April. If they leave it any later to claim they won't benefit until later and will have to wait for a rebate.

Martin Barnes, director of the charity Child Poverty Action Group, says: "I think the main reasons many people have not yet made a claim for the new tax credit is that so far there has been a lack of publicity about it and a lot of people simply aren't aware that it could potentially give them a sizeable reduction in their tax bill.

"The new tax credit is a significant boost to parents and carers with children. But to get it, you must put in a claim. So anyone who thinks they may be eligible should claim now if they haven't already done so."

The Treasury says a remedy, in the form of a £4.8m advertising campaign, is due to start in February.

The Children's Tax Credit is designed to help families who have at least one child under 16 living with them. It is available to married or unmarried couples and to single parents. To claim you must have at least one child - your own child, a stepchild, adopted child or a child you look after at your own expense - who is living with you for at least part of the tax year and is under 16 at the start of the tax year on April 6.

There is only one credit for each family and if you are living with a partner, you can only have one credit between you, even if you have more than one child under 16 living with you.

Unlike the personal tax allowance, the Children's Tax Credit is not an amount of income you can receive without paying tax. Instead it reduces your tax bill by up to a set amount and this is reflected in your tax code.

New tax codes currently being sent out for the new tax year have an "H" beside the number if you are receiving the basic personal allowance plus full Children's Tax Credit. Eligible claimants should note that if their new tax code has an "L" beside the number, they have not yet made a claim.

You may be confused as to how much the new credit is worth. In last year's Budget it was announced that the credit would be worth up to £442 a year (£8.50 a week) off the tax you have to pay.

However, in last November's pre-Budget report, the Chancellor said it was his intention to boost the credit and make it worth up to £10 a week or £520 a year. So, though £442 remains the official figure that you'll see used in all Inland Revenue booklets and illustrations, it is safe to assume that when the credit takes effect in April it will be worth up to £520 a year.

The credit is paid at the full rate unless the person claiming it is a higher rate tax payer, that is, if their individual income is likely to be more than £32,785 (based on 2000/2002 tax bands).

The credit is reduced at the rate of £1 for every £15 of income taxed at the higher rate. This means that you are unlikely to receive any credit if your income is above around £41,000 (£42,000 at the £520 per year rate). The credit is expressed as an allowance of £4,420 given at the rate of 10% (£5,200 at 10% expected).

If you are a higher rate taxpayer, you may see the reduction of the credit expressed as £2 of the allowance withdrawn for every £3 of income at the higher rate band.

If neither partner in a couple pays higher rate tax, then either of them can have the whole credit or they can elect to share the credit equally between them. Both partners must agree if the partner with the lower income is to have all the credit allocated to him or her. If the partner who receives the credit does not pay enough tax to use all of it, he or she will be able to transfer the unused credit to the other partner after the end of the tax year.

If either, or both, partners pay higher rate tax, the partner with the larger income must claim the credit. One anomaly has arisen in the system as a direct result of independent taxation which means that a family with two working partners can get more tax credit than a couple where only one partner works.

For example, a couple where both partners each earn £30,000, just below the higher rate tax threshold, would be entitled to receive full Children's Tax Credit even though their joint income is £60,000.

In a household where only one partner works and earns just over the £32,785 higher rate tax threshold would have the credit gradually withdrawn and if he or she earned over £41,000 (over £42,000 when the £520 rate comes in), they would get none at all.

The Child Poverty Action Group has published a factsheet on the Children's Tax Credit. Copies are available on its website at Child Poverty Action Group or if you send an S.A.E to CPAG, White Lion Street, London N1 9PY.

The Inland Revenue gives the following example of how the credit reduces for a higher rate taxpayer.

Jeremy and Louise have two children under 16. Louise earns £36,010 and Jeremy earns £25,000. Louise has to claim the Children's Tax Credit as she is the higher rate taxpayer.

Louise is taxed as follows (using 2000/2001 rate bands and personal allowances):

 0% on the first £4,385 of her income (the limit of her personal allowance)

 10% on the next £1,520 of her income (that is, at the starting rate up to £5,905)

 22% on the next £26,880 of her income (that is, at the basic rate up to £32,785)

 40% on the remaining £3,225 of her income (that is, at the higher rate up to £36,010)

The credit is reduced on £3,225 at the rate of £1 for every £15 = £215

Therefore, the credit is worth £442 - £215 = £227 off the tax that Louise has to pay.

fields.headline: Growth falls to two-year low
fields.trailText: Economic growth fell to a two-year low in the final quarter of last year, reinforcing expectations in the City that the Bank of England will cut interest rates next month to boost demand.
fields.body:
Economic growth fell to a two-year low in the final quarter of last year, reinforcing expectations in the City that the Bank of England will cut interest rates next month to boost demand.

Output of goods and services expanded by 0.3% between October and December, reducing the annual growth rate from 3% to 2.4% in the third quarter, according to figures published by the office for national statistics.

The quarterly growth rate was the weakest since the end of 1998, when the Bank's monetary policy committee slashed rates to ward off a global slump.

City economists said yesterday's figures exaggerated the weakness of the economy at the end of last year - which was mainly due, they say, to a sharp drop in erratic energy output linked to unseasonably warm weather and maintenance work on North Sea oil platforms.

It was also likely that growth of services output, which slowed from 0.9% to 0.7%, had been artificially depressed by chaos on the railways. But analysts said growth still appeared to be slowing and, with inflation below target, the monetary policy committee would probably cut rates from 6% next month.

Gerard Lyons, global head of treasury research at Standard Chartered Bank, said: "The Bank of England will cut interest rates probably in February by 0.25%. But [GDP] does not imply the economy is about to go into recession as there are many strengths in the economy."

This month's vote on the MPC was the closest for some time, with four out of nine members pressing for a reduction in the cost of borrowing.

Since then, underlying inflation has fallen further below the government's 2.5% target to 2%, and employment shrank for the first time in more than seven years.

Some members of the MPC still remain cautious about the inflationary implications of the continued strength of consumer spending and a pick-up in wage growth at the start of the new year. For last year as a whole, growth was 3%, in line with the chancellor's forecast in November's pre-Budget report.

But the final quarter figures mean that growth has now slowed to an annualised rate of just 1.3%, compared to the long term average of 2.25%-2.5%.

ONS officials said manufacturing output grew slightly in the fourth quarter but energy supply and agriculture declined. Construction output was static compared with Q3, when there was a quarterly decline of 1.4%.

The slowdown in the services sector was mainly due to weaker output growth in business services and finance and, to a lesser extent, in transport.

fields.headline: Barbara Bonney
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Barbara Bonney was recently quoted in the Guardian saying how important it is for a singer to find a voice that is truly her own. She's not one to ignore her own advice - the sweet, silvery tone that is this American soprano's hallmark rarely sounds anything but natural.

Given these vocal qualities, it was surprising that she should have chosen Schumann's Dichterliebe for this recital programme. It's unusual for a soprano to perform this song cycle at all, as the poems are addressed to a female beloved. Secondly, this "Poet's Love" is full of depths that need to be plumbed by a riper, more dramatic voice than Bonney's.

The cycle was performed as an almost seamless whole, with little or no pause between songs. Accompanist Malcolm Martineau was sensitive, reliable and utterly musical - it's little wonder that A-list singers are queuing up to work with him. He held back in the final song, Die alten bösen Lieder, to let Bonney's voice through, but made the ensuing postlude into something truly enchanting.

Despite the intelligence and fine pacing of Bonney's and Martineau's performance, however, these songs of uneasy infatuation and thwarted passion sounded just too shiny. Ich grolle nicht, often performed as a noble rage, was interpreted as a song of resignation, which was better suited to Bonney's voice. She extolled the joyful side of Dichterliebe, but her voice, using often unnaturally bright German vowels, is the wrong instrument to bring out its tortured undercurrent.

The Scandinavian songs of the second half proved much more gratifying. Though dubbed "A Nordic Dichterliebe", they had little to link them with the genuine cycle save for a general theme of love expressed through allusions to nature.

Certainly the tongue-in-cheek Vilse by Sibelius, dashed off wittily by Bonney and Martineau, has no counterpart in Schumann's selection. There were musical riches here - two songs by Grieg, underrated as a Lieder composer, and several by the Swedish composer Wilhelm Stenhammar. His large-scale song Flickan kom, anticipating the harmonies of Debussy, brought Bonney's first gleam of really impassioned singing.

Tonerna by Sjoberg highlighted the beauty at the uppermost end of her range, and the heart-on-sleeve Var det en drom? by Sibelius, despite ending literally on a low note, preceded three encores. Perhaps it was the darker vowels of these languages that helped Bonney to find a richer side to her palette. If only this had occurred earlier.

fields.headline: The electro-squelching hip-hop messiah
fields.standfirst:
Xzibit
Subterania, London
****
fields.trailText:
Xzibit
Subterania, London
****
fields.body:
An hour before midnight, a wave of Wagnerian classical music engulfs the small Subterania, accompanied by the sound of helicopter blades and Norman Schwarzkopf barking orders (rock had the Vietnam war, rap has the Gulf conflict). When Xzibit hits the stage sporting a cavernous, black hooded anorak, worn off the shoulder, and blue bandana (which, in gang terms, makes him a Crip), the crowd greet him like they know something we don't: that Xzibit is the next hip-hop messiah.

It's not too far-fetched an idea. A former crack dealer from Los Angeles via New Mexico, born Alvin Joiner 26 years ago in Detroit, Xzibit has spent the past 12 months making guests appearances on records by everyone from De La Soul to Limp Bizkit. Dr Dre was the executive producer for Xzibit's imminent third album, Restless, which also features cameos from Snoop Dogg, Eminem, KRS One and Erick Sermon.

Next month sees a series of live dates supporting Eminem and the highly touted OutKast. Remember how big Dre's last two proteges - the aforementioned Calvin Broadus (Snoop) and Marshall Mathers - blew up. Although he doesn't have the cachet of a by-proxy murder rap, as did Snoop when he first emerged, or the National Enquirer status of Mathers, all Xzibit has to do is harness our fascination for AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted and he can't fail.

There are people hanging off the rafters upstairs to grab a glimpse of the man. Even Damon Albarn of Blur is here. The DJ assumes his position behind twin decks, a vinyl copy of Dre's classic The Chronic at his side like a talisman. As though straight off the street, Xzibit runs on to the churning rhythm of Alkaholik, holding the mike in one hand and a bottle of beer in the other, moving with considerable grace considering his short and stocky frame.

Something of a showman, raconteur and mimic (his cockney accent is, shall we say, endearing), Xzibit's face is fixed in a scowl even when he's grinning. By the second song Los Angeles Times, he's stripped down to regulation baggy pants, vest and gold medallion, revealing a muscular, compact body. He'll never be a pin-up like Eminem, but the ladies in the house aren't displeased.

The electro squelch and phat G-Funk of Dre's production are reduced in the PA mire to a muffled subterranean quake. Oblivious, the immaculately dressed kids down by the stage slam into each other with the sort of force you normally see at a nu metal gig. The reaction to Paparazzi is so extreme it's contagious. Lyrically, it's all non sequiturs ("Goddammit never no superstar/ I'm more like a planet") and ethical posturing ("Niggas in the rap game/ Only for the money and the fame"); luckily, they're drowned out by the cyborg boogie.

Besides, what counts is conviction. For all his comic banter, Xzibit has serious intent, sampling Travis Bickle as Taxi Driver on At the Speed of Life. If he allows himself to become a character, he could play the avenging angel to Snoop's louche gangsta and Eminem's petulant sociopath.

fields.headline: RSNO/Alsop
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
***
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
***
fields.body:
James MacMillan's Confessions of Isobel Gowdie is a contemporary classic. It has everything: violence, agonised conflict and a searing beauty that is as heart-rending now as it was at the time of its composition 11 years ago. Its source of inspiration - witch-hunting in medieval Scotland - is also compelling. MacMillan's requiem for the murdered Isobel Gowdie is a haunting threnody that communicates with a vengeance.

Concert programming that treats Confessions as a stimulating opening piece is about as misjudged as it gets. It dealt a fatal blow to Barber's Violin Concerto, which was overshadowed completely. This was a terrible shame, since Marin Alsop, who is currently recording Barber's complete works with the Royal Scottish National Orchestra, is a skilled and dedicated interpreter of his music. The soloist James Buswell gave a fine performance, but a sickening sense of anti-climax hung over the first movement. Barber's bittersweet brand of lyricism may not be to everyone's taste, but placing it first would at least have saved it from sounding trivial.

The atmosphere was salvaged briefly in the second movement by Stephane Rancourt's soulful oboe solo. When the finale began, however, the spell was broken. It was well played, with all the obsessive energy it needed. But with the best will in the world, it could not follow Confessions without sounding devastatingly superficial. This had nothing to do with either soloist or orchestra; it may be that this movement's flippancy creates an imbalance within the Concerto itself, regardless of programming anomalies. That was indeed the impression formed by Iso Briselli, the work's intended first performer. Claiming, untruthfully, that the finale was unplayable in its present form, Briselli tried to persuade Barber to make it more substantial; he later explained that he had found it too lightweight.

Whatever the Concerto's problems, the audience responded far more warmly to it than to the MacMillan, which received lukewarm applause. Whether this was due to shell-shock or dislike was impossible to judge.

Mendelssohn's Third Symphony is Scottish in subtitle only; its introductory theme occurred to the composer while on holiday in Edinburgh. Its Beethovian energy was brilliantly captured, though the last movement was rather bottom-heavy; pounding timpani clouded the final Allegro maestoso, obscuring its exultant closing theme.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Will consumer spending decline?

fields.headline: Why you may have to drop the shops
fields.standfirst: A leading economic forecaster predicts a downturn in consumer spending this year and an increase in credit. Liz Stuart reports
fields.trailText: A leading economic forecaster predicts a downturn in consumer spending this year and an increase in credit. Liz Stuart reports.
fields.body:
In spite of the current feelgood factor in the economy, belt-tightening will be the order of 2001 for consumers, according to one of the leading economic forecasters, the Item Club.

"Consumers are now spending more than they earn and windfalls and bonuses have masked the threat of mounting debt. Last year's euphoric spenders will be in for a nasty shock when they assess their true financial position over the coming weeks," says Professor Peter Spencer, the Club's economic adviser. He says that people will have to be more prudent with their spending.

There are various factors to blame: capital gains from shares and unit trusts are set to fall, demutualisation windfalls have dried up, house price increases have levelled off and indirect taxation continues to increase while bonuses are falling. Pensions and retirement savings have been diminished by lower stock market returns. The Bank of England will also be relying on the man in the street to practice Chancellor Gordon Brown's favourite virtue, prudence, before it cuts interest rates.

"With employers suffering a profit squeeze and the governement raising taxes, people may be forced to continue to dig into their savings or, more likely, push credit to its limits," says Mr Spencer.

But spending will be a hard habit to break. Although many retailers, including Marks & Spencer, are blaming slow sales over Christmas for their poor financial performance, figures released by the Credit Card Research Group this week show spending on plastic jumped by nearly a quarter on the previous year: a record £18bn, of which £9.5bn was on debit cards. The biggest outlays were on food, drink and travel. Most people left their shopping until late and took full advantage of the sales.

But while credit card spending continues to grow, the percentage of cardhold ers paying interest on their account (ie, who do not pay off their full balance at the end of each month) fell last year from 78% in 1999 to 74%. fields.headline: Raging Speedhorn: better than a trouser press
fields.standfirst:
Raging Speedhorn
Scala, London
***
fields.trailText:
Raging Speedhorn
Scala, London
***
fields.body:
The boundaries of British heavy metal have become so elastic that out-and-out popmongers such as the Stereophonics have crept into the formerly purist pages of rock magazine Kerrang! Raging Speedhorn (best name of the year by miles) have arrived from Corby, Northants, to restore the genre to its pariah status. Their ammunition is nihilism, humongous riffery and an attitude problem, adding up to a sludgy racket with few redeeming qualities. Fantastic fun, in other words.

If you could decipher the lyrics screeched by dual lead vocalists John Loughlin and Frank Regan, you'd be treated to apocalyptic angst eloquently summed up in Necrophiliac Glue Sniffer: "You throw the petrol and the matchstick/ You stupid fuck, you forgot to light it."

Their squabbling over a petrol bomb makes them a refreshing alternative to the humourless American thrash-lords who have turned 2001 into the year that rock went overground. The Speedhorn are as English as battered sausages, from Loughlin and Regan's hooligan scowls to the amphetamine-fuelled pogoing of the undernourished guitarists. They even mind their manners - when Loughlin, a bald bruiser who looks older than his 21 years, shoulders his way into the audience for some hands-on shrieking, he mouths "Sorry" as he squashes a moshing fan's foot.

Their musical inspiration, as such, is also British. From the way songs trundle ponderously along, it's obvious Black Sabbath are never off the CD player chez Speedhorn. The Clash figure in there, too, when they crank up the pace a few notches. Gangly bassist Darren Smith even looks like that band's Paul Simonon, his instrument slung near his knees. The rest of the group, to go by their skinny frames and wild eyes, seem to be descended from one of the murkier 1970s punk bands.

The set consists of what might as well be one long song, interrupted by pauses for Regan and Loughlin to get their breath back for more growling. It's impossible to make out lyrics, or even who is singing what. They use their voices as rappers do, bouncing verses back and forth, then melding as they sweep into cacophonous crescendos. There are no tunes, subtlety or pacing, but that's what George Michael is for.

Dumb and dumber, Raging Speedhorn are primitive, cathartic and could soon supplant the trouser press as Corby's most famous contribution to British culture.

 Raging Speedhorn play Rock City, Nottingham (0115-958 8484), tonight, then Manchester and Glasgow.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Public sector recruitment

fields.headline: Now they want you  back on duty
fields.standfirst:
It's going to be tough getting key public sector workers to return to fill the gaping holes left by the droves who have taken early retirement. Phillip Inman reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's going to be tough getting key public sector workers to return to fill the gaping holes left by the droves who have taken early retirement. Phillip Inman reports.
fields.body:
Teachers, police officers and nurses who quit their professions to enjoy early retirement are finding the pressure is on to get back in the saddle.

A concerted effort by the government to produce a package of inducements and rule changes targeting this gang of 50-somethings is underway. Ministers hope it will fend off criticism that it is doing little to rescue the public services from a chronic shortage of workers.

The Home Office is looking at ways to entice retired police officers back to the beat with refresher courses like those already available to former teachers and nurses. Earlier this month Liberal Democrat MP Simon Hughes said the government must speed up efforts to prevent the shortfall in policemen becoming wider.

"Officers coming up to retirement should be encouraged to stay on for up to an extra five years," he said in a letter to the Home Secretary Jack Straw. "Good police officers who have retired in recent years should be encouraged to return for up to five years."

To help private and public sector employers, the Inland Revenue is examining the strict rules that prevent people who take early retirement carrying on working for the same employer. Many private sector employers want to keep on older workers but find the Revenue's rules get in the way. And if this doesn't work, Gordon Brown's proposal for an army of 1m volunteers is supposed to persuade the rest that some work is more fulfilling than pruning roses. The government reckons 2m people over 50 live on pensions after retirement at a cost to the Exchequer of £16bn in benefit payments and lost tax.

But the likelihood of a huge grey army rushing to take stressful jobs in the public sector is extremely unlikely, according to pensions experts and pensioner groups. The lure of a highly regulated and stressful job like teaching, policing or nursing is severely limited, especially among people who have probably baled out to get away from the stress and regulation they experienced.

"It is not the answer to call back people who have already put in 30 to 35 years' service," says a spokesman for the National Pensioners Convention. "It has been tried in nursing and has proved unsuccessful. People who have retired are not falling over themselves to go back to long hours and stress."

The Employers Forum on Age, an employer-led anti-ageism campaign group backed by Help the Aged, agrees that front-line staff are unlikely to flock back to their old jobs if they have taken early retirement. A spokesman said it wanted the government to think more imaginatively.

The Police Federation, which says the service has lost 2,500 officers since 1997, says the issue is so complex it is waiting for more details before making any comment. But it reckons police officers have experienced a 33% increase in workload since the present government took office and many leave the service to get away from it. Whether they will return without radical changes to the service is a moot point.

NUT, the teachers' union, believes there is only a slim chance of persuading teachers to return after they retire. "The last government changed the rules and passed the cost of pension enhancements to local authorities. That happened five years ago and early retirements stopped. So after a period when lots of teachers took early retirement there haven't been many," says a spokeswoman.

The generation that ministers would like to encourage back might have to work 53 hours in a primary school and 51 in a secondary school, according to government statistics, for a maximum £24,000. "Many retired teachers miss the children, but not the hassle," she adds. Yet ministers will come under further pressure if strike ballots this week over teacher shortages come out in favour.

To support employers' attempts to keep key staff, the government plans to scrap rules that prevent workers from taking part of their pension and some income from their employer. The proposal has been championed by the Employers Forum on Age, which last year attacked the Revenue for failing to produce a new scheme. It said employers had seen many staff take early retirement who wanted to work part-time but were prevented by Revenue rules which stipulate workers must change to another type of job or allow "sufficient" time to elapse before returning to the same employer. Nothing stopped them defecting to a rival employer down the road, so that's what they did.

"The Revenue has taken people to court and taken away their pension benefits when this has become a disputed matter, but there has never been a definition of "sufficient" time. Now an employee of Tesco who wants to work part-time must quit Tesco to get their full pension rights and go to Sainsbury's to get the extra income."

The Inland Revenue says it shared the view that people should get more flexibility. But a spokeswoman added that changes to social security laws and complex tax practices needed to be thrashed out. Talks are continuing with the National Association of Pension Funds, which represents the pension funds of major employers, she said, "but I'm afraid we can't say anything on timing".

Some experts are more upbeat. Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, says: "You are seeing organisations buying back retired staff between 50 and 55 years old. Some companies have found they are too lean or can't recruit. Others might feel they don't have enough wise heads around.

"I'm sure there are many managers in the private sector who have a university degree who will dedicate themselves to teaching, even if not many former teachers want to return after they have been burned out."

Peter Thompson, a pensions expert at William M Mercer, says Inland Revenue changes to pension arrangements are part of the solution but "getting people who have retired back into work is going to be a very difficult task. It is going to be much more about changing people's expectations."

He believes that dramatic rises in life expectancy will continue. Government figures show that a male who currently retires at 65 will on average live to be 85. Worries about further rises in life expectancy have spurred ministers to add a little coercion to their list of incentives.

A report out last year called Winning the Generation Game, produced by the prime minister's performance and innovation unit, recommended that new company and personal pension contracts increase the retirement age from 50 to 55. It is unclear what will happen to existing contracts, but changes may be phased in as they were when the retirement age for women was increased from 60 to 65. Not a quick-fix solution, but one that will delay many early retirement plans if the inducements fail to work.

fields.headline: Bankers slam UK euro policy
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The president of the Bundesbank, Ernst Welteke, raised the temperature yesterday in the debate over Britain's membership of the single currency, when he flatly rejected Labour's argument and said a single government in Europe would inevitably follow monetary union.
fields.body:
The president of the Bundesbank, Ernst Welteke, raised the temperature yesterday in the debate over Britain's membership of the single currency, when he flatly rejected Labour's argument and said a single government in Europe would inevitably follow monetary union.

Despite Labour's attempts to downplay the constitutional ramifications of adopting the euro, Mr Welteke said monetary union must be followed by more political cooperation and integration.

"The single currency does not require a single government but it is my conviction that a single government will follow the single currency," he said at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

Labour has insisted that membership of the single currency has no political implications but depends on whether the UK meets the five economic tests laid down by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in October 1997.

Faced with strong opposition in the UK to any moves that would involve the creation of a European government, Labour is hoping that any future referendum in Britain can be fought purely on economic grounds.

However, Mr Welteke's comments reflect the growing conviction among the 12 nations that have signed up to the euro that Britain's hesitation over the project cannot be allowed to delay political steps that would help the single currency become more successful and enjoy greater popular support.

His views were backed by Otmar Issing, chief economist of the European Central Bank, who said he had initially been sceptical about starting monetary union before political union, but for the time being it appeared possible to have a single currency without changing political structures.

However, he added that in the long run, deeper political union was needed. "We have to search for the proper political environment so that this institutional environment can survive in the long run. It [the new political environment] will be nothing of the kind that we have seen before."

Daniel Bouton, chairman of the French bank, Société Générale, said there was a need to place a maximum of regulatory systems at a European level, and warned that the postponement of a decision on EU governance while enlargement went ahead was "a dangerous price to pay".

Mr Issing and Mr Welteke also played down speculation that they would follow the lead of the US Federal Reserve and cut interest rates sharply, arguing that Europe was set to enjoy healthy growth this year.

Mr Welteke said he was confident that Germany would grow by 2.75% this year, with consumer spending boosted by income tax cuts and gradually falling unemployment. "Upside inflation risks have clearly lessened of late. We are seeing an appreciation of the euro, we are seeing the oil price falling. The economy is running somewhat more moderately, thus the price risks have lessened.

"But this does not yet signal that we now have to go in a different direction with monetary policy."

Mr Issing said euro zone inflation was likely to come down, and that the euro's exchange rate was on course for long term gains.

"Markets are confident we will succeed in keeping inflation below the 2% benchmark we have identified as being compatible with medium term price stability."

fields.headline: Search and Destroy
fields.standfirst:
New End, London
***
fields.trailText:
New End, London
***
fields.body:
Martin Mirkheim is a dope. But this small-time loser has big-time dreams. When we first meet Martin he is spouting new age spiritual claptrap to a Florida tax evasion officer who is about to screw him for unpaid back taxes.

His wife wants out. He wants to make a movie out of a trashy book written by a self-help guru but he hasn't a dime. Quite frankly, Martin seems like a bit of a likable nutter.

When we last catch up with Martin, after two murders and a journey that crisscrosses the US like an unending road movie, he is in control. He has a successful career making slasher movies. It is rather like witnessing your goofy pet goldfish suddenly leap out of the bowl and turn into a piranha. You can hardly believe what you've seen.

Howard Korder's modern morality tale is a satiric cross between Everyman, Faust and Pilgrim's Progress. Mirkheim learns his lessons well. He rises above the charlatan gurus, the coke sniffers and dealers, the botched drug deal and those with sharper suits and sharper brains - to become the biggest fish in the pool. The loser turns winner: Martin is the personification of the American dream turned nightmare.

Search and Destroy was written in 1990 and first seen in this country at the Royal Court in 1993. It was an extraordinarily prescient play about the social, political, business and spiritual values of the US in the 1990s. The culture that Korder explores has come to pass. But because it turned out to be true, Korder's play now also suffers from being over-familiar.

What saves Korder's play is the cleverness of the vignettes of the people Martin meets on his odyssey - the quiet receptionist with a horror movie in her back pocket; the violent drug dealer who must rush to pick up his daughter from school - and the sheer bravado of the writing.

He writes sentences that, when delivered by class actors (as they are here), make the audience feel that they are looking down the barrel of a sawn-off shotgun. Like Martin himself, every word of the script is keyed-up, edgy, coiled and frightening. The scenes even begin and end abruptly, like real life.

Director Simon Cox keeps things simple and the acting is as subtle and sharp as a paper cut. Even if you've seen, or think you've seen, this kind of sour American morality tale before, it's worth seeing again.

 Until February 11. Box office: 020-7794 0022.

fields.standfirst:
The impending flotation is either brave or foolhardy. Investors will be hard pressed to find out which

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The impending flotation is either brave or foolhardy. Investors will be hard pressed to find out which.
fields.body:
Never mind the price, feel the width. The impending flotation of Orange will, in time, come to be hailed as either brave or foolhardy. It's no surprise, then, that this new issue has highlighted once again the stresses in the fabric of equity capital markets.

Orange's re-entry to the stock market values the mobile phone giant at only half the value that its owner, France Telecom, had originally hoped. Even at a cut price £40bn, the plethora of investment banks standing behind the flotation still have a stonking £5bn plus of paper to shift.

Of course, France Telecom's advisors would love to have a more propitious investment environment - especially for telecoms companies. Of course, the vendor would love to see its offspring attain the valuations thought possible only a few months ago. But the reality is that Orange is just the first in a string of mobile telecom issues and, with debts to pay, France Telecom would rather sell at a cut price than find the market completely saturated later on.

I've no idea whether the Orange issue price represents good value or not. If you can foresee, with pinpoint accuracy, future demand for the new mobile services made possible by third generation technology, and exactly when these services will be made available to the public, then I might just be able to hazard a guess.

Third generation is the critical factor. Worldwide, the telecoms majors have splashed out billions on 3G licences, praying that the services they enable don't prove as damp a squib as WAP. The current SMS texting craze has got the mobile players salivating, but it's a big step up to a full internet by phone revolution.

The extraordinary cost of these licences is at present borne directly by banks, in the form of loans, and indirectly by the telecoms company shareholders, who have to foot the interest bill. If some of the alarmist talk about telecoms debt is on the mark, it may be that shareholders in the lending banks may yet shoulder the burden. No wonder the telecoms companies are under pressure to equitise some of their 3G debts by issuing new shares.

France Telecom is sparing no effort in ensuring that Orange doesn't go pear-shaped. It is using a conventional structure of investment bank supporters - a syndicate of the major players who compete with each other to secure buy orders from the big investment institutions. The research analysts working for the banks in the syndicate will all be "on message", and hence enthusiastic about Orange's prospects. The problem for potential investors in a big issue is that syndicates are typically so large that it is difficult to obtain a genuinely independent view. In the case of Orange, France Telecom has attempted to influence analysts outside the syndicate by asking to vet their research in return for access to data about Orange.

The Association of British Insurers has railed against this Stalinist approach. Their voice has been reinforced by Terry Smith, the chief executive of independent broker Collins Stewart, who has built a fearsome reputation on the back of trenchant observations about the workings and failings of the equity market system.

While it is healthy that the likes of the ABI and Smith voice their concerns about constraints on independent analysis, this fiddling will not stop Rome burning. Truly independent research is a dying art because the economics of the stock market are loaded heavily against it.

Selling commissions paid to sponsoring banks on a new issue can, for the smallest and most obscure companies, be up to 7% of the funds raised from new investors. Compare this with the average commission rate paid by major institutions on equity transactions in the secondary market - somewhere around 0.15% - and you have the problem.

And then the circle becomes vicious. Investors spot that investment bank analysts have become slaves to their corporate finance departments. They place less weight on the analysts' views and, as a result, haggle secondary market commission rates lower.

This exacerbates the revenue differential for the investment banks, bringing analysts even closer to corporate financiers.

Many of the larger investment management groups have sought to resolve the dilemma by building their own in-house research teams.

This can be expensive, but a small price to pay if it helps secure superior performance and hence a growing pile of funds under management. In the real world, however, not everyone can outperform.

Unless the investment houses are prepared to back independent research boutiques directly - and history suggests they will only do so on a minor scale - they must find other ways of sustaining healthy investment advice.

One approach would be to boycott new issues which paid high commissions to sponsoring banks. These commissions often come out of the company's own coffers, and so are effectively paid by the buyers of its shares on flotation. But, up to now, very little attention has been paid by investors to the costs associated with new issues.

Another more Machiavellian solution would be to boycott the annual surveys in which investors rank investment bank analysts.

Either action would build a dam in the river of revenue that runs through the equity market and, if reinforced, would over time help change its course for the better.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: Moving question of price
fields.standfirst: Some estate agents claim house valuation is an artform shrouded in mystery. But their estimates often differ wildly. Elizabeth Langton investigates
fields.trailText: Some estate agents claim house valuation is an artform shrouded in mystery. But their estimates often differ wildly. Elizabeth Langton investigates.
fields.body:
When thoughts turn to moving, the first question homeowners ask themselves is: "How much is my house worth?" Usually, sellers depend on estate agents to give them the most accurate answer. But will estate agents tell you the truth about the appeal of your rotten window frames, stone cladding and pebble-dashed feature wall? Or will they play to your vanity and whisper outlandish sums in a bid to secure your business?

A seller in Cheshire found herself questioning estate agents' ability to carry out valuations when marketing her mother's flat at the end of 1999. Julie Brown (not her real name) asked three local estate agents to value the flat, located on the outskirts of a village in a highly desirable corner of Cheshire. Ms Brown knew the flat, packed with original features and in an attractive building, would sell and expected the agents to come up with similar prices. She was stunned when the valuations arrived.

The agents wanted to begin marketing the property at £95,000, £225,000 and £325,000 respectively. Ms Brown was particularly surprised because the lowest price was suggested by the "poshest" agent - one she had expected to overvalue the property. The agent who valued the flat at £225,000 came across as complacent.

In the end she plumped for the agent who valued that flat at £325,000. "I felt they were enthusiastic, appreciated the flat and they sent a man and a woman to assess it, something that appealed to me." The firm marketed the flat at an asking price of £295,000 and Ms Brown waited. "It sat on the market for a while before we decided to come down in price. An offer came in at £240,000 and after assuring us at the outset that it would sell at over £300,000 they were falling over themselves to tell us to accept the £240,000 offer."

The family was at the point of taking their business to another agent when they received an offer of £250,000 that was accepted. The transaction had taken seven months from initial marketing to completion. Ms Brown says it is disturbing that the flat sold for £150,000 more than the lowest valuation. She points out that sellers who fail to get several valuations or who are vulnerable could fall prey to incompetent or sharkish agents. In her case she believes the fact that the agent was new to the area may be partly to blame, adding: "The agent who gave us the sky-high valuation was equally dodgy and the flat sat on their books for months."

How much a home is worth is one aspect of marketing a home that sellers and agents can come to blows over, says estate agent ombudsman Stephen Carr-Smith. Members of the main estate agency trade bodies are expected to abide by a code of practice that includes never deliberately misrepresenting the value of property in order to gain an instruction.

According to Mr Carr-Smith problems occur when estate agents don't explain to clients the rationale behind their valuations. He says: "The key thing for estate agents is to manage a clients' expectations. To do this they should explain how the sale is progressing and make a record of why they are taking the action they are."

When asked, estate agents will hint that valuation is an art form, a mysterious process only to be undertaken by those experienced and selling homes. Certainly experience is key, says Richard Gayner, head of country houses department at FPD Savills. When valuing properties, bricks and mortar is only one consideration, he says. "If you asked me to draw a picture and write a specification of a house worth £1 million and another that is worth £2 million, you would be surprised how similar they are. In that bracket the dominant factor is the setting."

Agents have to have their finger on the pulse of local demand, says Mr Gayner. When it comes to the top end of the market Georgian properties are still popular with the buying public. "Although if you have two homes that are essentially the same one may be decorated well, another may be decorated expensively but dreadfully and the simpler one may sell for more," he adds.

The problem for agents, says Jeremy Leaf, housing spokesman for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, is that sellers only hear what they want to hear. "Sometimes it can turn into an auction where the agent who says he or she will get the highest price for the property, gets the business."

He says the first two to three weeks of marketing a home are key. Once a property has sat on the market for a while it is less appealing.

Sellers should find an agent used to marketing properties similar to theirs and ask them to show why their home will fetch the price the agent is suggesting. Buyers should ask for evidence of recent sales of similar properties.

In a busy market, Mr Leaf adds, nearly anyone can sell a house. Good agents come to the fore when the market is quiet. Stephen Carr-Smith says sellers should do their homework. Most buying and selling members of the public do not have as much knowledge as they should do about a transaction that is likely to be the most costly they make. Mr Leaf advises sellers to take a long hard look at their home and be realistic about its advantages and deficiencies. "Even in a block of identical flats there will always be a difference in price," he adds.

One flat may be in better condition or have a slightly different layout. In a pleasant street of three-bedroom homes the one with the loft conversion will sell for more but won't be worth as much as a four-bedroom home in the street, he explains. For sellers interested in undertaking their own research before going to agents, use property websites to get a snapshot of the property market.

 By typing in their postcode visitors to Up my street can find the selling price of similar houses in their area.

fields.headline: Internet revolution 'is over'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The internet revolution was pronounced dead at the World Economic Forum yesterday as industry figures downgraded the net to the status of a business tool that is not immune to old-fashioned economic realities, writes Peter Capella.
fields.body:
The internet revolution was pronounced dead at the World Economic Forum yesterday as industry figures downgraded the net to the status of a business tool that is not immune to old-fashioned economic realities, writes Peter Capella.

Tim Koogle, chief executive of Yahoo!, one of the most consistently profitable internet ventures, said large companies would survive and there would be space at the other end of the scale for small, niche-based, companies provided they did not rely on borrowed capital, but "nothing in-between".

Hasso Plattner, chief executive of SAP, the world's largest enterprise software maker, said: "We've seen too much greed, including from ourselves. People thought that a 30% profit on investments was easy and 100% was possible."

The downbeat assessment was in stark contrast to euphoria at last year's forum.

fields.headline: Verdi's elephants
fields.standfirst:
Verdi Gala
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
*****
fields.trailText:
Verdi Gala
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
*****
fields.body:
Believe it or not, Aida works perfectly well without the elephants. It could be argued that the Triumphal March is even more triumphant without the marching. And if any doubt remains about Verdi's facility as an orchestrator, they ought to let the band out of the pit like this more often.

In current music director Mark Elder, the Hallé has the most distinguished Verdi interpreter in the country; it was only a matter of time before he brought his operatic pedigree to the concert platform, and the 100th anniversary of the composer's death is the perfect place to start. What was less predictable is that the result should be such a revelation.

A substantial part of the impact is down to the intelligence of the programming. Rather than the meaningless grab-bag, which the fatal word "gala" usually implies, Elder presents extended sequences from three very different operas with something of their internal architecture intact. As an accelerated analysis of Verdi's career it could hardly be bettered - the sinfonia from Nabucco to set the tone, a scene from Trovatore to represent the firebrand younger Verdi, the study scene from Don Carlos to demonstrate the ice-cool older one. And finally, act two of Aida in its entirety, summing up the totality of his mature achievement.

The singers brought in for the occasion are world class: among them the outstanding Chilean soprano Veronica Villarroel, rising young Moscow-trained mezzo Maria Raidtchikova and - for Don Carlos's doom-laden battle of the basses - Clive Bayley versus Willard White. In search of extra volume, the Hallé Choir double up impressively with the Leeds Festival Chorus, creating a wall of sound more sturdily built than on any operatic stage.

But the astonishing feature is the orchestra itself: far larger than the average pit-band of course, and handling music it would not normally touch like newly minted gold. The visceral impact of a vast operatic monster with Willard White at the front and eight double basses at the back is an exceptional sonic experience. Under Elder's pin-point direction even Aida's cheesy trumpets rise above their own cliche, the over-familiar march ringing out with a new sense of Mahlerian intensity. Elder proves that you don't have to take Verdi to the theatre - Verdi brings the theatre with him in every bar of his score.

 Programme repeated tonight. Box office: 0161-907 9000.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Venture Capital Trusts

fields.headline: Ventures well worth trying
fields.standfirst: VCTs offer the well-off the most attractive means of tax-friendly investment with the fair hope of a good return. Robin Stoddart reports
fields.trailText: VCTs offer the well-off the most attractive means of tax-friendly investment with the fair hope of a good return. Robin Stoddart reports.
fields.body:
As deadlines for returns and payments for the previous tax year pass, the need to arrange finances to maximise the benefits of saving persists. Apart from National Savings and some other fairly long-term investments through life assurance companies, the means by which UK residents may minimise annual taxation involves risk.

Leaving out gambling, the National Lottery and Premium Bonds, the most attractive means for the well-off to lay out free capital to both limit tax liabilities and give a fair hope of good returns is through venture, enterprise, or private capital investment. Subscriptions to Venture Capital Trusts rose sharply last year and the flow of Enterprise Investment Schemes, which involves the backing of a single company, is continuing at a fair pace. So far casualties have been limited.

Venture Capital Trusts (VCTs) spread the high risk of investing in young companies by deploying experienced managers to choose investments over an extended period. The flow of deals offered by entrepreneurs, inventors and managers breaking away from large companies has remained strong. Certainly, the dot.com boom and bust last year provides a warning of the losses that may be incurred on new ethereal ventures, but the communications revolution is bringing rich rewards. VCTs' track record so far is encouraging, though mixed. The initial 20% income tax relief on investment and the deferral of capital gains tax on gains placed into the schemes is real enough.

Although the five-year period (now three) required for such investment to ensure tax relief is ending for the earliest funds, decisions about returning funds to shareholders remain open. Sometimes tax-free returns have been so good that continuation looks attractive.

At the same time, when most holdings are listed on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), where tax concessions apply on investment in trading companies and more fully on new share issues, VCTs bring additional running costs.

Consultation about the best course is adequate in most cases and one of the earliest, though smaller VCT groups, Pennine, commissioned the publisher of the newsletter SmallCapShares to review its funds in order to help in the decision on continuation. Pennine AIM, launched in April 1996, briefly doubled asset value, including payments to shareholders, by last October and the directors anticipate annual 10p capital distributions.

As with other funds, including Foresight Technology, the star of the sector so far, technology investment produced the best returns. Timely part-realisations of Pennine's investments in IS Solutions, before this year's profit warning, brought much of the appreciation.

All three Pennine funds have stakes in IS and several other AIM and unlisted companies. They include XKO, the software and maintenance provider to smaller companies. At one time it accounted for around 10% of all three funds, but its share price is off-peak now. E-Go Systems, a smaller investment common to the funds, may or may not be worth much more than cost after seeking additional funds. Pennine Downing AIM VCT and the intermittently appreciating Downing Classic have launched new funds.

Quester, a specialist venture manager, has an outstanding record with several lucrative profit realisations in high technology. A ninefold gain came from the sale of a Canadian management buy-out in fibre optic communications to a German company. The asset value of Quester 2 leaped by three-quarters in only 18 months as a result of such transactions, including stakes in JSB Software, now Surfcontrol. Orchestream is now easily Quester's largest holding. Quester 3, launched a year ago, suffered an early half million loss on an early-stage investment, but Quester 4 quickly pulled in the amount sought recently.

Baronsmead VCT 3 is currently raising £30m for investment in a mixture of AIM and unlisted companies. Part of Friends Ivory & Sime, Baronsmead's record is mixed, but winners outnumber a few heavy losers.

The first Baronsmead VCT extended its life, with shareholder agreement, ahead of its five-year term. Singer & Friedlander is raising a similar amount for its AIM 3 VCT and the management won support with a good performance last year. British Smaller Technology VCT 2, whose managers are part of Yorkshire Enterprise, will benefit from the advice of Generics, the technology adviser based in Cambridge and itself the subject of a well-received stock market placing recently.

Whether investors prefer early-stage technology stocks or a mix of more established companies will depend on income and willingness to risk capital.

 Reviews of VCTs have been published by IFA David Aaron partnership, tel 01908 281544, and Hargreaves Lansdown, tel 0117 900 9000.

All three Pennine funds have stakes in IS and several other AIM and unlisted companies. They include XKO, the software and maintenance provider to smaller companies. At one time it accounted for around 10% of all three funds, but its share price is off-peak now. E-Go Systems, a smaller investment common to the funds, may or may not be worth much more than cost after seeking additional funds. Pennine Downing AIM VCT and the intermittently appreciating Downing Classic have launched new funds. Quester, a specialist venture manager, has an outstanding record with several lucrative profit realisations in high technology. A ninefold gain came from the sale of a Canadian management buy-out in fibre optic communications to a German company. The asset value of Quester 2 leaped by three-quarters in only 18 months as a result of such transactions, including stakes in JSB Software, now Surfcontrol. Orchestream is now easily Quester's largest holding. Quester 3, launched a year ago, suffered an early half million loss on an early-stage investment, but Quester 4 quickly pulled in the amount sought recently. Baronsmead VCT 3 is currently raising £30m for investment in a mixture of AIM and unlisted companies. Part of Friends Ivory & Sime, Baronsmead's record is mixed, but winners outnumber a few heavy losers. The first Baronsmead VCT extended its life, with shareholder agreement, ahead of its five-year term. Singer & Friedlander is raising a similar amount for its AIM 3 VCT and the management won support with a good performance last year. British Smaller Technology VCT 2, whose managers are part of Yorkshire Enterprise, will benefit from the advice of Generics, the technology adviser based in Cambridge and itself the subject of a well-received stock market placing recently. Whether investors prefer early-stage technology stocks or a mix of more established companies will depend on income and willingness to risk capital.  Reviews of VCTs have been published by IFA David Aaron partnership, tel 01908 281544, and Hargreaves Lansdown, tel 0117 900 9000.

webTitle: Row over reform of tax havens

fields.headline: Row over reform of tax havens
fields.trailText: The London-based Commonwealth Secretariat was criticised yesterday for siding with tax havens in a row with wealthy industrialised nations over attempts to clean up the offshore financial services industry.
fields.body:
The London-based Commonwealth Secretariat was criticised yesterday for siding with tax havens in a row with wealthy industrialised nations over attempts to clean up the offshore financial services industry.

At the start of a three-day conference in the capital, the Secretariat suggested scrapping the OECD's drive to crack down on tax evasion and replacing it with a new global forum including members from both developed and developing nations.

However, the OECD fears the momentum for reform will flag unless it presses ahead with the established process, involving the threat of blacklisting tax havens - many in the Commonwealth - unless they agree to cooperate with the OECD by the end of July.

So far, eight offshore centres have agreed to cooperate with the OECD, leaving 27 facing the threat of sanctions.

A spokesman for the Secretariat denied siding with tax havens. "We see ourselves as responding to requests for help from member countries," he said.

fields.headline: Employers stung as staff  surf for jobs at work
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Growing numbers of workers are risking the wrath of their bosses by surfing the net for new job opportunities while at work.
fields.body:
Growing numbers of workers are risking the wrath of their bosses by surfing the net for new job opportunities while at work.

Meanwhile, it might surprise many to learn that the number one reason why people read the job ads in the papers isn't to find a new job.

These are just two of the findings of a new survey from recruitment group Bernard Hodes and the Guardian which looks at people's attitudes to job-hunting and the impact new technology is having on the whole process.

The research, conducted among almost 5,500 people, predominantly white collar professionals, in Britain, Ireland, France, Germany and Spain, found that while two-thirds of those quizzed have a PC at home, well over half the UK respondents (59%) would use the internet to look for a job while at work.

Few seemed concerned at the prospect of getting caught by their bosses, with just 14% saying they would feel uncomfortable using an office computer to look for a new job.

Helen Rosethorn at Bernard Hodes says the bulk of the people it quizzed said they would make greater use of the internet at home if the costs were lower. "The implication is clear: until the telecoms companies cut the high price of internet access, staff will continue to abuse their employers' trust by using work facilities to surf the net for job opportunities."

However, new government guidelines brought in after the survey was carried out, which give employers more rights when it comes to monitoring staff emails and internet activity, could well make people more wary about using the net at work.

One of the most surprising findings was just how many people now log on as part of their job-hunting efforts. Even taking into account that those surveyed were a fairly net-savvy bunch, it's still an eye-opener that 78% of the UK respondents had used the internet to look for a job. This is way ahead of the other four countries surveyed - in Spain and France the figures were 42% and 54% respectively.

With those quizzed also anticipating using national newspapers less and the internet more for job-hunting in the future, the figures will provide a boost to the growing numbers of online recruitment websites springing up.

So why, then, do the job ads sections of newspapers seem to be thicker than ever? Predictions two or three years ago that we would all soon be finding and applying for jobs online have proved way off the mark. In fact, the amount spent on recruitment advertising in the UK national, regional and trade press is on the rise, climbing from £1.32bn in 1999 to 1.39bn last year.

Part of the answer, according to some, is that most of the people using recruitment websites are actively seeking a new job, whereas the group employers really want to target are the much larger army of "browsers," many of whom may not actually be looking to move but would probably be open to offers. These people are considered more desirable than full-on seekers because they are often people who are doing their job well within an organisation rather than those who, dare one say it, are desperate to find a new job because they are disaffected or poorly regarded within their current company.

The research suggests that only a small proportion of those people reading job ads are actually looking for a new job. Some 64% of those asked said they look at recruitment adverts to see what is around in the marketplace compared to 56% who want to find a new job and 49% who said they wanted ideas about their next career move. Almost a third (30%) were keen to check their salary against the market.

Most of us still tend to turn to a particular national newspaper or trade publication when we're thinking of getting a new job. If you are a teacher, you will almost certainly turn to this newspaper's Tuesday education section and/or the Times Educational Supplement. The idea of wading through thousands of different jobs on a website might be a bit of a turn-off. "People look at screens all day at work - it is extremely tiring. With a newspaper you can dip in and out of it in a way that you cannot do on the internet," says Charles Walker at recruitment agency Blue Arrow.

However, the recruitment websites reject this and argue that the internet is actually a better tool for passive job-seekers than the newspapers. Several of the sites, including Monster.co.uk, Reed.co.uk, Stepstone.co.uk and Workthing.com (owned by the Guardian Media Group), offer facilities that allow you to register with them and then have vacancies which meet your criteria emailed to you as soon as they come in.

With the labour market so tight the internet clearly does offer new opportunities for reaching potential employees. However, where the net is really making itself indispensable is as a research tool for finding out about a would-be employer once you've decided where you want to work. "There is now no excuse for turning up not knowing about the company interviewing you and the markets in which they operate," says Mr Walker.
