fields.headline: Eden
fields.standfirst:
Peacock Theatre, Dublin
***
fields.trailText:
Peacock Theatre, Dublin
***
fields.body:
Monologues and the dramatic ironies of unreconstructed masculinity have always been the preferred territory of Conor McPherson's stagework. So, as a director, he returns to fairly manageable ground with this play of two cross-cutting monologues by fellow playwright and actor Eugene O'Brien.

It's a sordidly commonplace tragedy of a blighted young marriage, told through the present-tense narrations of a husband and wife who never address each other. Instead, they each appeal directly to the audience's sympathies. The setting is a long weekend in an Irish midlands small town, and the language is an adrenalised, semi-rural dialect which you could cut with a slurry shovel. Billy (Don Wycherley) is a gormless lad's lad, drinking himself and his libido rigid, while nursing an infatuation with a young lassie of the town. However, Billy is married - with two daughters - to Breda (Catherine Walsh), although sexually he can't even look at her, bowed by the taunts of others. Yet they share a bed, where she, victim-like, has built romantic fantasies around his slightest drunken intimacies.

Breda sits in while Billy goes out; maybe treating herself to a vodka, or a sneak read of her book of women's sexual fantasies, particularly the one of getting gang-relished by the Sultan's harem, while her tied-up husband is forced to watch.

Scriptwise, it's a ginger probe into female sexuality. Breda has dieted down from an obesity which earned her the local moniker of "Pig-arse". Now she re-emerges, thanks to a baby-sitter, to her first night on the town in years; aching to re-seduce her long-alienated Billy. But Billy, alcohol-addled, chases after the young girl, and Breda desolately staggers homeward, only to experience an unexpected, open-air ecstasy with a travelling salesman.

Like recent work from Enda Walsh, Ken Harmon and Mark O'Rowe, this slots into an Irish idiom of monologue-driven, dialect-intoxicated, only part-feminised lad's theatre full of adrenalised Hiberno-English, rhyming slang and florid nicknames painting a vivid portrait of pub-drenched machos and their foolish sexual rivalries.

It's a familiar instrument dial for McPherson, and his direction is taut and top-spun, cleverly blocked, with the odd, telling pause pressing home an old-fashioned storytelling. His actors serve him particularly well with their searching, committed performances. However, this remains a man's world. It's an enormously engaging piece, a story well told, but not always convincing.

 Until February 17. Box office: 00-353-1-878 7222. Then tours.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Norwich Union's endowments

fields.headline: On a fragile promise
fields.standfirst: Norwich Union has said it will top-up any policy shortfalls if it can't pay off the mortgage. But, asks Patrick Collinson, how good is NU's word?
fields.trailText: Norwich Union has said it will top-up any policy shortfalls if it can't pay off the mortgage. But, asks Patrick Collinson, how good is NU's word?
fields.body:
This week Norwich Union became the latest insurer to give the all-clear to its endowment policies, promising to make up potential shortfalls. But are these pledges a guarantee of future security or little more than a PR ploy?

Norwich Union has 500,000 policyholders whose mortgage endowments have fallen off track, but this week it pledged to top up final bonuses if they don't grow sufficiently to pay off the mortgage. The big winners are the 50,000 NU policyholders who last year were sent a "red" warning letter that their policy was at serious risk of failing to pay off a home loan. A further 450,000 of NU's 700,000 policyholders were sent an "amber" letter warning of a possible shortfall. All policyholders will now receive "green" letters telling them of the shortfall promise.

But the promise does not come without strings, and NU was at pains this week to point out that its pledge was precisely that - not a guarantee. NU's promise is identical to that offered by parent company CGNU to policyholders who bought endowments under the Commercial Union, General Accident and Provident Mutual brands. Standard Life, the biggest single endowment provider, also has a similar pledge.

Underlying their promises is a big catch - the funds have to earn an average of 6% a year after tax for the rest of the life of the policy. Only then will they "guarantee" to top up any endowment that still fails to pay off the mortgage on maturity.

Norwich Union is confident that it will achieve 6% a year; after all, its 25-year endowments that are maturing this year have earned an average return of 12.1% a year.

However, the pledge comes at an inauspicious time for investments; last year NU saw no investment growth at all on its with-profits fund after a gain of 17% in 1999. The major risk to endowment holders will be if the UK stock market goes into a long-term bear market of the type that has left shares in Tokyo stagnating for a decade.

Most investment analysts believe such a scenario is highly unlikely in the UK. But the history books do show long periods of time in Britain where investment returns have averaged below 6%, and suggest that the 12% returns of the more recent past may turn out to be an inflation-era phenomenon only.

According to Barclays, which every year analyses returns going back a century, real (post-inflation) investment returns have been below 6% in several decades during the 20th century, including the 30s, 40s, 60s and 70s compared with 10%-plus real returns during the 50s, 80s and 90s.

There are a couple of other caveats regarding the NU pledge; the small print of the agreement says that top-up payments will only be made where premiums have been maintained throughout the policy term. It also does not apply to endowments that have been bought through the "second-hand" or traded market.

Despite the caveats, the pledge puts CGNU and Standard Life's three million endowment holders in a better position than the remaining nine million at rival insurers. Why don't they follow suit and attach a shortfall pledge to their policies?

CGNU and Standard Life say it is because only they can afford to do so, as they are protected by a large "free assets" cushion which could finance any shortfall payouts. They are at the opposite end of the scale to Equitable Life, which had few free assets to fall back on when its guarantees turned out to be very costly.

Legal & General, the next biggest endowment provider with 1m policies and Scottish Amicable, another very big player with 800,000 policies, dispute such a view.

Hugh McKie of Scottish Amicable says: "These companies have not put aside real reserves to cover the cost of the guarantee. You have to ask to what extent the pledges have any value if there is no reserving. The fact is that we have a good financial strength record, but we feel it is important to protect all classes of policyholders, not just one."

Legal & General also questions the quality of its rivals pledges. A spokesman said: "What they are doing is giving promises, not guarantees. Endowments were not designed to contain guarantees and offering them could prejudice other customers' interests. It would be inappropriate to offer absolute guarantees."

However, there is one company which is offering an absolute guarantee. Liverpool Victoria is giving a no-strings guarantee to all its endowment policyholders, backed by one of the highest free asset cushions in the insurance industry. Unfortunately, there are only a few beneficiaries; Liverpool Victoria has just 7,500 endowment policies, a mere drop in the ocean of the 12m policies in total and 3-4m that are believed to be at risk of not paying off mortgages.

Payouts pain across board

Despite its pledge to protect endowment holders from mortgage shortfalls, Norwich Union joined other insurers this week in chopping payouts on these controversial policies.

It knocked 3.9% off the amount a 25-year policy will pay this year, cutting the maturity value to £86,028 from £89,518. Endowments sold under the CGU label (Commercial Union and General Accident), the parent company of Norwich Union, were cut even more deeply, falling by nearly 10% to £105,291 from £116,839.

NU defended the cuts as part of a strategy to bring bonuses on policies in line with low inflation and lower investment returns. It said that despite getting a return of zero on its investments last year, it has added a 4.75% regular bonus to ongoing endowment policies and 6.25% to pension policies.

The payout figures above also reveal the big disparities between different insurers' endowment policies. Someone who paid £50 per month over the last 25 years at Scottish Provident will this year pick up £79,893, 31% less than the £115,305 payout at Scottish Life.

Scottish Life has bucked the trend by increasing pay outs, partly because of its lower exposure to equity markets and bigger holdings in lower-risk gilts and bonds. But David Carrington at endowment market maker PolicyPlus says: "Perhaps these payouts are a sweetener to policy holders prior to the vote on the proposed Royal London takeover."

However, few endowments enjoy the payouts listed above. Around 30% are cancelled in the first three years, sometimes leaving policyholders with less cash than they paid in.

Endowment returns

Companies 2000 | 2001 | % rise/fall

CGU £116,839 | £105,291 | -9.9%

Friends Provident £102,341 | £93,144 | -9.0%

Norwich Union £89,518 | £86,028 | -3.9%

Scottish Life £101,899 | £115,305 | +13.2%

Scottish Provident £85,120 | £79,893 | -6.1%

 Figures based on £50 per month endowment over 25 years.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Home loans too high

fields.headline: Key message is sinking in
fields.standfirst: Millions of homeowners are still repaying far too much on their properties, reports Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Millions of homeowners are still repaying far too much on their properties, reports Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Only one in six borrowers has at some point switched their home loan to another lender, despite reams of publicity about the savings you can make by remortgaging, a new survey reveals.

However, the message is clearly starting to get through - this figure is far higher than a year ago, when it stood at just one in 10 borrowers.

While millions of homeowners are needlessly paying over the odds, during the last few months growing numbers of people have become aware of the benefits of moving their home loan, and the predictions are that remortgaging will now soar to record levels.

The new Mori survey from the Council of Mortgage Lenders, which represents banks and building societies, also reveals that people are still cautious when it comes to applying for a mortgage online, and that while so-called flexible mortgages are becoming increasingly popular, hardly anyone actually seems to make use of the features they offer. Jobs & Money has repeatedly highlighted the benefits that switching your loan can provide and we make no apologies for repeating that message here. Mortgage lenders are fighting tooth and nail for people's custom and many borrowers will be able to save hundreds or even thousands of pounds by remortgaging.

Many people could easily slice 20%-25% off their mortgage payments - perhaps £100 a month or more. The typical bank standard variable mortgage rate is still around 7.75%, but there are decent two and three-year deals around at between 5% and 5.5%. And contrary to what many might think, remortgaging doesn't have to be a huge hassle. The form-filling required is often minimal and some lenders will pay some or even all of the fees.

Mortgage Intelligence, a nationwide network of mortgage brokers, published its own research recently which found that of the 12m people that hadn't remortgaged, 3.6m said the reason was that they "could not be bothered".

It gives an example of the money you could save by switching. Someone with an average £60,000 repayment mortgage paying his lender's standard variable rate of 7.75% is currently forking out £453.20 a month. If he switched to a 5.35% two-year capped rate offered by the Woolwich, the monthly payment would be slashed to £363.10. That's a saving of £2,160 over two years, though you'd have to deduct the £195 application fee and your legal and valuation costs.

And this assumes there aren't early redemption penalties locking you in to your current loan. If there are, you will need to look carefully at the maths to see whether it is going to be worth your while moving. This Woolwich deal is capped at 5.35% until April 1 2003 - that means you'll never pay a higher rate than that over the period, but if the mortgage rate were to fall below this level, so would what you pay. There are redemption penalties, but only within the two years, and you are allowed to make overpayments. Minimum deposit required is 10% (5% for those moving home).

We identify some of the other attractive remortgage deals around above. Of the 3,480 people Mori quizzed for the CML, 17% of borrowers had remortgaged to a new lender at some point, while a further 12% had renegotiated the terms of their mortgage with their existing lender.

Around one in six borrowers now has a flexible mortgage - defined as one where the interest is calculated daily or monthly rather than annually, which saves you money over the long term; where you can make increased monthly or lump-sum payments to bring down the cost or duration of the mortgage; and where underpayments and payment holidays are usually allowed.

More than 50 mortgage lenders now offer loans with varying degrees of flexibility, ranging from giants such as the Halifax to smaller players such as the Scottish building society, and they are particularly popular with Londoners, the self-employed and better-off households.

But the research found that only about one in 20 people with a flexible loan had ever taken a payment holiday from their mortgage. The CML says this is good news because it shows people are attracted to these deals because of the opportunities they offer for saving money over the long term and are reluctant to use them as a short-term means of juggling their finances.

But cynics might say it suggests that people are paying for features they are not using. Meanwhile, the research also found that despite all the hype about the internet, there is still some way to go before many people will feel comfortable shopping for mortgages online. While nearly a quarter of people are likely to look for mortgage information on the net next time they are looking to take out a home loan, only 9% say they would be likely to apply for a mortgage online.

This finding is in stark contrast to a prediction this week from internet bank Egg that online home loans will grow to account for 10% of all mortgage sales by 2004. Next month Egg launches its "mortgage supermarket", which it says will give borrowers access to hundreds of home loans, including its own-brand flexible loan and a range of exclusive deals from leading lenders including Coventry, West Bromwich and Market Harborough building societies.

Remortgage to save a fortune

You could be handing over £50, £100 or even £200 a month needlessly to your home loan company. But don't expect your mortgage lender to tell you.

Checking out remortgaging - ditching your present lender and switching to a new mortgage firm - could be the answer. It's easy. And now the first step is even simpler.

The Guardian has published a new 36 page Guide to Remortgaging Your Home in association with broker London & Country Mortgages. It's full of practical advice to help you make up your own mind on the best way forward.

The Guide is free - call 0800 694 6444 for a copy. But it could save you a fortune.

Shop around for the best deals

 In addition to the 5.35% two-year capped rate highlighted above, the Woolwich is also doing a three-year discounted deal available exclusively through mortgage broker Charcol. You pay 2.16% off the standard variable rate, giving an initial pay rate of 5.59%. There are redemption penalties within the three-year period, but you are allowed to make overpayments. Minimum deposit required is 5%. There is a £195 arrangement fee to pay.

 Independent Mortgage Collection, a group of independent mortgage advisers, favours a two-year discounted rate deal from GMAC, the UK home loans business owned by General Motors. It gives a 2.25% discount off the standard variable rate for the first year (initial pay rate: 5.44%), then a 1.75% discount in the second year. There are no redemption penalties at any time, and there are some bonuses for remortgagers: you get a £250 contribu tion towards your legal costs, and they'll throw in a free valuation. However, there is a £195 arrangement fee which is automatically added to the loan. Minimum deposit required is 10%.

 IMC also likes a discounted deal from Birmingham Midshires Solutions (part of the Halifax) where you get 2.5% off the standard mortgage rate for two years (or 2.25% plus a free valuation). There is a £299 arrangement fee. Minimum deposit required is 5%.

 If you're keen to fix your monthly payments, mortgage broker London & Country is offering an exclusive three-year deal from Portman building society fixed at 5.49% until April 1 2004. There are redemption penalties within the three-year period, but you are allowed to make overpayments. There is a £300 arrangement fee but you get £250 cashback. Minimum deposit required is 5%.

fields.headline: Silence is far from golden
fields.standfirst: With-profit bonds, favoured by older people seeking security, could harbour the same risks that have reduced many endowment holders to tears, says Tony Levene
fields.trailText: With-profit bonds, favoured by older people seeking security, could harbour the same risks that have reduced many endowment holders to tears, says Tony Levene.
fields.body:
UK money watchdog the Financial Services Authority has barked at millions of endowment mortgage holders, warning them that the billions invested in their policies may not grow fast enough to pay off their home loans.

But around a million other savers are to receive no such warnings, despite their financial futures depending on the same funds that have sometimes reduced homeowners to fear and despair. They are the holders of some of the most impenetrable investments on sale to the public - with-profits bonds.

The FSA says that the original investment return figures used by endowment compa nies to sell with-profits policies are no longer valid in the current investment and inflation environment. It now regards reviewing with-profits business as a "key project".

The bonds are lump-sum investments which offer annual gains while maintaining the initial capital. They have been on sale for more than a decade but their popularity has soared over the past five years as returns on bank and building society accounts fell with interest rates.

Typical high-rate savings accounts yield around 6% before tax, compared to the bonds, which promise 7.5% tax-free to basic rate taxpayers and give the impression that your capital is safe.

But these claims may not al ways be as watertight as they seem. (see opposite) The buyers of the bonds are mainly retired people or those approaching retirement. They are pouring around £15bn a year into them- often attracted by first-year rates that depend more on financial engineering than investment returns.

Now Barnstaple-based independent financial adviser Phillip Milton has broken ranks with a whistle-blowing booklet With Profits Bonds - Have You Been Myth-sold? which takes the lid off the steamy but very profitable world of the bonds.

And next month a working party at the Faculty and Institute of Actuaries - the insurance professionals whose decisions govern returns on with-profits investments - will warn of the dangers investors face if they place too much reliance on returns promised in marketing literature following an actuarial paper last June which told companies not to hype figures artificially.

But individual actuaries admit that it will need more than a warning to prevent financial advisers from puffing the plus points and deleting, as far as legally possible, the drawbacks. Commission on these products is very high - the Prudential has, in the past, offered some IFAs up to 7% on its top-selling Prudence Bond. Others include Eagle Star and Scottish Widows, also paying advisers up to 7% of what you pay in. Britannic and Sun Life pay a maximum 6.75%, and many others are at levels up to 6%.

Sums invested in these bonds are large, typically £25,000, therefore earning advisers up to £1,750. These commissions are twice the level paid to advisers when the recommend a unit trust. And while some advisers discount part or even all of this commission, many insurers are now paying annual "renewal" commission whose cost has, ultimately, to come from investors. Those working for banks and insurers directly do not generally rebate.

T he suspicion remains that the bonds are pushed by advisers simply because the pay more commission than unit trusts. Yet the advisers' own professional body, the Chartered Insurance Institute, says: "There should not be incentives that might create a bias towards plans where higher initial commission is paid to advisers."

But potential difficulties go beyond high commission. "These bonds have been gaining in popularity just when the bonus rates on which they depend have been dropping and the volatility of the funds has been increasing. These are supposed to be safe investments where the ups and downs are smoothed out but they are becoming increasingly risky as they become more reliant on equities to produce returns," Mr Milton says.

With-profits bond money is managed in a very similar way to endowment mortgages and with-profits pension funds. But returns from these funds are falling. This month, insurance companies are declaring annual bonuses and, according to figures from second-hand policy dealer Beale Dobie, of the ones to declare annual, or reversionary, bonuses so far, three have fallen, four are unchanged and one very small player has risen.

"The money going into with-profits bonds ends up in the same pots as used by endowment policies to fund mortgages like the ones now suffering awful performance projections and fears of mis-selling," says Mr Milton.

"People don't realise that mutual companies pay regulatory fines and compensation for mis-selling out of with-profits funds. Other companies may even try subsidising loss-making stakeholder pensions from with-profits funds," he adds.

We asked leading providers whether they offered high initial rates and how their rates had moved.

Friend s Provident has a first year guarantee ranging from 5% on £3,000 to 8.5% on £100,000. It justifies not alerting customers to the potential of falling rates because the plans do not have a target, unlike endowments.

Norwich Union had a 25% market share last year. It says it complies with PIA guidelines on projection rates used and supports the Faculty and Institute of Actuaries on the promotion or marketing of headline bonus rates. NU does not declare high first year bonus rates and will not be doing so in the future. Since 1997 rates have fallen from 7.25% to 5.75%.

Legal & General has a confusing variety of products but says each year's plan is managed separately. It is replacing penalties for withdrawal in certain circumstances by managing a combination of lower annual growth rates plus higher terminal bonuses.

Liverpool Victoria has around £4.5bn in its bonds which offer a guaranteed 7.5% over the first two years by "creating additional units."

Royal & Sun Alliance Annual bonuses have fallen from 7% in 1996 to 5% in 2000. It says: "Our aim is to be fair to all policyholders by offering appropriate bonus rates, rather than trying to attract business by offering inflated rates at the outset."

Standard Life has only been selling bonds since last August. Its bonus rate is 4.5%. There are no special deals.

Scottish Friendly guarantees 6% in the first year but it will not market using "an artificially high rate only to cut it dramatically in subsequent years". Bonus rates have fallen from 7% to 6% since 1998.

Prudential, Scottish Widows and Scottish Mutual were unable to reply.

Truth that lies behind the fanciful claims

With profits bonds have been one of the most successful investment products of the past decade - seeming to square the circle of safety combined with high returns.

But they are far harder to fathom than unit or investment trusts. And that lets the insurers try to weasel their way into potential buyers' affections with big print claims that could be too good to be true. Here we examine assertions and reality.

"Your money is safe - your capital can never fall. "

True, but only up to a point. Many bonds take up to 5% upfront to cover charges including commission. But despite the reputation with-profits funds have of never falling back, the bond companies have the market value adjustment or 'MVA' in reserve. They all say this is rarely used but many wanting their money back during the 1998 Asian crisis suffered an Equitable Life style deduction of around 10%. Bonds often offer MVA-free encashments on the fifth or ten anniversary and always on death. Most say they never (or hardly ever) apply the adjustment. But what happens if shares melt down as they did in Japan where the Nikkei index is little more than a third of its 1989 value?

"The returns on with-profits bonds are totally free of basic rate tax and capital gains tax."

Technically true but otherwise to be taken with a pinch of salt. Insurance funds are hit by corporation tax which is the equivalent of basic tax and capital gains tax. Non and lower rate taxpayers lose out while most basic rate payers do so as well as they cannot use their capital gains tax annual exemption - currently £7,200. This contrasts strongly with Isas. The only possible winners from the tax treatment are higher rate taxpayers and those caught in the age allowance trap.

"You can have tax-free withdrawals."

This is true up to 5% of the original sum paid in. But as the fund has already paid tax, further payments would would add up to double deductions.

"Bonds invest in a wide portfolio to provide a consistent return by smoothing out the ups and downs of the stock market"

That's what they should do. But to produce the rates investors demand (and sellers need to justify commissions), insurers have to use higher proportions of volatile shares. The effect is that annual growth rates are variable, not smooth. And if markets fall with a bump, the annual bonus will be very low, the terminal bonus practically non existent while exits will be barred by the MVA.

"You get an allocation of 103% of your original investment."

Sounds great - more money from the outset but this depends on what you regard as your original investment. Savers with £10,000 see it as £10,000. Insurers take off 5% upfront and call it £9,500 of which 103% is only £9,885.

"We rebate all the commission"

Ask what happens to any annual renewal payments - advisers cannot live on air.

"No annual management charges"

True as far as it goes. There are no explicit charges in with-profits bonds. But insurance actuaries adjust bonuses to take care of expenses.

"Higher current returns than on deposit accounts" Remains true but for how long - and will it apply to all bonds?

webTitle: Equitable's poacher up for gamekeeper post

fields.headline: Equitable's poacher up for gamekeeper post
fields.trailText: The leader of the policyholder group whose legal action precipitated Equitable Life's present predicament is being touted as a candidate for the next presidency of the mutual firm, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The leader of the policyholder group whose legal action precipitated Equitable Life's present predicament is being touted as a candidate for the next presidency of the mutual firm, it emerged last night.

Policyholders and even some staff of Equitable Life, still seeking a potential last-minute buyer, have submitted the name of Stuart Bayliss, the head of the Equitable Life Guaranteed Annuity Rate Action Group, to headhunting agency Egon Zehnder, charged with finding a new president.

Mr Bayliss, who has not put forward his own name, has set his sights on securing a deal to cap the insurer's £1.5bn-plus of liabilities from the guaranteed annunities which have turned away potential bidders for the 237-year-old institution. However, he added that if this can be achieved, he would "consider" the idea.

Equitable embarked on a search for a new board after the president, John Sclater, and seven non-executive directors announced last month they would be resigning following fierce criticism of the company's actions.

Equitable, which refused to comment last night, is being courted by Australian financial services group AMP, which yesterday emerged as the most likely bidder for parts or all of the troubled insurer after Dutch group Aegon pulled out of the bidding process.

Equitable closed its doors to new business early last month after failing to find a buyer.

fields.bodyText: The leader of the policyholder group whose legal action precipitated Equitable Life's present predicament is being touted as a candidate for the next presidency of the mutual firm, it emerged last night. Policyholders and even some staff of Equitable Life, still seeking a potential last-minute buyer, have submitted the name of Stuart Bayliss, the head of the Equitable Life Guaranteed Annuity Rate Action Group, to headhunting agency Egon Zehnder, charged with finding a new president. Mr Bayliss, who has not put forward his own name, has set his sights on securing a deal to cap the insurer's £1.5bn-plus of liabilities from the guaranteed annunities which have turned away potential bidders for the 237-year-old institution. webTitle: Skills shortage on British job market

fields.headline: New labour needed to keep Britain working
fields.standfirst:
Government, management bodies and local authorities agree: we are suffering from a crippling lack of skilled workers. But moves to fill the gaps may be too few and too late. Liz Stuart reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Government, management bodies and local authorities agree: we are suffering from a crippling lack of skilled workers. But moves to fill the gaps may be too few and too late. Liz Stuart reports.
fields.body:
In the States things are so bad that recruiters need to offer diamond rings to girlfriends and luxury cars to spouses as part of the deal. So desperate is the situation that companies advertise jobs on lunch bags in the dot.com corridors of San Francisco and hire planes to blaze sits-vac ads through the skies.

We're talking the skills gap, and as well as being a major headache in the US, it's the biggest problem facing Britain plc today. Companies simply cannot find people to employ, and this problem now extends way beyond the lack of people fluent in specialised computer languages or even the well-known difficulty the government is experiencing in recruiting newly qualified teachers and nurses. The country is now running dry of occupational therapists, doctors, accountants, social workers, engineers and even recruitment consultants: positions which just five years ago graduates and second and third jobbers were clamouring to fill.

A report from The Cranfield School of Management this week reveals that 81% of manufacturers say it is difficult to recruit at the senior managerial level and that junior and middle managers are even harder to find. The latest Mori poll tells the same story. The problems are similar in the blue-collar industries: hotels, restaurants and the leisure industry in general are thirsty for staff who, once trained, often quit the country for a warmer working environment.

Jobs which in the past have been filled by school leavers are going begging as demographics and the increase in numbers of young people going into higher education squeeze the labour supply at source. This week the Institute for the Management of Information Systems, which represents IT companies, said it would press Chancellor Gordon Brown to use his pre-election Budget to give tax relief to employers and staff for IT training, making the skills shortage an election issue.

So seriously does the government view the problem, that industry minister Kim Howells will next month launch a tour promoting, among other things, workforce training and retraining. The Cabinet Office's Performance and Innovation Unit has set up a task force which has nine months to report on the skills shortage problem in the UK. So-called third-leg funding for universities to liaise with businesses to ensure that degree courses teach relevant skills to students has been tripled.

The problem has been bubbling under for the past 10 years as the country moved from recession in the early 90s into a period of full employment, as defined by economist John Maynard Keynes. Companies which slashed recruitment and training budgets in the lean times failed to reinflate them as the economy picked up.

Neil Barnes, director of media recruitment specialists Phee Farrar Jones, says the problem has arisen because of a lack of investment in graduate recruitment. "The underlying reason is because companies have not pre-planned graduate recruitment in the past so they don't have the talent coming through the company. Particularly in the area of new media there has also been the problem of sheer growth. It would have been a very brave person indeed who could have predicted numbers needed even three years ago. Although some start-ups have failed, others have grown beyond their wildest dreams."

Kevin Hogarth, national resourcing director at professional services group Ernst & Young, agrees: "We're trying to recruit people who started their training in the early 90s and effectively we're reaping what we sowed. Numbers of graduate recruits were much reduced in all the accountancy firms because of economic conditions. Now we're trying to broaden the net of people we can attract who may have relevant experience."

In the public sector, recruitment difficulties have more to do with poor pay and overwork. A spokeswoman for the public sector workers' union Unison says: "There is a huge problem with a lack of social workers, particularly in inner city areas. Pay is always an issue, but there is also the problem of caseloads. Lisa Artherworry, the care worker involved in the Anna Climbie case, had 50% more work that she should have done, although I'm not excusing what happened. With residential social work there is even more of a problem: it is even worse paid and the environment is very difficult - you often find that there will be just one person sleeping in the home alone when there should be two people there."

Separately, the Cabinet Office this week published a paper on the role immigrants can fill in helping slake the staffing drought as more and more blue-chip companies are actively recruiting in Europe, Australia, New Zealand and India. Essex County Council is already forced abroad by staffing gaps: it employs social workers from South Africa. Ernst & Young is launching its first careers round in India next month. But Mr Howells warns that for Britain simply to import workers from overseas would mean that "we have not convinced enough of our people there are viable careers here and they should retrain for them".

Tom Hadley, senior policy adviser and manager of the Employee Relocation Council at the CBI, says: "We are keen to stress that bringing in foreign labour needs to be seen in conjunction with a number of other solutions. It is part of an on-going debate. But we see this as a positive thing. It is an advantage to get people from overseas: a lot of companies are operating in a global marketplace and it is an advantage to have multicultural teams." He adds that the international exchange of personnel is just that, an exchange, and that British companies are using overseas relocation as one of their development tools.

But back to the US, and New York recruitment consultant Rohit Sawhney says there has been a dire shortage of IT experts in the US for two years. The government has relaxed quotas on its business visa, meaning that 190,000 immigrants are now allowed into the country to work compared with 65,000 previously. "The situation has altered slightly, however. Whereas last year companies would just take on anyone, employers are now far more selective. This is because the website infrastructure is now in place and people are needed just to enhance it, which can wait. There is no longer a mad rush for staff," say Mr Sawhney.

But he adds that the upshift in the number of immigrants allowed in the US has not had the anticipated effect in the major cities such as New York and New Jersey: large corporations are increasingly unwilling to go to the expense of relocating an IT expert from India or New Zealand who is under no contractual obligation to stay.

Mr Hogarth says overseas recruiting will be just one way of plugging the gap. His company has also been forced to accept beefing up the quality of jobs offered to graduate employees, as well as taking on non-graduates into areas where a degree has, in the past, been a pre-requisite for working. "To fill vacancies we're not frightened of paying. What does frighten us more is the number of vacancies unfilled. We have literally hundreds of vacancies - I would say that vacancies are up 25% on this time last year." Qualified accountants with experience, tax and corporate finance specialists are particularly in short supply.

"Now we're trying to broaden the net of people we can attract who may have relevant experience. We're also looking at the way we undertake audits. We're defining separate roles so we can now focus graduates on developing skills for their longer term career, whereas in the past they had to do some tedious stuff as well," he says.

Where it's hurting worst

City

"There are skills shortages across the board in the City, whether you are looking for professional accountants, bankers or legal personnel," says Alison Smith, director of recruitment consultants Badenoch & Clark. The situation is a vicious circle: increasingly people are rejecting the City's long working hours, which means employers demanding more of their staff as they cannot find enough people to do the work. "But if firms were more willing to train those with potential or retrain those with redundant skills, flexible working practices have more chance of happening," she says.

IT

Recruitment consultants Computer People say the most sought-after IT experts are people with Java, C++, telecoms and Wap knowledge. High-level database skills such as Unix and Linux are also much in demand. "The increased demand for Java skills does not seem to be abating, but companies are now being more realistic about the availability of such people and are prepared to look at candidates with OO and procedural programming skills. Graduates with OO skills are finding it easier to get first-time work and training on the job," says a spokeswoman. The average hourly rate for a Java developer in London is £70, but can be as high as £90 with experience in some sectors.

Charities

While higher salaries in the sector, plus growing interest in jobs which benefit the community or environment, should mean a glut of candidates, charities are experiencing "severe recruitment difficulties", according to the Voluntary Sector National Training Council in England. "There have been particular problems with charities in London and the south-east, where applications for jobs have declined severely in the last six to nine months. Charities are being forced to be far more lateral in the way in which they look for staff: they will take on people with sales experience to work in fundraising," says a spokesman.

Hospitality

"The hospitality and tourism industry is the fastest-growing job sector in the world," according to Anne Walker, managing director of Springboard UK, an independent organisation promoting career opportunities in the leisure industry. "There are skills shortages at almost all levels and with every category of staff. There are currently 30,000 vacancies for chefs in this country: one of the problems is that cooking is not on the national curriculum."

Media

John Foscolo, tutor at the Cardiff Centre for Journalism Studies, says there are more jobs on weekly papers than at any time in his eight years in teaching. "I've never seen anything like it. There are far more jobs than students to fill them. It's because so many have been going into dot.coms because they pay so much better than weekly papers. On daily papers the jobs market is pretty good too as people are moving round so much. You've got to be trained, though. Papers want to put you straight to work. In PR there are so many jobs you can name your price."

Teaching

Education secretary David Blunkett last year admitted that had salaries of £6,000 not been introduced for teachers in training the situation would have been "very close to meltdown".Stories of schools cancelling classes because of staff shortages are increasingly common. Areas with shortfalls are London and the south-east in maths, technology, science and foreign languages: trainees in these areas now receive a golden hello of £4,000.

Occupational therapy

"We have noticed a huge increase in the number of posts for occupational therapists advertised in our publications and we know there are not enough to deliver the service users need. We believe that nationwide the shortage is running at 20%," says Sheelagh Richards, chief executive of the College of Occupational Therapists. An Audit Commission report published last June showed that the gravest shortages were at the most senior level. According to NHS figures, the highest vacancy rates are in London, followed by the east, then the west midlands.

Social work

According to an Employers' Organisation survey published in April 2000, there was a 16% vacancy rate nationally for social workers, rising to almost 20% in London, the south east and east Anglia - that is, one in five positions was unfilled. According to a spokesman for the organisation, there is no evidence that this has changed in the nine months since, but the problem had doubled in severity in the 18 months since the previous survey. In London and the home counties there are now around 500 vacancies for field social workers.
